His technical versatility extends to full stack development, demonstrated through his work at ChoiceGuard Insurance Services where he built a HIPAA-compliant onboarding platform, and at Calisto Inc as a Founding Software Engineer, taking the company from zero software to a pilot with a major pest control company in just 5 months.

Ben's academic achievements are equally impressive, maintaining a 3.98 GPA and making the Dean's List four times. He co-authored a research paper published at the prestigious AAAI Conference on enhancing story comprehension for large language models through dynamic document-based knowledge graphs, which improved the quality of AI-generated text by up to 1.9x.

Beyond his tech career, Ben has an entirely separate professional identity as "The Bake King," one of the UK's most celebrated cake artists. He began his artistic journey as a graphic designer after studying Art & Design at Chester University, then worked as a tattoo artist before discovering his passion for creating hyper-realistic cakes. His transition to cake art began in 2014 when he made his first cake for his father, inspired by a design shown to him by a tattoo client's mother.

As The Bake King, Ben has won multiple gold awards at Cake International in 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019, and was named one of the UK's Top 10 Cake Artists at Cakemasters in 2019. His extraordinary talent for creating life-like edible sculptures has earned him celebrity clients like Rita Ora, appearances on Channel 4's "Extreme Cake Makers," and hundreds of thousands of followers across social media platforms. His work is particularly notable for making objects so realistic that they're often indistinguishable from the real items they represent.

Throughout both of his careers, Ben has demonstrated an exceptional ability to bridge technical innovation with artistic creativity and practical business applications, making him a uniquely versatile professional who excels in both technology and artistic fields.

suggested_people.name: Audrey Chen
suggested_people.short_description: Serial hackathon winner (21 wins) and tech entrepreneur with a passion for AI innovation. Co-founder of VC-backed nosu.io, Software Engineering Intern at Intuit, and content creator with 68K Instagram followers. Currently pursuing Computer Engineering at Michigan State University while balancing multiple tech roles including NASA USRC research and Intel AI projects.
suggested_people.long_description:
Audrey Chen is a dynamic force in the tech world, particularly known for her exceptional track record of winning 21 hackathons with a 70% win rate, accumulating over $20,000 in prizes. Her technical prowess spans multiple domains within AI and software engineering, demonstrated through her diverse professional experiences.

As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Aidan Gollan
suggested_people.short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

suggested_people.name: Max Forsey
suggested_people.short_description: Max Forsey is an AI researcher at the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University who explores the fundamental nature of intelligence. As a co-founder of justbuild.ing and former Vice President of BYU's Artificial Intelligence Association, he actively organizes AI hackathons and community events while developing practical tools to advance the field.
suggested_people.long_description:
Max Forsey is a dedicated AI researcher affiliated with the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University, where he explores the fundamental nature of intelligence through artificial intelligence systems. His research has led to publications like "Gradient Sparse Autoencoders," which introduces novel approaches to extracting neural network features.

Max has taken on leadership roles in the AI community, serving as the Vice President of the BYU Artificial Intelligence Association, where he helped organize events and foster a community of AI enthusiasts. In November 2024, he co-founded "justbuild.ing," an initiative focused on building a community of AI developers and hosting collaborative events.

He is particularly active in organizing and participating in AI hackathons, recently working with Sameday through the justbuild community to host a 2-hour AI hackathon featuring Cerebras Systems. His involvement in these rapid development events demonstrates his commitment to practical AI application and innovation.

Beyond his research, Max is passionate about creating practical AI tools. He developed FreshSesh AI, a developer tool that uses local LLMs to provide personalized context summaries of previous work sessions, helping developers quickly get back into flow. He's also reimplemented Andrej Karpathy's nanoGPT, showing his hands-on approach to understanding AI systems.

Max maintains a personal website where he shares detailed resources for those looking to bridge the gap between using AI APIs and actually training models. His curated learning path includes visual resources, essential reading, and practical project suggestions for newcomers to the field. He emphasizes starting with fundamentals and learning through implementation, reflecting his own approach to AI development.

Outside of his professional interests, Max maintains a holistic approach to life, with detailed attention to health and longevity practices. He values deep friendships and community connections, having written thoughtfully about the nature of friendship and human connection. His background combines theoretical AI research with practical application, demonstrating a commitment to both advancing the field and making AI more accessible to others.

suggested_people.name: Yeabsera Afework
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with extensive game development experience. Co-founder of 646 Studios and former Software Engineer at Microsoft, specializing in user authentication systems and facial recognition technology. First-generation college student from Ethiopia with a passion for technology and community service.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yeabsera Afework is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with a diverse background spanning game development, software engineering, and entrepreneurship. As the co-founder of 646 Studios, Yeabsera has developed three successful video games that amassed over 200,000 community members and achieved 9,000+ concurrent players on release. This entrepreneurial venture led to contracts with major brands like Gen G and Crocs, where Yeabsera's work boosted concurrent players by 5,000+.

At Microsoft, Yeabsera worked as a Software Engineer designing the backend client for the company's first in-house user authentication system, leveraging facial recognition and AI-based liveness verification to enhance security protocols. The role also involved developing secure clients in C# and creating metric dashboards in KustoQL to help on-call engineers identify bugs and outages.

Yeabsera's game development expertise extends to RB Battles LLC, where they designed immersive 3D environments using Blender and Adobe Substance Painter, leading a team of 3D artists to create game elements that attracted over 100,000 concurrent players. Their implementation of efficient workflow strategies accelerated project completion by 20%.

Originally from Ethiopia, Yeabsera moved to Spokane, Washington at the age of 10 and attended All Saints Catholic School before graduating from Gonzaga Preparatory School. At Gonzaga Prep, Yeabsera was recognized as a Salutatorian, placing in the second-highest academic group in the graduating class. He was also a recipient of the Mike Shanks scholarship, which supported his education at Gonzaga Prep.

Yeabsera has been actively involved in community service through Gonzaga Prep's Knights of the Leash program, particularly providing after-school tutoring at his former elementary school, All Saints Catholic School. His AP calculus teacher, Stephen Manfred, described him as an outgoing student with a great personality who "brings joy to the people around him" and "interacts with his peers really well."

As a first-generation university student, Yeabsera is involved with ColorStack, a tech nonprofit that creates academic and professional opportunities for Black and Latinx students entering STEM fields. At Stanford, he benefits from programs designed to support first-generation, low-income (FLI) students in their transition to college life.

Academically, Yeabsera has taken courses in Computer Systems, Design and Analysis of Algorithms, Infrastructure at Scale, Mathematical Foundations of Computer Science, Operating System Principles, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Programming Abstractions and Methodologies at Stanford.

Yeabsera has also participated in selective development programs, including the HeadStart Fellowship for diverse students with outstanding leadership potential, and Jane Street's UNBOXED Scholar program, where they gained experience in quantitative trading through probability, statistics, and game theory challenges.

Currently, Yeabsera is set to join LinkedIn as a Software Engineer for Summer 2025, continuing to build on their impressive technical foundation and entrepreneurial spirit with the long-term goal of establishing a career in the tech industry.

name: joel grayson
short_description: Joel is a Stanford University student with a passion for software development, engineering, and climate solutions. He has created multiple successful applications including Buseroo.com and Focus for Google Docs, while also building physical projects like a vending machine and Jacob's ladder. His environmental work includes bringing solar installations to his high school and researching organic solar cells at NYU's Lee Research Lab.
long_description:
Joel Grayson is a student at Stanford University (2024-2028) with a multifaceted background spanning software development, engineering, and climate activism. His software portfolio includes several successful applications: Buseroo.com, which helps students find appropriate school buses; Homework Checker, used by 2,000 students for assignment management; Focus for Google Docs, a productivity tool with 1,000 users; Edit Time, which helps 4,000 users manage file modification properties; and LirongArt.com, a showcase for his mother's artwork.

Beyond software, Joel demonstrates strong engineering skills through physical projects including a functional vending machine, a Jacob's ladder alarm clock, a wooden pinball machine, and a slayer exciter. His technical interests extend to quantum computing, having earned a Professional Certificate from MIT xPRO in 2023.

Joel is deeply committed to environmental causes. He spearheaded a solar installation project at Riverdale Country School that reduces carbon emissions by 250 metric tons annually while providing backup power and educational data. He founded Students for Electric Buses to promote sustainable transportation and conducted research on organic solar cells at NYU's Lee Research Lab. His civic engagement includes serving on Manhattan Community Board One's Environmental Protection Committee and Youth & Education Committee (May 2023-May 2024), where he worked on climate resiliency projects for Lower Manhattan. He also collaborated with the Mayor's Office of Climate and Environmental Justice to connect street vendors to the electrical grid as an alternative to gas generators.

Joel's professional experience includes a research position at NYU Lee Lab (July-August 2023) and an internship at The Stone House Group (June 2023). He graduated from Riverdale Country School (2017-2024) before beginning his studies at Stanford. At Stanford, he is an undergraduate researcher in the Mai Lab in the Chemical Engineering department (Spring 2024-present), where he contributes to research on biopolymer engineering. He maintains a YouTube channel featuring father-and-son comedy, project records, and claymation. Joel is also an accomplished violinist, performing recitals and creating his own compositions.

His technical skills include full-stack web development (Next.js/React, TypeScript, SQL, Docker, Express, PHP, Node), app development (Swift, SwiftUI, Java, React Native, Supabase), and embedded systems (Arduino, Raspberry Pi, ESP32, Python, C++). Joel gave a TEDx talk on combating climate change in 2024 and is an En-ROADS Ambassador (climate educator) since 2022.

suggested_people.name: Nicole Ma
suggested_people.short_description: Nicole Ma is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with a strong background in climate science research. She has published work on global surface temperature projections and has experience at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where she developed machine learning models for offshore wind resource assessment and forecasting.
suggested_people.long_description:
Nicole Ma is pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science and Mathematics at Stanford University (2024-2028). Her research interests span climate science, machine learning, and environmental engineering, with a particular focus on applying computational methods to address climate challenges.

Nicole has built an impressive research portfolio at a young age. As a Research Fellow at the Simons Summer Research Program at Stony Brook University, she has been working on novel stochastic process models to simulate the latitude of the North Atlantic Jet Stream. Previously, she interned at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory for over two years, where she developed machine learning models to improve offshore wind resource assessment and forecasting.

Her research has already gained recognition in the scientific community. She published a paper titled "21st Century Global and Regional Surface Temperature Projections" in Earth and Space Science, analyzing observed global surface temperature trends across different latitudinal regions. This work earned her the 2023 CESASC JHJ Prize for Fundamental Science in Physics, an award given to researchers under 26 who have published lead-authored papers in reputable international journals.

Nicole is also passionate about climate justice, serving as President of the Climate Justice Global Alliance. Her commitment to environmental causes is further demonstrated by her numerous awards in science fairs, particularly in environmental engineering and energy conversion/alternate energy categories.

Beyond her environmental work, Nicole has excelled in mathematics and programming competitions. She is a National Merit Scholarship Finalist, American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) Qualifier, and has won multiple hackathons and programming competitions, including 1st Place at the 2022 igniteCS Programming Expo and 2021 GameGala.

Nicole is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Mandarin. She will be participating in Jane Street's WiSE Program in July 2024, further expanding her experience in quantitative fields.

At Stanford, Nicole is registered as an undergraduate student in the Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education department, where she continues to pursue her academic interests while contributing to the university community.

suggested_people.name: Arihant Choudhary
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley with extensive research experience across AI, cryptography, and computational game theory. Currently working as a Software Intern at Intel and Lead Undergraduate Researcher at UC Berkeley, focusing on multi-agent systems, AI applications, and CS education.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arihant Choudhary is a multifaceted Computer Science, Data Science, and Applied Mathematics student at UC Berkeley with a remarkable research portfolio spanning diverse technical domains. His research journey includes work at Stanford University on multi-agent systems for inference, reasoning, and planning, as well as climate data analysis using CMIP-6 models.

At UC Berkeley, Arihant has made significant contributions across multiple research labs. He serves as a Lead Undergraduate Researcher in two labs under Prof. Dan Garcia - the Computational Game Theory Lab (GamesCrafters) and the CS Education Lab (ACE Lab). In the ACE Lab, he authored papers on dynamic animated feedback for randomized graph problems (accepted at SIGCSE 2024) and co-authored work on personalized reminders for mastery learning (AutoRemind, accepted at SIGCSE 2025). His work in the Computational Game Theory Lab involved developing solvers for games like Quick Cross and Euclid's Game, researching pure draw theory, and creating human-robot interaction systems.

Professionally, Arihant is currently working as a Software Intern at Intel Corporation, implementing cutting-edge research and building products for Intel Foundry. His previous role as a Research Intern at Intel focused on text-to-video research and building Intel's Personal Educator (IPED) using large language models and text-to-speech libraries to support employee training. He also serves as a Dean's Engineering Ambassador at UC Berkeley's College of Engineering, working on programs for high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.

Arihant's journey to UC Berkeley is particularly inspiring. After being rejected from all colleges in his first application cycle, he took a gap year in 2020 and pursued multiple projects, including a significant climate change research project through Polygence. Working with his mentor Tristan Ballard, a Stanford PhD in earth systems science, Arihant analyzed a petabyte of climate data to study monsoons in Kolkata and assess climate change impacts on agriculture. This experience not only built his technical skills but also helped him secure admission to UC Berkeley on his second attempt.

Arihant's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Berkeley Social, a platform he developed to help incoming UC Berkeley students connect with peers sharing similar interests. He also co-founded Yindu & Zhongguo Inc, which included the Bangla Machinery Bank, an AgriTech enterprise providing efficient farm machinery to farmers in West Bengal.

His academic pursuits extend beyond UC Berkeley, with coursework at Stanford University in CS224G: Apps with LLMs Inside. Arihant's technical expertise spans AI, machine learning, cryptography, and data science, complemented by his multilingual proficiency in English, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, and Marwari.

Through his diverse experiences in research, entrepreneurship, and community service, Arihant demonstrates a commitment to leveraging technology for social impact and educational advancement. Expected to graduate in Spring 2025, he is now interested in pursuing a graduate degree and a career in artificial intelligence/machine learning.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

name: vivek vajipey
short_description: Vivek Vajipey is a Computer Science student at Stanford University pursuing both Bachelor's and Master's degrees with a minor in Geophysics. His research at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) focuses on reasoning in large language models, while his previous work applied machine learning to agricultural remote sensing. He has developed innovative AI applications including ExplainAI, CriticAL, and WorldDex, winning awards at major hackathons like PennApps XXIV and Cal Hacks 10.0.
long_description:
Vivek Vajipey is pursuing both a Bachelor's and Master's degree in Computer Science at Stanford University, with a minor in Geophysics. His academic journey reflects a deep interest in the intersection of artificial intelligence and practical applications.

At the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL), Vivek researches reasoning capabilities in large language models through the Computation & Cognition Lab. His work in AI extends beyond theoretical research - he has recently co-authored "CriticAL: Critic Automation with Language Models," demonstrating his contribution to advancing LLM technologies.

Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya
suggested_people.short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese. Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

suggested_people.name: Joe Qiaoyun Li
suggested_people.short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

name: andrew tan
short_description: Andrew Tan is a Stanford University alumnus and entrepreneur focused on democratizing career growth. With a strong background in computer science and data science from UC Berkeley, he has conducted research in stock market prediction using sentiment analysis and has been recognized with numerous academic honors including Phi Beta Kappa and the EECS Honors Program.
long_description:
Andrew Tan is an accomplished technologist and entrepreneur currently associated with Humans and Stanford University. He's working on democratizing access to career growth through his venture joinnova.co.

Andrew has an impressive academic background, having graduated from UC Berkeley where he was part of the EECS Honors Program and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa as a junior (top 20 students in his class). During his time at Berkeley, he excelled as a student instructor in the Data Science Department, earning recognition as an Outstanding Student Instructor.

His research interests include applying AI to financial markets, as evidenced by his publication "Sentiment Predictability for Stocks" where he explored stock market prediction using textual sentiment analysis tools and advanced prediction models like LSTMs and convolutional architectures.

Andrew has a strong entrepreneurial spirit, having been selected for the Pear VC Summer Fellowship which provided seed investment for his early-stage startup. He was also named a Jack Larson Scholar at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business, receiving a scholarship to pursue entrepreneurship in technology and research.

His technical talents were recognized early, being one of only 11 students nationwide awarded the Snap Research Scholarship for his academic performance, research experience, and ability to solve tough technical challenges. Before college, Andrew was the Salutatorian of his high school class and achieved success in both mathematics competitions (qualifying for AIME four times) and business competitions (placing 2nd at the DECA International Competition).

Andrew is bilingual, with native English proficiency and professional working proficiency in Chinese, adding to his versatile skill set that spans technology, research, and entrepreneurship.

It's important to note that there is another prominent Andrew Tan who is a Filipino billionaire businessman. This Andrew Tan is the chairman of Alliance Global Group, Inc., a major conglomerate with interests in real estate, food and beverage, gaming, and hospitality. Born in Fujian, China, he moved to Hong Kong at age 4 and later to the Philippines as a teenager. He graduated with a degree in accounting from the University of the East in Manila and built his fortune developing large apartment complexes around Manila. His company Megaworld Corporation pioneered the "live-work-play" concept in township development, and he also runs Emperador, the world's largest brandy company by sales volume. As of 2024, his net worth is estimated at $1.5 billion. This is a different individual from the Andrew Tan described in the main profile.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Jalen Xing
suggested_people.short_description: Venture Fellow at General Catalyst with a strong technical background in AI and software engineering. UC Berkeley EECS graduate with experience at Meta, Capital One, and AWS, specializing in semantic search, large language models, and machine learning image classification.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jalen Xing is a Venture Fellow at General Catalyst, where he focuses on scouting and investing in promising student startups. With a solid foundation in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from UC Berkeley, Jalen has built an impressive technical background through various software engineering roles at leading tech companies.

His professional experience includes working at Meta on Facebook Search's Vertical Ranking team, developing semantic search and large language model applications at Capital One, and implementing machine learning image classification and search solutions at Amazon Web Services (AWS). He also gained experience in compliance and equity technology during his time at Balyasny Asset Management.

Jalen's academic credentials include a Master's degree from UC Berkeley with an exceptional 3.95/4.00 GPA, where he was involved with Codebase and received the Fung Excellence Scholarship. Prior to Berkeley, he completed his Bachelor of Science at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign with a near-perfect 3.98/4.00 GPA, where he also worked as a Research Assistant under Professor Bao.

His unique combination of technical expertise in AI, particularly in semantic search and large language models, along with his current focus on venture capital, positions him at the intersection of cutting-edge technology and investment. Jalen actively seeks connections with student entrepreneurs and innovators, offering his expertise to help them build and grow their startups.

Note: The scraped website information appears to reference different individuals with similar surnames (Xing Wu, Galen Xing, and Xin Xing) who are not related to Jalen Xing. These individuals have different academic and professional backgrounds, including positions at Berkeley in integrative biology, computational biology, and mathematics/quantum chemistry research.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

name: thomaz felipe bonato
short_description: Brazilian AI researcher and entrepreneur studying at USC as a Trustee Scholar. Thomaz has excelled in hackathons, winning first place at HackMIT and second place at PennApps in 2024, while conducting AI research at USC Marshall School of Business focusing on educational applications and LLMs.
long_description:
Thomaz Felipe Bonato is a passionate engineer, researcher, and lifelong learner from Brazil currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence for Business at the University of Southern California as a prestigious Trustee Scholar with full tuition. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his National Merit Finalist status.

Thomaz has established himself as an exceptional hackathon competitor, securing first place at HackMIT 2024 with PalmLabs (focused on education) and second place at PennApps 2024 with Cypress MFA (addressing security and privacy challenges). He also won first place with Azalea, an eco-friendly AI model selector, demonstrating his commitment to sustainable AI solutions.

His professional experience spans multiple domains within AI and business. As an AI Research Assistant at USC Marshall School of Business since December 2023, he initially explored AI applications in education and has since expanded to researching LLMs and cluster-based probing techniques. Thomaz has entrepreneurial experience as a founder of a stealth startup focused on AI solutions for law firms, and currently serves as a Data Science Intern at Trudy and a Growth Strategist at Mercor.

Within the USC community, Thomaz has taken on leadership roles as the Director of Founder's Education at SEP (Student Entrepreneurship Program) and previously served as Director of External Relations for USC Business Technology Group. He was also a Student Founder at SEP, demonstrating his commitment to entrepreneurship education.

Thomaz is multilingual, with native proficiency in Portuguese and English, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. He is also a Management Leadership Tomorrow (MLT) Fellow, indicating his commitment to leadership development. His technical skills are evidenced by certifications in Linear Algebra for Machine Learning and Neural Networks and Deep Learning from DeepLearning.AI, as well as UX design skills certified by LinkedIn.

His contribution to policy is demonstrated through his publication "A Blueprint for Greece's AI Transformation" for the Special Secretariat for Foresight, Presidency of the Government, Hellenic Republic, showing his interest in AI governance and national strategy development.

It's important to note that there is another Thomaz Bonato who has had a distinguished career in the pharmaceutical industry, serving in various executive roles at AstraZeneca and Alexion. This Thomaz Bonato has held positions including US Chief Financial Officer and Vice President of Finance at AstraZeneca, Interim Country President of AstraZeneca Australia and New Zealand, and most recently as Global Head of Research Development & Medical Finance at Alexion. His career has included significant financial leadership roles across multiple countries including Brazil, Costa Rica, Australia, and the United States.
