However, this is a different individual than the USC student and AI researcher profiled here.

suggested_people.name: David Bai
suggested_people.short_description: David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at USC with diverse research experience in AI alignment, multi-agent robotic planning, and reinforcement learning for legged robots. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's developing language learning tools while also working on innovative projects like brain-controlled drones and GPS-denied navigation systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at the University of Southern California (2023-2027), where he serves as a USC Presidential Scholar. His academic journey is marked by a deep commitment to artificial intelligence research across multiple domains.

Currently, David is a Research Fellow at the Supervised Program for Alignment Research, where he investigates reasoning and AI agents from capabilities and security perspectives. Simultaneously, he works as a Research Assistant at USC Viterbi School of Engineering's GLAMOR Lab through the CURVE Fellowship, focusing on multi-agent robotic planning at the intersection of LLMs and symbolic planners.

David's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of Jargon, where he's building a language learning Chrome extension. His technical versatility extends to his work with USC Makers, where he manages projects involving brain-controlled drones using electroencephalography, having previously contributed to an autonomous greenhouse with computer vision.

His professional experience includes a Machine Learning & Computer Vision Internship at Rhoman Aerospace, enabling GPS-denied navigation through VIO and building simulation/SLAM pipelines. David has also served as a Research Assistant at the Dynamic Robotics and Control Laboratory, where he augmented model predictive control for legged robots with reinforcement learning.

In the academic community, David is active with USC's Center for AI in Society's Student Branch (CAIS++), where he contributes to research and projects in artificial intelligence with social impact applications. He is part of the Fall 2024 cohort, demonstrating his commitment to applying AI for societal benefit.

David is also involved with the USC Computational Aerospace Lab, where he works on projects related to BCD (Binary Collision Detection), showcasing his interdisciplinary approach to engineering challenges. This involvement highlights his ability to apply computational methods to aerospace applications.

Prior to USC, David demonstrated academic excellence at Cambridge University, where he compiled comprehensive lecture notes across various mathematical disciplines, indicating his strong foundation in theoretical concepts that underpin his current technical work.

David's commitment to social impact is demonstrated through his volunteer work with the Cheyenne River Youth Project and Friends of Children with Special Needs, where he developed educational courses. His multidisciplinary approach to AI research, combined with his technical skills and social consciousness, positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Rez Havaei
suggested_people.short_description: Rez Havaei is the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis (YC S24), a startup developing automated AI safety and red-teaming tools. With expertise in AI research and quantitative trading, his career includes roles at Cohere, NVIDIA, Jane Street, and as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rez Havaei is an accomplished entrepreneur and AI specialist currently serving as the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis, a Y Combinator-backed startup (S24 batch) focused on AI safety and evaluation. The company provides a comprehensive suite of tools for identifying and addressing vulnerabilities in AI systems, including red-teaming frameworks and interpretability techniques.

General Analysis was founded in 2024 and is based in San Francisco. The company's mission is to address the growing risks associated with deploying increasingly capable AI systems in high-stakes environments. Their approach involves developing automated tools that systematically find model failure modes and enhance model robustness, delivering detailed safety and performance reports to customers.

One of their notable projects demonstrated how GPT-4o is susceptible to hallucinating when asked about legal cases or concepts. Their research showed they could train an attacker model that caused GPT-4o to hallucinate on more than 35% of prompts related to legal questions.

Before founding General Analysis, Rez worked as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform and benchmark. This startup, co-founded by Stanford AI students, aimed to create a standardized test for measuring artificial intelligence and large language models, providing an unbiased, third-party review system.

Rez's professional experience spans both AI research and finance. He has worked as an Applied Research Intern in Deep Learning at Snap Inc., a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Cohere (a leading AI company developing large language models), and held an Applied Research position in Artificial Intelligence at NVIDIA. His finance background includes quantitative trading internships at prestigious firms like Jane Street and Susquehanna International Group (SIG).

His academic research experience includes positions at the USC Information Sciences Institute and as a Research Assistant at UC Davis, where he also served as a Teaching Assistant. Rez earned a Bachelor of Science in Engineering from the University of California, Davis (2018-2023), maintaining a 3.97 GPA.

Rez is also involved in another venture called Kart AI, which serves as an interactive search platform that simplifies research for electronic products. The platform extracts relevant recommendations from Reddit, YouTube, and trusted content creators to help users find and compare electronic products.

His technical interests and expertise span AI safety, interpretability, evaluation, deep learning, and statistical inference. Rez's career trajectory demonstrates his commitment to addressing the challenges of AI safety and evaluation while building practical tools that can help organizations deploy AI systems more responsibly.

suggested_people.name: Eric Mao
suggested_people.short_description: Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), former MasterChef Australia contestant, and UPenn M&T student with a strong background in AI research. Eric has worked on diverse projects from carbon sequestration estimation to cognitive status prediction using machine learning, and is currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's accelerator program.
suggested_people.long_description:
Eric Mao is a multifaceted entrepreneur and researcher at the intersection of technology, business, and culinary arts. As the Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), he's currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's prestigious accelerator program. His product has shown impressive early traction, with 18,000 users spending over 1,350 hours on the site within 48 hours of launch.

Eric was previously enrolled in the Jerome Fisher Program in Management & Technology (M&T) at the University of Pennsylvania, pursuing a dual degree in Computer Science and Business Administration at Wharton. He's currently on leave to focus on his startup.

His research experience spans multiple AI applications. He has worked on machine learning approaches for carbon credit accuracy, deep learning for 3D printing reliability enhancement, cognitive status prediction from fMRI data, and mind-controlled wheelchairs for ALS patients. His research on carbon sequestration earned him the Best Research Poster award at the International Conference on Climate Change in 2024.

Eric gained national recognition as a contestant on Season 13 of MasterChef Australia at the age of 21. As one of the youngest competitors, he showcased his passion for regional Chinese cuisine and Pan-Asian cooking. His culinary journey began early - he had previously auditioned for Junior MasterChef Australia at age 10. With roots in Wuxi, Eastern China, Eric's cooking is deeply influenced by his heritage and family traditions. During the competition, he created signature dishes including Shanghai Chive Pancake with Black Garlic Prawns, Three Treasure Wonton, and Strange Flavour Chicken.

Before MasterChef, Eric was a medical student at the University of New South Wales, where he made the difficult decision to defer his studies to pursue his culinary passion. His dream has been to create a pop-up restaurant that brings regional Chinese cuisine into a modern Australian setting.

Eric was also selected as a Fellow at Telora, where he worked on Iris, an improved file management system for video editors. His entrepreneurial journey includes participation in Z Fellows, a program for founders and builders.

During his high school years at Crescent School, Eric demonstrated exceptional talent in physics and computer science, representing Team Canada in the International Young Physicists' Tournament, earning a Gold Medal in the Canadian Young Physicists' Tournament, winning the High School Big Data Challenge, and reaching the Platinum Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO).

Eric combines technical expertise in AI and machine learning with business acumen, entrepreneurial drive, and culinary creativity, focusing on creating practical solutions to real-world problems across multiple disciplines.

name: arihan v.
short_description: Stanford CS student and accomplished ML researcher specializing in computer vision and LLM applications. With multiple hackathon wins and research experience at UNT's Computer Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Arihan has developed innovative solutions ranging from cropland optimization using neural networks to sign language interpretation systems.
long_description:
Arihan V. is a promising talent in the field of machine learning and AI, currently pursuing a Computer Science degree at Stanford University (Class of 2028). His technical journey began early, with exceptional academic performance at the Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science and Coppell High School.

As an Undergraduate Researcher at the University of North Texas Computer Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Arihan has worked on sophisticated projects funded by NASA, USGS, and Physmodo Inc. He also contributed to research at UNT's Functional Glass Materials and Modeling (FGMM) Laboratory as a TAMS student. His research contributions include developing bi-stream convolutional neural networks and deep learning autoencoders to identify cropland levees and optimize farming structures, as well as creating a novel human tracking method using point clouds and depth videos to improve pose estimation accuracy.

Arihan has demonstrated remarkable success in competitive environments, winning multiple hackathons with innovative AI solutions. His projects showcase versatility across different domains:
- Shush: A WhisperV3 model with Flash Attention v2 deployed on Modal via a NextJS app (197 GitHub stars)
- CoWorkr: An AI-powered team knowledge bot
- Koios GPT: A web application combining AI algorithms and LLMs to process research articles and PDFs (1st Place at HackLah! and Code4Good)
- Sign Ease: An app utilizing machine learning to interpret sign language gestures (Winner at MLH's Hack Your Portfolio)
- Transcribi: A web app leveraging OpenAI GPT, Whisper, and Langchain for audio transcription and analysis (1st Place Education Hack at PantherHack)
- SightSense: A wearable device using object detection and text-to-speech to aid visually impaired individuals (1st Place Generative AI at Treasure Hacks)
- ReadSpeak: A comprehensive app for improving reading and pronunciation skills (1st Place at LaunchHacks II)
- PromptGPT: A tool that generates efficient prompts using a custom, finetuned, opensource Dolly v2 model
- Zenset: An expressive writing and journaling app with rewards

His technical expertise spans Python, React, Next.js, TensorFlow, PyTorch, convolutional neural networks, machine learning, statistical analysis, and LLM applications. Arihan has also received recognition for his academic excellence, including the UNT President's List for a perfect 4.0 GPA and the TAMS Summer Scholarship for continued research work.

At Stanford, Arihan is part of the IRIS lab community, which focuses on robotics and machine learning research. He's also been selected as a National Security Innovation Scholar at the Gordian Knot Center for National Security Innovation.

Beyond his technical accomplishments, Arihan has demonstrated business acumen as a DECA Collegiate Business Ethics State Finalist and ICDC Qualifier. His multilingual capabilities include proficiency in English (native), Hindi, Telugu, and Spanish, reflecting his diverse skill set and global perspective.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Vivek Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vivek Vajipey is a Computer Science student at Stanford University pursuing both Bachelor's and Master's degrees with a minor in Geophysics. His research at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) focuses on reasoning in large language models, while his previous work applied machine learning to agricultural remote sensing. He has developed innovative AI applications including ExplainAI, CriticAL, and WorldDex, winning awards at major hackathons like PennApps XXIV and Cal Hacks 10.0.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vivek Vajipey is pursuing both a Bachelor's and Master's degree in Computer Science at Stanford University, with a minor in Geophysics. His academic journey reflects a deep interest in the intersection of artificial intelligence and practical applications.

At the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL), Vivek researches reasoning capabilities in large language models through the Computation & Cognition Lab. His work in AI extends beyond theoretical research - he has recently co-authored "CriticAL: Critic Automation with Language Models," demonstrating his contribution to advancing LLM technologies.

Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Vijay Kumaravelrajan
suggested_people.short_description: Vijay is a junior at USC studying Math and Computer Science, where he serves as a Project Lead at USC's Center for AI in Society. His research spans inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, robotic manipulation, and 6G wireless technology. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's building an LLM-powered language learning Chrome extension.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vijay Kumaravelrajan is a junior at the University of Southern California pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics and Computer Science. As a Trustee Scholar and Viterbi Fellow, he has established himself as a multifaceted researcher and entrepreneur in the AI space.

At USC's Center for AI in Society (CAIS++), Vijay currently leads a team of five researchers focused on inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, where they're achieving superior pass@k performance under tighter inference budgets compared to larger models. His work involves implementing and analyzing various inference-time scaling strategies including best-of-n approaches, tree search with PRMs, and Chain of Thought with reinforcement learning. Previously at CAIS++, he conducted research in robotic manipulation through collaboration with USC's SLURM lab, implementing environment simulations using MuJoCo and ManiSkill with Gymnasium for reinforcement learning training. He has also served as a Curriculum Lead, mentoring underclassmen through practical ML projects and teaching comprehensive curriculum covering neural networks, classical ML, NLP, computer vision, transformers, and generative modeling.

Beyond his academic research, Vijay co-founded Jargon, a startup developing a Chrome extension that transforms everyday browsing into language learning opportunities powered by large language models. His entrepreneurial venture demonstrates his ability to apply AI technologies to practical educational tools.

Since August 2022, Vijay has been a Directed Researcher at USC's WiDES Lab, where he collaborates with PhD leads and a team of graduate and undergraduate researchers. His work includes designing and optimizing ray tracers for 6G wireless installations and using convolutional neural networks alongside traditional algorithms to detect edges in point cloud data. He implements C++ libraries in Python and MATLAB, showcasing his versatility across programming languages.

Earlier in his academic career, Vijay worked as a Research Assistant at Scholar Launch, conducting research on open star clusters under the guidance of a professor from UT Austin. He created generalizable algorithms for determining the age of any star cluster of interest using Python.

Vijay has demonstrated his programming skills in competitive settings, participating in the Fall 2024 USC Programming Contest where he successfully solved the "5-Mile Hike" problem using Python. He also contributed to the "Gen-AI for Multi-Agent Deformable Object Manipulation" project at CAIS++, working alongside other researchers to advance robotic manipulation of deformable objects like bread and clothing. This project integrated various robotic platforms including ALOHA and Baxter into the MuJoCo simulation environment using Robosuite, setting up bimanual configurations to explore different arm controllers.

Outside of his AI and computer science pursuits, Vijay is involved with USC's Rocket Propulsion Lab as a General Member focusing on simulations. He achieved the rank of Eagle Scout with Boy Scout Troop 1776 and graduated with an IB Diploma, demonstrating his well-rounded capabilities and leadership potential.

Vijay's personal website (jaykr.dev) features his projects and writing, reflecting his passion for discovering and building new technologies at the intersection of mathematics, computer science, and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

name: suresh nambi
short_description: Stanford University researcher specializing in hardware optimization for AI systems. Published author with expertise in efficient neural network design, approximate computing, and laser-induced graphitic carbon for electronics. Focused on developing low-power, high-performance hardware solutions for next-generation AI applications.
long_description:
Suresh Nambi is a researcher at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, focusing on the development and implementation of efficient and effective hardware solutions for AI systems. His research interests span several specialized areas within hardware optimization, including approximate computing, FPGA-based neural network implementations, and novel materials for electronics.

Suresh has made significant contributions to the field through his publications in prestigious journals. His work on "ExPAN(N)D" explored the use of posits (an alternative to floating-point representation) for efficient neural network design in FPGA-based systems, demonstrating his expertise in hardware-optimized AI implementations. He also developed "DeBAM," a decoder-based approximate multiplier designed specifically for low-power applications, showcasing his innovation in energy-efficient computing architectures.

Beyond traditional computing hardware, Suresh has explored novel materials and fabrication techniques. His research on laser-induced graphitic carbon has led to breakthroughs in creating low-resistance conductors, including work on 3D-printed structures. This interdisciplinary approach bridges electronics, materials science, and advanced manufacturing.

Additionally, Suresh has ventured into sustainable energy applications, conducting performance analysis of submerged photovoltaic cells under varying water conditions, demonstrating his versatility and interest in environmentally conscious technologies.

His GitHub repository for the DeBAM project indicates his commitment to open-source contributions and knowledge sharing within the research community. At Stanford, he continues to push the boundaries of hardware design for AI applications, likely focusing on creating more efficient, powerful, and specialized computing solutions for the next generation of artificial intelligence systems.

suggested_people.name: Fengrui Zuo
suggested_people.short_description: Fengrui Zuo is a hardware specialist focusing on Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory. With a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, he brings specialized expertise in hardware acceleration for AI applications and serves as an Analog Design Co-Lead and Industry Outreach Officer at Open Source Silicon @ Stanford.
suggested_people.long_description:
Fengrui Zuo is a hardware engineer specializing in Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, which is operated by Stanford University. He currently holds dual positions as a Staff Engineer at SLAC and is pursuing his Master's degree in Electrical Engineering (MSEE) at Stanford University, which he began in Autumn 2023.

Fengrui has established himself as a leader in the open-source silicon community at Stanford, where he serves in multiple leadership roles. He is the Industry Outreach Officer for Open Source Silicon @ Stanford (OS3), helping to bridge academic research with industry applications. Additionally, he co-leads the Analog Design Subteam at OS3, where he focuses on designing and verifying analog components such as amplifiers, voltage references, and Power Management ICs (PMICs). His work involves device simulations, schematic generation and routing using both open-source and proprietary software, and conducting bench testing and verification.

His technical expertise spans across several domains including CUDA kernel optimization, autonomous systems, and chip design. Fengrui demonstrates particular interest in cutting-edge hardware developments such as NVIDIA's Jetson Orin Nano platform for edge AI applications, open-source chip design, and specialized motherboards with timing synchronization capabilities. His work at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory likely involves specialized hardware systems for scientific research and experimentation, integrating AI capabilities into high-performance computing environments for physics research.

Fengrui's professional address is at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, located at 2575 Sand Hill Rd, Menlo Park, California. His dual role as both a graduate student and staff engineer positions him uniquely at the intersection of academic research and practical engineering applications, particularly in the field of analog design for advanced computing systems.

suggested_people.name: Yuwei Qin
suggested_people.short_description: A results-driven AI hardware specialist currently at d-Matrix with a strong background in computational electromagnetics and machine learning. Yuwei holds a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University and has extensive research experience in applying deep neural networks to data detection and electromagnetic analysis.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yuwei Qin is a technical professional specializing in AI hardware optimization, currently working at d-Matrix, a company focused on AI compute platforms for inference. With a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University's Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Yuwei has developed expertise at the intersection of hardware engineering and machine learning.

Yuwei's research contributions are particularly notable in the fields of computational electromagnetics, machine learning applications for hardware, and magnetic recording technologies. His publication record includes over 20 papers with more than 150 citations, demonstrating significant impact in his field. His most cited work includes "Machine learning based method of moments (ML-MoM)" (46 citations) and "Deep Neural Network: Data Detection Channel for Hard Disk Drives by Learning" (22 citations).

His research has focused on applying deep neural networks and machine learning to improve data detection in storage systems, particularly for hard disk drives. Notable achievements include developing a CNN-based read channel for hard disk drives that achieved a 30% error rate reduction and 200Mbits/s throughput in 28nm CMOS technology. This work represents a significant advancement in storage system performance through the application of machine learning techniques.

Yuwei has also made contributions to computational electromagnetics, developing machine learning-based approaches for electromagnetic compatibility analysis and parasitic capacitance extractions. His work on electrically tunable polarizers based on graphene-loaded plasmonic cross antennas demonstrates his expertise in applied physics and device modeling.

In the field of heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), Yuwei has conducted research on improving recording performance through micromagnetic modeling and analysis of thermal profiles, contributing to advancements in storage technology.

Throughout his career, Yuwei has collaborated with researchers from institutions including the University of Hong Kong, Western Digital, and Zhejiang University, building a strong professional network in the field of AI hardware and computational electromagnetics.

His technical expertise spans computer engineering, deep learning, storage systems, device modeling, semiconductor device physics, and applied physics, making him a versatile professional at the cutting edge of AI hardware optimization and machine learning applications for hardware systems.

suggested_people.name: Sathvik Redrouthu
suggested_people.short_description: Sathvik Redrouthu is a tech innovator and entrepreneur who founded Procyon Photonics while in high school to develop photonic computing technology. Currently at Etched, he previously worked on chip design tooling through his startup Instachip. His research focuses on optical computing, photonic integrated circuits, and tensor algebra implementations for next-generation computing architectures.
suggested_people.long_description:
Sathvik Redrouthu is a forward-thinking technologist, entrepreneur, and researcher at the intersection of optoelectronics, hardware acceleration, and advanced computing architectures. Currently working at Etched and previously associated with Y Combinator, Sathvik has established himself as an innovator in specialized computing hardware despite his young age.

As the founder, CEO, and CTO of Procyon Photonics, Sathvik became the world's youngest CEO in the photonic and optical computing sector. Founded in 2021 while he was still in high school at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, Procyon develops revolutionary photon-based computing technology that aims to overcome the limitations of traditional electronic computing. The company's optical chips are designed to be significantly more energy-efficient than conventional processors, with prototypes reportedly 55,000 times more energy-efficient than the Intel i9 and over 100 times more efficient than Nvidia's A100 or Google's TPU. Procyon secured venture funding from Peter Thiel's 1517 Fund and has attracted interest from tech leaders like Sam Altman of OpenAI.

Before joining Etched, Sathvik founded Instachip, an EDA (Electronic Design Automation) startup focused on chip design tooling, and participated in Y Combinator. He is also conducting Formal Verification research with Dr. Mark Santolucito at Columbia University.

His research portfolio includes significant contributions to optical computing, with publications focused on optoelectronic hardware accelerators for tensor arithmetic. His work on "Tachyon," a programmable optoelectronic hardware accelerator, demonstrates his expertise in designing systems for ultrafast tensor operations. His team at Procyon was the first to run tensor algebra on an optical chip. Additionally, he has published on tensor algebra implementations for optoelectronic microchips and the use of interferometer-based photonic integrated circuits for rapid unitary transformations.

Sathvik's technical focus is on leveraging optical technologies to overcome limitations in traditional electronic computing, particularly for matrix multiplication and tensor operations critical for AI and machine learning workloads. His work on implementing unitary matrix transformations through Mach-Zehnder interferometers shows a deep understanding of how to harness photonic principles for computational advantage.

Beyond his professional work, Sathvik has developed numerous projects including AI chess engines, regex interpreters using Brzozowski derivatives, tensor algebra compilers with sparse tensor storage systems, and various AI applications. He is also skilled in hardware development, having created electric guitars and EMP generators from scratch.

Sathvik graduated high school in June 2024 but decided not to attend university, instead pursuing entrepreneurship and practical research. His vision is to someday "power the world with light" through photon-based computing, which he believes represents the next revolution in computing technology.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Anush Mutyala
suggested_people.short_description: Anush Mutyala is a biomedical engineering student at UBC and multifaceted researcher working at the intersection of neuroscience, robotics, and hardware engineering. Currently developing calibration-free robotics at NC4 Lab while building electronics for STEM cell factories at General Cybernetics, he's also passionate about DIY semiconductor fabrication and neuromorphic computing.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anush Mutyala is a biomedical engineering student at the University of British Columbia, attending on a prestigious $120,000 Schulich Leader Scholarship. His research interests span multiple cutting-edge domains, with a particular focus on neuromorphic computing, robotics, and hardware engineering.

Currently, Anush works as a Robotics Researcher at NC4 Lab, where he's developing neural manifold approaches to eliminate sensor calibration in robotics systems. His work involves building ROS/Gazebo simulations to generate rich LIDAR datasets. Simultaneously, he serves as an Electrical Engineering Intern at General Cybernetics, designing PCBs for bioelectric cell reprogramming experiments using LTSpice and Altium/Kicad.

Anush's research background is impressively diverse. At York University's LCRAIN lab, he led a cross-institutional team developing bio-plausible spiking neural network training algorithms using EEG-fMRI data. At the University of Toronto's Intelligent Sensory Microsystems Lab, he integrated spiking neural networks into low-power neural implants, reducing latency by 5x through algorithmic optimizations while enabling wearable form factors. He also designed gate-level implementations on FPGA to support future ASIC/tape-out efforts.

His entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of NeuraDAO, which aimed to create a democratized funding ecosystem for neuroscience and technology research. The project raised over $6,000 in Gitcoin Round 15 and involved developing a decentralized marketplace for neuroimaging datasets built on Web3 protocols.

Anush has also contributed to consumer neurotechnology at Divergence Neuro, where he helped build an EEG-based neurofeedback therapy platform, working on visualization modules and event-related potential experiments.

His innovation in neural implant technology has gained recognition, winning a bronze excellence award at the Canada-Wide Science Fair in 2023 for his project "Enerspike." This algorithm dramatically improves battery life in neural implants by optimizing power usage, potentially extending battery lifespan by up to 70 times and eliminating the need for surgical replacement every few years. The project was inspired by both Elon Musk's Neuralink and Stephen Hawking's vision of brain-computer interfaces as the future of communication.

Beyond his formal roles, Anush is passionate about DIY semiconductor fabrication, having received an Emergent Ventures Fellowship grant to build a maskless photolithography stepper for Hacker Fab at UBC. His team was also a finalist at Hack The North 2022 with the project "ConnexSci," which used Graph Neural Networks to optimize drug discovery.

Anush represents a new generation of interdisciplinary researchers working at the convergence of neuroscience, electrical engineering, and artificial intelligence, with a particular focus on developing energy-efficient, brain-inspired computing systems and their applications in healthcare and robotics.

name: nicole ma
short_description: Nicole Ma is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with a strong background in climate science research. She has published work on global surface temperature projections and has experience at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where she developed machine learning models for offshore wind resource assessment and forecasting.
long_description:
Nicole Ma is pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science and Mathematics at Stanford University (2024-2028). Her research interests span climate science, machine learning, and environmental engineering, with a particular focus on applying computational methods to address climate challenges.

Nicole has built an impressive research portfolio at a young age. As a Research Fellow at the Simons Summer Research Program at Stony Brook University, she has been working on novel stochastic process models to simulate the latitude of the North Atlantic Jet Stream. Previously, she interned at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory for over two years, where she developed machine learning models to improve offshore wind resource assessment and forecasting.

Her research has already gained recognition in the scientific community. She published a paper titled "21st Century Global and Regional Surface Temperature Projections" in Earth and Space Science, analyzing observed global surface temperature trends across different latitudinal regions. This work earned her the 2023 CESASC JHJ Prize for Fundamental Science in Physics, an award given to researchers under 26 who have published lead-authored papers in reputable international journals.

Nicole is also passionate about climate justice, serving as President of the Climate Justice Global Alliance. Her commitment to environmental causes is further demonstrated by her numerous awards in science fairs, particularly in environmental engineering and energy conversion/alternate energy categories.

Beyond her environmental work, Nicole has excelled in mathematics and programming competitions. She is a National Merit Scholarship Finalist, American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) Qualifier, and has won multiple hackathons and programming competitions, including 1st Place at the 2022 igniteCS Programming Expo and 2021 GameGala.

Nicole is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Mandarin. She will be participating in Jane Street's WiSE Program in July 2024, further expanding her experience in quantitative fields.

At Stanford, Nicole is registered as an undergraduate student in the Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education department, where she continues to pursue her academic interests while contributing to the university community.

suggested_people.name: Joel Grayson
suggested_people.short_description: Joel is a Stanford University student with a passion for software development, engineering, and climate solutions. He has created multiple successful applications including Buseroo.com and Focus for Google Docs, while also building physical projects like a vending machine and Jacob's ladder. His environmental work includes bringing solar installations to his high school and researching organic solar cells at NYU's Lee Research Lab.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joel Grayson is a student at Stanford University (2024-2028) with a multifaceted background spanning software development, engineering, and climate activism. His software portfolio includes several successful applications: Buseroo.com, which helps students find appropriate school buses; Homework Checker, used by 2,000 students for assignment management; Focus for Google Docs, a productivity tool with 1,000 users; Edit Time, which helps 4,000 users manage file modification properties; and LirongArt.com, a showcase for his mother's artwork.

Beyond software, Joel demonstrates strong engineering skills through physical projects including a functional vending machine, a Jacob's ladder alarm clock, a wooden pinball machine, and a slayer exciter. His technical interests extend to quantum computing, having earned a Professional Certificate from MIT xPRO in 2023.

Joel is deeply committed to environmental causes. He spearheaded a solar installation project at Riverdale Country School that reduces carbon emissions by 250 metric tons annually while providing backup power and educational data. He founded Students for Electric Buses to promote sustainable transportation and conducted research on organic solar cells at NYU's Lee Research Lab. His civic engagement includes serving on Manhattan Community Board One's Environmental Protection Committee and Youth & Education Committee (May 2023-May 2024), where he worked on climate resiliency projects for Lower Manhattan. He also collaborated with the Mayor's Office of Climate and Environmental Justice to connect street vendors to the electrical grid as an alternative to gas generators.

Joel's professional experience includes a research position at NYU Lee Lab (July-August 2023) and an internship at The Stone House Group (June 2023). He graduated from Riverdale Country School (2017-2024) before beginning his studies at Stanford. At Stanford, he is an undergraduate researcher in the Mai Lab in the Chemical Engineering department (Spring 2024-present), where he contributes to research on biopolymer engineering. He maintains a YouTube channel featuring father-and-son comedy, project records, and claymation. Joel is also an accomplished violinist, performing recitals and creating his own compositions.

His technical skills include full-stack web development (Next.js/React, TypeScript, SQL, Docker, Express, PHP, Node), app development (Swift, SwiftUI, Java, React Native, Supabase), and embedded systems (Arduino, Raspberry Pi, ESP32, Python, C++). Joel gave a TEDx talk on combating climate change in 2024 and is an En-ROADS Ambassador (climate educator) since 2022.

suggested_people.name: Alicia Li
suggested_people.short_description: MIT CS/AI & Math double major with a strong research background in robot learning and reinforcement learning. First author on a NeurIPS 2024 workshop paper and incoming ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics. Founded Watch To Donate, raising over $6,000 for various causes while reaching millions of people.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alicia Li is a talented undergraduate at MIT pursuing a double major in Computer Science/AI (specifically course 6-4: AI and Decision Making) and Mathematics (2023-2027). Her research interests span robot learning, planning, and reinforcement learning, with particular focus on safe RL applications.

As an undergraduate researcher at MIT CSAIL's Learning & Intelligent Systems Group, she works on robot learning and planning, and is the first author on a paper accepted to the NeurIPS 2024 Open-World Agents Workshop titled "Learning to Bridge the Gap: Efficient Novelty Recovery with Planning and Reinforcement Learning." She's also researching safe reinforcement learning for power grid optimization at MIT's Donti Lab, where she was listed as a past member in 2024.

Alicia has an impressive publication record for her career stage, with multiple published papers including work on adversarial attacks against online reinforcement learning agents (as part of MIT PRIMES research project 2022-2023), magic SET squares classification, the Post Correspondence Problem, and coin weighing problems. Her academic excellence is further demonstrated by her coursework in graduate-level subjects including Advanced Algorithms, Inference and Information, and Sensorimotor Learning.

Beyond her academic pursuits, Alicia founded and served as CEO of Watch To Donate from 2020 to 2023, an international student organization that donates revenue from social media videos, mobile apps, and business collaborations. Under her leadership, the organization raised over $6,000 for 27 causes, reached over 6 million people, and developed apps with 9,000+ downloads. She also created a Family Fund to help their online community of 50,000 in need. Additionally, she developed "Play To Donate," an app that leverages ad revenue to enable users to donate to charity by playing games.

Alicia is active in MIT's campus life, participating in MIT Asian Dance Team and Ridonkulous (MIT's competitive hip hop dance team), and was previously on Fixation (MIT's competitive contemporary dance team). She also enjoys figure skating and watching movies with friends in her free time.

She is currently preparing for her upcoming role as an ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics, where she'll likely apply her expertise in AI and mathematics to challenges in the therapeutic development space.

suggested_people.name: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya
suggested_people.short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese. Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

suggested_people.name: Trishala Neeraj
suggested_people.short_description: Trishala Neeraj is a Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube with a strong academic background from Cornell University. She specializes in computer vision and natural language processing, bringing technical expertise to cybersecurity analytics and has contributed to several influential AI research papers.
suggested_people.long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. She works with terabyte-scale data to develop models using Deep Learning and Matrix Factorization techniques, with a particular focus on language data and models.

Her academic foundation was built at Cornell University, where she graduated in 2018 after focusing on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing during her graduate studies. She also holds a Bachelor of Engineering degree from BITS Pilani, India, and spent time as a visiting research scholar at the Predictive Technology Lab at the University of Virginia.

Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022). Her work on "BigBIO: A Framework for Data-Centric Biomedical Natural Language Processing" (2022) has also gained recognition in the field.

Her professional experience includes a summer internship at BuzzFeed in 2017, where she worked on a project using K-Means Clustering to tag over 14,000 BuzzFeed quizzes, which she documented in a blog post on the BuzzFeed Tech Blog. She has also published research on "A Computational Approach to Perceived Trustworthiness of Airbnb Host Profiles" (2017) and "Longitudinal Analysis of Cyber-Related Articles" (2020).

Beyond her technical work, Trishala has been actively involved in the tech community. She represented the student body at the Cornell Tech Campus Dedication ceremony in August 2017 and moderated a conversation with Eric Schmidt in March 2018. She maintains a personal blog where she documents her research projects on topics like Weak Supervision, Feature-based Approaches with BERT, and Semantic Entailment.

Trishala is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Hindi, which enhances her ability to work in diverse teams and global environments. Her involvement with organizations like Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) demonstrates her commitment to the broader AI community and diversity in tech.

suggested_people.name: Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at UMD with diverse expertise in computer vision, high-performance computing, and quantitative finance. Currently researching LLMs under Dr. Tom Goldstein while interning at Scale AI for code reasoning models. Published work on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models at ICLR 2023.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan is a Computer Science and Mathematics double major at the University of Maryland with a multifaceted background in AI research and software engineering. His technical interests span computer vision, concurrent and high-performance computing, networks, quantitative finance, and large model efficiency.

Currently, Vijaykaarti serves as a Technical Advisor Intern at Scale AI, where he works on code reasoning models for Olympiad-level competitive programming problems. Simultaneously, he conducts research on Large Language Models under Dr. Tom Goldstein at UMD. His research contributions include a notable paper on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models, recognized as a Notable TinyPaper at ICLR 2023, which has been cited 13 times since publication.

Vijaykaarti's professional experience is extensive for a student. He completed a software engineering internship at Uber, focusing on networking infrastructure with Envoy proxy. He also worked as a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory and at NonExomics, where he developed deep learning models for cancer prediction over a two-year period.

Within the UMD community, Vijaykaarti serves as Senior Quantitative Analyst and Lead Architect for the Smith Investment Fund's automated trading platform. He previously conducted computer vision research under Dr. Jia-Bin Huang. He has also contributed to social impact initiatives as a Software Engineer at Hack4Impact, developing web applications for nonprofit organizations.

His technical prowess is further evidenced by his competitive programming achievements, including participation in the ICPC NA South Division 2024 as part of the UMD GOATS team alongside Mazin Karjikar and Spencer Lutz. He has also competed at the ICPC Mid-Atlantic Regionals, where he previously placed 7th.

Beyond technical skills, Vijaykaarti is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Tamil, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. His academic excellence is reflected in his numerous accolades, including being a Presidential Scholar Candidate, National Merit Finalist, and recipient of the UKG Global Scholarship. His community engagement is demonstrated through his Eagle Scout achievement and multiple Silver President's Volunteer Service Awards for significant community service hours.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Liangze Li
suggested_people.short_description: Liangze Li is an AI researcher at Google DeepMind with a background from Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science. His research focuses on natural language processing and AI detection, with publications on distinguishing human from AI-generated content. He has demonstrated leadership through founding multiple organizations at CMU and is multilingual with proficiency in Mandarin, English, Cantonese, and Russian.
suggested_people.long_description:
Liangze Li is an AI researcher currently working at Google DeepMind, one of the world's leading artificial intelligence research labs. He joined DeepMind in 2024 after completing his education at Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science, where he earned his Master's degree in Language Technologies. His academic journey at CMU began in 2017 as an undergraduate student before continuing with graduate studies from 2022 to 2024.

Liangze's research focuses primarily on natural language processing and AI detection systems. He has published several notable papers in this field, including "GPT-Sentinel: Distinguishing Human and ChatGPT Generated Content" and "Token Prediction as Implicit Classification to Identify LLM-Generated Text," both published in 2023. These works have received significant attention in the academic community, with his GPT-Sentinel paper garnering over 70 citations. He has also contributed to research on referential games in NLP with his paper "Listener Model for the PhotoBook Referential Game with CLIPScores as Implicit Reference Chain."

During his time at Carnegie Mellon, Liangze demonstrated exceptional leadership and initiative by founding and presiding over several organizations. He was the Founder and President of the CMU Blackjack Society, as well as the Founder and Lecturer of the Carnegie Mellon University Student College. He also served as President of the Student College Executive Committee and as a Representative in the Graduate Student Assembly.

Before focusing on AI and natural language processing, Liangze had research interests in cryptography, with several publications between 2012-2014 on topics such as pairing computation on Edwards curves and Jacobi quartic curves with high-degree twists. This demonstrates his versatility and depth of knowledge across different areas of computer science.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Liangze has diverse interests in music, having played Alto Saxophone in both the Carnegie Mellon University Kiltie Band and the Pinghe Chamber Orchestra. His intellectual curiosity extends to philosophy as well, as evidenced by his founding of the Pinghe School Philosophy Club and his connection to CMU's Department of Philosophy.

Liangze is impressively multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Mandarin and English, full professional proficiency in Cantonese, and limited working proficiency in Russian. This linguistic versatility enhances his ability to collaborate in international research settings.

In his own words, Liangze describes himself as being "involved in AI research and startups," indicating his dual interests in both the theoretical advancement of AI and its practical applications in entrepreneurial contexts. His engagement with posts related to machine learning, AI development, and technology startups on LinkedIn further reflects his professional focus and interests in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

name: emily t.
short_description: Emily is a Computer Science and Management Science & Engineering student at Stanford University with a keen interest in AI innovation and medical research. Her academic pursuits bridge technical expertise with healthcare applications, particularly in orthopedics and AI integration in medicine.
long_description:
Emily T. (also known as Emily Phu Tran or Emily Thomas-Tran) is currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science degree in Computer Science with a focus on Management Science & Engineering at Stanford University. Her academic profile shows a multifaceted individual who bridges technical expertise with medical interests.

In 2022, Emily was a medical student at Stanford University School of Medicine, where she participated in Match Day and was accepted for a psychiatry residency at the University of Washington alongside her spouse, Jane Thomas-Tran. This suggests she may have completed or is pursuing a dual degree program combining her technical background with medical education.
