He has also written about practical AI applications like "Agent for Seamless Meeting Scheduling" and financial analysis with "Tempus AI Short Recommendation."

As a developer, Aadit maintains an active GitHub profile (ajuneja23) with repositories focused on AI, machine learning, and practical applications. His projects include implementations of Monte Carlo integration, PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization) algorithms from scratch, and an Agentic Meeting Scheduler, demonstrating his technical skills in both finance and computer science domains.

His contact information includes his email (aadit@aaditjuneja.com) and phone number (224-443-2889), making him accessible for professional and academic opportunities.

Aadit's dual expertise in finance and computer science, combined with his research experience in healthcare AI applications and technical writing skills, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving domains.

suggested_people.name: Ally Nakamura
suggested_people.short_description: Recent Stanford graduate currently building at PearX and involved with Catapult AI. Ally has a background in deep learning, AI, and scientific research, with notable achievements including a gold medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, selection as a Masason Foundation Scholar, and research on Chinese censorship.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ally Nakamura is a recent Stanford University graduate with BS/MS degrees in Computer Science with a focus on AI. She is currently building at PearX while also being involved with Catapult AI, where she's working on helping medical device companies deploy AI to make their workflows easier.

Her academic journey has been complemented by her deep interest in artificial intelligence and healthcare technology. She holds a Neural Networks and Deep Learning certification from deeplearning.ai and has worked with Stanford's Open Virtual Assistant Lab to build EHR-Xamine, a virtual assistant for electronic clinical health records designed to reduce physician burnout.

Ally has demonstrated exceptional scientific aptitude, having published research on Fluorescence-Guided Surgery in Frontiers in Oncology, where she reviewed applications of fluorescent probes in defining tumor locations during surgical procedures. Her scientific excellence was recognized internationally when she represented the United States at the International Earth Science Olympiad, earning a gold medal and ranking among the top 15 students out of nearly 400 participants from over 30 countries.

Her technical accomplishments include leading an AI-enabled email client at DoNotPay that was featured by Forbes and Wired, and building a voice agent to automatically handle reference checks for healthcare staffing agencies. She also enjoys participating in hackathons, where she has built AI dating apps and launched an AI crypto coin that scaled to $15M market cap.

Beyond her technical work, Ally has conducted significant research on Chinese censorship. Working with Jeffrey Shen, she created CensorScout and the Weibo Censorship Dashboard, two applications that increase transparency into censorship on Weibo. Their published paper on SSRN made daily top-tens in several sections and was in the top 10% of authors by downloads in the year following publication. This project was completed as part of Digital Propaganda & Censorship, an Independent Project at Phillips Academy.

Her entrepreneurial spirit is evident through her involvement with various organizations at Stanford, including co-founding the Stanford Chapter of Scholar of Finance and being a member of the Asia-Pacific Student Entrepreneurship Society. She also served as an intern at Stanford Women in Business, showcasing her interest in the intersection of business and technology.

Ally was selected as one of just 42 students to join the prestigious Masason Foundation after a rigorous three-round admissions process, further highlighting her exceptional potential. During her high school years, she contributed to STEM education as an Event Coordinator for Techstravaganza with Tomorrow's Women in Science and Technology.

She is bilingual in English and Japanese with limited working proficiency in German, giving her a global perspective that complements her technical skills and entrepreneurial mindset. In her free time, she enjoys hiking, attending DJ sets, eating sushi, and playing poker with friends.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tran
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tran is a junior at Yale University with a strong focus on computer science, particularly in molecular AI research. He has contributed to MolLM, a unified language model integrating biomedical text with 2D and 3D molecular representations, and has experience at Hudson River Trading. His coursework spans deep learning, natural language processing, and graph-structured data.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tran is an undergraduate junior at Yale University pursuing computer science with specialized interests in computational biology and AI. His research work is evidenced by his contribution to MolLM, a sophisticated unified language model that integrates biomedical text with both 2D and 3D molecular representations. This project, presented at ISMB 2024, demonstrates his capability in developing advanced AI systems for molecular modeling.

Andrew has professional experience at Hudson River Trading, a quantitative trading firm known for its algorithmic trading strategies and high-performance computing infrastructure. This suggests his skills extend to financial technology applications of computer science.

His academic foundation is robust, with coursework covering both theoretical computer science (Compilers and Interpreters, Computer Architecture, Operating Systems, Discrete Mathematics) and cutting-edge AI topics (Deep Learning on Graph-Structured Data, Natural Language Processing, Probabilistic Machine Learning). This diverse technical background positions him well at the intersection of traditional computer science and modern AI applications.

Andrew's interest in molecular AI research, as shown by his publication work, indicates his potential to contribute to the growing field of AI applications in healthcare and drug discovery. His engagement with content related to diffusion models, geometry problem-solving AI, and other technical developments (as seen in his LinkedIn activity) suggests he stays current with the latest advancements in artificial intelligence.

It's important to note that there are several other professionals named Andrew Tran in different fields, including an investigative data reporter at The Washington Post (who won a Pulitzer Prize), an orthopedic surgeon specializing in sports medicine, a UCLA law lecturer, and a visual effects artist who has worked on major films like The Hunger Games and Avengers: Infinity War. Our Andrew Tran is specifically the Yale computer science student focused on molecular AI research.

suggested_people.name: Eduardo Pontes Reis
suggested_people.short_description: Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher specializing in radiology and AI applications in healthcare. Currently affiliated with Stanford University and Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein, he focuses on developing AI tools for medical imaging and clinical documentation. His research has been cited over 1,200 times, with significant contributions to medical text summarization, chest X-ray interpretation, and multimodal medical AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher at the intersection of medicine and artificial intelligence, currently serving as a Visiting Scholar at Stanford University's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI) and as a researcher at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil.

His educational background includes an MD from State of Sao Paulo University (UNESP) in 2013, followed by a Radiology Residency at UNICAMP in 2017, and Neuroradiology specialization at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in 2018. This clinical foundation has informed his research focus on applying AI to healthcare challenges.

Eduardo's research has gained significant recognition in the field of medical AI. According to Google Scholar, his work has been cited over 1,200 times, with an h-index of 13. His research contributions span several important areas:

1. Medical Text Summarization: He co-authored a groundbreaking study published in Nature Medicine demonstrating that adapted large language models can outperform medical experts in clinical text summarization, potentially reducing documentation burden for clinicians.

2. Medical Imaging AI: He has contributed to multiple projects involving AI applications in radiology, including the development of BRAX (Brazilian labeled chest X-ray dataset), and participated in the creation of ChexAgent, a foundation model for chest X-ray interpretation.

3. Multimodal Medical AI: His work includes contributions to Med-Flamingo (a multimodal medical few-shot learner) and Merlin (a vision-language foundation model for 3D computed tomography).

4. Clinical Applications: Eduardo's research focuses on practical applications that can improve healthcare delivery, including automated contrast phase detection in abdominal CT and AI tools for radiology report generation.

At Stanford, Eduardo is part of the Machine Intelligence for Medical Imaging (MIMI) research group led by Dr. Akshay Chaudhari, where his research focuses on developing AI tools to improve healthcare, particularly in radiology and medical records. His specific interests include methods that use pairs of images and reports to teach radiology to computers, and applying large language models to reduce documentation burden for medical professionals.

Eduardo is an advocate for open data in healthcare when safe and feasible, contributing to the development of open-source datasets and tools. His professional affiliations include membership in the Sociedade Paulista de Radiologia (São Paulo Radiology Society), Colégio Brasileiro de Radiologia (Brazilian College of Radiology), and CREMESP (Regional Council of Medicine of the State of São Paulo).

Beyond his professional pursuits, Eduardo enjoys tennis, music (particularly playing the piano), and hiking. He is fluent in Portuguese (native) and English (professional proficiency), enabling him to engage with international research and collaboration opportunities in his field.

suggested_people.name: Arnav Adhikari
suggested_people.short_description: 19-year-old EECS and Finance student at MIT with a passion for building innovative solutions in fintech, robotics, and healthtech. First place winner at HackMIT 2024 with a nicotine cessation patch project, and currently working on semantic operators at MIT CSAIL while also running a stealth startup.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arnav Adhikari is a dynamic 19-year-old undergraduate at MIT pursuing a dual focus in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and Finance. His technical interests span across multiple domains including fintech (payments, wealth management, AI analysts), robotics (collaboration and control), healthtech (LLM-aided care), and productivity tools. He describes himself as a "big proponent of automating the mundane" and believes that jobs should be automated to redirect human attention toward tasks requiring ingenuity.

Arnav has built an impressive track record of achievements. Most notably, he and his team won the First Place Grand Prize at HackMIT 2024 with their algorithmically-driven nicotine cessation patch. He's currently working as a Builder at MIT's prestigious Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), focusing on semantic operators.

Entrepreneurially minded, Arnav is the Founder and CEO of a stealth startup that he's been running since January 2024. His previous experience includes work at Boston Consulting Group (BCM), Rice University, Stanford's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI), and Harvard Medical School, demonstrating his ability to collaborate with top-tier institutions across academia and industry.

Arnav's research work is particularly notable in healthcare technology. He has worked on cardiac imaging interpretability and standardized cardiac measurements at BCM, Texas Children's Hospital, and Stanford AIMI, with his work being featured in Circulation by the American Heart Association in November 2023. He has also analyzed teamwork synergy for AI Surgical Robotic Coaches at Rice HCAIR and Harvard Medical School, and developed smarter irrigation and water management systems for the City of Southside Place in Houston.

His technical background is further strengthened by his experience in robot motion planning and control at Rice RobotPI, and his achievements as a retired USAJMO winner and USACO Gold Medalist. Arnav is also an author, having written the Cubronix Competitive Math Practice Book for charity, which was featured in the Houston Chronicle in January 2022.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Arnav offers tutoring services in the Greater Houston area, specializing in math, science, engineering, and test preparation. He enjoys tennis, basketball, football, biking, the outdoors, and various forms of media entertainment.

Currently a freshman at MIT (class of 2028), Arnav graduated from Carnegie Vanguard High School in 2024 after previously attending Bellaire High School. He describes himself as someone who loves "learning and building fast," and is always open to discussing innovative ideas and groundbreaking technologies.

name: locke cai
short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Alex Fan
suggested_people.short_description: Alex Fan is a talented undergraduate at MIT studying Mathematics and Computer Science with a focus on AI research. A USACO Finalist in 2021 and 2022, he's currently working as a Research Engineer at Pika, tackling challenges in generative video and image models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alex Fan is a promising talent in the AI field, currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023-2026). His academic journey includes rigorous coursework in graduate-level Machine Learning, Advanced Algorithms, Advances in Computer Vision, and Computational Cognitive Science, demonstrating his commitment to mastering both the theoretical foundations and cutting-edge applications of AI.

Alex's technical prowess was evident early on, as he was a USACO (USA Computing Olympiad) Finalist in both 2021 and 2022 during his time at Lexington High School. This competitive programming background has provided him with strong algorithmic thinking skills that complement his AI research interests.

Currently, Alex is working as a Research Engineer at Pika, where he focuses on solving engineering and research challenges related to generative video/image models and data curation. This practical experience in the rapidly evolving field of generative AI is giving him hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art techniques and real-world applications.

During his time at MIT, Alex has been involved in various research projects. In 2022, he participated in the PRIMES program where he collaborated on research leveraging statistical distributions for RNA sequencing across time, working with Prof. Gil Alterovitz. This experience demonstrates his interest in applying computational methods to biological data.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Alex is an active member of the MIT community. He lives in La Maison Française (MIT French House) where he embraces French culture and language. He's also involved in the performing arts, having performed in the MIT Musical Theatre Guild's Cabaret Night in Fall 2023 and cast as John Hinckley Jr. in their production of "Assassins" for Fall 2024.

Alex has diverse personal interests including cooking, baking, fermentation, Broadway musicals, and playing piano. He describes himself as a francophile who dreams of returning to Parisian cafes. In his spare time, he enjoys working on programming projects and writing blog posts, showcasing his passion for both technical and creative pursuits.

His engagement with the AI community is evident through his LinkedIn activity, where he follows developments in AI research, particularly in generative models and applications in various domains. Alex represents the next generation of AI researchers and engineers who are combining strong mathematical foundations with practical implementation skills to push the boundaries of what's possible in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Joe Qiaoyun Li
suggested_people.short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Ye
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford University undergraduate studying Mathematics and Computer Science with research focus on AI, particularly neural architectures and network compression. Published at NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with experience as a software engineering intern, teaching assistant, and visiting instructor.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Ye is a talented undergraduate student currently pursuing his B.S. in Mathematics and Computer Science at Stanford University, having transferred there in 2024. Prior to Stanford, Andrew studied at Case Western Reserve University from 2022 to 2024, also focusing on Mathematics and Computer Science.

Andrew has built an impressive research portfolio in artificial intelligence. Since June 2023, he has been working as an Undergraduate Researcher at the Case School of Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, collaborating with Dr. Shuai Xu, Dr. Vipin Chaudhary, and researchers at Rice AI and MIT. His research has led to publications at prestigious AI conferences including NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with his work "GNNs also deserve editing, and they need it more than once" receiving multiple citations.

Andrew's research interests span several areas of AI including neural architectures, human-computer interaction, probability/combinatorics, metacognition, and learning theory. He is particularly focused on addressing key questions in AI such as ensuring system faithfulness and security, balancing the scale-bloat tradeoff in neural networks, and understanding how neural networks fundamentally reason and learn. He founded quant@CWRU, a student-led research group supported by professors at Case Western Reserve University focused on integrating machine learning paradigms to solve complex financial tasks.

Beyond research, Andrew has gained practical industry experience as a Software Engineering Intern at Zventus from May to August 2023, where he worked with Angel Alban on healthcare technologies. He has also developed his teaching skills as a Teaching Assistant at Case Western Reserve University, where he assisted with courses in Algorithms and Discrete Mathematics from August 2023 to May 2024. Most recently, he served as a Visiting Instructor at DigiPen Institute of Technology, teaching Data Analytics and Statistics during the summer of 2024.

Andrew grew up in Seattle and Hong Kong and has diverse personal interests including solving puzzles, playing piano (with a particular fondness for Liszt), hiking with his dog, and writing on his blog. His commitment to community service is evident from his volunteer work with North Helpline from May 2021 to April 2022. His academic profile, research contributions, and diverse experiences showcase his versatility and dedication to advancing the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

name: ian lim
short_description: Ian Lim is a Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. He co-founded Stanford BCI and has been recognized as one of MinneInno's 25 Under 25 rising entrepreneurs and technologists in Minnesota.
long_description:
Ian Lim is a talented Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. His technical interests focus on brain-computer interfaces (BCI), as evidenced by his co-founding of Stanford BCI, an organization dedicated to advancing cutting-edge technology that connects neural activity with computing systems.

Ian has been involved with TreeHacks as an organizer, Stanford's premier hackathon that brings together students to collaborate on technological solutions to real-world problems. His entrepreneurial talent was recognized early when he was named to MinneInno's 25 Under 25 List in September 2018, highlighting him as one of Minnesota's most promising young entrepreneurs and technologists. He hails from Overland Park, Kansas, as indicated by his profile at the University of Kansas School of Engineering.

Despite his relatively early career stage, Ian has already built a substantial professional network with over 500 connections and 3,000 followers on LinkedIn, suggesting his influence in tech and entrepreneurial circles. His activity on LinkedIn shows engagement with content related to AI in education, talent development, and leadership, indicating his broader interests in how technology can transform learning and organizational development.

It's worth noting that there are several other professionals named Ian Lim in different fields, including a Senior Lecturer at Monash University specializing in computer science and data science, and a character portrayed by actor James Chen in the TV series "FBI" as an intelligence analyst. Our Ian Lim maintains a personal website at ianlim.com and is active on Twitter under the handle @ianclim, where he likely shares insights about his work and interests in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Mikael Haji
suggested_people.short_description: A pioneering 19-year-old electrical engineering student at University of Waterloo who leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility for under $10K. With extensive experience in neurotech, Mikael has worked with Prophetic on ultrasound technology, contributed to neuromorphic chip design at University of Toronto, and was the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech.
suggested_people.long_description:
Mikael Haji is an innovative 19-year-old electrical engineering student at the University of Waterloo and recipient of the prestigious $120K Schulich Leaders Scholarship. He currently leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab team, where he's building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility in Waterloo with the ambitious goal of creating a process for under $10K that can produce approximately 1,000 transistors.

His GitHub profile reveals his deep involvement in brain-computer interface (BCI) technology, with multiple repositories focused on EEG applications, including projects for motor imagery systems, P300 spellers, emotion classification, and artifact detection algorithms. He's currently working on burning a GPT-2 layer on silicon and has previously designed a TPU-like systolic array and a neuromorphic chip for neural implants, with a pending IEEE ISSCC paper.

His professional journey showcases remarkable depth in cutting-edge technology fields. At Prophetic, Mikael built an entire transcranial focused ultrasound infrastructure, deploying advanced optimization techniques and accelerating transducer prototyping while creating an $80K hydrophone for under $2K. Prior to this, he worked at the University of Toronto on the digital back-end of a novel neuromorphic chip design, integrating spiking neural networks for advanced neural implants with the Intelligent Sensory Microsystems Lab.

At just 15, Mikael joined WATOLINK as a system integration engineer, helping build a mind-controlled speech interface using SSVEP with GPT-3 integration, which won first place in the Neurotech X student competition. His early accomplishments include being hired as the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech, where he engineered custom circuitry enclosures and fabricated high-precision electrode arrays.

Mikael's expertise has earned him recognition beyond academia. He was flown to Dubai for the Global Citizen Forum Conference to discuss his neurotech work and was selected as a Villars Fellow to participate in the inaugural Villars Symposium in Geneva. His entrepreneurial potential was further validated by a $250K matching trust fund from Patrick Poirier at Dragon's Vault to fuel his work in the neurotech space.

His technical innovation began early, with the development of a novel Thermoelectric Generator using fluid technology that earned him the Worley Parsons Engineers of Tomorrow award in 2019. Mikael's unique combination of hardware expertise, neuromorphic computing knowledge, and entrepreneurial drive positions him at the forefront of emerging technologies in chip fabrication and neural interfaces.

One of his notable projects includes developing a highly efficient compression algorithm for Neuralink's N1 implant as part of their compression challenge, which has gained significant attention on GitHub. His diverse portfolio of projects demonstrates his commitment to advancing both hardware and software solutions in the field of neurotechnology and chip design.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

suggested_people.name: Tristan Trouwen
suggested_people.short_description: Tristan Trouwen is a researcher and software engineer affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology, with expertise in AI, algorithms, and compiler optimization. His research explores the interaction between automated systems and humans in software development environments, and he has been recognized with the ALSP Scholarship for academic excellence.
suggested_people.long_description:
Tristan Trouwen is a promising researcher at the intersection of software engineering and artificial intelligence, currently affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology. His research interests are evidenced by his publication "Between JIRA and GitHub: ASFBot and its Influence on Human Comments in Issue Trackers" (IEEE, 2022), which explores how automated systems interact with and influence human behavior in software development environments.

Tristan's academic excellence has been recognized through the Amandus H. Lundqvist Scholarship Program (ALSP), a merit-based scholarship that includes a tuition waiver and monthly stipend. This prestigious award highlights his standing as a top student in his field.

As an AI Software Architecture Intern at d-Matrix, a series A deep tech startup recognized by Business Insider as one of the 13 most promising AI startups, Tristan worked on optimizing compilers. He applied his algorithmic knowledge from his master's studies to improve existing algorithms, making the platform faster and more power-efficient. This experience allowed him to deepen his understanding of chip architecture and compilers while working in a highly intercultural team environment.

Beyond his technical work, Tristan has demonstrated entrepreneurial initiative through his project "From Scribble To Readable," a book he co-created with fellow student Lourens Touwen to help people write mathematical symbols legibly. The project began when they noticed the difficulty in deciphering their professor's handwriting during an Analysis lecture. They designed practice pages for common mathematical symbols, created promotional videos, and launched a successful Kickstarter campaign to publish the book.

Tristan has also demonstrated leadership capabilities through his role as Board Treasurer for E.S.D.A. Chronos from May 2019 to May 2020. He is also a member of Nova (since November 2022), suggesting continued engagement with professional or academic organizations.

His background combines strong computational methods and software engineering expertise, with a particular interest in how automated systems and human users interact in technical environments - a crucial area for advancing AI systems that can effectively collaborate with human operators. Tristan is fluent in Dutch (native proficiency) and English (full professional proficiency), enabling him to collaborate effectively in international research and development environments.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

suggested_people.name: Max Forsey
suggested_people.short_description: Max Forsey is an AI researcher at the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University who explores the fundamental nature of intelligence. As a co-founder of justbuild.ing and former Vice President of BYU's Artificial Intelligence Association, he actively organizes AI hackathons and community events while developing practical tools to advance the field.
suggested_people.long_description:
Max Forsey is a dedicated AI researcher affiliated with the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University, where he explores the fundamental nature of intelligence through artificial intelligence systems. His research has led to publications like "Gradient Sparse Autoencoders," which introduces novel approaches to extracting neural network features.

Max has taken on leadership roles in the AI community, serving as the Vice President of the BYU Artificial Intelligence Association, where he helped organize events and foster a community of AI enthusiasts. In November 2024, he co-founded "justbuild.ing," an initiative focused on building a community of AI developers and hosting collaborative events.

He is particularly active in organizing and participating in AI hackathons, recently working with Sameday through the justbuild community to host a 2-hour AI hackathon featuring Cerebras Systems. His involvement in these rapid development events demonstrates his commitment to practical AI application and innovation.

Beyond his research, Max is passionate about creating practical AI tools. He developed FreshSesh AI, a developer tool that uses local LLMs to provide personalized context summaries of previous work sessions, helping developers quickly get back into flow. He's also reimplemented Andrej Karpathy's nanoGPT, showing his hands-on approach to understanding AI systems.

Max maintains a personal website where he shares detailed resources for those looking to bridge the gap between using AI APIs and actually training models. His curated learning path includes visual resources, essential reading, and practical project suggestions for newcomers to the field. He emphasizes starting with fundamentals and learning through implementation, reflecting his own approach to AI development.

Outside of his professional interests, Max maintains a holistic approach to life, with detailed attention to health and longevity practices. He values deep friendships and community connections, having written thoughtfully about the nature of friendship and human connection. His background combines theoretical AI research with practical application, demonstrating a commitment to both advancing the field and making AI more accessible to others.

name: kyle cui
short_description: Kyle Cui is the Co-Founder & CEO of CTRL Sheet, a recent graduate from UC Berkeley with degrees in Computer Science (Honors) and Physics. His background spans virtual reality research, AI development, and entrepreneurship, with experience in both academic and industry settings.
long_description:
Kyle Cui is an emerging tech entrepreneur who recently graduated from UC Berkeley with a dual degree in Computer Science (Honors) and Physics. He is currently the Co-Founder and CEO of CTRL Sheet, an AI agent for spreadsheets that helps users build models and gather data from the internet.

Kyle's technical expertise is particularly strong in the intersection of AI and virtual reality. During his time at Berkeley, he conducted significant research in this field, working with the ScenicVR Research Group under Professor Sanjit Seshia where he developed adversarial AI agents in simulated scenarios to boost rapid skill acquisition in VR environments. His research contributions are documented in academic publications, including "A Principled Intelligent Occupational Training of Psychomotor Skills in Virtual Reality" (2023) and "Task Distribution Aware Psychomotor Skill Training with Probabilistic Programs and Bayesian Knowledge Tracing in Virtual Reality" (2024), where he worked alongside researchers like Edward Kim, Zachary Pardos, and Björn Hartmann.

In these research projects, Kyle helped develop innovative approaches to VR training, including the use of Bayesian knowledge tracing (BKT) to predict psychomotor skill mastery, which proved more effective than traditional self-assessment methods. His work demonstrated how probabilistic programming and machine learning techniques could create more effective VR training systems with consistent learning outcomes.

His leadership experience includes serving as Executive Vice President at Extended Reality at Berkeley, where he led internal and external functions for over 50 club members, managing resources, partnerships, and events. Kyle also has teaching experience, having worked as Course Staff for Discrete Math and Probability (CS70) and Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs (CS61A) at UC Berkeley.

Kyle's industry experience includes a Software Engineering internship at Metaphor3D, where he deployed TypeScript applications with Azure for cloud API endpoints, designed user data pipelines in Python, and optimized data processing with Rust. He also gained venture capital experience as an analyst at Steel Perlot.

Multilingual and globally-minded, Kyle is fluent in English and Chinese, with working proficiency in French and Spanish. He also spent time studying abroad at Uppsala University in Sweden. His diverse skill set spans programming languages (including TypeScript, Python, Rust, and C#), AI/ML development, VR/AR technologies, and entrepreneurship, making him a versatile technologist at the forefront of emerging tech.

suggested_people.name: Soham Vasanawala
suggested_people.short_description: Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics student at Stanford University with a strong focus on the intersection of AI and healthcare. He has co-founded two startups, including Intratalent AI and Gains Coach LLC, where he's developing AI-powered coaching platforms. His research experience spans medical mixed reality and algorithm development for medical procedures, with notable presentations at ISMRM 2023.
suggested_people.long_description:
Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics undergraduate at Stanford University with entrepreneurial drive and technical expertise in AI applications for healthcare and biotech.

As a co-founder of Intratalent AI (since November 2024) and Gains Coach LLC (since December 2021), Soham demonstrates his entrepreneurial spirit. At Gains Coach, he's developing a real-time, AI-powered coaching platform for various physical movements including physiotherapy, sports, fitness, and dance.

His research experience is impressive for his age. During his internship at Stanford University School of Medicine, he worked with the Incubator for Medical Mixed and Extended Reality, developing a real-time augmented-reality visualization of knee motion from MRI data for the HoloLens2. At Stanford University School of Engineering, he designed and conducted research that led to a time-saving algorithm for a medical procedure, which he presented at Stanford BioX 2022 and ISMRM 2023.

Notably, at ISMRM 2023, he presented research on "Predicting MR Image Quality from Breathing Patterns" where he demonstrated that detected breathing patterns could be utilized to predict whether adequate MR image quality would be obtained. Using a K-means clustering algorithm, his work showed that 9 in 10 forty-second breathing waveforms could be correctly predicted as either resulting in high or low image quality, potentially saving time from unnecessary scans.

Soham has also gained industry experience as a Software Engineer at Turboprop, a fintech startup in Menlo Park. His academic background includes a Bachelor of Science degree from Stanford University (2023-2027) and previous education at Henry M. Gunn High School.

Beyond his technical work, Soham has contributed to a publication titled "Essays and Interviews with Bay Area Entrepreneurs" (September 2022), showing his interest in entrepreneurship. He is also a member of The International Society for Magnetic Resonance in Medicine, further demonstrating his commitment to the medical technology field.

Soham is proficient in English (native) and has limited working proficiency in French. His diverse experiences in AI, healthcare technology, and entrepreneurship position him uniquely at the intersection of technology and medicine, with a particular focus on using AI to solve real-world healthcare challenges.

He appears to be related to Shreyas Vasanawala, MD/PhD, who serves as the William R. Brody Professor of Pediatric Radiology and Child Health at Stanford Medicine, suggesting a family connection that may have influenced his interest in medical technology.

suggested_people.name: Vivek Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vivek Vajipey is a Computer Science student at Stanford University pursuing both Bachelor's and Master's degrees with a minor in Geophysics. His research at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) focuses on reasoning in large language models, while his previous work applied machine learning to agricultural remote sensing. He has developed innovative AI applications including ExplainAI, CriticAL, and WorldDex, winning awards at major hackathons like PennApps XXIV and Cal Hacks 10.0.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vivek Vajipey is pursuing both a Bachelor's and Master's degree in Computer Science at Stanford University, with a minor in Geophysics. His academic journey reflects a deep interest in the intersection of artificial intelligence and practical applications.

At the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL), Vivek researches reasoning capabilities in large language models through the Computation & Cognition Lab. His work in AI extends beyond theoretical research - he has recently co-authored "CriticAL: Critic Automation with Language Models," demonstrating his contribution to advancing LLM technologies.

Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Aidan Gollan
suggested_people.short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

suggested_people.name: Anirudh Kotamraju
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

name: tony wang
short_description: Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, with a diverse portfolio spanning tech, venture capital, and public interest technology. He has research experience at Stanford AI Lab and Harvard Medical School, and has worked with companies like Amazon and Microsoft.
long_description:
Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University focusing on Artificial Intelligence. His professional experience spans multiple domains including venture capital, public interest technology, and software engineering.

At Stanford, Tony has taken on leadership roles as the Freshman Council President, where he managed $35,500 for over 1,700 students. He's also involved with TreeHacks as an Alumni Director and serves as the ACM ProCo Director.

Tony's venture capital experience includes positions as a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, a Scout at Soma Capital, and a Founder Fellow at RippleX Fellowship. His interest in public policy is evident through his work as a Fellow at Paragon Policy Fellowship and as a Co-Founder of the Public Interest Technology Lab at Stanford University, where he led the inaugural student govtech fellowship program.

His technical experience includes a software engineering internship at Amazon, contracting work for Swim England and Hypelist, and research at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) where he worked on deep learning to predict transcription factor binding motifs. He also conducted research at Harvard Medical School under the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Boston Children's Hospital.

Tony has received several prestigious recognitions, including being a Rise Fellow at Schmidt Futures, where he completed a fully-funded summer intensive in London/Oxford and founded the Rise North America Union. During his high school years at Amador Valley High School, he was the Salutatorian, a Coca-Cola Scholar, a National Merit Scholar, won two gold medals with Kungfu Team USA, and was an ISEF Finalist.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Tony has demonstrated a commitment to community service as the Founder and President of the Alameda County Science and Engineering Fair and as a Teaching Facilitator for Non-Trivial.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.
