suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Joe Qiaoyun Li
suggested_people.short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Ye
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford University undergraduate studying Mathematics and Computer Science with research focus on AI, particularly neural architectures and network compression. Published at NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with experience as a software engineering intern, teaching assistant, and visiting instructor.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Ye is a talented undergraduate student currently pursuing his B.S. in Mathematics and Computer Science at Stanford University, having transferred there in 2024. Prior to Stanford, Andrew studied at Case Western Reserve University from 2022 to 2024, also focusing on Mathematics and Computer Science.

Andrew has built an impressive research portfolio in artificial intelligence. Since June 2023, he has been working as an Undergraduate Researcher at the Case School of Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, collaborating with Dr. Shuai Xu, Dr. Vipin Chaudhary, and researchers at Rice AI and MIT. His research has led to publications at prestigious AI conferences including NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with his work "GNNs also deserve editing, and they need it more than once" receiving multiple citations.

Andrew's research interests span several areas of AI including neural architectures, human-computer interaction, probability/combinatorics, metacognition, and learning theory. He is particularly focused on addressing key questions in AI such as ensuring system faithfulness and security, balancing the scale-bloat tradeoff in neural networks, and understanding how neural networks fundamentally reason and learn. He founded quant@CWRU, a student-led research group supported by professors at Case Western Reserve University focused on integrating machine learning paradigms to solve complex financial tasks.

Beyond research, Andrew has gained practical industry experience as a Software Engineering Intern at Zventus from May to August 2023, where he worked with Angel Alban on healthcare technologies. He has also developed his teaching skills as a Teaching Assistant at Case Western Reserve University, where he assisted with courses in Algorithms and Discrete Mathematics from August 2023 to May 2024. Most recently, he served as a Visiting Instructor at DigiPen Institute of Technology, teaching Data Analytics and Statistics during the summer of 2024.

Andrew grew up in Seattle and Hong Kong and has diverse personal interests including solving puzzles, playing piano (with a particular fondness for Liszt), hiking with his dog, and writing on his blog. His commitment to community service is evident from his volunteer work with North Helpline from May 2021 to April 2022. His academic profile, research contributions, and diverse experiences showcase his versatility and dedication to advancing the field of artificial intelligence.

name: leo nagel
short_description: Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with expertise in GPU optimization, quantitative finance, and physics. Former Chief Executive at Global Society of Young Physicists and published researcher with a focus on computational efficiency and mathematical modeling.
long_description:
Leo Nagel is an Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley who combines technical expertise with leadership experience to drive technological innovation. His academic focus spans GPU kernel optimization, quantitative finance, computing theory, mathematics, and physics.

Currently, Leo is deeply involved in several cutting-edge projects that showcase his technical abilities. He collaborated with Bradley Hsu to develop cuBogo, the fastest bogosort implementation ever run on a single device, optimizing custom CUDA (C++) kernels for the Nvidia H100. He's also working on cuDream, rewriting DreamCoder to leverage GPU optimizations, and cuPrimes, a custom kernel implementing the Fermat test of pseudo-primality using the Schönhage-Strassen algorithm and optimized Fast Fourier Transform with Nvidia H100 tensor cores.

Leo's leadership capabilities are evident through his role as Chief Executive at the Global Society of Young Physicists (2022-2024), where he founded a physics nonprofit that organizes summer programs and publishes a journal. Prior to this, he served as a Curriculum Developer at Mad for Stem, creating interdisciplinary courses spanning economics, computer science, data science, and technology.

His academic achievements include placing first out of 130+ participants in the Berkeley Trading Invitational 2024, demonstrating his aptitude for quantitative finance. Leo has also published research, including a paper on "Derivation of a Function for Velocity for Falling Objects with Non-Negligible Air Resistance," showcasing his mathematical modeling skills.

Leo's educational background includes studies at UC Berkeley, a visiting undergraduate experience at The University of Hong Kong, and participation in specialized programs like the Quantum Cryptography School for Young Students at the University of Waterloo. He graduated from Dulwich College Shanghai Pudong with an International Baccalaureate score of 44/45.

With a multicultural background having lived in Germany (8 years), China (10 years), and the United States (2 years), Leo brings a global perspective to his work. He is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and German, and elementary proficiency in Chinese and Latin. Beyond academics, he enjoys chess and hiking in the Berkeley Hills, particularly at night.

Leo's unique combination of technical expertise in GPU optimization, research experience, leadership skills, and interdisciplinary knowledge positions him as a promising innovator in the fields of computer science and electrical engineering.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

suggested_people.name: Pavan Jayasinha
suggested_people.short_description: Pavan Jayasinha is a versatile technologist specializing in the intersection of machine learning, quantum computing, and low-level systems engineering. Currently a student at the University of Waterloo, he has contributed to cutting-edge research and development at organizations like Modular, Extropic AI, and the Institute for Quantum Computing, with particular expertise in GPU kernel optimization, quantum generative models, and robotics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Pavan Jayasinha is a multifaceted technologist pursuing a Bachelor of Applied Science at the University of Waterloo with an impressive 4.0 GPA. His technical expertise spans several specialized domains, with particular focus on machine learning, robotics, quantum computing, and low-level kernel development.

Pavan's professional experience demonstrates remarkable versatility across cutting-edge fields. At Modular, he worked as an AI GPU Engineering Intern, developing GPU kernels in Mojo language, optimizing end-to-end pipelines, and implementing multi-GPU tensor parallelism from scratch. His work at Extropic involved building high-performance JAX codebases for analog simulation of probabilistic ML models on hardware, conducting over 1000 Bayesian hyperparameter sweeps, and creating a state-of-the-art JAX library for tensor network simulation of quantum circuits on CUDA GPUs.

In the quantum computing space, Pavan has made significant contributions. At the Institute for Quantum Computing, he researched methods to realize the Bose-Hubbard Hamiltonian through Rydberg neutral atoms and built large-scale physics simulations. As an IBM Qiskit Advocate, he authored a chapter on Quantum Generative Adversarial Networks for the Qiskit Textbook QML course and mentored at the Qiskit Global Summer School. His quantum expertise extended to Zapata Computing, where he investigated quantum generative models and developed Orquestra codebase for QGANs.

Pavan has also contributed significantly to open-source projects, becoming the largest non-Google contributor to TensorFlow Quantum by implementing Bazel build infrastructure and cuQuantum SDK GPU kernels for quantum circuit simulation on heterogeneous devices. His project work includes developing a hybrid quantum graph neural network for particle trajectory reconstruction, which placed in the top 5 at QHack 2022, and building a quantum portfolio optimization project that placed in the 95th percentile at QHack 2021.

Pavan's academic achievements include being a Masason Scholar, selected as part of the 6th generation cohort by SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's foundation that supports youth with exceptional talents. He has received the President's Research Award and maintained Dean's Honours List status. He has earned multiple certifications in quantum computing, including becoming an IBM Certified Associate Developer for Quantum Computation using Qiskit.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Pavan has diverse experiences including serving as a lifeguard for the City of Toronto and working as a dog walker, demonstrating his well-rounded character and work ethic. His unique combination of expertise in quantum computing, machine learning, and low-level systems engineering positions him as a promising innovator at the intersection of these transformative technologies.

suggested_people.name: Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla
suggested_people.short_description: A multilingual Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard with exceptional achievements in quantum computing and international physics competitions. Ricardo combines technical expertise with diplomatic skills, having led international relations organizations and conducted research spanning solid-state physics, ESG consulting, and quantum algorithm development across multiple languages.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla is a Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard University with a remarkable blend of technical expertise and international perspective. His academic journey is distinguished by significant achievements in quantum computing, where he serves as Vice President of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantum Computing Association (HUQCA) and won 2nd place at MIT's Quantum Computing Hackathon 2024, developing theoretical error bounds for quantum algorithms.

Ricardo's technical prowess extends beyond quantum computing to solid-state physics research, where he worked with 2D transition metal dichalcogenides and Van der Waals heterostructures under Professor Hongkun Park. His computational skills have been recognized through multiple hackathon victories, including Microsoft's Student Hackathon 2021 and CdCMx 2020, where he developed mathematical models for COVID-19 comorbidity analysis.

In the quantum computing field, Ricardo has demonstrated exceptional talent, helping to grow HUQCA to over 300 members. At the MIT Interdisciplinary Quantum Hackathon (iQuHACK), his team created an "experimental harness" that allowed them to run quantum simulations at scale and efficiently collect data, earning them second place. As Ricardo noted, "It's one thing to learn something in a classroom, and another to try to code one and see if it runs. That's different, and I think it adds an extra layer to fully mastering the concepts."

What sets Ricardo apart is his exceptional international background and linguistic abilities. Fluent in six languages (Spanish, English, French, Chinese, Russian, and German), he has leveraged these skills in various leadership roles. As Co-President of Harvard International Relations on Campus and in his work with the Harvard International Relations Council, he has bridged cultural divides and facilitated international dialogue. His language proficiency earned him first place in Harvard's Chinese Poetry Recitation Contest and supported his research for a Radcliffe Fellow's project on underground economies in Greater China.

Ricardo's professional experience spans diverse sectors, from ESG consulting at PwC China, where he spearheaded sustainable design strategies for LEED-certified real estate projects, to his upcoming role as a Business Analyst at Alibaba Group. During his internship at PwC Shanghai through the Harvard China Fund Student Internship Program, he significantly improved his professional Chinese language skills while working on technical projects. As Ricardo reflected, "My biggest achievement from this experience was the consolidation of my Chinese speaking, reading and writing skills at the professional level."

His commitment to diplomacy and international cooperation is evident in his work with the United Nations Information Center, where he led a conference commemorating the UN's 75th anniversary with 500+ Latin American students.

His academic excellence is further demonstrated by his impressive collection of medals from international physics competitions, including the International Physics Olympiad, European Physics Olympiad, and Mexican Physics Olympiad. Ricardo's multidisciplinary approach combines rigorous scientific training with global perspective, positioning him uniquely at the intersection of technology, diplomacy, and sustainable development.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

suggested_people.name: Arihant Choudhary
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley with extensive research experience across AI, cryptography, and computational game theory. Currently working as a Software Intern at Intel and Lead Undergraduate Researcher at UC Berkeley, focusing on multi-agent systems, AI applications, and CS education.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arihant Choudhary is a multifaceted Computer Science, Data Science, and Applied Mathematics student at UC Berkeley with a remarkable research portfolio spanning diverse technical domains. His research journey includes work at Stanford University on multi-agent systems for inference, reasoning, and planning, as well as climate data analysis using CMIP-6 models.

At UC Berkeley, Arihant has made significant contributions across multiple research labs. He serves as a Lead Undergraduate Researcher in two labs under Prof. Dan Garcia - the Computational Game Theory Lab (GamesCrafters) and the CS Education Lab (ACE Lab). In the ACE Lab, he authored papers on dynamic animated feedback for randomized graph problems (accepted at SIGCSE 2024) and co-authored work on personalized reminders for mastery learning (AutoRemind, accepted at SIGCSE 2025). His work in the Computational Game Theory Lab involved developing solvers for games like Quick Cross and Euclid's Game, researching pure draw theory, and creating human-robot interaction systems.

Professionally, Arihant is currently working as a Software Intern at Intel Corporation, implementing cutting-edge research and building products for Intel Foundry. His previous role as a Research Intern at Intel focused on text-to-video research and building Intel's Personal Educator (IPED) using large language models and text-to-speech libraries to support employee training. He also serves as a Dean's Engineering Ambassador at UC Berkeley's College of Engineering, working on programs for high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.

Arihant's journey to UC Berkeley is particularly inspiring. After being rejected from all colleges in his first application cycle, he took a gap year in 2020 and pursued multiple projects, including a significant climate change research project through Polygence. Working with his mentor Tristan Ballard, a Stanford PhD in earth systems science, Arihant analyzed a petabyte of climate data to study monsoons in Kolkata and assess climate change impacts on agriculture. This experience not only built his technical skills but also helped him secure admission to UC Berkeley on his second attempt.

Arihant's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Berkeley Social, a platform he developed to help incoming UC Berkeley students connect with peers sharing similar interests. He also co-founded Yindu & Zhongguo Inc, which included the Bangla Machinery Bank, an AgriTech enterprise providing efficient farm machinery to farmers in West Bengal.

His academic pursuits extend beyond UC Berkeley, with coursework at Stanford University in CS224G: Apps with LLMs Inside. Arihant's technical expertise spans AI, machine learning, cryptography, and data science, complemented by his multilingual proficiency in English, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, and Marwari.

Through his diverse experiences in research, entrepreneurship, and community service, Arihant demonstrates a commitment to leveraging technology for social impact and educational advancement. Expected to graduate in Spring 2025, he is now interested in pursuing a graduate degree and a career in artificial intelligence/machine learning.

name: david bai
short_description: David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at USC with diverse research experience in AI alignment, multi-agent robotic planning, and reinforcement learning for legged robots. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's developing language learning tools while also working on innovative projects like brain-controlled drones and GPS-denied navigation systems.
long_description:
David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at the University of Southern California (2023-2027), where he serves as a USC Presidential Scholar. His academic journey is marked by a deep commitment to artificial intelligence research across multiple domains.

Currently, David is a Research Fellow at the Supervised Program for Alignment Research, where he investigates reasoning and AI agents from capabilities and security perspectives. Simultaneously, he works as a Research Assistant at USC Viterbi School of Engineering's GLAMOR Lab through the CURVE Fellowship, focusing on multi-agent robotic planning at the intersection of LLMs and symbolic planners.

David's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of Jargon, where he's building a language learning Chrome extension. His technical versatility extends to his work with USC Makers, where he manages projects involving brain-controlled drones using electroencephalography, having previously contributed to an autonomous greenhouse with computer vision.

His professional experience includes a Machine Learning & Computer Vision Internship at Rhoman Aerospace, enabling GPS-denied navigation through VIO and building simulation/SLAM pipelines. David has also served as a Research Assistant at the Dynamic Robotics and Control Laboratory, where he augmented model predictive control for legged robots with reinforcement learning.

In the academic community, David is active with USC's Center for AI in Society's Student Branch (CAIS++), where he contributes to research and projects in artificial intelligence with social impact applications. He is part of the Fall 2024 cohort, demonstrating his commitment to applying AI for societal benefit.

David is also involved with the USC Computational Aerospace Lab, where he works on projects related to BCD (Binary Collision Detection), showcasing his interdisciplinary approach to engineering challenges. This involvement highlights his ability to apply computational methods to aerospace applications.

Prior to USC, David demonstrated academic excellence at Cambridge University, where he compiled comprehensive lecture notes across various mathematical disciplines, indicating his strong foundation in theoretical concepts that underpin his current technical work.

David's commitment to social impact is demonstrated through his volunteer work with the Cheyenne River Youth Project and Friends of Children with Special Needs, where he developed educational courses. His multidisciplinary approach to AI research, combined with his technical skills and social consciousness, positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Vijay Kumaravelrajan
suggested_people.short_description: Vijay is a junior at USC studying Math and Computer Science, where he serves as a Project Lead at USC's Center for AI in Society. His research spans inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, robotic manipulation, and 6G wireless technology. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's building an LLM-powered language learning Chrome extension.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vijay Kumaravelrajan is a junior at the University of Southern California pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics and Computer Science. As a Trustee Scholar and Viterbi Fellow, he has established himself as a multifaceted researcher and entrepreneur in the AI space.

At USC's Center for AI in Society (CAIS++), Vijay currently leads a team of five researchers focused on inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, where they're achieving superior pass@k performance under tighter inference budgets compared to larger models. His work involves implementing and analyzing various inference-time scaling strategies including best-of-n approaches, tree search with PRMs, and Chain of Thought with reinforcement learning. Previously at CAIS++, he conducted research in robotic manipulation through collaboration with USC's SLURM lab, implementing environment simulations using MuJoCo and ManiSkill with Gymnasium for reinforcement learning training. He has also served as a Curriculum Lead, mentoring underclassmen through practical ML projects and teaching comprehensive curriculum covering neural networks, classical ML, NLP, computer vision, transformers, and generative modeling.

Beyond his academic research, Vijay co-founded Jargon, a startup developing a Chrome extension that transforms everyday browsing into language learning opportunities powered by large language models. His entrepreneurial venture demonstrates his ability to apply AI technologies to practical educational tools.

Since August 2022, Vijay has been a Directed Researcher at USC's WiDES Lab, where he collaborates with PhD leads and a team of graduate and undergraduate researchers. His work includes designing and optimizing ray tracers for 6G wireless installations and using convolutional neural networks alongside traditional algorithms to detect edges in point cloud data. He implements C++ libraries in Python and MATLAB, showcasing his versatility across programming languages.

Earlier in his academic career, Vijay worked as a Research Assistant at Scholar Launch, conducting research on open star clusters under the guidance of a professor from UT Austin. He created generalizable algorithms for determining the age of any star cluster of interest using Python.

Vijay has demonstrated his programming skills in competitive settings, participating in the Fall 2024 USC Programming Contest where he successfully solved the "5-Mile Hike" problem using Python. He also contributed to the "Gen-AI for Multi-Agent Deformable Object Manipulation" project at CAIS++, working alongside other researchers to advance robotic manipulation of deformable objects like bread and clothing. This project integrated various robotic platforms including ALOHA and Baxter into the MuJoCo simulation environment using Robosuite, setting up bimanual configurations to explore different arm controllers.

Outside of his AI and computer science pursuits, Vijay is involved with USC's Rocket Propulsion Lab as a General Member focusing on simulations. He achieved the rank of Eagle Scout with Boy Scout Troop 1776 and graduated with an IB Diploma, demonstrating his well-rounded capabilities and leadership potential.

Vijay's personal website (jaykr.dev) features his projects and writing, reflecting his passion for discovering and building new technologies at the intersection of mathematics, computer science, and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Thomaz Felipe Bonato
suggested_people.short_description: Brazilian AI researcher and entrepreneur studying at USC as a Trustee Scholar. Thomaz has excelled in hackathons, winning first place at HackMIT and second place at PennApps in 2024, while conducting AI research at USC Marshall School of Business focusing on educational applications and LLMs.
suggested_people.long_description:
Thomaz Felipe Bonato is a passionate engineer, researcher, and lifelong learner from Brazil currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence for Business at the University of Southern California as a prestigious Trustee Scholar with full tuition. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his National Merit Finalist status.

Thomaz has established himself as an exceptional hackathon competitor, securing first place at HackMIT 2024 with PalmLabs (focused on education) and second place at PennApps 2024 with Cypress MFA (addressing security and privacy challenges). He also won first place with Azalea, an eco-friendly AI model selector, demonstrating his commitment to sustainable AI solutions.

His professional experience spans multiple domains within AI and business. As an AI Research Assistant at USC Marshall School of Business since December 2023, he initially explored AI applications in education and has since expanded to researching LLMs and cluster-based probing techniques. Thomaz has entrepreneurial experience as a founder of a stealth startup focused on AI solutions for law firms, and currently serves as a Data Science Intern at Trudy and a Growth Strategist at Mercor.

Within the USC community, Thomaz has taken on leadership roles as the Director of Founder's Education at SEP (Student Entrepreneurship Program) and previously served as Director of External Relations for USC Business Technology Group. He was also a Student Founder at SEP, demonstrating his commitment to entrepreneurship education.

Thomaz is multilingual, with native proficiency in Portuguese and English, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. He is also a Management Leadership Tomorrow (MLT) Fellow, indicating his commitment to leadership development. His technical skills are evidenced by certifications in Linear Algebra for Machine Learning and Neural Networks and Deep Learning from DeepLearning.AI, as well as UX design skills certified by LinkedIn.

His contribution to policy is demonstrated through his publication "A Blueprint for Greece's AI Transformation" for the Special Secretariat for Foresight, Presidency of the Government, Hellenic Republic, showing his interest in AI governance and national strategy development.

It's important to note that there is another Thomaz Bonato who has had a distinguished career in the pharmaceutical industry, serving in various executive roles at AstraZeneca and Alexion. This Thomaz Bonato has held positions including US Chief Financial Officer and Vice President of Finance at AstraZeneca, Interim Country President of AstraZeneca Australia and New Zealand, and most recently as Global Head of Research Development & Medical Finance at Alexion. His career has included significant financial leadership roles across multiple countries including Brazil, Costa Rica, Australia, and the United States. However, this is a different individual than the USC student and AI researcher profiled here.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Vivek Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vivek Vajipey is a Computer Science student at Stanford University pursuing both Bachelor's and Master's degrees with a minor in Geophysics. His research at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) focuses on reasoning in large language models, while his previous work applied machine learning to agricultural remote sensing. He has developed innovative AI applications including ExplainAI, CriticAL, and WorldDex, winning awards at major hackathons like PennApps XXIV and Cal Hacks 10.0.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vivek Vajipey is pursuing both a Bachelor's and Master's degree in Computer Science at Stanford University, with a minor in Geophysics. His academic journey reflects a deep interest in the intersection of artificial intelligence and practical applications.

At the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL), Vivek researches reasoning capabilities in large language models through the Computation & Cognition Lab. His work in AI extends beyond theoretical research - he has recently co-authored "CriticAL: Critic Automation with Language Models," demonstrating his contribution to advancing LLM technologies.

Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

name: krish parikh
short_description: Krish Parikh is a researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a student at Stanford University. He recently led the first all-freshmen team to win first place at TreeHacks among 1,124 competitors, demonstrating exceptional talent in AI development early in his academic career.
long_description:
Krish Parikh is an emerging talent in the field of artificial intelligence, currently affiliated with the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and studying at Stanford University. Despite being early in his academic journey, Krish has already demonstrated remarkable achievement by leading the first all-freshmen team in TreeHacks history to win first place among 1,124 competitors in February 2024. His team also won the Reazon Holdings award, earning round-trip tickets to Tokyo.

Prior to Stanford, Krish's academic excellence was recognized with several prestigious awards, including the Lam Research Scholarship ($10,000) awarded to only 11 students from 5,250 graduating seniors, and the National Merit Scholarship as a finalist in the 99th percentile of 1.5 million PSAT examinees.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Krish has shown commitment to community service, working as a Computer Science Teacher for SEWA International USA from May 2020 to June 2023. His dedication to volunteering was acknowledged with the President's Volunteer Service Award from AmeriCorps in November 2021 for completing over 100 volunteer hours.

Krish's early success in competitive AI hackathons, combined with his research position at one of the world's leading AI laboratories, positions him as a promising contributor to the field of artificial intelligence with a demonstrated ability to lead and innovate.

suggested_people.name: Tony Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, with a diverse portfolio spanning tech, venture capital, and public interest technology. He has research experience at Stanford AI Lab and Harvard Medical School, and has worked with companies like Amazon and Microsoft.
suggested_people.long_description:
Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University focusing on Artificial Intelligence. His professional experience spans multiple domains including venture capital, public interest technology, and software engineering.

At Stanford, Tony has taken on leadership roles as the Freshman Council President, where he managed $35,500 for over 1,700 students. He's also involved with TreeHacks as an Alumni Director and serves as the ACM ProCo Director.

Tony's venture capital experience includes positions as a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, a Scout at Soma Capital, and a Founder Fellow at RippleX Fellowship. His interest in public policy is evident through his work as a Fellow at Paragon Policy Fellowship and as a Co-Founder of the Public Interest Technology Lab at Stanford University, where he led the inaugural student govtech fellowship program.

His technical experience includes a software engineering internship at Amazon, contracting work for Swim England and Hypelist, and research at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) where he worked on deep learning to predict transcription factor binding motifs. He also conducted research at Harvard Medical School under the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Boston Children's Hospital.

Tony has received several prestigious recognitions, including being a Rise Fellow at Schmidt Futures, where he completed a fully-funded summer intensive in London/Oxford and founded the Rise North America Union. During his high school years at Amador Valley High School, he was the Salutatorian, a Coca-Cola Scholar, a National Merit Scholar, won two gold medals with Kungfu Team USA, and was an ISEF Finalist.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Tony has demonstrated a commitment to community service as the Founder and President of the Alameda County Science and Engineering Fair and as a Teaching Facilitator for Non-Trivial.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

name: tristan trouwen
short_description: Tristan Trouwen is a researcher and software engineer affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology, with expertise in AI, algorithms, and compiler optimization. His research explores the interaction between automated systems and humans in software development environments, and he has been recognized with the ALSP Scholarship for academic excellence.
long_description:
Tristan Trouwen is a promising researcher at the intersection of software engineering and artificial intelligence, currently affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology. His research interests are evidenced by his publication "Between JIRA and GitHub: ASFBot and its Influence on Human Comments in Issue Trackers" (IEEE, 2022), which explores how automated systems interact with and influence human behavior in software development environments.

Tristan's academic excellence has been recognized through the Amandus H. Lundqvist Scholarship Program (ALSP), a merit-based scholarship that includes a tuition waiver and monthly stipend. This prestigious award highlights his standing as a top student in his field.

As an AI Software Architecture Intern at d-Matrix, a series A deep tech startup recognized by Business Insider as one of the 13 most promising AI startups, Tristan worked on optimizing compilers. He applied his algorithmic knowledge from his master's studies to improve existing algorithms, making the platform faster and more power-efficient. This experience allowed him to deepen his understanding of chip architecture and compilers while working in a highly intercultural team environment.

Beyond his technical work, Tristan has demonstrated entrepreneurial initiative through his project "From Scribble To Readable," a book he co-created with fellow student Lourens Touwen to help people write mathematical symbols legibly. The project began when they noticed the difficulty in deciphering their professor's handwriting during an Analysis lecture. They designed practice pages for common mathematical symbols, created promotional videos, and launched a successful Kickstarter campaign to publish the book.

Tristan has also demonstrated leadership capabilities through his role as Board Treasurer for E.S.D.A. Chronos from May 2019 to May 2020. He is also a member of Nova (since November 2022), suggesting continued engagement with professional or academic organizations.

His background combines strong computational methods and software engineering expertise, with a particular interest in how automated systems and human users interact in technical environments - a crucial area for advancing AI systems that can effectively collaborate with human operators. Tristan is fluent in Dutch (native proficiency) and English (full professional proficiency), enabling him to collaborate effectively in international research and development environments.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Diddi
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Diddi is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform bringing on-device AI solutions with a focus on privacy and accessibility. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, he specializes in Applied Machine Learning and has experience as an instructor at General Assembly. A graduate of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Dhruv combines technical expertise with entrepreneurial vision, particularly in healthcare AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Diddi is an engineer and entrepreneur based in the San Francisco Bay Area with specialized experience in Applied Machine Learning. He is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform that brings AI directly to users' devices, ensuring data privacy, personalized experiences, and accessibility without reliance on cloud infrastructure. Solo has particularly focused on healthcare applications, addressing challenges around data privacy (HIPAA compliance), accessibility in low-connectivity environments, and customization for specific healthcare scenarios.

Dhruv actively promotes Solo through his newsletter "Get Solo Tech" on Substack, where he discusses innovations like Solo Health, which aims to transform patient care through on-device AI that protects sensitive patient data while providing robust performance for diagnostics, patient monitoring, and workflow optimization.

As a tech community participant, Dhruv has been featured as a speaker and host at San Francisco tech events, including a panel discussion on "AI + Human Intelligence" where he presented Solo alongside other founders. He's also participated in hackathons, with his profile showing attendance at AI hackathon events.

Dhruv brings a strong educational foundation from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign where he was recognized as a James Scholar and made the Dean's List. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, including Machine Learning, Algorithms, Computer Architecture (Honors), Data Structures (Honors), Interactive Computer Graphics, and R Programming. His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English, Hindi, and Punjabi, along with working knowledge of French and Mandarin Chinese.

As an educator, Dhruv has received glowing recommendations for his work as an instructor at General Assembly's boot camp program. Former students praise his patience, extensive knowledge, and ability to break down complex concepts in accessible ways. His teaching style is described as easy-going yet effective, making him a favorite resource for students struggling with difficult concepts.

Dhruv maintains an active presence in the AI and tech community, regularly publishing his newsletter "So Essentially Weekly" that covers developments in the field. His project portfolio demonstrates versatility and practical application of his skills, including work with Illini Hyperloop, a Kaggle Challenge on Titanic Prediction, and various web and mobile applications like Flare, Anthem Web App, and a Dwolla Pebble App.

Dhruv's professional focus appears to be at the intersection of privacy-first AI applications and healthcare innovation, with an emphasis on bringing powerful machine learning capabilities directly to devices while protecting user data and ensuring accessibility regardless of internet connectivity.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

suggested_people.name: Ian Lim
suggested_people.short_description: Ian Lim is a Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. He co-founded Stanford BCI and has been recognized as one of MinneInno's 25 Under 25 rising entrepreneurs and technologists in Minnesota.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ian Lim is a talented Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. His technical interests focus on brain-computer interfaces (BCI), as evidenced by his co-founding of Stanford BCI, an organization dedicated to advancing cutting-edge technology that connects neural activity with computing systems.

Ian has been involved with TreeHacks as an organizer, Stanford's premier hackathon that brings together students to collaborate on technological solutions to real-world problems. His entrepreneurial talent was recognized early when he was named to MinneInno's 25 Under 25 List in September 2018, highlighting him as one of Minnesota's most promising young entrepreneurs and technologists. He hails from Overland Park, Kansas, as indicated by his profile at the University of Kansas School of Engineering.

Despite his relatively early career stage, Ian has already built a substantial professional network with over 500 connections and 3,000 followers on LinkedIn, suggesting his influence in tech and entrepreneurial circles. His activity on LinkedIn shows engagement with content related to AI in education, talent development, and leadership, indicating his broader interests in how technology can transform learning and organizational development.

It's worth noting that there are several other professionals named Ian Lim in different fields, including a Senior Lecturer at Monash University specializing in computer science and data science, and a character portrayed by actor James Chen in the TV series "FBI" as an intelligence analyst. Our Ian Lim maintains a personal website at ianlim.com and is active on Twitter under the handle @ianclim, where he likely shares insights about his work and interests in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Aidan Gollan
suggested_people.short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

suggested_people.name: Arjun Melwani
suggested_people.short_description: Arjun Melwani is an Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and Physics student at MIT and researcher at the MIT Media Lab. He is an accomplished hackathon winner, having secured first place at HackMIT with his team's innovative project. Arjun combines his technical expertise with entrepreneurial experience, having previously owned Techabyte3d and worked in product development at Articulate Labs.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arjun Melwani is a multifaceted technologist currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2024-2028). As a researcher at the MIT Media Lab, he is positioned at the forefront of innovative technological research.

Arjun has already demonstrated exceptional technical capabilities and entrepreneurial spirit. Most notably, he and his team won first place at HackMIT, one of the most prestigious hackathons in the academic world. His team's project, HarmoNIC, was recognized not only as the overall grand prize winner but also won the TerraAPI track, showcasing his ability to develop cutting-edge solutions in competitive environments.

Prior to his academic journey at MIT, Arjun gained valuable industry experience through his work in product development at Articulate Labs from July 2021 to January 2024. During this 2.5-year tenure, he contributed to the development of medical technology solutions in the Dallas, Texas area.

Arjun also demonstrated his entrepreneurial acumen as the owner of Techabyte3d from May 2016 to January 2024, a venture he successfully managed for nearly 8 years. This experience highlights his ability to balance business operations with technical innovation from a young age.

His educational background includes attending Greenhill School from 2008 to 2024 before enrolling at MIT. Arjun's activities on LinkedIn reflect his keen interest in AI innovation, entrepreneurship, and technological advancement, particularly in areas where hardware and software intersect.

Arjun comes from a family with strong business and academic connections. His father, Andy Wu, serves as the Arjun and Minoo Melwani Family Associate Professor of Business Administration at Harvard Business School, suggesting the professorship may be named after Arjun and his family. This connection to Harvard Business School provides Arjun with unique exposure to business strategy and entrepreneurship from an academic perspective.

Arjun's combination of formal education, research experience, entrepreneurial background, and demonstrated excellence in competitive technical challenges positions him as a promising talent in the fields of electrical engineering, computer science, and physics, with particular strengths in applied technology development and innovation.

name: liangze li
short_description: Liangze Li is an AI researcher at Google DeepMind with a background from Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science. His research focuses on natural language processing and AI detection, with publications on distinguishing human from AI-generated content. He has demonstrated leadership through founding multiple organizations at CMU and is multilingual with proficiency in Mandarin, English, Cantonese, and Russian.
long_description:
Liangze Li is an AI researcher currently working at Google DeepMind, one of the world's leading artificial intelligence research labs. He joined DeepMind in 2024 after completing his education at Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science, where he earned his Master's degree in Language Technologies. His academic journey at CMU began in 2017 as an undergraduate student before continuing with graduate studies from 2022 to 2024.

Liangze's research focuses primarily on natural language processing and AI detection systems. He has published several notable papers in this field, including "GPT-Sentinel: Distinguishing Human and ChatGPT Generated Content" and "Token Prediction as Implicit Classification to Identify LLM-Generated Text," both published in 2023. These works have received significant attention in the academic community, with his GPT-Sentinel paper garnering over 70 citations. He has also contributed to research on referential games in NLP with his paper "Listener Model for the PhotoBook Referential Game with CLIPScores as Implicit Reference Chain."

During his time at Carnegie Mellon, Liangze demonstrated exceptional leadership and initiative by founding and presiding over several organizations. He was the Founder and President of the CMU Blackjack Society, as well as the Founder and Lecturer of the Carnegie Mellon University Student College. He also served as President of the Student College Executive Committee and as a Representative in the Graduate Student Assembly.

Before focusing on AI and natural language processing, Liangze had research interests in cryptography, with several publications between 2012-2014 on topics such as pairing computation on Edwards curves and Jacobi quartic curves with high-degree twists. This demonstrates his versatility and depth of knowledge across different areas of computer science.
