Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Liangze has diverse interests in music, having played Alto Saxophone in both the Carnegie Mellon University Kiltie Band and the Pinghe Chamber Orchestra. His intellectual curiosity extends to philosophy as well, as evidenced by his founding of the Pinghe School Philosophy Club and his connection to CMU's Department of Philosophy.

Liangze is impressively multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Mandarin and English, full professional proficiency in Cantonese, and limited working proficiency in Russian. This linguistic versatility enhances his ability to collaborate in international research settings.

In his own words, Liangze describes himself as being "involved in AI research and startups," indicating his dual interests in both the theoretical advancement of AI and its practical applications in entrepreneurial contexts. His engagement with posts related to machine learning, AI development, and technology startups on LinkedIn further reflects his professional focus and interests in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Trishala Neeraj
suggested_people.short_description: Trishala Neeraj is a Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube with a strong academic background from Cornell University. She specializes in computer vision and natural language processing, bringing technical expertise to cybersecurity analytics and has contributed to several influential AI research papers.
suggested_people.long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. She works with terabyte-scale data to develop models using Deep Learning and Matrix Factorization techniques, with a particular focus on language data and models.

Her academic foundation was built at Cornell University, where she graduated in 2018 after focusing on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing during her graduate studies. She also holds a Bachelor of Engineering degree from BITS Pilani, India, and spent time as a visiting research scholar at the Predictive Technology Lab at the University of Virginia.

Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022). Her work on "BigBIO: A Framework for Data-Centric Biomedical Natural Language Processing" (2022) has also gained recognition in the field.

Her professional experience includes a summer internship at BuzzFeed in 2017, where she worked on a project using K-Means Clustering to tag over 14,000 BuzzFeed quizzes, which she documented in a blog post on the BuzzFeed Tech Blog. She has also published research on "A Computational Approach to Perceived Trustworthiness of Airbnb Host Profiles" (2017) and "Longitudinal Analysis of Cyber-Related Articles" (2020).

Beyond her technical work, Trishala has been actively involved in the tech community. She represented the student body at the Cornell Tech Campus Dedication ceremony in August 2017 and moderated a conversation with Eric Schmidt in March 2018. She maintains a personal blog where she documents her research projects on topics like Weak Supervision, Feature-based Approaches with BERT, and Semantic Entailment.

Trishala is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Hindi, which enhances her ability to work in diverse teams and global environments. Her involvement with organizations like Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) demonstrates her commitment to the broader AI community and diversity in tech.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya
suggested_people.short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese. Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

suggested_people.name: Rez Havaei
suggested_people.short_description: Rez Havaei is the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis (YC S24), a startup developing automated AI safety and red-teaming tools. With expertise in AI research and quantitative trading, his career includes roles at Cohere, NVIDIA, Jane Street, and as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rez Havaei is an accomplished entrepreneur and AI specialist currently serving as the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis, a Y Combinator-backed startup (S24 batch) focused on AI safety and evaluation. The company provides a comprehensive suite of tools for identifying and addressing vulnerabilities in AI systems, including red-teaming frameworks and interpretability techniques.

General Analysis was founded in 2024 and is based in San Francisco. The company's mission is to address the growing risks associated with deploying increasingly capable AI systems in high-stakes environments. Their approach involves developing automated tools that systematically find model failure modes and enhance model robustness, delivering detailed safety and performance reports to customers.

One of their notable projects demonstrated how GPT-4o is susceptible to hallucinating when asked about legal cases or concepts. Their research showed they could train an attacker model that caused GPT-4o to hallucinate on more than 35% of prompts related to legal questions.

Before founding General Analysis, Rez worked as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform and benchmark. This startup, co-founded by Stanford AI students, aimed to create a standardized test for measuring artificial intelligence and large language models, providing an unbiased, third-party review system.

Rez's professional experience spans both AI research and finance. He has worked as an Applied Research Intern in Deep Learning at Snap Inc., a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Cohere (a leading AI company developing large language models), and held an Applied Research position in Artificial Intelligence at NVIDIA. His finance background includes quantitative trading internships at prestigious firms like Jane Street and Susquehanna International Group (SIG).

His academic research experience includes positions at the USC Information Sciences Institute and as a Research Assistant at UC Davis, where he also served as a Teaching Assistant. Rez earned a Bachelor of Science in Engineering from the University of California, Davis (2018-2023), maintaining a 3.97 GPA.

Rez is also involved in another venture called Kart AI, which serves as an interactive search platform that simplifies research for electronic products. The platform extracts relevant recommendations from Reddit, YouTube, and trusted content creators to help users find and compare electronic products.

His technical interests and expertise span AI safety, interpretability, evaluation, deep learning, and statistical inference. Rez's career trajectory demonstrates his commitment to addressing the challenges of AI safety and evaluation while building practical tools that can help organizations deploy AI systems more responsibly.

name: vivan madan
short_description: Vivan Madan is a freshman pursuing Computer Science and Mathematics at the University of Maryland. As a new entrant to the field, he is exploring the intersection of computational methods and mathematical theory, likely with interests in AI applications.
long_description:
Vivan Madan is currently a freshman at the University of Maryland, where he is pursuing a dual focus in Computer Science and Mathematics (2024-2028). As a newcomer to the collegiate academic environment, Vivan represents the next generation of computational thinkers who are building their foundation in both the theoretical aspects of mathematics and the practical applications of computer science.

While Vivan's professional profile is still developing, his choice of dual disciplines suggests an interest in the mathematical foundations that underpin modern AI and computational methods. The combination of CS and Math is particularly valuable for areas like machine learning algorithms, data analysis, and theoretical computer science.

As a participant in an AI hackathon, Vivan demonstrates early initiative to gain hands-on experience in applying his academic knowledge to real-world AI challenges, showing promise as an emerging talent in the field despite being at the beginning of his academic journey.

suggested_people.name: Alex Fan
suggested_people.short_description: Alex Fan is a talented undergraduate at MIT studying Mathematics and Computer Science with a focus on AI research. A USACO Finalist in 2021 and 2022, he's currently working as a Research Engineer at Pika, tackling challenges in generative video and image models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alex Fan is a promising talent in the AI field, currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023-2026). His academic journey includes rigorous coursework in graduate-level Machine Learning, Advanced Algorithms, Advances in Computer Vision, and Computational Cognitive Science, demonstrating his commitment to mastering both the theoretical foundations and cutting-edge applications of AI.

Alex's technical prowess was evident early on, as he was a USACO (USA Computing Olympiad) Finalist in both 2021 and 2022 during his time at Lexington High School. This competitive programming background has provided him with strong algorithmic thinking skills that complement his AI research interests.

Currently, Alex is working as a Research Engineer at Pika, where he focuses on solving engineering and research challenges related to generative video/image models and data curation. This practical experience in the rapidly evolving field of generative AI is giving him hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art techniques and real-world applications.

During his time at MIT, Alex has been involved in various research projects. In 2022, he participated in the PRIMES program where he collaborated on research leveraging statistical distributions for RNA sequencing across time, working with Prof. Gil Alterovitz. This experience demonstrates his interest in applying computational methods to biological data.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Alex is an active member of the MIT community. He lives in La Maison Française (MIT French House) where he embraces French culture and language. He's also involved in the performing arts, having performed in the MIT Musical Theatre Guild's Cabaret Night in Fall 2023 and cast as John Hinckley Jr. in their production of "Assassins" for Fall 2024.

Alex has diverse personal interests including cooking, baking, fermentation, Broadway musicals, and playing piano. He describes himself as a francophile who dreams of returning to Parisian cafes. In his spare time, he enjoys working on programming projects and writing blog posts, showcasing his passion for both technical and creative pursuits.

His engagement with the AI community is evident through his LinkedIn activity, where he follows developments in AI research, particularly in generative models and applications in various domains. Alex represents the next generation of AI researchers and engineers who are combining strong mathematical foundations with practical implementation skills to push the boundaries of what's possible in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

suggested_people.name: David Bai
suggested_people.short_description: David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at USC with diverse research experience in AI alignment, multi-agent robotic planning, and reinforcement learning for legged robots. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's developing language learning tools while also working on innovative projects like brain-controlled drones and GPS-denied navigation systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at the University of Southern California (2023-2027), where he serves as a USC Presidential Scholar. His academic journey is marked by a deep commitment to artificial intelligence research across multiple domains.

Currently, David is a Research Fellow at the Supervised Program for Alignment Research, where he investigates reasoning and AI agents from capabilities and security perspectives. Simultaneously, he works as a Research Assistant at USC Viterbi School of Engineering's GLAMOR Lab through the CURVE Fellowship, focusing on multi-agent robotic planning at the intersection of LLMs and symbolic planners.

David's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of Jargon, where he's building a language learning Chrome extension. His technical versatility extends to his work with USC Makers, where he manages projects involving brain-controlled drones using electroencephalography, having previously contributed to an autonomous greenhouse with computer vision.

His professional experience includes a Machine Learning & Computer Vision Internship at Rhoman Aerospace, enabling GPS-denied navigation through VIO and building simulation/SLAM pipelines. David has also served as a Research Assistant at the Dynamic Robotics and Control Laboratory, where he augmented model predictive control for legged robots with reinforcement learning.

In the academic community, David is active with USC's Center for AI in Society's Student Branch (CAIS++), where he contributes to research and projects in artificial intelligence with social impact applications. He is part of the Fall 2024 cohort, demonstrating his commitment to applying AI for societal benefit.

David is also involved with the USC Computational Aerospace Lab, where he works on projects related to BCD (Binary Collision Detection), showcasing his interdisciplinary approach to engineering challenges. This involvement highlights his ability to apply computational methods to aerospace applications.

Prior to USC, David demonstrated academic excellence at Cambridge University, where he compiled comprehensive lecture notes across various mathematical disciplines, indicating his strong foundation in theoretical concepts that underpin his current technical work.

David's commitment to social impact is demonstrated through his volunteer work with the Cheyenne River Youth Project and Friends of Children with Special Needs, where he developed educational courses. His multidisciplinary approach to AI research, combined with his technical skills and social consciousness, positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Locke Cai
suggested_people.short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

name: dylan b allen
short_description: CEO & Co-Founder of Cheers (YC S24), a frontline experience management platform that transforms in-person business interactions using NFC technology. Dylan has a background in product management and software engineering, with experience at Microsoft Azure and Utah-based B2B tech companies.
long_description:
Dylan B Allen is the CEO and Co-Founder of Cheers, a startup that was accepted into Y Combinator's Summer 2024 batch (YC S24). Founded in 2024 and based in San Francisco (after relocating from Utah), Cheers is building the first Frontline Experience Management platform that transforms in-person service interactions through NFC-enabled employee badges.

Cheers' technology unifies onsite payments, digital tips, real-time reviews, and new-customer referrals in one frictionless flow, helping companies increase their online 5-star ratings, reduce churn, and drive more revenue. The platform is particularly valuable for businesses in home services, field sales, healthcare, and other industries where employees work primarily outside a specific place of business.

Under Dylan's leadership, Cheers has shown impressive early traction, growing from approximately $1,400 MRR in July 2024 to around $4,000 shortly after, with 25 customers including small businesses and one enterprise-level client. The company has processed over 3,000 reviews for customers, with the average client seeing a 5-10x increase in monthly 5-star Google Reviews.

Prior to founding Cheers, Dylan interned at Microsoft Azure and worked at other Utah-based B2B tech companies as a product manager and software engineer. His technical background in frontend engineering has been praised by colleagues, with Adnan Chowdhury describing him as a "well-rounded engineer who also has product management" experience and commending his "can-do attitude and eagerness to learn to solve complex problems."

Dylan graduated from Brigham Young University (BYU) with a degree in computer science and was named to the Marriott School Dean's List in April 2021. During his academic career, he placed in the top 20 of the Student Innovator of the Year competition in Utah, where he pitched his startup idea to a panel of tech investors.

Originally from Dallas, Texas, Dylan is multilingual with professional working proficiency in Spanish, elementary proficiency in Swedish, and native proficiency in English. He earned the Eagle Scout rank from the Boy Scouts of America in 2016, demonstrating his leadership abilities and commitment to community service from an early age.

Dylan's entrepreneurial journey reflects his persistence and dedication, as he himself noted that "seriously crazy that if you're persistent, things work out." His combination of technical skills, entrepreneurial drive, and leadership qualities position him as a promising founder in the startup ecosystem.

suggested_people.name: Rez Havaei
suggested_people.short_description: Rez Havaei is the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis (YC S24), a startup developing automated AI safety and red-teaming tools. With expertise in AI research and quantitative trading, his career includes roles at Cohere, NVIDIA, Jane Street, and as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rez Havaei is an accomplished entrepreneur and AI specialist currently serving as the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis, a Y Combinator-backed startup (S24 batch) focused on AI safety and evaluation. The company provides a comprehensive suite of tools for identifying and addressing vulnerabilities in AI systems, including red-teaming frameworks and interpretability techniques.

General Analysis was founded in 2024 and is based in San Francisco. The company's mission is to address the growing risks associated with deploying increasingly capable AI systems in high-stakes environments. Their approach involves developing automated tools that systematically find model failure modes and enhance model robustness, delivering detailed safety and performance reports to customers.

One of their notable projects demonstrated how GPT-4o is susceptible to hallucinating when asked about legal cases or concepts. Their research showed they could train an attacker model that caused GPT-4o to hallucinate on more than 35% of prompts related to legal questions.

Before founding General Analysis, Rez worked as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform and benchmark. This startup, co-founded by Stanford AI students, aimed to create a standardized test for measuring artificial intelligence and large language models, providing an unbiased, third-party review system.

Rez's professional experience spans both AI research and finance. He has worked as an Applied Research Intern in Deep Learning at Snap Inc., a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Cohere (a leading AI company developing large language models), and held an Applied Research position in Artificial Intelligence at NVIDIA. His finance background includes quantitative trading internships at prestigious firms like Jane Street and Susquehanna International Group (SIG).

His academic research experience includes positions at the USC Information Sciences Institute and as a Research Assistant at UC Davis, where he also served as a Teaching Assistant. Rez earned a Bachelor of Science in Engineering from the University of California, Davis (2018-2023), maintaining a 3.97 GPA.

Rez is also involved in another venture called Kart AI, which serves as an interactive search platform that simplifies research for electronic products. The platform extracts relevant recommendations from Reddit, YouTube, and trusted content creators to help users find and compare electronic products.

His technical interests and expertise span AI safety, interpretability, evaluation, deep learning, and statistical inference. Rez's career trajectory demonstrates his commitment to addressing the challenges of AI safety and evaluation while building practical tools that can help organizations deploy AI systems more responsibly.

suggested_people.name: Eric Mao
suggested_people.short_description: Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), former MasterChef Australia contestant, and UPenn M&T student with a strong background in AI research. Eric has worked on diverse projects from carbon sequestration estimation to cognitive status prediction using machine learning, and is currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's accelerator program.
suggested_people.long_description:
Eric Mao is a multifaceted entrepreneur and researcher at the intersection of technology, business, and culinary arts. As the Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), he's currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's prestigious accelerator program. His product has shown impressive early traction, with 18,000 users spending over 1,350 hours on the site within 48 hours of launch.

Eric was previously enrolled in the Jerome Fisher Program in Management & Technology (M&T) at the University of Pennsylvania, pursuing a dual degree in Computer Science and Business Administration at Wharton. He's currently on leave to focus on his startup.

His research experience spans multiple AI applications. He has worked on machine learning approaches for carbon credit accuracy, deep learning for 3D printing reliability enhancement, cognitive status prediction from fMRI data, and mind-controlled wheelchairs for ALS patients. His research on carbon sequestration earned him the Best Research Poster award at the International Conference on Climate Change in 2024.

Eric gained national recognition as a contestant on Season 13 of MasterChef Australia at the age of 21. As one of the youngest competitors, he showcased his passion for regional Chinese cuisine and Pan-Asian cooking. His culinary journey began early - he had previously auditioned for Junior MasterChef Australia at age 10. With roots in Wuxi, Eastern China, Eric's cooking is deeply influenced by his heritage and family traditions. During the competition, he created signature dishes including Shanghai Chive Pancake with Black Garlic Prawns, Three Treasure Wonton, and Strange Flavour Chicken.

Before MasterChef, Eric was a medical student at the University of New South Wales, where he made the difficult decision to defer his studies to pursue his culinary passion. His dream has been to create a pop-up restaurant that brings regional Chinese cuisine into a modern Australian setting.

Eric was also selected as a Fellow at Telora, where he worked on Iris, an improved file management system for video editors. His entrepreneurial journey includes participation in Z Fellows, a program for founders and builders.

During his high school years at Crescent School, Eric demonstrated exceptional talent in physics and computer science, representing Team Canada in the International Young Physicists' Tournament, earning a Gold Medal in the Canadian Young Physicists' Tournament, winning the High School Big Data Challenge, and reaching the Platinum Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO).

Eric combines technical expertise in AI and machine learning with business acumen, entrepreneurial drive, and culinary creativity, focusing on creating practical solutions to real-world problems across multiple disciplines.

suggested_people.name: Kevin F.
suggested_people.short_description: Product professional at Replo (YC S21) with a unique background in space technology, having led teams for NASA proposals and worked on the smallest and lightest rover to reach space. Carnegie Mellon graduate with dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration, Kevin also hosts the Product Valley podcast and leads the CMU Tech & Entrepreneurship community.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kevin F. is a multifaceted product professional currently working at Replo (YC S21), where he brings his technical and business expertise to the startup environment. A recent graduate from Carnegie Mellon University with dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration, Kevin has built an impressive portfolio spanning space technology, product management, and community leadership.

His space technology experience is particularly notable, having worked on mission operations for both the Iris Lunar Rover and MoonRanger projects at Carnegie Mellon. Kevin led teams for NASA proposals and contributed to building what he describes as "the smallest and lightest rover to reach space" - a significant achievement in aerospace engineering.

Kevin's professional journey includes product roles at several startups and companies. Before joining Replo, he worked in Cloud & Digital at PwC, managed Product Growth at Expii for over a year, served as a Quantitative Analyst at Paratus Capital, and held Product Manager positions at both Stayflexi and TruePlan.io. His recommendation from Daniel Green at TruePlan highlights his ability to "pick up context quickly and add value from day one" while helping rebuild their website, analyzing customer usage patterns, and supporting sales efforts.

Beyond his professional work, Kevin is deeply involved in the tech and entrepreneurship community. He serves as the Community Lead for CMU Tech & Entrepreneurship (cmute.io) and produces and hosts the Product Valley podcast through Product@CMU. His leadership extends to his role as Activities Board Finance Chair at Carnegie Mellon and as President of The Triple Helix.

Kevin is bilingual in English and Mandarin Chinese, and his academic achievements include making the Dean's List, being a National Merit Scholarship Award Finalist, and winning the FBLA National Championship. This combination of technical knowledge, business acumen, and leadership experience positions Kevin as a versatile professional at the intersection of product development, technology, and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tan
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tan is a Stanford University alumnus and entrepreneur focused on democratizing career growth. With a strong background in computer science and data science from UC Berkeley, he has conducted research in stock market prediction using sentiment analysis and has been recognized with numerous academic honors including Phi Beta Kappa and the EECS Honors Program.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tan is an accomplished technologist and entrepreneur currently associated with Humans and Stanford University. He's working on democratizing access to career growth through his venture joinnova.co.

Andrew has an impressive academic background, having graduated from UC Berkeley where he was part of the EECS Honors Program and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa as a junior (top 20 students in his class). During his time at Berkeley, he excelled as a student instructor in the Data Science Department, earning recognition as an Outstanding Student Instructor.

His research interests include applying AI to financial markets, as evidenced by his publication "Sentiment Predictability for Stocks" where he explored stock market prediction using textual sentiment analysis tools and advanced prediction models like LSTMs and convolutional architectures.

Andrew has a strong entrepreneurial spirit, having been selected for the Pear VC Summer Fellowship which provided seed investment for his early-stage startup. He was also named a Jack Larson Scholar at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business, receiving a scholarship to pursue entrepreneurship in technology and research.

His technical talents were recognized early, being one of only 11 students nationwide awarded the Snap Research Scholarship for his academic performance, research experience, and ability to solve tough technical challenges. Before college, Andrew was the Salutatorian of his high school class and achieved success in both mathematics competitions (qualifying for AIME four times) and business competitions (placing 2nd at the DECA International Competition).

Andrew is bilingual, with native English proficiency and professional working proficiency in Chinese, adding to his versatile skill set that spans technology, research, and entrepreneurship.

It's important to note that there is another prominent Andrew Tan who is a Filipino billionaire businessman. This Andrew Tan is the chairman of Alliance Global Group, Inc., a major conglomerate with interests in real estate, food and beverage, gaming, and hospitality. Born in Fujian, China, he moved to Hong Kong at age 4 and later to the Philippines as a teenager. He graduated with a degree in accounting from the University of the East in Manila and built his fortune developing large apartment complexes around Manila. His company Megaworld Corporation pioneered the "live-work-play" concept in township development, and he also runs Emperador, the world's largest brandy company by sales volume. As of 2024, his net worth is estimated at $1.5 billion. This is a different individual from the Andrew Tan described in the main profile.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

name: justin ji
short_description: Junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University with a focus on AI interpretability research. Justin is active in multiple campus organizations including Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders and Book Club @ Harvard, which he founded. He balances academic pursuits with interests in volleyball, reading, and community leadership.
long_description:
Justin Ji (also known as Juji) is a junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University (class of 2026). His academic focus has evolved toward AI interpretability research—understanding how AI models work internally to make them safer and more trustworthy for society. During his junior year, he collaborated with the Harvard Kempner Institute on a project investigating how language models adopt "personas" and designing interventions to influence them.

Justin's technical background includes competitive programming and mathematics in high school, where he reached USACO Platinum level and qualified for AIME. At Harvard, he has pursued a rigorous computer science curriculum including graduate-level coursework in Deep Learning (MIT 6.S898), Sensorimotor Learning (MIT 6.8200), and Training Foundation Models (CS 2281R). He has also conducted supervised research (CS 91R) and participated in the Kempner REU summer research program focused on AI interpretability.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Justin is deeply involved in campus life. He founded Book Club @ Harvard and serves on the board of Startups @ Harvard. He is also the Social Chair for Harvard Men's Club Volleyball, Director of Engagement for Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders, and a member of several other organizations including the Harvard AI Safety Student Team, Harvard College Christian Students, and the Taiwanese Cultural Society.

Before Harvard, Justin served as the Whitney High School Middle School Branch and Online Director for Math Matters 4 All, demonstrating his early leadership abilities. His digital creativity was previously showcased through projects like his participation in the Chipotle + David Dobrik TikTok Contest in May 2020.

Justin is an avid reader with diverse literary interests. His favorite books include "The Three-Body Problem" by Cixin Liu, "The Book Thief" by Markus Zusak, and "All the Light We Cannot See" by Anthony Doerr. He maintains an active Goodreads profile and encourages connections through his social media channels.

In his free time, Justin enjoys playing volleyball, reading, and eating at Chipotle. He welcomes connections via LinkedIn or email and is "always happy to meet new people," reflecting his collaborative and community-oriented approach to both his academic and personal pursuits.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Alicia Li
suggested_people.short_description: MIT CS/AI & Math double major with a strong research background in robot learning and reinforcement learning. First author on a NeurIPS 2024 workshop paper and incoming ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics. Founded Watch To Donate, raising over $6,000 for various causes while reaching millions of people.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alicia Li is a talented undergraduate at MIT pursuing a double major in Computer Science/AI (specifically course 6-4: AI and Decision Making) and Mathematics (2023-2027). Her research interests span robot learning, planning, and reinforcement learning, with particular focus on safe RL applications.

As an undergraduate researcher at MIT CSAIL's Learning & Intelligent Systems Group, she works on robot learning and planning, and is the first author on a paper accepted to the NeurIPS 2024 Open-World Agents Workshop titled "Learning to Bridge the Gap: Efficient Novelty Recovery with Planning and Reinforcement Learning." She's also researching safe reinforcement learning for power grid optimization at MIT's Donti Lab, where she was listed as a past member in 2024.

Alicia has an impressive publication record for her career stage, with multiple published papers including work on adversarial attacks against online reinforcement learning agents (as part of MIT PRIMES research project 2022-2023), magic SET squares classification, the Post Correspondence Problem, and coin weighing problems. Her academic excellence is further demonstrated by her coursework in graduate-level subjects including Advanced Algorithms, Inference and Information, and Sensorimotor Learning.

Beyond her academic pursuits, Alicia founded and served as CEO of Watch To Donate from 2020 to 2023, an international student organization that donates revenue from social media videos, mobile apps, and business collaborations. Under her leadership, the organization raised over $6,000 for 27 causes, reached over 6 million people, and developed apps with 9,000+ downloads. She also created a Family Fund to help their online community of 50,000 in need. Additionally, she developed "Play To Donate," an app that leverages ad revenue to enable users to donate to charity by playing games.

Alicia is active in MIT's campus life, participating in MIT Asian Dance Team and Ridonkulous (MIT's competitive hip hop dance team), and was previously on Fixation (MIT's competitive contemporary dance team). She also enjoys figure skating and watching movies with friends in her free time.

She is currently preparing for her upcoming role as an ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics, where she'll likely apply her expertise in AI and mathematics to challenges in the therapeutic development space.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Alex Fan
suggested_people.short_description: Alex Fan is a talented undergraduate at MIT studying Mathematics and Computer Science with a focus on AI research. A USACO Finalist in 2021 and 2022, he's currently working as a Research Engineer at Pika, tackling challenges in generative video and image models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alex Fan is a promising talent in the AI field, currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023-2026). His academic journey includes rigorous coursework in graduate-level Machine Learning, Advanced Algorithms, Advances in Computer Vision, and Computational Cognitive Science, demonstrating his commitment to mastering both the theoretical foundations and cutting-edge applications of AI.

Alex's technical prowess was evident early on, as he was a USACO (USA Computing Olympiad) Finalist in both 2021 and 2022 during his time at Lexington High School. This competitive programming background has provided him with strong algorithmic thinking skills that complement his AI research interests.

Currently, Alex is working as a Research Engineer at Pika, where he focuses on solving engineering and research challenges related to generative video/image models and data curation. This practical experience in the rapidly evolving field of generative AI is giving him hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art techniques and real-world applications.

During his time at MIT, Alex has been involved in various research projects. In 2022, he participated in the PRIMES program where he collaborated on research leveraging statistical distributions for RNA sequencing across time, working with Prof. Gil Alterovitz. This experience demonstrates his interest in applying computational methods to biological data.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Alex is an active member of the MIT community. He lives in La Maison Française (MIT French House) where he embraces French culture and language. He's also involved in the performing arts, having performed in the MIT Musical Theatre Guild's Cabaret Night in Fall 2023 and cast as John Hinckley Jr. in their production of "Assassins" for Fall 2024.

Alex has diverse personal interests including cooking, baking, fermentation, Broadway musicals, and playing piano. He describes himself as a francophile who dreams of returning to Parisian cafes. In his spare time, he enjoys working on programming projects and writing blog posts, showcasing his passion for both technical and creative pursuits.

His engagement with the AI community is evident through his LinkedIn activity, where he follows developments in AI research, particularly in generative models and applications in various domains. Alex represents the next generation of AI researchers and engineers who are combining strong mathematical foundations with practical implementation skills to push the boundaries of what's possible in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Bill Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Yale '26 computer science student in the BS/MS program with a background in competitive programming and mathematics. Currently researching LLMs and code generation, with experience in systems and machine learning. Incoming Software Engineering Intern at Citadel Securities with previous roles at The New York Times and Yale's Gerstein Laboratory. Also serves as Chairman of Cypher Capital, a prominent multi-strategy crypto investment firm.
suggested_people.long_description:
Bill Qian is a computer science student at Yale University (Class of 2026) pursuing a combined BS/MS degree. His technical foundation stems from competitive programming (USACO/ICPC) and mathematics (USAMO/Putnam), which has evolved into expertise in systems, machine learning, and full-stack development.

At Yale's Gerstein Laboratory, Bill has established himself as a researcher in Large Language Models and code generation, publishing multiple papers in natural language processing. His research contributions include work on "ToolLLM: Facilitating Large Language Models to Master 16000+ Real-world APIs" and "BioCoder: A Benchmark for Bioinformatics Code Generation with Contextual Pragmatic Knowledge." He has collaborated with researchers from prominent organizations including Google DeepMind.

Bill's professional experience spans diverse environments. He's secured an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Citadel Securities (New York) focusing on high-performance C++. Previously, he worked at The New York Times on their Research and Development team, exploring ethical applications of AI and LLMs in journalism. At DeepMedia, he designed and optimized algorithms for heterogeneous data analysis, creating a machine translation model with 10% better performance than competitors using Transformers, Python, PyTorch, and Rust.

His technical versatility extends to infrastructure development, having designed distributed computing systems using AWS, Azure, and on-premise hardware with Docker, Kubernetes, and SQS. At Thomas Ho Company, he applied neural networks to assess mortgage loan pricing models and implemented ETL pipelines that improved data processing efficiency by 30%.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Bill is actively involved in campus life as a Project Manager at the Student Technology Collaborative, where he manages knowledge base development and provides technical support across multiple operating systems. He balances his technical interests with creative outlets, singing with the Yale Glee Club and making short films.

In parallel to his academic career, Bill serves as the Chairman of Cypher Capital, a leading multi-strategy crypto investment firm based in the UAE. Before joining Cypher Capital in 2022, he was the Global Head of Fundraising, Binance Labs, and M&A for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency platform. Prior to that, he was Head of Investment for Fintech and Technology at JD.com, a leading Asian internet platform generating over $400 billion in annual gross merchandise volume.

Throughout his career in the blockchain and cryptocurrency sectors, Bill has deployed and managed over $30 billion in investments across AI, cryptocurrency, and fintech. He has successfully invested in prominent blockchain projects including Solana, Mysten Labs (Sui), Ton, Sei, and Bouncebit. He also serves on the board of the TON Foundation and is Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer of Phoenix Group (ADX: PHX), the first cryptocurrency company to go public in the Middle East.

Bill holds a Bachelor of Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, an MSc in Finance from Nanyang Technological University, and an MBA from the University of Toronto. He is also an executive committee member of the Hillhouse Value Investing Institution.

His unique combination of deep technical expertise in computer science, extensive experience in blockchain investment, and leadership in the cryptocurrency industry positions him as a multifaceted contributor across both academic and professional domains.

name: alicia li
short_description: MIT CS/AI & Math double major with a strong research background in robot learning and reinforcement learning. First author on a NeurIPS 2024 workshop paper and incoming ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics. Founded Watch To Donate, raising over $6,000 for various causes while reaching millions of people.

suggested_people.name: Locke Cai
suggested_people.short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Justin Ji
suggested_people.short_description: Junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University with a focus on AI interpretability research. Justin is active in multiple campus organizations including Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders and Book Club @ Harvard, which he founded. He balances academic pursuits with interests in volleyball, reading, and community leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Justin Ji (also known as Juji) is a junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University (class of 2026). His academic focus has evolved toward AI interpretability research—understanding how AI models work internally to make them safer and more trustworthy for society. During his junior year, he collaborated with the Harvard Kempner Institute on a project investigating how language models adopt "personas" and designing interventions to influence them.

Justin's technical background includes competitive programming and mathematics in high school, where he reached USACO Platinum level and qualified for AIME. At Harvard, he has pursued a rigorous computer science curriculum including graduate-level coursework in Deep Learning (MIT 6.S898), Sensorimotor Learning (MIT 6.8200), and Training Foundation Models (CS 2281R). He has also conducted supervised research (CS 91R) and participated in the Kempner REU summer research program focused on AI interpretability.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Justin is deeply involved in campus life. He founded Book Club @ Harvard and serves on the board of Startups @ Harvard. He is also the Social Chair for Harvard Men's Club Volleyball, Director of Engagement for Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders, and a member of several other organizations including the Harvard AI Safety Student Team, Harvard College Christian Students, and the Taiwanese Cultural Society.

Before Harvard, Justin served as the Whitney High School Middle School Branch and Online Director for Math Matters 4 All, demonstrating his early leadership abilities. His digital creativity was previously showcased through projects like his participation in the Chipotle + David Dobrik TikTok Contest in May 2020.

Justin is an avid reader with diverse literary interests.
