His favorite books include "The Three-Body Problem" by Cixin Liu, "The Book Thief" by Markus Zusak, and "All the Light We Cannot See" by Anthony Doerr. He maintains an active Goodreads profile and encourages connections through his social media channels.

In his free time, Justin enjoys playing volleyball, reading, and eating at Chipotle. He welcomes connections via LinkedIn or email and is "always happy to meet new people," reflecting his collaborative and community-oriented approach to both his academic and personal pursuits.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

name: min xu
short_description: Min Xu is an Associate Professor in the Computational Biology Department at Carnegie Mellon University, with courtesy appointments in the Robotics Institute and Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. His research focuses on computer vision and machine learning methods for analyzing cellular systems using imaging and omics data.
long_description:
Min Xu (徐旻) is an Associate Professor at the Computational Biology Department within the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University. He holds Courtesy Appointments at the Robotics Institute and Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. He serves as training faculty at the Joint CMU-Pitt Ph.D. Program in Computational Biology and as co-director of the Master of Science in Computational Biology (MSCB) program. He is also a training faculty member at the Master of Science in Computer Vision (MSCV) program at CMU.

Dr. Xu is an investigator at the National Center for Multiscale Modeling of Biological Systems and is affiliated with the Computer Vision Department at the Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence in UAE. His career has been dedicated to developing computer vision and machine learning methods for analyzing cellular systems using imaging and omics data.

His early work (2000-2009) focused on developing machine learning methods for analyzing functional genomics data. Since 2008, he has shifted his focus to developing computer vision methods for the analysis of Cellular Cryo-Electron Tomography (Cryo-ET) 3D image data. Dr. Xu and his team have designed novel structural pattern mining methods and were the first to demonstrate the feasibility of De Novo extraction of structures and spatial organizations of macromolecular complexes in single cells using Cryo-ET data. His current research focuses on Cryo-ET derived modeling of cellular organization at molecular resolution.

Dr. Xu has published extensively in top peer-reviewed journals and conferences, including PNAS, Structure, ISMB, CVPR, NeurIPS, and MICCAI. His work has been cited over 3,700 times according to Google Scholar. He serves as Principal Investigator on US NIH R01 and NSF awards and received an NSF CAREER award in 2023.

Dr. Xu received his B.E. in Computer Science from Beihang University, M.Sc. from the School of Computing at the National University of Singapore, M.A. in Applied Mathematics from the University of Southern California (USC), and Ph.D. in Computational Biology and Bioinformatics from USC. Before joining CMU, he was a postdoctoral researcher at USC.

In his own words, "Dr. Xu researches for fun, and he enjoys working with highly talented and motivated students." He is open to research collaborations and can be contacted via email at mxu1@cs.cmu.edu.

suggested_people.name: Zhizhuo Z. Zhou
suggested_people.short_description: Zhizhuo is a PhD student at Stanford University working at the intersection of Generative AI and 3D computer vision. Previously affiliated with IBM and Carnegie Mellon University, they have also contributed to AI education as a Lead TA for AI4ALL at CMU.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zhizhuo Z. Zhou is a PhD student in Computer Science at Stanford University, working in the Gradient Spaces Lab under the advisorship of Professor Iro Armeni. His research focuses on 3D generative AI, particularly understanding and generating 3D scenes from casual videos, images, and text.

Prior to Stanford, Zhizhuo was an MSR (Master of Science in Robotics) student at Carnegie Mellon University, where he worked with Professor Shubham Tulsiani. He completed his undergraduate studies at the University of Michigan, where he had the opportunity to work with Professor David Fouhey.

Zhizhuo's research contributions include several significant publications in top computer vision conferences. His recent work "MVD-Fusion: Single-view 3D via Depth-consistent Multi-view Generation" was accepted at CVPR 2024, proposing a novel depth-aware 3D attention mechanism for generating multi-view consistent RGB-D images from a single RGB image. Another notable publication, "SparseFusion: Distilling View-conditioned Diffusion for 3D Reconstruction" (CVPR 2023), introduced a 3D neural mode-seeking formulation that combines probabilistic generation of unseen regions with faithful reprojection of seen regions in a consistent 3D representation.

His earlier work includes "Quantifying Bird Skeletons" presented at the CV4Animals Workshop in conjunction with CVPR 2021, which demonstrated how deep learning can be used to measure bird skeleton specimens with extraordinary accuracy and speed, potentially unlocking datasets at unprecedented scales.

Zhizhuo has been recognized with several awards, including the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) from 2021-2024. He also won the Meta-AI CO3D Challenge few-view reconstruction track at the ECCV 2022 NGR-CO3D workshop and received the Best Paper Award at the ProjectX 2020 ML for Climate Change Competition.

Beyond his research, Zhizhuo has demonstrated a commitment to AI education, serving as the Lead Teaching Assistant for AI4ALL at Carnegie Mellon University in 2022 and as a Project Mentor for AI4ALL at the University of Michigan in 2021. These experiences highlight his dedication to nurturing the next generation of AI talent through mentorship and education.

His publications have garnered significant attention in the field, with his work cited hundreds of times according to Google Scholar. Zhizhuo's unique specialization in combining generative AI with 3D technologies positions him at the forefront of creating more immersive and interactive AI-powered experiences.

suggested_people.name: Zarif Azher
suggested_people.short_description: Bioengineering and Computer Science undergraduate at Caltech with extensive research experience in computational pathology and medical technology innovation. Published 10+ peer-reviewed papers in leading journals, focusing on applying AI and spatial transcriptomics to biomedical problems with the goal of expanding global healthcare access.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zarif Azher is an undergraduate student at Caltech pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Bioengineering and Computer Science (2024-2028). He is a passionate innovator and researcher at the intersection of AI and healthcare, with a particular focus on computational pathology, spatial transcriptomics, and medical technology development.

Zarif has an impressive research portfolio with over 10 peer-reviewed publications in prestigious journals and conferences, including the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing, BioData Mining, and the Journal of Pathology Informatics. His research spans innovative applications of AI in healthcare, such as inferring spatial transcriptomics from histological patterns, developing multimodal deep learning models for cancer prognostication, and creating interpretable AI systems for biomedical analysis.

His work has been cited over 60 times by researchers in the field, demonstrating the impact of his contributions to computational biology and medical AI. His recent projects include mapping three-dimensional tumor heterogeneity through deep learning inference of spatial transcriptomics from routine histopathology, and developing LLM-driven agent approaches to modeling legislative behavior.

Beyond his technical research, Zarif is committed to making healthcare more accessible globally. On his personal website, he states: "I want to use powerful technology to improve healthcare access and quality worldwide." He describes himself as a leader who organizes "people and things to accomplish ambitious goals" and a researcher developing "novel solutions to real-world issues – science for action, not observation."

Zarif's professional experience includes working in the Gao Research Group at Caltech and collaborating with researchers from institutions like Case Western Reserve University, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Dartmouth College. He has also been involved in projects to fight government corruption in Bangladesh, advocate for environmental justice in the USA, and deploy novel assistive technology for medical practitioners in underserved regions.

His interdisciplinary approach combines expertise in machine learning, bioinformatics, multimodal deep learning, cancer research, and pathology, positioning him as an emerging leader in the application of AI to solve complex healthcare challenges.

suggested_people.name: Rex Liu
suggested_people.short_description: Undergraduate at Caltech pursuing Computer Science and Biology with a focus on Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. Research Fellow at Thomson Lab developing innovative AI systems including thalamus-inspired LLM routers and GNN-based spatial proteomics. Currently interning at NASA JPL for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft mission and competing on Caltech's Water Polo team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rex Liu is an undergraduate student at Caltech studying Computer Science and Biology, with a particular focus on the intersection of these fields through Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. As a Research Fellow at Caltech's Thomson Lab, Rex has developed several cutting-edge AI systems that demonstrate his innovative approach to machine learning.

His research portfolio includes a Thalamus-inspired LLM Router called "Herd" that creates scalable ensembles of small, open-source language models capable of outperforming larger proprietary models through Q-learning-based dynamic model selection. This work was presented at the NeurIPS Efficient Natural Language and Speech Processing Workshop. He's also worked on Hierarchical Chains with Multi-Level Abstention (HCMA), optimizing Black-box API deployments with uncertainty-based delegation and improved risk control, and published a paper on "Cost-Saving LLM Cascades with Early Abstention."

In the biomedical space, Rex has applied Graph Neural Networks to spatial proteomics, using counterfactual learning to identify tumor perturbations that enhance T-cell infiltration, with validated combinatorial therapies in collaboration with Cedars-Sinai. He's also worked on "Building Foundation Models to Characterize Cellular Interactions via Geometric Self-Supervised Learning on Spatial Genomics."

His most significant research contribution is on Functionally Invariant Path (FIP), a differential geometry-based framework that allows neural networks to adapt to secondary tasks without catastrophic forgetting. This groundbreaking work was published in Nature Machine Intelligence in 2024 and has already been cited by other researchers in the field. The FIP algorithm has wide-ranging applications from improving recommendations on online stores to fine-tuning self-driving cars.

Currently, Rex is interning at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, writing software for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft as part of the Mission Operations and Ground Data Systems team. He is also a member of Caltech's Men's Water Polo team, competing as an Attacker.

Prior to Caltech, Rex worked as a research assistant at National Taiwan University's Systems Biology Epithelia Lab, where he designed a lethal Zika virus-driven plasmid for transgenic mosquitoes, expressing a hybrid neurotoxin upon Zika infection. He also integrated a protein BLAST search engine to identify sequence alignments in the lab's online databases.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Rex has extensive experience in cybersecurity, having worked as a Security Researcher at HackerOne and a Bug Bounty Hunter at Bugcrowd for over five years. He has also served as a Teaching Assistant at Taipei American School, instructing students in Mechanical Engineering (CAD, CNC, water jet cutting, TIG welding) and Modern Topics in Computer Science (logic gates, quantum mechanics, deep learning).

Rex's multidisciplinary background, spanning AI, biology, cybersecurity, and aerospace, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving fields. He is fluent in Chinese and English, with working proficiency in Spanish and Japanese, further enhancing his ability to collaborate in global research environments. Outside of his academic and research work, Rex plays the violin and guitar.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tran
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tran is a junior at Yale University with a strong focus on computer science, particularly in molecular AI research. He has contributed to MolLM, a unified language model integrating biomedical text with 2D and 3D molecular representations, and has experience at Hudson River Trading. His coursework spans deep learning, natural language processing, and graph-structured data.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tran is an undergraduate junior at Yale University pursuing computer science with specialized interests in computational biology and AI. His research work is evidenced by his contribution to MolLM, a sophisticated unified language model that integrates biomedical text with both 2D and 3D molecular representations. This project, presented at ISMB 2024, demonstrates his capability in developing advanced AI systems for molecular modeling.

Andrew has professional experience at Hudson River Trading, a quantitative trading firm known for its algorithmic trading strategies and high-performance computing infrastructure. This suggests his skills extend to financial technology applications of computer science.

His academic foundation is robust, with coursework covering both theoretical computer science (Compilers and Interpreters, Computer Architecture, Operating Systems, Discrete Mathematics) and cutting-edge AI topics (Deep Learning on Graph-Structured Data, Natural Language Processing, Probabilistic Machine Learning). This diverse technical background positions him well at the intersection of traditional computer science and modern AI applications.

Andrew's interest in molecular AI research, as shown by his publication work, indicates his potential to contribute to the growing field of AI applications in healthcare and drug discovery. His engagement with content related to diffusion models, geometry problem-solving AI, and other technical developments (as seen in his LinkedIn activity) suggests he stays current with the latest advancements in artificial intelligence.

It's important to note that there are several other professionals named Andrew Tran in different fields, including an investigative data reporter at The Washington Post (who won a Pulitzer Prize), an orthopedic surgeon specializing in sports medicine, a UCLA law lecturer, and a visual effects artist who has worked on major films like The Hunger Games and Avengers: Infinity War. Our Andrew Tran is specifically the Yale computer science student focused on molecular AI research.

name: vishal nandakumar
short_description: Vishal Nandakumar is a freshman student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with research experience in quantum physics, specifically in hydrodynamic quantum field theory analogs. He graduated from Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, one of the nation's premier STEM-focused high schools.
long_description:
Vishal Nandakumar is currently pursuing his undergraduate studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he enrolled in 2024 and is expected to graduate in 2027. Prior to MIT, Vishal attended Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology from 2020 to 2024, which is widely recognized as one of the top STEM-focused high schools in the United States.

During his time at Thomas Jefferson, Vishal demonstrated exceptional aptitude in physics and quantum mechanics. He was involved in a significant research project at the Q Lab focused on "Hydrodynamic Quantum Field Theory Analogs" alongside collaborators Pranav Panicker and Kai Wang. This project explored hydrodynamic quantum field theory, a model of quantum dynamics inspired by Louis de Broglie's double-solution pilot wave theory. Their research involved physically modeling superwalking droplets and pilot wave theory in a silicone oil bath, and extending the two-dimensional form of the hydrodynamic pilot wave to three dimensions by exploring free particles, harmonic oscillators, and other quantum analogs. They also investigated the possible link between non-Markovian dynamics of physical pilot wave systems and nonlocality in quantum systems.

As a developer, Vishal maintains a GitHub presence where he has contributed to projects including "konnecthru" (a JavaScript project) and "Formalin_Predictions_in_Fruits" (a Python project). These repositories demonstrate his programming skills across different languages and domains.

At MIT, Vishal is continuing to build on his strong foundation in STEM fields, particularly in physics and quantum mechanics. His research experience and technical skills position him well for further exploration in quantum physics, computational modeling, and related fields that align with MIT's strengths in these areas.

suggested_people.name: Harshil Avlani
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Physics student at MIT with award-winning research in quantum computing. Former Research Intern at MIT's Quanta Group and Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab, focusing on quantum error characterization and quantum machine learning applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Harshil Avlani is a dual-major student in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), with an exceptional research background in quantum computing and physics. His academic journey showcases a consistent focus on quantum technologies and computational physics.

Currently, Harshil serves as a Research Intern with the Quanta Group at MIT's Research Laboratory of Electronics, where he applies his interdisciplinary knowledge to cutting-edge quantum research. Prior to this, he gained valuable experience as a Research Intern at Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab under Dr. Houlong Zhuang for over a year, developing expertise in quantum mechanical applications and quantum machine learning.

Harshil has achieved remarkable recognition for his research. His project "Analyzing the Effect of Mid-Circuit Measurement (MCM) on Spectator Qubits" earned him first place in the Systems Software category at the International Science Fair and qualified him as a finalist in the prestigious 2024 Regeneron Science Talent Search, where he received a $25,000 academic scholarship. This groundbreaking work identified a previously uncharacterized type of quantum error and revealed significant deficiencies in current quantum simulators.

His research portfolio includes collaborative work on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) for solving combinatorial optimization problems, documented in his GitHub repository. He has also worked with the Hauser Research Group at the University of Alabama, where he spent 9 months contributing to physics research projects, and gained experience in computer security at Arizona State University's SEFCOM Lab.

In 2022, Harshil participated in the MIT Beaver Works Summer Institute as a Quantum Software Student, further enhancing his skills in quantum computing applications. He has also co-founded the Quantum Beavers hackathon group, which tied for first place in the IBM Quantum Explorers Hackathon.

Harshil has already begun contributing to scientific literature, with a publication in Data in Brief journal on "Dataset on density functional theory investigation of ternary Heusler alloys" in February 2024. More recently, he has been exploring the intersection of quantum computing and transformer models in machine learning, with applications in mitigating misinformation through quantum-enhanced GAN architectures.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Harshil is an accomplished pianist and has a passion for aviation, being able to identify most major aircraft models by sight. His diverse research experiences across multiple institutions highlight his versatility and dedication to advancing the fields of quantum computing and physics through rigorous academic inquiry and practical applications.

suggested_people.name: Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla
suggested_people.short_description: A multilingual Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard with exceptional achievements in quantum computing and international physics competitions. Ricardo combines technical expertise with diplomatic skills, having led international relations organizations and conducted research spanning solid-state physics, ESG consulting, and quantum algorithm development across multiple languages.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla is a Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard University with a remarkable blend of technical expertise and international perspective. His academic journey is distinguished by significant achievements in quantum computing, where he serves as Vice President of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantum Computing Association (HUQCA) and won 2nd place at MIT's Quantum Computing Hackathon 2024, developing theoretical error bounds for quantum algorithms.

Ricardo's technical prowess extends beyond quantum computing to solid-state physics research, where he worked with 2D transition metal dichalcogenides and Van der Waals heterostructures under Professor Hongkun Park. His computational skills have been recognized through multiple hackathon victories, including Microsoft's Student Hackathon 2021 and CdCMx 2020, where he developed mathematical models for COVID-19 comorbidity analysis.

In the quantum computing field, Ricardo has demonstrated exceptional talent, helping to grow HUQCA to over 300 members. At the MIT Interdisciplinary Quantum Hackathon (iQuHACK), his team created an "experimental harness" that allowed them to run quantum simulations at scale and efficiently collect data, earning them second place. As Ricardo noted, "It's one thing to learn something in a classroom, and another to try to code one and see if it runs. That's different, and I think it adds an extra layer to fully mastering the concepts."

What sets Ricardo apart is his exceptional international background and linguistic abilities. Fluent in six languages (Spanish, English, French, Chinese, Russian, and German), he has leveraged these skills in various leadership roles. As Co-President of Harvard International Relations on Campus and in his work with the Harvard International Relations Council, he has bridged cultural divides and facilitated international dialogue. His language proficiency earned him first place in Harvard's Chinese Poetry Recitation Contest and supported his research for a Radcliffe Fellow's project on underground economies in Greater China.

Ricardo's professional experience spans diverse sectors, from ESG consulting at PwC China, where he spearheaded sustainable design strategies for LEED-certified real estate projects, to his upcoming role as a Business Analyst at Alibaba Group. During his internship at PwC Shanghai through the Harvard China Fund Student Internship Program, he significantly improved his professional Chinese language skills while working on technical projects. As Ricardo reflected, "My biggest achievement from this experience was the consolidation of my Chinese speaking, reading and writing skills at the professional level."

His commitment to diplomacy and international cooperation is evident in his work with the United Nations Information Center, where he led a conference commemorating the UN's 75th anniversary with 500+ Latin American students.

His academic excellence is further demonstrated by his impressive collection of medals from international physics competitions, including the International Physics Olympiad, European Physics Olympiad, and Mexican Physics Olympiad. Ricardo's multidisciplinary approach combines rigorous scientific training with global perspective, positioning him uniquely at the intersection of technology, diplomacy, and sustainable development.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

suggested_people.name: Pavan Jayasinha
suggested_people.short_description: Pavan Jayasinha is a versatile technologist specializing in the intersection of machine learning, quantum computing, and low-level systems engineering. Currently a student at the University of Waterloo, he has contributed to cutting-edge research and development at organizations like Modular, Extropic AI, and the Institute for Quantum Computing, with particular expertise in GPU kernel optimization, quantum generative models, and robotics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Pavan Jayasinha is a multifaceted technologist pursuing a Bachelor of Applied Science at the University of Waterloo with an impressive 4.0 GPA. His technical expertise spans several specialized domains, with particular focus on machine learning, robotics, quantum computing, and low-level kernel development.

Pavan's professional experience demonstrates remarkable versatility across cutting-edge fields. At Modular, he worked as an AI GPU Engineering Intern, developing GPU kernels in Mojo language, optimizing end-to-end pipelines, and implementing multi-GPU tensor parallelism from scratch. His work at Extropic involved building high-performance JAX codebases for analog simulation of probabilistic ML models on hardware, conducting over 1000 Bayesian hyperparameter sweeps, and creating a state-of-the-art JAX library for tensor network simulation of quantum circuits on CUDA GPUs.

In the quantum computing space, Pavan has made significant contributions. At the Institute for Quantum Computing, he researched methods to realize the Bose-Hubbard Hamiltonian through Rydberg neutral atoms and built large-scale physics simulations. As an IBM Qiskit Advocate, he authored a chapter on Quantum Generative Adversarial Networks for the Qiskit Textbook QML course and mentored at the Qiskit Global Summer School. His quantum expertise extended to Zapata Computing, where he investigated quantum generative models and developed Orquestra codebase for QGANs.

Pavan has also contributed significantly to open-source projects, becoming the largest non-Google contributor to TensorFlow Quantum by implementing Bazel build infrastructure and cuQuantum SDK GPU kernels for quantum circuit simulation on heterogeneous devices. His project work includes developing a hybrid quantum graph neural network for particle trajectory reconstruction, which placed in the top 5 at QHack 2022, and building a quantum portfolio optimization project that placed in the 95th percentile at QHack 2021.

Pavan's academic achievements include being a Masason Scholar, selected as part of the 6th generation cohort by SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's foundation that supports youth with exceptional talents. He has received the President's Research Award and maintained Dean's Honours List status. He has earned multiple certifications in quantum computing, including becoming an IBM Certified Associate Developer for Quantum Computation using Qiskit.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Pavan has diverse experiences including serving as a lifeguard for the City of Toronto and working as a dog walker, demonstrating his well-rounded character and work ethic. His unique combination of expertise in quantum computing, machine learning, and low-level systems engineering positions him as a promising innovator at the intersection of these transformative technologies.

suggested_people.name: Shaurya Agrawal
suggested_people.short_description: Shaurya Agrawal is a first-year student at MIT pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Physics. He is a promising young researcher with accomplishments in scientific research, having participated in prestigious programs like Research Science Institute (RSI) and the International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF).
suggested_people.long_description:
Shaurya Agrawal is a talented young scientist and researcher currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), class of 2028. Prior to MIT, he graduated from Stevenson High School in Lincolnshire, Illinois.

Shaurya has already built an impressive research portfolio at a young age, as evidenced by his participation in prestigious scientific programs. He was selected for the Research Science Institute (RSI) in 2023, an elite summer research program for high school students hosted at MIT. He also competed in the International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF) in both 2022 and 2024, one of the world's largest pre-college science competitions.

In 2023, Shaurya was recognized as a BioGENEius winner, suggesting his research excellence in biotechnology. He was also part of the ZFellows program in 2023, which supports young entrepreneurs and innovators.

It's important to note that Shaurya Agrawal (the MIT student) should not be confused with Dr. Shaurya Agarwal, who is an Associate Professor at the University of Central Florida specializing in civil engineering, smart cities, and transportation systems. The professor appears in the scraped website information but is a different individual with a similar name.

Based on his activity and interests on LinkedIn, Shaurya shows a keen interest in cutting-edge technologies including artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and computational physics. He has engaged with content related to advanced AI research, quantum technologies, and scientific breakthroughs, indicating his multidisciplinary approach to science and technology.

His background combining computer science and physics, along with his demonstrated excellence in research competitions, positions him as a promising young researcher at the intersection of computational methods and physical sciences. Shaurya appears to be particularly interested in the application of computational approaches to solve complex scientific problems.

name: yeabsera afework
short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with extensive game development experience. Co-founder of 646 Studios and former Software Engineer at Microsoft, specializing in user authentication systems and facial recognition technology. First-generation college student from Ethiopia with a passion for technology and community service.
long_description:
Yeabsera Afework is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with a diverse background spanning game development, software engineering, and entrepreneurship. As the co-founder of 646 Studios, Yeabsera has developed three successful video games that amassed over 200,000 community members and achieved 9,000+ concurrent players on release. This entrepreneurial venture led to contracts with major brands like Gen G and Crocs, where Yeabsera's work boosted concurrent players by 5,000+.

At Microsoft, Yeabsera worked as a Software Engineer designing the backend client for the company's first in-house user authentication system, leveraging facial recognition and AI-based liveness verification to enhance security protocols. The role also involved developing secure clients in C# and creating metric dashboards in KustoQL to help on-call engineers identify bugs and outages.

Yeabsera's game development expertise extends to RB Battles LLC, where they designed immersive 3D environments using Blender and Adobe Substance Painter, leading a team of 3D artists to create game elements that attracted over 100,000 concurrent players. Their implementation of efficient workflow strategies accelerated project completion by 20%.

Originally from Ethiopia, Yeabsera moved to Spokane, Washington at the age of 10 and attended All Saints Catholic School before graduating from Gonzaga Preparatory School. At Gonzaga Prep, Yeabsera was recognized as a Salutatorian, placing in the second-highest academic group in the graduating class. He was also a recipient of the Mike Shanks scholarship, which supported his education at Gonzaga Prep.

Yeabsera has been actively involved in community service through Gonzaga Prep's Knights of the Leash program, particularly providing after-school tutoring at his former elementary school, All Saints Catholic School. His AP calculus teacher, Stephen Manfred, described him as an outgoing student with a great personality who "brings joy to the people around him" and "interacts with his peers really well."

As a first-generation university student, Yeabsera is involved with ColorStack, a tech nonprofit that creates academic and professional opportunities for Black and Latinx students entering STEM fields. At Stanford, he benefits from programs designed to support first-generation, low-income (FLI) students in their transition to college life.

Academically, Yeabsera has taken courses in Computer Systems, Design and Analysis of Algorithms, Infrastructure at Scale, Mathematical Foundations of Computer Science, Operating System Principles, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Programming Abstractions and Methodologies at Stanford.

Yeabsera has also participated in selective development programs, including the HeadStart Fellowship for diverse students with outstanding leadership potential, and Jane Street's UNBOXED Scholar program, where they gained experience in quantitative trading through probability, statistics, and game theory challenges.

Currently, Yeabsera is set to join LinkedIn as a Software Engineer for Summer 2025, continuing to build on their impressive technical foundation and entrepreneurial spirit with the long-term goal of establishing a career in the tech industry.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Niya Ma
suggested_people.short_description: Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI with a strong background in hackathons, having won multiple awards and served as Director of Hack@Davidson. She graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics, and has experience in machine learning, automation, and full-stack development.
suggested_people.long_description:
Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI who graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics. Her technical journey showcases a diverse range of experiences across machine learning, software development, and leadership roles.

As the former Director of Hack@Davidson, Niya has deep roots in the hackathon community, both as an organizer and participant. Her impressive track record includes winning multiple hackathon awards, such as 2nd Place at the Twilio LLM Hackathon, Best project using Wolfram API at Stanford LLM x Law Hackathon, and awards for sustainability, security, and automation at various other competitions.

Niya's professional experience includes software engineering internships at major tech companies. At Oracle, she pioneered a Python script that accelerated network traffic simulation by 250x and engineered MySQL database and Grafana dashboard integration. At Qualtrics, she worked on the Developer Experience team, creating efficient updating mechanisms for services and making substantial open-source contributions to the Backstage project.

Her academic background includes coursework in Natural Language Processing, Concurrent & Parallel Computing, Deep Learning, Operating Systems, and Applied Cryptography. She also took CS229 - Machine Learning at Stanford University.

At Oracle, Niya has been working with OCI Landing Zones, contributing to enterprise cloud infrastructure deployment solutions. Her GitHub profile shows involvement with Oracle's cloud infrastructure projects, including forking and working with the oracle-enterprise-landingzone repository, which focuses on deploying typical architecture used by enterprise customers in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.

Beyond technical skills, Niya demonstrated leadership as President of the Association For Women In Mathematics at Davidson College and was involved in campus activities including Davidson Chorale and the Residence Life Office. She is bilingual in English and Mandarin, adding a multicultural dimension to her skill set.

Niya's combination of technical expertise, leadership experience, and hackathon success positions her as a versatile software engineer with particular strengths in machine learning applications, cloud infrastructure, and automation.

suggested_people.name: Olsen B.
suggested_people.short_description: Software Engineer at Affirm and MLH Top 50 recipient with expertise in workflow orchestration infrastructure and LLMs. Founded Hack@Davidson, Davidson College's first student-led hackathon, and has won multiple hackathon awards including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech. Currently consulting for Cognition to help improve Devin AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Olsen B. (Oğuzhan Budanur) is a Software Engineer at Affirm working on the Workflow Orchestration Infrastructure Team, where he manages distributed systems integrating Airflow, Luigi, Spark, and Kubernetes that handle over 1,000,000 actions monthly. He developed a high-performance gRPC server in Kotlin and built a Slack bot leveraging semantic search and LLMs for efficient triage.

With a strong entrepreneurial spirit, Olsen founded and served as President of Hack@Davidson, organizing Davidson College's first student-led hackathon that raised over $6,000 and accommodated 90+ participants. His leadership extended to founding Competitive Coding at Davidson (C-CAD), which prepares members for software engineering jobs and internships. Under his guidance, the team won 11 prizes across 7 hackathons, including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech.

Olsen's professional experience includes working as a Software Consultant for Cognition AI Labs, helping to improve Devin AI, and founding Motate LLC, a boutique software contracting firm that secured multiple contracts and achieved quarterly revenue of ~$20,000. He also interned at Aptos Labs, where he created a 7,000-line open-source Python CLI for Kubernetes deployments that saved $70,000 through multithreading optimizations.

His technical expertise spans workflow orchestration, distributed systems, Kubernetes, Python, Kotlin, Java, C++, Firebase, and LLMs. Olsen is particularly passionate about building AI-powered tools, as demonstrated by his work on semantic search systems and LLM applications. He's recognized as part of the MLH Top 50 and has received multiple academic scholarships and hackathon awards, including wins for projects like WaitFree DMV, ImmiGrace, SusEats, BlockAide, and CodeViolet.

Olsen grew up in the DC Metro Area and discovered his passion for coding in middle school, starting with VisualBasic's GUI-based desktop apps. His love for technology was truly ignited at his first hackathon, VTHacks 7, in 2019. He studied Computer Science at Davidson College after transferring from Virginia Tech, where he was pursuing a double major in Computer Science and Computational Modeling & Data Analytics. He maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA in his major courses and served as a Teaching Assistant for a Blockchains class at Davidson College.

Beyond his technical work, Olsen enjoys exploring new technologies, participating in hackathons, and building innovative projects. His personal website at olsenbudanur.com showcases his portfolio of work and technical achievements.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

name: vijaykaarti sundarapandiyan
short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at UMD with diverse expertise in computer vision, high-performance computing, and quantitative finance. Currently researching LLMs under Dr. Tom Goldstein while interning at Scale AI for code reasoning models. Published work on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models at ICLR 2023.
long_description:
Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan is a Computer Science and Mathematics double major at the University of Maryland with a multifaceted background in AI research and software engineering. His technical interests span computer vision, concurrent and high-performance computing, networks, quantitative finance, and large model efficiency.

Currently, Vijaykaarti serves as a Technical Advisor Intern at Scale AI, where he works on code reasoning models for Olympiad-level competitive programming problems. Simultaneously, he conducts research on Large Language Models under Dr. Tom Goldstein at UMD. His research contributions include a notable paper on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models, recognized as a Notable TinyPaper at ICLR 2023, which has been cited 13 times since publication.

Vijaykaarti's professional experience is extensive for a student. He completed a software engineering internship at Uber, focusing on networking infrastructure with Envoy proxy. He also worked as a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory and at NonExomics, where he developed deep learning models for cancer prediction over a two-year period.

Within the UMD community, Vijaykaarti serves as Senior Quantitative Analyst and Lead Architect for the Smith Investment Fund's automated trading platform. He previously conducted computer vision research under Dr. Jia-Bin Huang. He has also contributed to social impact initiatives as a Software Engineer at Hack4Impact, developing web applications for nonprofit organizations.

His technical prowess is further evidenced by his competitive programming achievements, including participation in the ICPC NA South Division 2024 as part of the UMD GOATS team alongside Mazin Karjikar and Spencer Lutz. He has also competed at the ICPC Mid-Atlantic Regionals, where he previously placed 7th.

Beyond technical skills, Vijaykaarti is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Tamil, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. His academic excellence is reflected in his numerous accolades, including being a Presidential Scholar Candidate, National Merit Finalist, and recipient of the UKG Global Scholarship. His community engagement is demonstrated through his Eagle Scout achievement and multiple Silver President's Volunteer Service Awards for significant community service hours.

suggested_people.name: Aaquib Syed
suggested_people.short_description: AI researcher at Google with a focus on interpretability and language model behavior. Aaquib has published significant work on refusal mechanisms in LLMs, attribution patching for circuit discovery, and efficient pruning techniques for massive language models. A Banneker-Key Scholar at the University of Maryland with a strong competitive programming background.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aaquib Syed is an AI researcher currently working at Google while affiliated with the University of Maryland, where he is pursuing a CS and Math degree as a Banneker-Key Scholar (full merit scholarship for the top 0.5% of incoming class). His research focuses on understanding and improving large language models, with particular emphasis on interpretability and model behavior mechanisms.

His recent publication "Refusal in Language Models Is Mediated by a Single Direction" (NeurIPS 2024, Poster) has garnered significant attention with 98+ citations. This groundbreaking work demonstrates that refusal behavior in conversational LLMs is controlled by a one-dimensional subspace across multiple open-source chat models, providing important insights into how safety mechanisms function in these systems.

Aaquib has also made significant contributions to automated interpretability research with his work "Attribution Patching Outperforms Automated Circuit Discovery" (BlackboxNLP at EMNLP 2024), which has received 47+ citations. In this paper, he developed a simple yet powerful method based on attribution patching that outperforms existing approaches while requiring minimal computational resources - just two forward passes and a backward pass.

In the area of model efficiency, his research "Prune and Tune: Improving Efficient Pruning Techniques for Massive Language Models" (ICLR TinyPapers Workshop 2023, top 6%) advanced techniques for pruning large language models without extensive retraining, addressing critical compute expense issues in deploying massive models.

His most recent work includes "Mechanistic Unlearning: Robust Knowledge Unlearning and Editing via Mechanistic Localization" (2024), exploring techniques for targeted knowledge editing in language models.

Beyond pure AI research, Aaquib has applied machine learning to medical imaging, co-authoring a paper in PLOS ONE that uses XGBoost with MRI and non-imaging data to predict pathological complete response in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

As a student, Aaquib has received numerous prestigious recognitions, including the USA Computing Olympiad Gold rank and the National Merit Scholarship. He has also developed several projects including a Personal Distance Monitor, a Stress Level Manager for students with autism spectrum disorder, and a FIRST Robotics Competition Scouting system.

According to his GitHub profile, Aaquib describes himself as someone who enjoys "thinking about and solving problems in AI/ML and finance" with a current interest in "creating scalable methods to attribute and edit behaviors and knowledge in large language models." He also mentions a love for competitive programming, working with low-level languages, and creating infrastructure and trading strategies for financial markets.

His interests span AI/ML and finance, with a particular focus on solving complex problems at the intersection of these fields. Aaquib's combination of theoretical research and practical applications demonstrates his versatility and depth of expertise in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Bill Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Yale '26 computer science student in the BS/MS program with a background in competitive programming and mathematics. Currently researching LLMs and code generation, with experience in systems and machine learning. Incoming Software Engineering Intern at Citadel Securities with previous roles at The New York Times and Yale's Gerstein Laboratory. Also serves as Chairman of Cypher Capital, a prominent multi-strategy crypto investment firm.
suggested_people.long_description:
Bill Qian is a computer science student at Yale University (Class of 2026) pursuing a combined BS/MS degree. His technical foundation stems from competitive programming (USACO/ICPC) and mathematics (USAMO/Putnam), which has evolved into expertise in systems, machine learning, and full-stack development.

At Yale's Gerstein Laboratory, Bill has established himself as a researcher in Large Language Models and code generation, publishing multiple papers in natural language processing. His research contributions include work on "ToolLLM: Facilitating Large Language Models to Master 16000+ Real-world APIs" and "BioCoder: A Benchmark for Bioinformatics Code Generation with Contextual Pragmatic Knowledge." He has collaborated with researchers from prominent organizations including Google DeepMind.

Bill's professional experience spans diverse environments. He's secured an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Citadel Securities (New York) focusing on high-performance C++. Previously, he worked at The New York Times on their Research and Development team, exploring ethical applications of AI and LLMs in journalism.
