At DeepMedia, he designed and optimized algorithms for heterogeneous data analysis, creating a machine translation model with 10% better performance than competitors using Transformers, Python, PyTorch, and Rust.

His technical versatility extends to infrastructure development, having designed distributed computing systems using AWS, Azure, and on-premise hardware with Docker, Kubernetes, and SQS. At Thomas Ho Company, he applied neural networks to assess mortgage loan pricing models and implemented ETL pipelines that improved data processing efficiency by 30%.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Bill is actively involved in campus life as a Project Manager at the Student Technology Collaborative, where he manages knowledge base development and provides technical support across multiple operating systems. He balances his technical interests with creative outlets, singing with the Yale Glee Club and making short films.

In parallel to his academic career, Bill serves as the Chairman of Cypher Capital, a leading multi-strategy crypto investment firm based in the UAE. Before joining Cypher Capital in 2022, he was the Global Head of Fundraising, Binance Labs, and M&A for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency platform. Prior to that, he was Head of Investment for Fintech and Technology at JD.com, a leading Asian internet platform generating over $400 billion in annual gross merchandise volume.

Throughout his career in the blockchain and cryptocurrency sectors, Bill has deployed and managed over $30 billion in investments across AI, cryptocurrency, and fintech. He has successfully invested in prominent blockchain projects including Solana, Mysten Labs (Sui), Ton, Sei, and Bouncebit. He also serves on the board of the TON Foundation and is Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer of Phoenix Group (ADX: PHX), the first cryptocurrency company to go public in the Middle East.

Bill holds a Bachelor of Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, an MSc in Finance from Nanyang Technological University, and an MBA from the University of Toronto. He is also an executive committee member of the Hillhouse Value Investing Institution.

His unique combination of deep technical expertise in computer science, extensive experience in blockchain investment, and leadership in the cryptocurrency industry positions him as a multifaceted contributor across both academic and professional domains.

name: jalen xing
short_description: Venture Fellow at General Catalyst with a strong technical background in AI and software engineering. UC Berkeley EECS graduate with experience at Meta, Capital One, and AWS, specializing in semantic search, large language models, and machine learning image classification.
long_description:
Jalen Xing is a Venture Fellow at General Catalyst, where he focuses on scouting and investing in promising student startups. With a solid foundation in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from UC Berkeley, Jalen has built an impressive technical background through various software engineering roles at leading tech companies.

His professional experience includes working at Meta on Facebook Search's Vertical Ranking team, developing semantic search and large language model applications at Capital One, and implementing machine learning image classification and search solutions at Amazon Web Services (AWS). He also gained experience in compliance and equity technology during his time at Balyasny Asset Management.

Jalen's academic credentials include a Master's degree from UC Berkeley with an exceptional 3.95/4.00 GPA, where he was involved with Codebase and received the Fung Excellence Scholarship. Prior to Berkeley, he completed his Bachelor of Science at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign with a near-perfect 3.98/4.00 GPA, where he also worked as a Research Assistant under Professor Bao.

His unique combination of technical expertise in AI, particularly in semantic search and large language models, along with his current focus on venture capital, positions him at the intersection of cutting-edge technology and investment. Jalen actively seeks connections with student entrepreneurs and innovators, offering his expertise to help them build and grow their startups.

Note: The scraped website information appears to reference different individuals with similar surnames (Xing Wu, Galen Xing, and Xin Xing) who are not related to Jalen Xing. These individuals have different academic and professional backgrounds, including positions at Berkeley in integrative biology, computational biology, and mathematics/quantum chemistry research.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tan
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tan is a Stanford University alumnus and entrepreneur focused on democratizing career growth. With a strong background in computer science and data science from UC Berkeley, he has conducted research in stock market prediction using sentiment analysis and has been recognized with numerous academic honors including Phi Beta Kappa and the EECS Honors Program.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tan is an accomplished technologist and entrepreneur currently associated with Humans and Stanford University. He's working on democratizing access to career growth through his venture joinnova.co.

Andrew has an impressive academic background, having graduated from UC Berkeley where he was part of the EECS Honors Program and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa as a junior (top 20 students in his class). During his time at Berkeley, he excelled as a student instructor in the Data Science Department, earning recognition as an Outstanding Student Instructor.

His research interests include applying AI to financial markets, as evidenced by his publication "Sentiment Predictability for Stocks" where he explored stock market prediction using textual sentiment analysis tools and advanced prediction models like LSTMs and convolutional architectures.

Andrew has a strong entrepreneurial spirit, having been selected for the Pear VC Summer Fellowship which provided seed investment for his early-stage startup. He was also named a Jack Larson Scholar at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business, receiving a scholarship to pursue entrepreneurship in technology and research.

His technical talents were recognized early, being one of only 11 students nationwide awarded the Snap Research Scholarship for his academic performance, research experience, and ability to solve tough technical challenges. Before college, Andrew was the Salutatorian of his high school class and achieved success in both mathematics competitions (qualifying for AIME four times) and business competitions (placing 2nd at the DECA International Competition).

Andrew is bilingual, with native English proficiency and professional working proficiency in Chinese, adding to his versatile skill set that spans technology, research, and entrepreneurship.

It's important to note that there is another prominent Andrew Tan who is a Filipino billionaire businessman. This Andrew Tan is the chairman of Alliance Global Group, Inc., a major conglomerate with interests in real estate, food and beverage, gaming, and hospitality. Born in Fujian, China, he moved to Hong Kong at age 4 and later to the Philippines as a teenager. He graduated with a degree in accounting from the University of the East in Manila and built his fortune developing large apartment complexes around Manila. His company Megaworld Corporation pioneered the "live-work-play" concept in township development, and he also runs Emperador, the world's largest brandy company by sales volume. As of 2024, his net worth is estimated at $1.5 billion. This is a different individual from the Andrew Tan described in the main profile.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Rez Havaei
suggested_people.short_description: Rez Havaei is the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis (YC S24), a startup developing automated AI safety and red-teaming tools. With expertise in AI research and quantitative trading, his career includes roles at Cohere, NVIDIA, Jane Street, and as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rez Havaei is an accomplished entrepreneur and AI specialist currently serving as the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis, a Y Combinator-backed startup (S24 batch) focused on AI safety and evaluation. The company provides a comprehensive suite of tools for identifying and addressing vulnerabilities in AI systems, including red-teaming frameworks and interpretability techniques.

General Analysis was founded in 2024 and is based in San Francisco. The company's mission is to address the growing risks associated with deploying increasingly capable AI systems in high-stakes environments. Their approach involves developing automated tools that systematically find model failure modes and enhance model robustness, delivering detailed safety and performance reports to customers.

One of their notable projects demonstrated how GPT-4o is susceptible to hallucinating when asked about legal cases or concepts. Their research showed they could train an attacker model that caused GPT-4o to hallucinate on more than 35% of prompts related to legal questions.

Before founding General Analysis, Rez worked as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform and benchmark. This startup, co-founded by Stanford AI students, aimed to create a standardized test for measuring artificial intelligence and large language models, providing an unbiased, third-party review system.

Rez's professional experience spans both AI research and finance. He has worked as an Applied Research Intern in Deep Learning at Snap Inc., a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Cohere (a leading AI company developing large language models), and held an Applied Research position in Artificial Intelligence at NVIDIA. His finance background includes quantitative trading internships at prestigious firms like Jane Street and Susquehanna International Group (SIG).

His academic research experience includes positions at the USC Information Sciences Institute and as a Research Assistant at UC Davis, where he also served as a Teaching Assistant. Rez earned a Bachelor of Science in Engineering from the University of California, Davis (2018-2023), maintaining a 3.97 GPA.

Rez is also involved in another venture called Kart AI, which serves as an interactive search platform that simplifies research for electronic products. The platform extracts relevant recommendations from Reddit, YouTube, and trusted content creators to help users find and compare electronic products.

His technical interests and expertise span AI safety, interpretability, evaluation, deep learning, and statistical inference. Rez's career trajectory demonstrates his commitment to addressing the challenges of AI safety and evaluation while building practical tools that can help organizations deploy AI systems more responsibly.

suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. suggested_people.name: Arihant Choudhary
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley with extensive research experience across AI, cryptography, and computational game theory. Currently working as a Software Intern at Intel and Lead Undergraduate Researcher at UC Berkeley, focusing on multi-agent systems, AI applications, and CS education.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arihant Choudhary is a multifaceted Computer Science, Data Science, and Applied Mathematics student at UC Berkeley with a remarkable research portfolio spanning diverse technical domains. His research journey includes work at Stanford University on multi-agent systems for inference, reasoning, and planning, as well as climate data analysis using CMIP-6 models.

At UC Berkeley, Arihant has made significant contributions across multiple research labs. He serves as a Lead Undergraduate Researcher in two labs under Prof. Dan Garcia - the Computational Game Theory Lab (GamesCrafters) and the CS Education Lab (ACE Lab). In the ACE Lab, he authored papers on dynamic animated feedback for randomized graph problems (accepted at SIGCSE 2024) and co-authored work on personalized reminders for mastery learning (AutoRemind, accepted at SIGCSE 2025). His work in the Computational Game Theory Lab involved developing solvers for games like Quick Cross and Euclid's Game, researching pure draw theory, and creating human-robot interaction systems.

Professionally, Arihant is currently working as a Software Intern at Intel Corporation, implementing cutting-edge research and building products for Intel Foundry. His previous role as a Research Intern at Intel focused on text-to-video research and building Intel's Personal Educator (IPED) using large language models and text-to-speech libraries to support employee training. He also serves as a Dean's Engineering Ambassador at UC Berkeley's College of Engineering, working on programs for high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.

Arihant's journey to UC Berkeley is particularly inspiring. After being rejected from all colleges in his first application cycle, he took a gap year in 2020 and pursued multiple projects, including a significant climate change research project through Polygence. Working with his mentor Tristan Ballard, a Stanford PhD in earth systems science, Arihant analyzed a petabyte of climate data to study monsoons in Kolkata and assess climate change impacts on agriculture. This experience not only built his technical skills but also helped him secure admission to UC Berkeley on his second attempt.

Arihant's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Berkeley Social, a platform he developed to help incoming UC Berkeley students connect with peers sharing similar interests. He also co-founded Yindu & Zhongguo Inc, which included the Bangla Machinery Bank, an AgriTech enterprise providing efficient farm machinery to farmers in West Bengal.

His academic pursuits extend beyond UC Berkeley, with coursework at Stanford University in CS224G: Apps with LLMs Inside. Arihant's technical expertise spans AI, machine learning, cryptography, and data science, complemented by his multilingual proficiency in English, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, and Marwari.

Through his diverse experiences in research, entrepreneurship, and community service, Arihant demonstrates a commitment to leveraging technology for social impact and educational advancement. Expected to graduate in Spring 2025, he is now interested in pursuing a graduate degree and a career in artificial intelligence/machine learning.

name: ernesto nam
short_description: Ernesto Nam is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, currently building at 11x. With a multilingual background spanning Spanish, English, Korean, and Portuguese, he founded ENGLOBAR PY to address social issues in Latin America and was recognized as a 2020 Straubel Impact Leader. He serves as IFC Vice President of Membership at Stanford and previously gained professional experience at Amazon, Hashdex, and other tech companies during his two gap years.
long_description:
Ernesto Nam is a Computer Science junior at Stanford University with a focus on Artificial Intelligence. Currently, he's building at 11x, an agentic AI company. His professional journey is marked by diverse experiences across technology and entrepreneurship in both Latin America and the United States.

Before starting his university education, Ernesto took two gap years to gain professional experience, working as a Software Engineering Intern at Amazon (Alexa team) and Hashdex, a cryptocurrency investment firm. His entrepreneurial spirit led him to found ENGLOBAR PY, a non-profit organization that seeks to relieve poverty by empowering youth volunteers to engage and contribute to communities in need. Englobar operates in Paraguay and Mexico with over 250 volunteers, offering lessons in math, environmental sciences, and leadership development.

The inspiration for Englobar came during a challenging period in Ernesto's life when his family faced economic difficulties. While volunteering with TECHO (a "Habitat for Humanity" type foundation), he led a housing construction project as the first teenager to lead a build primarily of college students. This experience gave him perspective on helping those less fortunate and became his "true north" for social impact work.

Ernesto's background is impressively international and multilingual, with fluency in Spanish (native), English, Korean, and Portuguese at professional levels. This multicultural perspective has informed his work across borders, including roles at Cloud Humans for business development, content creation at Tract, and consulting for IDB Lab.

At Stanford, Ernesto serves as the IFC Vice President of Membership and has worked on various projects including Blank (a social reading app), AI Deck (a presentation about generative AI for executives in Brazil), Jobi (LinkedIn for blue-collar workers in Latin America), and Edus (cohort-based courses as a new type of university).

His educational journey includes not only Stanford but also participation in Latitud's LF3 program and the Latin American Leadership Academy, where he was an Inaugural Academy Alum and Brazil Leadership Bootcamp participant. Ernesto has also demonstrated exceptional mathematical aptitude, winning multiple medals in National Math Olympiads, including two gold medals and being a nine-time Alto Parana Department Champion.

In 2020, Ernesto was recognized as a Straubel Impact Leader for his work with Englobar, joining a cohort of young leaders developing sustainable solutions to environmental and societal challenges. His diverse background spanning technology, entrepreneurship, education, and social impact positions him uniquely at the intersection of AI innovation and cross-cultural leadership.

suggested_people.name: Thomaz Felipe Bonato
suggested_people.short_description: Brazilian AI researcher and entrepreneur studying at USC as a Trustee Scholar. Thomaz has excelled in hackathons, winning first place at HackMIT and second place at PennApps in 2024, while conducting AI research at USC Marshall School of Business focusing on educational applications and LLMs.
suggested_people.long_description:
Thomaz Felipe Bonato is a passionate engineer, researcher, and lifelong learner from Brazil currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence for Business at the University of Southern California as a prestigious Trustee Scholar with full tuition. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his National Merit Finalist status.

Thomaz has established himself as an exceptional hackathon competitor, securing first place at HackMIT 2024 with PalmLabs (focused on education) and second place at PennApps 2024 with Cypress MFA (addressing security and privacy challenges). He also won first place with Azalea, an eco-friendly AI model selector, demonstrating his commitment to sustainable AI solutions.

His professional experience spans multiple domains within AI and business. As an AI Research Assistant at USC Marshall School of Business since December 2023, he initially explored AI applications in education and has since expanded to researching LLMs and cluster-based probing techniques. Thomaz has entrepreneurial experience as a founder of a stealth startup focused on AI solutions for law firms, and currently serves as a Data Science Intern at Trudy and a Growth Strategist at Mercor.

Within the USC community, Thomaz has taken on leadership roles as the Director of Founder's Education at SEP (Student Entrepreneurship Program) and previously served as Director of External Relations for USC Business Technology Group. He was also a Student Founder at SEP, demonstrating his commitment to entrepreneurship education.

Thomaz is multilingual, with native proficiency in Portuguese and English, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. He is also a Management Leadership Tomorrow (MLT) Fellow, indicating his commitment to leadership development. His technical skills are evidenced by certifications in Linear Algebra for Machine Learning and Neural Networks and Deep Learning from DeepLearning.AI, as well as UX design skills certified by LinkedIn.

His contribution to policy is demonstrated through his publication "A Blueprint for Greece's AI Transformation" for the Special Secretariat for Foresight, Presidency of the Government, Hellenic Republic, showing his interest in AI governance and national strategy development.

It's important to note that there is another Thomaz Bonato who has had a distinguished career in the pharmaceutical industry, serving in various executive roles at AstraZeneca and Alexion. This Thomaz Bonato has held positions including US Chief Financial Officer and Vice President of Finance at AstraZeneca, Interim Country President of AstraZeneca Australia and New Zealand, and most recently as Global Head of Research Development & Medical Finance at Alexion. His career has included significant financial leadership roles across multiple countries including Brazil, Costa Rica, Australia, and the United States. However, this is a different individual than the USC student and AI researcher profiled here.

suggested_people.name: Arjun Banerjee
suggested_people.short_description: UC Berkeley student, Head of Education at Launchpad, and Industrial Relations Officer at HKN. Founder and CEO of Kids Teach Tech, a non-profit organization teaching technology to underserved youth.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arjun Banerjee is a student at UC Berkeley with extensive involvement in technology education and leadership. He serves as the Head of Education at Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on intelligent software and artificial intelligence, and as an Industrial Relations Officer at Eta Kappa Nu (HKN), the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science honor society.

Most notably, Arjun is the founder and CEO of Kids Teach Tech (KTT), a non-profit organization he started at the age of 10. Under his leadership, KTT has built a team of over 250 youth educators who have taught technology, programming, and AI to more than 8,000 students, primarily from underserved communities in the San Francisco Bay Area. The organization follows a "teach it forward" model, where students become teachers and leaders in their communities.

Arjun has established significant partnerships for KTT with UC Berkeley's IEOR Department, Georgia Tech, and the Urban League of Greater San Francisco Bay Area. Together they deliver the Seth Bonder Summer Program in Computational and Data Science for Engineering, which provides underserved youth with education in computer programming, data science, optimization, artificial intelligence, and computational biology.

His technical expertise spans multiple programming languages, with particular proficiency in Python and C#. Beyond his work with KTT, Arjun has contributed to data visualization projects, including the Ten Strands/CAELI Data Project which won the Fall 2022 Data Visualization Award at UC Berkeley. This project focused on understanding environmental literacy education in California K-12 schools.

Arjun also has experience as a Research Assistant at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, where he developed an interactive archive of declassified documents from the Intelligence Community. His diverse interests extend to national and international policy, philosophy, poetry, and quantum physics.

suggested_people.name: Tony Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, with a diverse portfolio spanning tech, venture capital, and public interest technology. He has research experience at Stanford AI Lab and Harvard Medical School, and has worked with companies like Amazon and Microsoft.
suggested_people.long_description:
Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University focusing on Artificial Intelligence. His professional experience spans multiple domains including venture capital, public interest technology, and software engineering.

At Stanford, Tony has taken on leadership roles as the Freshman Council President, where he managed $35,500 for over 1,700 students. He's also involved with TreeHacks as an Alumni Director and serves as the ACM ProCo Director.

Tony's venture capital experience includes positions as a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, a Scout at Soma Capital, and a Founder Fellow at RippleX Fellowship. His interest in public policy is evident through his work as a Fellow at Paragon Policy Fellowship and as a Co-Founder of the Public Interest Technology Lab at Stanford University, where he led the inaugural student govtech fellowship program.

His technical experience includes a software engineering internship at Amazon, contracting work for Swim England and Hypelist, and research at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) where he worked on deep learning to predict transcription factor binding motifs. He also conducted research at Harvard Medical School under the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Boston Children's Hospital.

Tony has received several prestigious recognitions, including being a Rise Fellow at Schmidt Futures, where he completed a fully-funded summer intensive in London/Oxford and founded the Rise North America Union. During his high school years at Amador Valley High School, he was the Salutatorian, a Coca-Cola Scholar, a National Merit Scholar, won two gold medals with Kungfu Team USA, and was an ISEF Finalist.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Tony has demonstrated a commitment to community service as the Founder and President of the Alameda County Science and Engineering Fair and as a Teaching Facilitator for Non-Trivial.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

name: ronak malik
short_description: Ronak Malik is a Computer Science student at Harvard University with impressive aerospace industry experience, including roles at SpaceX and NASA. He specializes in avionics software engineering and machine learning frameworks, having contributed to rocket engineering projects and remote inspection systems. He's also active in Harvard's Ultimate Frisbee community as a team captain.
long_description:
Ronak Malik is a Computer Science student at Harvard University (2021-2025) with a remarkable trajectory in aerospace and software engineering. His professional experience spans prestigious organizations, beginning with his role as a HUNCH Developer at NASA (2018-2020), where he developed a remote inspection system for a 4-axis Sherline mill with an HD inspection camera that allowed engineers to conduct inspections without visiting manufacturing facilities.

His aerospace expertise expanded through his three-year tenure (2021-2024) as an Avionics Software Responsible Engineer at the Texas Rocket Engineering Lab, followed by a Starship Software Internship at SpaceX in Hawthorne, California (May-August 2023). This diverse experience in rocket engineering systems demonstrates his specialized skills in avionics software.

Ronak has also ventured into other technical domains, working as a Machine Learning Frameworks Intern at AMD in Austin (Summer 2022) and as a Software Engineering Intern at Houston Radar LLC (Summer 2021). Currently, he serves as a Software Engineer at Altitude (since June 2024).

Beyond his professional endeavors, Ronak is deeply involved in Harvard's Ultimate Frisbee community, serving as a captain for both the Red Line and Bred Line teams. His leadership in this sport demonstrates his teamwork and organizational abilities outside of technical contexts.

As a software developer, Ronak maintains an active GitHub presence (BeyondPerception) where he showcases projects including a highly reliable relay server called BounceServer, a GPS simulator with Qt frontend, and various collaborative academic projects. His GitHub profile describes him as "passionate about computers, operating systems, networking, food, and interesting things." He has earned several GitHub achievements including Pair Extraordinaire, Arctic Code Vault Contributor, and Pull Shark.

Ronak also participated in the inaugural Harvard Match Poker Championships, where his team placed third, highlighting his strategic thinking abilities in competitive environments.

His technical foundation is further strengthened by certifications in computer architecture, having completed both parts of the "Build a Modern Computer from First Principles: Nand to Tetris" course series through Coursera in 2018. This combination of aerospace software engineering experience, machine learning knowledge, and fundamental computer science education positions Ronak as a versatile technologist with particular strength in aerospace software systems.

suggested_people.name: Porvesh Balasubramanian
suggested_people.short_description: Porvesh is a fourth-year Computer Science student at the University of Michigan with a unique blend of expertise in systems engineering, robotics, and distributed computing. As a Founding Engineer at Bronco AI, he's developing AI agents for chip design and verification while simultaneously contributing to autonomous vehicle research and distributed systems validation.
suggested_people.long_description:
Porvesh Balasubramanian is a fourth-year Computer Science student at the University of Michigan who has carved out a distinctive path at the intersection of systems engineering, robotics, and AI. Currently serving as a Founding Engineer at Bronco AI, he's building cutting-edge AI agents for chip design and verification.

His technical versatility is evident through his diverse research experiences. At Michigan's Real Time Computing Lab, Porvesh built and raced F1Tenth autonomous vehicles, demonstrating his hands-on skills in robotics. Simultaneously, he contributed to OrderLab's distributed systems research, working on OathKeeper—a tool that validates distributed systems by detecting and enforcing semantic rules at runtime.

Porvesh's industry experience includes a role as a Mission System Software Intern at Northrop Grumman, where he automated boot image generation, reducing processing time from 5 weeks to just 3 minutes. He's also worked as a Software Intern at DealsPlus, implementing a Flask-based backend and enhancing user experience with the Quasar Framework.

His academic contributions extend beyond research. Porvesh serves as a grader for advanced courses like Embedded Systems and Advanced Data Structures, and works as an Engineering Center Tutor providing one-on-one assistance for upper-level EECS classes. Previously, he led study groups for introductory data structures and algorithms courses.

Porvesh's technical foundation is complemented by a strong educational background, with coursework spanning algorithms, computer architecture, embedded systems, operating systems, robotics, and deep learning. He's consistently maintained a 3.8/4.0 GPA, earning a place on the Dean's Honor List every semester.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Porvesh has demonstrated leadership through various roles, including as part of the "Cyber Safety Team" at the University of Michigan's Barger Leadership Institute, where he created a resource guide about cybersecurity for students. He's also an active developer with several GitHub repositories, including a personal game engine called "EnfieldEngine" written in C++ and contributions to real-time object detection for autonomous driving using deep learning.

Porvesh is also an accomplished cricket player, representing the University of Michigan in various tournaments including CACTUS 2024 and playing for teams like Detroit Challengers CC and Chicago Panthers. As an all-rounder, he has demonstrated skills in both batting and bowling across multiple T20 matches.

In 2022, he was part of a team that developed "Freshify," an application that uses artificial intelligence to track food expiration dates and provide tailored recipe recommendations, showcasing his interest in practical AI applications. His diverse interests and technical skills make him a versatile computer scientist with experience spanning from embedded systems to artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Collin Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara with a minor in Mathematics, maintaining a 3.95 GPA. Currently serving as President of Alpha Kappa Psi. Collin has diverse software engineering experience across multiple industries, including Databricks, Amazon, Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory, and Intuitive. He excels in hackathons, having won first place in three competitive events.
suggested_people.long_description:
Collin Qian is a high-achieving fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara, complementing his technical studies with a minor in Mathematics. With an impressive 3.95/4.0 GPA and High Honors recognition, he demonstrates exceptional academic aptitude. His coursework includes Data Structures and Algorithms, Discrete Mathematics, Algorithms Engineering, Machine Learning, Object Oriented Design and Implementation, Computer Organization and Logic Design, Intelligent and Interactive Systems, Intro to Computational Science, Vector Calculus, Linear Algebra, and Differential Equations.

Collin has built a diverse portfolio of software engineering experience across multiple industries. He is currently at Databricks and is set to join their Multi Cloud Efficiency Team as a Software Engineer Intern in summer 2024. At Amazon, he implemented the Smart Home Widget using Alexa Presentation Language for an in-vehicle infotainment product, programmed the Weather Forecast APL Card feature for the Weather Widget leveraging APL Skill Connections, and produced a C++ Native App utilizing Yocto SDK for Widget rendering, improving rendering performance by 25%. He also contributed to 10+ code reviews, resulting in a 15% reduction in code defects. His previous experience includes working at Amazon's Smart Vehicles Team, contributing to marine conservation technology at the Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory on the WhaleSafe and SharkEye Projects, developing test automation at Rocket Lawyer, and supporting telepresence technology at Intuitive, a leader in surgical robotics.

Beyond his professional experience, Collin has demonstrated exceptional project development skills through hackathon competitions. He won first place at SB Hacks XI with SnapSell, a solution that automates the Facebook Marketplace selling process. He also secured first place in the 2024 Jumpstart Designathon, creating a wireframe for neurodivergent users to manage food waste, competing at the Intermediate+ level. Additionally, he won the Spring 2022 Blockchain Project Series, earning $3,750 for developing a web forum that incorporated cryptocurrency bounties for questions.

Collin is actively involved in campus leadership as the President of Alpha Kappa Psi, having previously served as VP of Internal Affairs, VP of Alumni Relations, and Philanthropy Director. He joined the fraternity during his freshman year and values the community of "intelligent and lively individuals" it has provided him.

Originally from Cupertino, CA, Collin's educational background includes international experience, having attended Shanghai High School International Division before completing his high school education at Monta Vista High School. He aspires to work in tech and possibly found his own company one day. In his free time, he enjoys playing sports like tennis, pickleball, volleyball, basketball, rock climbing, and weightlifting, as well as cooking new recipes.

Collin is an active GitHub user (CollinQ) with 12 followers and has contributed to numerous repositories, including projects for hackathons and university coursework. His combination of strong academic performance, diverse technical internships, leadership experience, and proven ability to develop innovative solutions in competitive environments positions him as a promising talent in the computer science field.

suggested_people.name: Anirudh Kotamraju
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

suggested_people.name: Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu
suggested_people.short_description: Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with diverse experience spanning aerospace, hardware engineering, and venture capital. Currently serving as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working at Amazon on ML quantization for embedded hardware and contributing to research at Stanford's PinCS Lab.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu is an Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University (2023-2027) with a remarkable breadth of technical and business experience. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, with a particular focus on the intersection of hardware and machine learning.

Currently, Yohannes serves as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working as a Hardware Engineer at Amazon in Sunnyvale, CA. At Amazon, he focuses on quantization of DNN models to be deployed on accelerators like NNA and MDLA for firmware applications such as Alexa. His work involves creating automated frameworks for NNA.3x aware training to avoid floating point numbers and transform to fixed point numbers, as well as extending frameworks to support TensorFlow model quantization and converting compatible audiotech models into firmware.

Yohannes is actively engaged in research at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, specifically in the PinCS Lab (Pedagogy in Computer Science Lab) where he works as an Undergraduate Researcher building drones. His aerospace interests extend to his earlier work as a Student Researcher at NASA, where he tested Aerogel insulation against radiation at 70,000 feet using weather balloon capsules.

His academic involvement at Stanford includes participation in the Leland Scholars Program, where he contributed to a research project titled "Equity in AI: Navigating Bias Through a Human-Centric Framework," analyzing approaches and implementing a paradigm shift for unbiased and ethical artificial intelligence.

Prior to Stanford, Yohannes worked as a Software Engineer at the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada, where he developed quantitative predictive modeling for city car crash data. He also conducted research at the University of Las Vegas Nevada for the International Science Fair, publishing work on "Analysis of Supersonic Parachutes On ReEntry" that examined crucial aspects of parachute design for rocket capsule reentry at supersonic speeds.

Yohannes possesses an impressive array of technical skills including machine learning frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras), programming languages (Python, C++, Java), hardware tools (Raspberry Pi, PCB design), robotics, computer vision (OpenCV), and data analysis tools (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Scikit-learn). His expertise also extends to aerospace engineering, mechatronics, embedded systems, and sensor fusion.

Based in both Palo Alto, CA and Las Vegas, NV, Yohannes represents a unique blend of technical depth across hardware engineering, aerospace, machine learning optimization, and venture capital experience - making him a versatile contributor to the AI and technology ecosystem.

name: aidan gollan
short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

suggested_people.name: Audrey Chen
suggested_people.short_description: Serial hackathon winner (21 wins) and tech entrepreneur with a passion for AI innovation. Co-founder of VC-backed nosu.io, Software Engineering Intern at Intuit, and content creator with 68K Instagram followers. Currently pursuing Computer Engineering at Michigan State University while balancing multiple tech roles including NASA USRC research and Intel AI projects.
suggested_people.long_description:
Audrey Chen is a dynamic force in the tech world, particularly known for her exceptional track record of winning 21 hackathons with a 70% win rate, accumulating over $20,000 in prizes. Her technical prowess spans multiple domains within AI and software engineering, demonstrated through her diverse professional experiences.

As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Max Forsey
suggested_people.short_description: Max Forsey is an AI researcher at the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University who explores the fundamental nature of intelligence. As a co-founder of justbuild.ing and former Vice President of BYU's Artificial Intelligence Association, he actively organizes AI hackathons and community events while developing practical tools to advance the field.
suggested_people.long_description:
Max Forsey is a dedicated AI researcher affiliated with the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University, where he explores the fundamental nature of intelligence through artificial intelligence systems. His research has led to publications like "Gradient Sparse Autoencoders," which introduces novel approaches to extracting neural network features.

Max has taken on leadership roles in the AI community, serving as the Vice President of the BYU Artificial Intelligence Association, where he helped organize events and foster a community of AI enthusiasts. In November 2024, he co-founded "justbuild.ing," an initiative focused on building a community of AI developers and hosting collaborative events.

He is particularly active in organizing and participating in AI hackathons, recently working with Sameday through the justbuild community to host a 2-hour AI hackathon featuring Cerebras Systems. His involvement in these rapid development events demonstrates his commitment to practical AI application and innovation.

Beyond his research, Max is passionate about creating practical AI tools. He developed FreshSesh AI, a developer tool that uses local LLMs to provide personalized context summaries of previous work sessions, helping developers quickly get back into flow. He's also reimplemented Andrej Karpathy's nanoGPT, showing his hands-on approach to understanding AI systems.

Max maintains a personal website where he shares detailed resources for those looking to bridge the gap between using AI APIs and actually training models. His curated learning path includes visual resources, essential reading, and practical project suggestions for newcomers to the field. He emphasizes starting with fundamentals and learning through implementation, reflecting his own approach to AI development.

Outside of his professional interests, Max maintains a holistic approach to life, with detailed attention to health and longevity practices. He values deep friendships and community connections, having written thoughtfully about the nature of friendship and human connection. His background combines theoretical AI research with practical application, demonstrating a commitment to both advancing the field and making AI more accessible to others.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Diddi
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Diddi is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform bringing on-device AI solutions with a focus on privacy and accessibility. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, he specializes in Applied Machine Learning and has experience as an instructor at General Assembly. A graduate of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Dhruv combines technical expertise with entrepreneurial vision, particularly in healthcare AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Diddi is an engineer and entrepreneur based in the San Francisco Bay Area with specialized experience in Applied Machine Learning. He is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform that brings AI directly to users' devices, ensuring data privacy, personalized experiences, and accessibility without reliance on cloud infrastructure. Solo has particularly focused on healthcare applications, addressing challenges around data privacy (HIPAA compliance), accessibility in low-connectivity environments, and customization for specific healthcare scenarios.

Dhruv actively promotes Solo through his newsletter "Get Solo Tech" on Substack, where he discusses innovations like Solo Health, which aims to transform patient care through on-device AI that protects sensitive patient data while providing robust performance for diagnostics, patient monitoring, and workflow optimization.

As a tech community participant, Dhruv has been featured as a speaker and host at San Francisco tech events, including a panel discussion on "AI + Human Intelligence" where he presented Solo alongside other founders. He's also participated in hackathons, with his profile showing attendance at AI hackathon events.

Dhruv brings a strong educational foundation from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign where he was recognized as a James Scholar and made the Dean's List. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, including Machine Learning, Algorithms, Computer Architecture (Honors), Data Structures (Honors), Interactive Computer Graphics, and R Programming. His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English, Hindi, and Punjabi, along with working knowledge of French and Mandarin Chinese.

As an educator, Dhruv has received glowing recommendations for his work as an instructor at General Assembly's boot camp program. Former students praise his patience, extensive knowledge, and ability to break down complex concepts in accessible ways. His teaching style is described as easy-going yet effective, making him a favorite resource for students struggling with difficult concepts.

Dhruv maintains an active presence in the AI and tech community, regularly publishing his newsletter "So Essentially Weekly" that covers developments in the field. His project portfolio demonstrates versatility and practical application of his skills, including work with Illini Hyperloop, a Kaggle Challenge on Titanic Prediction, and various web and mobile applications like Flare, Anthem Web App, and a Dwolla Pebble App.

Dhruv's professional focus appears to be at the intersection of privacy-first AI applications and healthcare innovation, with an emphasis on bringing powerful machine learning capabilities directly to devices while protecting user data and ensuring accessibility regardless of internet connectivity.

suggested_people.name: Tristan Trouwen
suggested_people.short_description: Tristan Trouwen is a researcher and software engineer affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology, with expertise in AI, algorithms, and compiler optimization. His research explores the interaction between automated systems and humans in software development environments, and he has been recognized with the ALSP Scholarship for academic excellence.
suggested_people.long_description:
Tristan Trouwen is a promising researcher at the intersection of software engineering and artificial intelligence, currently affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology. His research interests are evidenced by his publication "Between JIRA and GitHub: ASFBot and its Influence on Human Comments in Issue Trackers" (IEEE, 2022), which explores how automated systems interact with and influence human behavior in software development environments.

Tristan's academic excellence has been recognized through the Amandus H. Lundqvist Scholarship Program (ALSP), a merit-based scholarship that includes a tuition waiver and monthly stipend. This prestigious award highlights his standing as a top student in his field.

As an AI Software Architecture Intern at d-Matrix, a series A deep tech startup recognized by Business Insider as one of the 13 most promising AI startups, Tristan worked on optimizing compilers. He applied his algorithmic knowledge from his master's studies to improve existing algorithms, making the platform faster and more power-efficient. This experience allowed him to deepen his understanding of chip architecture and compilers while working in a highly intercultural team environment.

Beyond his technical work, Tristan has demonstrated entrepreneurial initiative through his project "From Scribble To Readable," a book he co-created with fellow student Lourens Touwen to help people write mathematical symbols legibly. The project began when they noticed the difficulty in deciphering their professor's handwriting during an Analysis lecture. They designed practice pages for common mathematical symbols, created promotional videos, and launched a successful Kickstarter campaign to publish the book.

Tristan has also demonstrated leadership capabilities through his role as Board Treasurer for E.S.D.A. Chronos from May 2019 to May 2020. He is also a member of Nova (since November 2022), suggesting continued engagement with professional or academic organizations.

His background combines strong computational methods and software engineering expertise, with a particular interest in how automated systems and human users interact in technical environments - a crucial area for advancing AI systems that can effectively collaborate with human operators. Tristan is fluent in Dutch (native proficiency) and English (full professional proficiency), enabling him to collaborate effectively in international research and development environments.

name: harshil avlani
short_description: Computer Science and Physics student at MIT with award-winning research in quantum computing. Former Research Intern at MIT's Quanta Group and Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab, focusing on quantum error characterization and quantum machine learning applications.
long_description:
Harshil Avlani is a dual-major student in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), with an exceptional research background in quantum computing and physics. His academic journey showcases a consistent focus on quantum technologies and computational physics.

Currently, Harshil serves as a Research Intern with the Quanta Group at MIT's Research Laboratory of Electronics, where he applies his interdisciplinary knowledge to cutting-edge quantum research. Prior to this, he gained valuable experience as a Research Intern at Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab under Dr. Houlong Zhuang for over a year, developing expertise in quantum mechanical applications and quantum machine learning.

Harshil has achieved remarkable recognition for his research. His project "Analyzing the Effect of Mid-Circuit Measurement (MCM) on Spectator Qubits" earned him first place in the Systems Software category at the International Science Fair and qualified him as a finalist in the prestigious 2024 Regeneron Science Talent Search, where he received a $25,000 academic scholarship. This groundbreaking work identified a previously uncharacterized type of quantum error and revealed significant deficiencies in current quantum simulators.

His research portfolio includes collaborative work on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) for solving combinatorial optimization problems, documented in his GitHub repository. He has also worked with the Hauser Research Group at the University of Alabama, where he spent 9 months contributing to physics research projects, and gained experience in computer security at Arizona State University's SEFCOM Lab.

In 2022, Harshil participated in the MIT Beaver Works Summer Institute as a Quantum Software Student, further enhancing his skills in quantum computing applications. He has also co-founded the Quantum Beavers hackathon group, which tied for first place in the IBM Quantum Explorers Hackathon.

Harshil has already begun contributing to scientific literature, with a publication in Data in Brief journal on "Dataset on density functional theory investigation of ternary Heusler alloys" in February 2024. More recently, he has been exploring the intersection of quantum computing and transformer models in machine learning, with applications in mitigating misinformation through quantum-enhanced GAN architectures.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Harshil is an accomplished pianist and has a passion for aviation, being able to identify most major aircraft models by sight. His diverse research experiences across multiple institutions highlight his versatility and dedication to advancing the fields of quantum computing and physics through rigorous academic inquiry and practical applications.

suggested_people.name: Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla
suggested_people.short_description: A multilingual Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard with exceptional achievements in quantum computing and international physics competitions. Ricardo combines technical expertise with diplomatic skills, having led international relations organizations and conducted research spanning solid-state physics, ESG consulting, and quantum algorithm development across multiple languages.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla is a Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard University with a remarkable blend of technical expertise and international perspective. His academic journey is distinguished by significant achievements in quantum computing, where he serves as Vice President of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantum Computing Association (HUQCA) and won 2nd place at MIT's Quantum Computing Hackathon 2024, developing theoretical error bounds for quantum algorithms.

Ricardo's technical prowess extends beyond quantum computing to solid-state physics research, where he worked with 2D transition metal dichalcogenides and Van der Waals heterostructures under Professor Hongkun Park. His computational skills have been recognized through multiple hackathon victories, including Microsoft's Student Hackathon 2021 and CdCMx 2020, where he developed mathematical models for COVID-19 comorbidity analysis.

In the quantum computing field, Ricardo has demonstrated exceptional talent, helping to grow HUQCA to over 300 members. At the MIT Interdisciplinary Quantum Hackathon (iQuHACK), his team created an "experimental harness" that allowed them to run quantum simulations at scale and efficiently collect data, earning them second place. As Ricardo noted, "It's one thing to learn something in a classroom, and another to try to code one and see if it runs. That's different, and I think it adds an extra layer to fully mastering the concepts."

What sets Ricardo apart is his exceptional international background and linguistic abilities. Fluent in six languages (Spanish, English, French, Chinese, Russian, and German), he has leveraged these skills in various leadership roles. As Co-President of Harvard International Relations on Campus and in his work with the Harvard International Relations Council, he has bridged cultural divides and facilitated international dialogue.
