suggested_people.name: Ian Lim
suggested_people.short_description: Ian Lim is a Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. He co-founded Stanford BCI and has been recognized as one of MinneInno's 25 Under 25 rising entrepreneurs and technologists in Minnesota.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ian Lim is a talented Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. His technical interests focus on brain-computer interfaces (BCI), as evidenced by his co-founding of Stanford BCI, an organization dedicated to advancing cutting-edge technology that connects neural activity with computing systems.

Ian has been involved with TreeHacks as an organizer, Stanford's premier hackathon that brings together students to collaborate on technological solutions to real-world problems. His entrepreneurial talent was recognized early when he was named to MinneInno's 25 Under 25 List in September 2018, highlighting him as one of Minnesota's most promising young entrepreneurs and technologists. He hails from Overland Park, Kansas, as indicated by his profile at the University of Kansas School of Engineering.

Despite his relatively early career stage, Ian has already built a substantial professional network with over 500 connections and 3,000 followers on LinkedIn, suggesting his influence in tech and entrepreneurial circles. His activity on LinkedIn shows engagement with content related to AI in education, talent development, and leadership, indicating his broader interests in how technology can transform learning and organizational development.

It's worth noting that there are several other professionals named Ian Lim in different fields, including a Senior Lecturer at Monash University specializing in computer science and data science, and a character portrayed by actor James Chen in the TV series "FBI" as an intelligence analyst. Our Ian Lim maintains a personal website at ianlim.com and is active on Twitter under the handle @ianclim, where he likely shares insights about his work and interests in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Soham Vasanawala
suggested_people.short_description: Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics student at Stanford University with a strong focus on the intersection of AI and healthcare. He has co-founded two startups, including Intratalent AI and Gains Coach LLC, where he's developing AI-powered coaching platforms. His research experience spans medical mixed reality and algorithm development for medical procedures, with notable presentations at ISMRM 2023.
suggested_people.long_description:
Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics undergraduate at Stanford University with entrepreneurial drive and technical expertise in AI applications for healthcare and biotech.

As a co-founder of Intratalent AI (since November 2024) and Gains Coach LLC (since December 2021), Soham demonstrates his entrepreneurial spirit. At Gains Coach, he's developing a real-time, AI-powered coaching platform for various physical movements including physiotherapy, sports, fitness, and dance.

His research experience is impressive for his age. During his internship at Stanford University School of Medicine, he worked with the Incubator for Medical Mixed and Extended Reality, developing a real-time augmented-reality visualization of knee motion from MRI data for the HoloLens2. At Stanford University School of Engineering, he designed and conducted research that led to a time-saving algorithm for a medical procedure, which he presented at Stanford BioX 2022 and ISMRM 2023.

Notably, at ISMRM 2023, he presented research on "Predicting MR Image Quality from Breathing Patterns" where he demonstrated that detected breathing patterns could be utilized to predict whether adequate MR image quality would be obtained. Using a K-means clustering algorithm, his work showed that 9 in 10 forty-second breathing waveforms could be correctly predicted as either resulting in high or low image quality, potentially saving time from unnecessary scans.

Soham has also gained industry experience as a Software Engineer at Turboprop, a fintech startup in Menlo Park. His academic background includes a Bachelor of Science degree from Stanford University (2023-2027) and previous education at Henry M. Gunn High School.

Beyond his technical work, Soham has contributed to a publication titled "Essays and Interviews with Bay Area Entrepreneurs" (September 2022), showing his interest in entrepreneurship. He is also a member of The International Society for Magnetic Resonance in Medicine, further demonstrating his commitment to the medical technology field.

Soham is proficient in English (native) and has limited working proficiency in French. His diverse experiences in AI, healthcare technology, and entrepreneurship position him uniquely at the intersection of technology and medicine, with a particular focus on using AI to solve real-world healthcare challenges.

He appears to be related to Shreyas Vasanawala, MD/PhD, who serves as the William R. Brody Professor of Pediatric Radiology and Child Health at Stanford Medicine, suggesting a family connection that may have influenced his interest in medical technology.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

name: mikael haji
short_description: A pioneering 19-year-old electrical engineering student at University of Waterloo who leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility for under $10K. With extensive experience in neurotech, Mikael has worked with Prophetic on ultrasound technology, contributed to neuromorphic chip design at University of Toronto, and was the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech.
long_description:
Mikael Haji is an innovative 19-year-old electrical engineering student at the University of Waterloo and recipient of the prestigious $120K Schulich Leaders Scholarship. He currently leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab team, where he's building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility in Waterloo with the ambitious goal of creating a process for under $10K that can produce approximately 1,000 transistors.

His GitHub profile reveals his deep involvement in brain-computer interface (BCI) technology, with multiple repositories focused on EEG applications, including projects for motor imagery systems, P300 spellers, emotion classification, and artifact detection algorithms. He's currently working on burning a GPT-2 layer on silicon and has previously designed a TPU-like systolic array and a neuromorphic chip for neural implants, with a pending IEEE ISSCC paper.

His professional journey showcases remarkable depth in cutting-edge technology fields. At Prophetic, Mikael built an entire transcranial focused ultrasound infrastructure, deploying advanced optimization techniques and accelerating transducer prototyping while creating an $80K hydrophone for under $2K. Prior to this, he worked at the University of Toronto on the digital back-end of a novel neuromorphic chip design, integrating spiking neural networks for advanced neural implants with the Intelligent Sensory Microsystems Lab.

At just 15, Mikael joined WATOLINK as a system integration engineer, helping build a mind-controlled speech interface using SSVEP with GPT-3 integration, which won first place in the Neurotech X student competition. His early accomplishments include being hired as the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech, where he engineered custom circuitry enclosures and fabricated high-precision electrode arrays.

Mikael's expertise has earned him recognition beyond academia. He was flown to Dubai for the Global Citizen Forum Conference to discuss his neurotech work and was selected as a Villars Fellow to participate in the inaugural Villars Symposium in Geneva. His entrepreneurial potential was further validated by a $250K matching trust fund from Patrick Poirier at Dragon's Vault to fuel his work in the neurotech space.

His technical innovation began early, with the development of a novel Thermoelectric Generator using fluid technology that earned him the Worley Parsons Engineers of Tomorrow award in 2019. Mikael's unique combination of hardware expertise, neuromorphic computing knowledge, and entrepreneurial drive positions him at the forefront of emerging technologies in chip fabrication and neural interfaces.

One of his notable projects includes developing a highly efficient compression algorithm for Neuralink's N1 implant as part of their compression challenge, which has gained significant attention on GitHub. His diverse portfolio of projects demonstrates his commitment to advancing both hardware and software solutions in the field of neurotechnology and chip design.

suggested_people.name: Anush Mutyala
suggested_people.short_description: Anush Mutyala is a biomedical engineering student at UBC and multifaceted researcher working at the intersection of neuroscience, robotics, and hardware engineering. Currently developing calibration-free robotics at NC4 Lab while building electronics for STEM cell factories at General Cybernetics, he's also passionate about DIY semiconductor fabrication and neuromorphic computing.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anush Mutyala is a biomedical engineering student at the University of British Columbia, attending on a prestigious $120,000 Schulich Leader Scholarship. His research interests span multiple cutting-edge domains, with a particular focus on neuromorphic computing, robotics, and hardware engineering.

Currently, Anush works as a Robotics Researcher at NC4 Lab, where he's developing neural manifold approaches to eliminate sensor calibration in robotics systems. His work involves building ROS/Gazebo simulations to generate rich LIDAR datasets. Simultaneously, he serves as an Electrical Engineering Intern at General Cybernetics, designing PCBs for bioelectric cell reprogramming experiments using LTSpice and Altium/Kicad.

Anush's research background is impressively diverse. At York University's LCRAIN lab, he led a cross-institutional team developing bio-plausible spiking neural network training algorithms using EEG-fMRI data. At the University of Toronto's Intelligent Sensory Microsystems Lab, he integrated spiking neural networks into low-power neural implants, reducing latency by 5x through algorithmic optimizations while enabling wearable form factors. He also designed gate-level implementations on FPGA to support future ASIC/tape-out efforts.

His entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of NeuraDAO, which aimed to create a democratized funding ecosystem for neuroscience and technology research. The project raised over $6,000 in Gitcoin Round 15 and involved developing a decentralized marketplace for neuroimaging datasets built on Web3 protocols.

Anush has also contributed to consumer neurotechnology at Divergence Neuro, where he helped build an EEG-based neurofeedback therapy platform, working on visualization modules and event-related potential experiments.

His innovation in neural implant technology has gained recognition, winning a bronze excellence award at the Canada-Wide Science Fair in 2023 for his project "Enerspike." This algorithm dramatically improves battery life in neural implants by optimizing power usage, potentially extending battery lifespan by up to 70 times and eliminating the need for surgical replacement every few years. The project was inspired by both Elon Musk's Neuralink and Stephen Hawking's vision of brain-computer interfaces as the future of communication.

Beyond his formal roles, Anush is passionate about DIY semiconductor fabrication, having received an Emergent Ventures Fellowship grant to build a maskless photolithography stepper for Hacker Fab at UBC. His team was also a finalist at Hack The North 2022 with the project "ConnexSci," which used Graph Neural Networks to optimize drug discovery.

Anush represents a new generation of interdisciplinary researchers working at the convergence of neuroscience, electrical engineering, and artificial intelligence, with a particular focus on developing energy-efficient, brain-inspired computing systems and their applications in healthcare and robotics.

suggested_people.name: Natnael Kahssay
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Engineering student at MIT with a unique blend of hardware expertise spanning RF systems, FPGA design, and nano-fabrication. Founder of Saverntronics technologies and researcher in bioelectronics, Natnael combines hands-on engineering with entrepreneurial vision.
suggested_people.long_description:
Natnael Kahssay is a Computer Science and Engineering student at MIT with an impressive breadth of technical expertise across hardware domains. His background spans RF systems, FPGA design, nano-fabrication, and hardware design, with proficiency in programming languages including Bluespec, C, and Python, as well as industry tools like Cadence and Vivado.

As an undergraduate researcher in MIT's Bioelectronics Group, Natnael works on cutting-edge optogenetic-based waveguide and neural implants used to study stress in addiction susceptibility, demonstrating his ability to apply engineering principles to neuroscience research. His academic contributions extend to teaching roles, where he serves as a Laboratory Teaching Assistant for Digital System Laboratory I (6.205), helping students implement digital design projects on Sparta-7 FPGAs.

Natnael's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Saverntronics technologies, where he led the development of an autonomous barbing machine, handling both digital modeling and actuator response characterization. This venture showcases his ability to take technical concepts from ideation to implementation.

His project portfolio reflects his diverse interests, including work on an 802.11a Physical layer on RFSoC, Nano MEMS Mirrors, and various software projects. On GitHub, he maintains several open-source projects, including "gestures" (a fluid gestures system for Linux with 68 stars), and extensions for GNOME window management. His GitHub profile, where he goes by "natask," emphasizes his philosophy that "Productivity is key. Planning is essential."

Natnael has also contributed to significant academic projects, including an HFT (High-Frequency Trading) Accelerator developed with his brother Endrias Kahssay and teammate Ziheng Wang as part of MIT's 6.111 (Digital Systems Laboratory) final project in Fall 2019. This project demonstrated his ability to work on complex, time-sensitive computational systems.

Currently, Natnael is set to join Etched, indicating his continued trajectory in the technology sector. His multidisciplinary background at the intersection of computer science, electrical engineering, and bioelectronics positions him uniquely in the field of hardware engineering and design.

suggested_people.name: Fengrui Zuo
suggested_people.short_description: Fengrui Zuo is a hardware specialist focusing on Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory. With a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, he brings specialized expertise in hardware acceleration for AI applications and serves as an Analog Design Co-Lead and Industry Outreach Officer at Open Source Silicon @ Stanford.
suggested_people.long_description:
Fengrui Zuo is a hardware engineer specializing in Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, which is operated by Stanford University. He currently holds dual positions as a Staff Engineer at SLAC and is pursuing his Master's degree in Electrical Engineering (MSEE) at Stanford University, which he began in Autumn 2023.

Fengrui has established himself as a leader in the open-source silicon community at Stanford, where he serves in multiple leadership roles. He is the Industry Outreach Officer for Open Source Silicon @ Stanford (OS3), helping to bridge academic research with industry applications. Additionally, he co-leads the Analog Design Subteam at OS3, where he focuses on designing and verifying analog components such as amplifiers, voltage references, and Power Management ICs (PMICs). His work involves device simulations, schematic generation and routing using both open-source and proprietary software, and conducting bench testing and verification.

His technical expertise spans across several domains including CUDA kernel optimization, autonomous systems, and chip design. Fengrui demonstrates particular interest in cutting-edge hardware developments such as NVIDIA's Jetson Orin Nano platform for edge AI applications, open-source chip design, and specialized motherboards with timing synchronization capabilities. His work at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory likely involves specialized hardware systems for scientific research and experimentation, integrating AI capabilities into high-performance computing environments for physics research.

Fengrui's professional address is at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, located at 2575 Sand Hill Rd, Menlo Park, California. His dual role as both a graduate student and staff engineer positions him uniquely at the intersection of academic research and practical engineering applications, particularly in the field of analog design for advanced computing systems.

suggested_people.name: Ian Lim
suggested_people.short_description: Ian Lim is a Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. He co-founded Stanford BCI and has been recognized as one of MinneInno's 25 Under 25 rising entrepreneurs and technologists in Minnesota.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ian Lim is a talented Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. His technical interests focus on brain-computer interfaces (BCI), as evidenced by his co-founding of Stanford BCI, an organization dedicated to advancing cutting-edge technology that connects neural activity with computing systems.

Ian has been involved with TreeHacks as an organizer, Stanford's premier hackathon that brings together students to collaborate on technological solutions to real-world problems. His entrepreneurial talent was recognized early when he was named to MinneInno's 25 Under 25 List in September 2018, highlighting him as one of Minnesota's most promising young entrepreneurs and technologists. He hails from Overland Park, Kansas, as indicated by his profile at the University of Kansas School of Engineering.

Despite his relatively early career stage, Ian has already built a substantial professional network with over 500 connections and 3,000 followers on LinkedIn, suggesting his influence in tech and entrepreneurial circles. His activity on LinkedIn shows engagement with content related to AI in education, talent development, and leadership, indicating his broader interests in how technology can transform learning and organizational development.

It's worth noting that there are several other professionals named Ian Lim in different fields, including a Senior Lecturer at Monash University specializing in computer science and data science, and a character portrayed by actor James Chen in the TV series "FBI" as an intelligence analyst. Our Ian Lim maintains a personal website at ianlim.com and is active on Twitter under the handle @ianclim, where he likely shares insights about his work and interests in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu
suggested_people.short_description: Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with diverse experience spanning aerospace, hardware engineering, and venture capital. Currently serving as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working at Amazon on ML quantization for embedded hardware and contributing to research at Stanford's PinCS Lab.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu is an Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University (2023-2027) with a remarkable breadth of technical and business experience. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, with a particular focus on the intersection of hardware and machine learning.

Currently, Yohannes serves as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working as a Hardware Engineer at Amazon in Sunnyvale, CA. At Amazon, he focuses on quantization of DNN models to be deployed on accelerators like NNA and MDLA for firmware applications such as Alexa. His work involves creating automated frameworks for NNA.3x aware training to avoid floating point numbers and transform to fixed point numbers, as well as extending frameworks to support TensorFlow model quantization and converting compatible audiotech models into firmware.

Yohannes is actively engaged in research at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, specifically in the PinCS Lab (Pedagogy in Computer Science Lab) where he works as an Undergraduate Researcher building drones. His aerospace interests extend to his earlier work as a Student Researcher at NASA, where he tested Aerogel insulation against radiation at 70,000 feet using weather balloon capsules.

His academic involvement at Stanford includes participation in the Leland Scholars Program, where he contributed to a research project titled "Equity in AI: Navigating Bias Through a Human-Centric Framework," analyzing approaches and implementing a paradigm shift for unbiased and ethical artificial intelligence.

Prior to Stanford, Yohannes worked as a Software Engineer at the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada, where he developed quantitative predictive modeling for city car crash data. He also conducted research at the University of Las Vegas Nevada for the International Science Fair, publishing work on "Analysis of Supersonic Parachutes On ReEntry" that examined crucial aspects of parachute design for rocket capsule reentry at supersonic speeds.

Yohannes possesses an impressive array of technical skills including machine learning frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras), programming languages (Python, C++, Java), hardware tools (Raspberry Pi, PCB design), robotics, computer vision (OpenCV), and data analysis tools (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Scikit-learn). His expertise also extends to aerospace engineering, mechatronics, embedded systems, and sensor fusion.

Based in both Palo Alto, CA and Las Vegas, NV, Yohannes represents a unique blend of technical depth across hardware engineering, aerospace, machine learning optimization, and venture capital experience - making him a versatile contributor to the AI and technology ecosystem.

name: anirudh kotamraju
short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

suggested_people.name: Arihant Choudhary
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley with extensive research experience across AI, cryptography, and computational game theory. Currently working as a Software Intern at Intel and Lead Undergraduate Researcher at UC Berkeley, focusing on multi-agent systems, AI applications, and CS education.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arihant Choudhary is a multifaceted Computer Science, Data Science, and Applied Mathematics student at UC Berkeley with a remarkable research portfolio spanning diverse technical domains. His research journey includes work at Stanford University on multi-agent systems for inference, reasoning, and planning, as well as climate data analysis using CMIP-6 models.

At UC Berkeley, Arihant has made significant contributions across multiple research labs. He serves as a Lead Undergraduate Researcher in two labs under Prof. Dan Garcia - the Computational Game Theory Lab (GamesCrafters) and the CS Education Lab (ACE Lab). In the ACE Lab, he authored papers on dynamic animated feedback for randomized graph problems (accepted at SIGCSE 2024) and co-authored work on personalized reminders for mastery learning (AutoRemind, accepted at SIGCSE 2025). His work in the Computational Game Theory Lab involved developing solvers for games like Quick Cross and Euclid's Game, researching pure draw theory, and creating human-robot interaction systems.

Professionally, Arihant is currently working as a Software Intern at Intel Corporation, implementing cutting-edge research and building products for Intel Foundry. His previous role as a Research Intern at Intel focused on text-to-video research and building Intel's Personal Educator (IPED) using large language models and text-to-speech libraries to support employee training. He also serves as a Dean's Engineering Ambassador at UC Berkeley's College of Engineering, working on programs for high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.

Arihant's journey to UC Berkeley is particularly inspiring. After being rejected from all colleges in his first application cycle, he took a gap year in 2020 and pursued multiple projects, including a significant climate change research project through Polygence. Working with his mentor Tristan Ballard, a Stanford PhD in earth systems science, Arihant analyzed a petabyte of climate data to study monsoons in Kolkata and assess climate change impacts on agriculture. This experience not only built his technical skills but also helped him secure admission to UC Berkeley on his second attempt.

Arihant's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Berkeley Social, a platform he developed to help incoming UC Berkeley students connect with peers sharing similar interests. He also co-founded Yindu & Zhongguo Inc, which included the Bangla Machinery Bank, an AgriTech enterprise providing efficient farm machinery to farmers in West Bengal.

His academic pursuits extend beyond UC Berkeley, with coursework at Stanford University in CS224G: Apps with LLMs Inside. Arihant's technical expertise spans AI, machine learning, cryptography, and data science, complemented by his multilingual proficiency in English, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, and Marwari.

Through his diverse experiences in research, entrepreneurship, and community service, Arihant demonstrates a commitment to leveraging technology for social impact and educational advancement. Expected to graduate in Spring 2025, he is now interested in pursuing a graduate degree and a career in artificial intelligence/machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

name: devanshi jain
short_description: Devanshi Jain is a Mathematics and Computer Science undergraduate at UC San Diego with a unique blend of software engineering and computational research experience. She has interned at Meta and Amazon, while also contributing to research in energy optimization and computational fluid dynamics. Her technical expertise spans backend development, signal processing, and mathematical modeling, with a particular focus on applying computational methods to solve complex engineering problems.
long_description:
Devanshi Jain is a Mathematics and Computer Science undergraduate at UC San Diego with a diverse portfolio spanning software engineering, computational research, and mathematical analysis. Her professional journey includes software engineering internships at both Meta and Amazon, where she worked on login core products and cross-border transportation systems respectively.

Beyond her industry experience, Devanshi has demonstrated exceptional research capabilities across multiple domains. At UC San Diego's Center for Energy Research, she improved energy efficiency by 20% through scheduler optimization algorithms. Her work at the Computational Modeling and Flow Physics Lab led to a 12.5% efficiency improvement for NASA's GE90 engine through non-linear optimization techniques, utilizing 200,000 high-performance computing hours for complex CFD simulations.

Devanshi's technical versatility extends to signal processing, where she developed algorithms for acoustic systems and beamforming while working with Triton Robosub. She also built a neurocognitive testing web application for sleep apnea patients at UC San Diego's School of Medicine, contributing to the San Diego Verbal Paired-Associates (SD-VPA) App for testing sleep-dependent memory.

Her leadership experience is equally impressive, serving as President of the Society of Undergraduate Mathematics Students and Technical Chair for IEEE's Student Branch at UC San Diego. She has also participated in multiple advanced mathematics reading groups, studying topics like commutative algebra, functional analysis, and translation surfaces.

Devanshi has published research on turbo-machinery compressor optimization, where her work exceeded NASA's 1980 model efficiency by 12.5%. Her technical skills include Python, JavaScript, React.js, NextJS, AWS, Git, HTML/CSS, Django, and specialized tools like Ansys for computational fluid dynamics.

As an active member of the academic community, she has served as a Teaching Assistant for UCSD Cosmos and participated in various innovation programs including QuForce Innovation Fellow and Blackstone LaunchPad Incubator. Her unique combination of software engineering expertise, mathematical rigor, and research experience positions her as a standout talent in computational problem-solving and optimization.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Alicia Li
suggested_people.short_description: MIT CS/AI & Math double major with a strong research background in robot learning and reinforcement learning. First author on a NeurIPS 2024 workshop paper and incoming ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics. Founded Watch To Donate, raising over $6,000 for various causes while reaching millions of people.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alicia Li is a talented undergraduate at MIT pursuing a double major in Computer Science/AI (specifically course 6-4: AI and Decision Making) and Mathematics (2023-2027). Her research interests span robot learning, planning, and reinforcement learning, with particular focus on safe RL applications.

As an undergraduate researcher at MIT CSAIL's Learning & Intelligent Systems Group, she works on robot learning and planning, and is the first author on a paper accepted to the NeurIPS 2024 Open-World Agents Workshop titled "Learning to Bridge the Gap: Efficient Novelty Recovery with Planning and Reinforcement Learning." She's also researching safe reinforcement learning for power grid optimization at MIT's Donti Lab, where she was listed as a past member in 2024.

Alicia has an impressive publication record for her career stage, with multiple published papers including work on adversarial attacks against online reinforcement learning agents (as part of MIT PRIMES research project 2022-2023), magic SET squares classification, the Post Correspondence Problem, and coin weighing problems. Her academic excellence is further demonstrated by her coursework in graduate-level subjects including Advanced Algorithms, Inference and Information, and Sensorimotor Learning.

Beyond her academic pursuits, Alicia founded and served as CEO of Watch To Donate from 2020 to 2023, an international student organization that donates revenue from social media videos, mobile apps, and business collaborations. Under her leadership, the organization raised over $6,000 for 27 causes, reached over 6 million people, and developed apps with 9,000+ downloads. She also created a Family Fund to help their online community of 50,000 in need. Additionally, she developed "Play To Donate," an app that leverages ad revenue to enable users to donate to charity by playing games.

Alicia is active in MIT's campus life, participating in MIT Asian Dance Team and Ridonkulous (MIT's competitive hip hop dance team), and was previously on Fixation (MIT's competitive contemporary dance team). She also enjoys figure skating and watching movies with friends in her free time.

She is currently preparing for her upcoming role as an ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics, where she'll likely apply her expertise in AI and mathematics to challenges in the therapeutic development space.

suggested_people.name: Niya Ma
suggested_people.short_description: Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI with a strong background in hackathons, having won multiple awards and served as Director of Hack@Davidson. She graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics, and has experience in machine learning, automation, and full-stack development.
suggested_people.long_description:
Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI who graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics. Her technical journey showcases a diverse range of experiences across machine learning, software development, and leadership roles.

As the former Director of Hack@Davidson, Niya has deep roots in the hackathon community, both as an organizer and participant. Her impressive track record includes winning multiple hackathon awards, such as 2nd Place at the Twilio LLM Hackathon, Best project using Wolfram API at Stanford LLM x Law Hackathon, and awards for sustainability, security, and automation at various other competitions.

Niya's professional experience includes software engineering internships at major tech companies. At Oracle, she pioneered a Python script that accelerated network traffic simulation by 250x and engineered MySQL database and Grafana dashboard integration. At Qualtrics, she worked on the Developer Experience team, creating efficient updating mechanisms for services and making substantial open-source contributions to the Backstage project.

Her academic background includes coursework in Natural Language Processing, Concurrent & Parallel Computing, Deep Learning, Operating Systems, and Applied Cryptography. She also took CS229 - Machine Learning at Stanford University.

At Oracle, Niya has been working with OCI Landing Zones, contributing to enterprise cloud infrastructure deployment solutions. Her GitHub profile shows involvement with Oracle's cloud infrastructure projects, including forking and working with the oracle-enterprise-landingzone repository, which focuses on deploying typical architecture used by enterprise customers in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.

Beyond technical skills, Niya demonstrated leadership as President of the Association For Women In Mathematics at Davidson College and was involved in campus activities including Davidson Chorale and the Residence Life Office. She is bilingual in English and Mandarin, adding a multicultural dimension to her skill set.

Niya's combination of technical expertise, leadership experience, and hackathon success positions her as a versatile software engineer with particular strengths in machine learning applications, cloud infrastructure, and automation.

suggested_people.name: Trishala Neeraj
suggested_people.short_description: Trishala Neeraj is a Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube with a strong academic background from Cornell University. She specializes in computer vision and natural language processing, bringing technical expertise to cybersecurity analytics and has contributed to several influential AI research papers.
suggested_people.long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. She works with terabyte-scale data to develop models using Deep Learning and Matrix Factorization techniques, with a particular focus on language data and models.

Her academic foundation was built at Cornell University, where she graduated in 2018 after focusing on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing during her graduate studies. She also holds a Bachelor of Engineering degree from BITS Pilani, India, and spent time as a visiting research scholar at the Predictive Technology Lab at the University of Virginia.

Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022). Her work on "BigBIO: A Framework for Data-Centric Biomedical Natural Language Processing" (2022) has also gained recognition in the field.

Her professional experience includes a summer internship at BuzzFeed in 2017, where she worked on a project using K-Means Clustering to tag over 14,000 BuzzFeed quizzes, which she documented in a blog post on the BuzzFeed Tech Blog. She has also published research on "A Computational Approach to Perceived Trustworthiness of Airbnb Host Profiles" (2017) and "Longitudinal Analysis of Cyber-Related Articles" (2020).

Beyond her technical work, Trishala has been actively involved in the tech community. She represented the student body at the Cornell Tech Campus Dedication ceremony in August 2017 and moderated a conversation with Eric Schmidt in March 2018. She maintains a personal blog where she documents her research projects on topics like Weak Supervision, Feature-based Approaches with BERT, and Semantic Entailment.

Trishala is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Hindi, which enhances her ability to work in diverse teams and global environments. Her involvement with organizations like Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) demonstrates her commitment to the broader AI community and diversity in tech.

suggested_people.name: Catherine Lee
suggested_people.short_description: Catherine Lee is a machine learning professional currently working at Lamini. She has developed expertise in LSTM networks and boosting algorithms, with award-winning projects focused on data usability and practical applications of AI, particularly in transportation safety and fraud detection. She is also an accomplished UX designer with experience optimizing user experiences for startups and enterprise clients.
suggested_people.long_description:
Catherine Lee is a machine learning professional currently working at Lamini, an AI company. She has demonstrated a strong foundation in machine learning, having completed the Machine Learning Specialization from DeepLearning.AI and Stanford University in January 2024.

Catherine has authored research publications including "Predicting the Number of Accidents in Different Weather Conditions in Barcelona Using Long Short Term Memory" (2019) and "Adtracking Fraud Detection Using Boosting Algorithms and Neural Networks" (2019), showing her expertise in applying advanced ML techniques to real-world problems.

Her project portfolio showcases diverse applications of AI and technology. Notable projects include "Bikeable," which won the Best Data Usability Hack at PennApps 2019 for using machine learning to generate safer bicycle routes based on accident data. She also worked on "PictRNNary," which earned the Best Use of Microsoft Azure Hack at Cal Hacks 5.0 in 2018, and "Place It," which won Best Under Construction Hack at LA Hacks 2020.

Catherine is also an accomplished UX designer with experience working with both startups and enterprise clients. Her design portfolio includes work for companies like Thoughtful, J.P. Morgan, Northwestern Mutual, and Masse, where she focused on optimizing user experiences and operational efficiency. Her design approach is methodical, using both data and qualitative user research to inform her designs. According to Elizabeth Cordry Shaffer, Co-Founder & CEO at Thoughtful, "She produces incredibly thoughtful work quickly, and handles feedback very well from team members. Communication and presentation of her ideas is a core strength of hers."

Catherine has participated in prestigious tech programs including the Google CodeU Program and JP Morgan Code for Good, demonstrating her commitment to applying technology for positive impact. Her recent project "Ayna" (November 2023) indicates her continued involvement in innovative tech development.

She is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Cantonese, and elementary proficiency in French, which enhances her ability to work in diverse environments. Catherine's consistent recognition through hackathon awards highlights her technical skills and ability to develop practical, impactful solutions using AI, machine learning, and user-centered design.

name: yuwei qin
short_description: A results-driven AI hardware specialist currently at d-Matrix with a strong background in computational electromagnetics and machine learning. Yuwei holds a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University and has extensive research experience in applying deep neural networks to data detection and electromagnetic analysis.
long_description:
Yuwei Qin is a technical professional specializing in AI hardware optimization, currently working at d-Matrix, a company focused on AI compute platforms for inference. With a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University's Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Yuwei has developed expertise at the intersection of hardware engineering and machine learning.

Yuwei's research contributions are particularly notable in the fields of computational electromagnetics, machine learning applications for hardware, and magnetic recording technologies. His publication record includes over 20 papers with more than 150 citations, demonstrating significant impact in his field. His most cited work includes "Machine learning based method of moments (ML-MoM)" (46 citations) and "Deep Neural Network: Data Detection Channel for Hard Disk Drives by Learning" (22 citations).

His research has focused on applying deep neural networks and machine learning to improve data detection in storage systems, particularly for hard disk drives. Notable achievements include developing a CNN-based read channel for hard disk drives that achieved a 30% error rate reduction and 200Mbits/s throughput in 28nm CMOS technology. This work represents a significant advancement in storage system performance through the application of machine learning techniques.

Yuwei has also made contributions to computational electromagnetics, developing machine learning-based approaches for electromagnetic compatibility analysis and parasitic capacitance extractions. His work on electrically tunable polarizers based on graphene-loaded plasmonic cross antennas demonstrates his expertise in applied physics and device modeling.

In the field of heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), Yuwei has conducted research on improving recording performance through micromagnetic modeling and analysis of thermal profiles, contributing to advancements in storage technology.

Throughout his career, Yuwei has collaborated with researchers from institutions including the University of Hong Kong, Western Digital, and Zhejiang University, building a strong professional network in the field of AI hardware and computational electromagnetics.

His technical expertise spans computer engineering, deep learning, storage systems, device modeling, semiconductor device physics, and applied physics, making him a versatile professional at the cutting edge of AI hardware optimization and machine learning applications for hardware systems.

suggested_people.name: Wanzin Yazar
suggested_people.short_description: AI researcher at d-Matrix and UC Berkeley alumnus specializing in LLM optimization. Published work on quantized LLMs and attention span acceleration for inference. Award-winning hackathon participant with expertise in cloud computing, deep learning, and healthcare AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Wanzin Yazar is a Staff ML Research Engineer at d-Matrix, a company focused on in-memory compute architecture for AI applications, and is an alumnus of the University of California, Berkeley, where they earned a Bachelor's degree in Applied Mathematics with a focus on AI. Their research focuses on optimizing large language models (LLMs) for more efficient inference and deployment.

Wanzin has published several significant papers in the field of AI optimization, including "Post Training Quantization of Large Language Models with Microscaling Formats" (2024), "Self-Selected Attention Span for Accelerating Large Language Model Inference" (2024), "Understanding the difficulty of low-precision post-training quantization of large language models" (2024), and "Scaling laws for post-training quantized large language models" (2024). Their work demonstrates expertise in model quantization and inference acceleration techniques, which are critical for deploying AI models in resource-constrained environments.

Beyond LLM optimization, Wanzin has also contributed to research in healthcare AI applications, with publications like "Through the Looking Glass: Unraveling the Stage-Shift of Acute Rejection in Renal Allografts" (2022) and "The self-upgrading mobile application for the automatic malaria detection" (2020). At Nephrosant, Inc., they developed productionized machine learning models from large healthcare datasets, showing versatility in applying AI to solve real-world problems in the medical field.

Wanzin previously worked as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Division of Computing, Data Science, and Society, focusing on deep learning-based recommender systems and student enrollment predictions using clustering practices and regression models. They also gained experience at Advancers.ai before joining d-Matrix.

Wanzin has an impressive track record in hackathons, winning the Grand Prize at AngelHack Silicon Valley 2019, Best Mobile Hack at SF HACK 2019, and the Best Asian Pacific Quest in the 2019 IBM Call For Code Global Challenge. These achievements highlight their ability to rapidly prototype and implement AI solutions.

Their professional certifications include Google Cloud Certified Data Engineer (issued January 2020), the Deep Learning Specialization from deeplearning.ai (issued January 2018), and Full Stack Machine Learning on AWS from AI Camp. These certifications demonstrate Wanzin's comprehensive understanding of cloud infrastructure, deep learning fundamentals, and practical implementation of machine learning systems.

Wanzin's research has been cited by other scholars in the field, with their papers on LLM optimization and healthcare applications receiving recognition in the academic community. Their expertise spans machine learning, pattern recognition, image processing, neural networks, computer vision, data mining, computational intelligence, statistical learning, and data analysis.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Suresh Nambi
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford University researcher specializing in hardware optimization for AI systems. Published author with expertise in efficient neural network design, approximate computing, and laser-induced graphitic carbon for electronics. Focused on developing low-power, high-performance hardware solutions for next-generation AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Suresh Nambi is a researcher at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, focusing on the development and implementation of efficient and effective hardware solutions for AI systems. His research interests span several specialized areas within hardware optimization, including approximate computing, FPGA-based neural network implementations, and novel materials for electronics.

Suresh has made significant contributions to the field through his publications in prestigious journals. His work on "ExPAN(N)D" explored the use of posits (an alternative to floating-point representation) for efficient neural network design in FPGA-based systems, demonstrating his expertise in hardware-optimized AI implementations. He also developed "DeBAM," a decoder-based approximate multiplier designed specifically for low-power applications, showcasing his innovation in energy-efficient computing architectures.

Beyond traditional computing hardware, Suresh has explored novel materials and fabrication techniques. His research on laser-induced graphitic carbon has led to breakthroughs in creating low-resistance conductors, including work on 3D-printed structures. This interdisciplinary approach bridges electronics, materials science, and advanced manufacturing.

Additionally, Suresh has ventured into sustainable energy applications, conducting performance analysis of submerged photovoltaic cells under varying water conditions, demonstrating his versatility and interest in environmentally conscious technologies.

His GitHub repository for the DeBAM project indicates his commitment to open-source contributions and knowledge sharing within the research community. At Stanford, he continues to push the boundaries of hardware design for AI applications, likely focusing on creating more efficient, powerful, and specialized computing solutions for the next generation of artificial intelligence systems.

suggested_people.name: Sathvik Redrouthu
suggested_people.short_description: Sathvik Redrouthu is a tech innovator and entrepreneur who founded Procyon Photonics while in high school to develop photonic computing technology. Currently at Etched, he previously worked on chip design tooling through his startup Instachip. His research focuses on optical computing, photonic integrated circuits, and tensor algebra implementations for next-generation computing architectures.
suggested_people.long_description:
Sathvik Redrouthu is a forward-thinking technologist, entrepreneur, and researcher at the intersection of optoelectronics, hardware acceleration, and advanced computing architectures. Currently working at Etched and previously associated with Y Combinator, Sathvik has established himself as an innovator in specialized computing hardware despite his young age.

As the founder, CEO, and CTO of Procyon Photonics, Sathvik became the world's youngest CEO in the photonic and optical computing sector. Founded in 2021 while he was still in high school at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, Procyon develops revolutionary photon-based computing technology that aims to overcome the limitations of traditional electronic computing. The company's optical chips are designed to be significantly more energy-efficient than conventional processors, with prototypes reportedly 55,000 times more energy-efficient than the Intel i9 and over 100 times more efficient than Nvidia's A100 or Google's TPU. Procyon secured venture funding from Peter Thiel's 1517 Fund and has attracted interest from tech leaders like Sam Altman of OpenAI.

Before joining Etched, Sathvik founded Instachip, an EDA (Electronic Design Automation) startup focused on chip design tooling, and participated in Y Combinator. He is also conducting Formal Verification research with Dr. Mark Santolucito at Columbia University.

His research portfolio includes significant contributions to optical computing, with publications focused on optoelectronic hardware accelerators for tensor arithmetic. His work on "Tachyon," a programmable optoelectronic hardware accelerator, demonstrates his expertise in designing systems for ultrafast tensor operations. His team at Procyon was the first to run tensor algebra on an optical chip.
