Additionally, he has published on tensor algebra implementations for optoelectronic microchips and the use of interferometer-based photonic integrated circuits for rapid unitary transformations.

Sathvik's technical focus is on leveraging optical technologies to overcome limitations in traditional electronic computing, particularly for matrix multiplication and tensor operations critical for AI and machine learning workloads. His work on implementing unitary matrix transformations through Mach-Zehnder interferometers shows a deep understanding of how to harness photonic principles for computational advantage.

Beyond his professional work, Sathvik has developed numerous projects including AI chess engines, regex interpreters using Brzozowski derivatives, tensor algebra compilers with sparse tensor storage systems, and various AI applications. He is also skilled in hardware development, having created electric guitars and EMP generators from scratch.

Sathvik graduated high school in June 2024 but decided not to attend university, instead pursuing entrepreneurship and practical research. His vision is to someday "power the world with light" through photon-based computing, which he believes represents the next revolution in computing technology.

name: joshua vallabhaneni
short_description: Computer Science student at University of Maryland and UMD Honors College with a focus on AI-enabled security solutions. Currently working as a Junior Software Engineer at AstraZeneca while developing innovative technologies for school safety through xFoundry@UMD and creating award-winning projects in AI and sustainability.
long_description:
Joshua Vallabhaneni is a Computer Science student at the University of Maryland and part of the UMD Honors College, who balances full-time studies with professional software engineering work. He currently serves as a Junior Software Engineer at AstraZeneca's health-tech subsidiary Evinova, where he works 40 hours per week while maintaining his academic commitments.

Joshua has demonstrated exceptional talent in technology innovation focused on safety and security applications. As a Product Innovation Engineer at xFoundry@UMD, he was selected as one of only 30 students for their inaugural cohort, where he's developing an AI-enabled detection, tracking, and notification system for identifying active shooter events in educational settings in real-time. This venture is backed by significant funding ranging from $250K to $2M.

His experience extends to human-computer interaction, where he worked as an intern at The Center for Applied Technologies for School Security, conducting user testing to enhance the OWL app's usability and applying UX design heuristics to support safer learning environments. Joshua also has experience in 3D animation and interactive media development from his three-year tenure at Siepser Eyecare.

Joshua's technical background includes software engineering internships at PayPal (upcoming), AstraZeneca, and Proxzar, showcasing his versatility across different technology domains. His academic journey includes studies at the University of Maryland, a period at Imperial College London where he focused on Mathematics for Machine Learning, and a high school diploma from Unionville High School in Kennett Square, Pennsylvania.

He has an impressive record of achievements, including first place at the AI for Change Hackathon among 493 participants, first place at JPMorgan Chase's Code For Good Hackathon (selected from 15,000 applicants), and multiple awards at PennApps XXV Hackathon for his work on gesture-driven facial authentication for anti-spoofing and AI deepfake detection. Joshua also received the President's Scholarship from the University of Maryland for his academic and extracurricular excellence.

His portfolio of innovative projects continues to grow, with recent developments including Azalea (an eco-friendly AI model selector that optimizes environmental impact), FireSync (an AI-driven disaster relief coordination system), CypressMFA (gesture-driven facial authentication for anti-spoofing), and SaveAPlate (a predictive modeling system to reduce food waste in dining halls).

Joshua's passion for innovation began at an early age. While still in high school, he invented the "Baby Saver" - a hot car alert device that sends automated alerts to parents and local authorities when the temperature inside a car crosses certain thresholds. This invention was inspired by his concern for child safety when his family was preparing for the birth of his younger brother. The device earned him first place in his grade category and the Safety Award at the 2020 Invention Convention Nationals, hosted by the Henry Ford Museum of American Innovation. His invention received national recognition for its potential to prevent tragic hot car deaths, which claim hundreds of children's lives annually. Joshua's early success with Baby Saver demonstrated his commitment to using technology to solve real-world problems and save lives.

suggested_people.name: Ben Cullen
suggested_people.short_description: Full stack engineer with expertise in AI/ML, currently working as an ML Engineer Intern at Spot Parking. Ben combines technical skills in machine learning, computer vision, and software development with business strategy acumen, having published research at AAAI and contributed to multiple startups. He is also known as "The Bake King," a renowned cake artist who creates hyper-realistic edible sculptures.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ben Cullen is a versatile full stack engineer with specialized expertise in AI/ML, currently serving as an ML Engineer Intern at Spot Parking where he's working on freeing up parking spaces through machine learning applications. He's pursuing a Computer Science degree with a Data Science emphasis at Brigham Young University, complemented by a minor in Business Strategy.

Ben's professional journey showcases a remarkable breadth of experience across AI and software development. At nCino, he developed features for their AI Assistant to enhance banker efficiency. His work at NEXU involved creating I.A.N., an AI phone platform that reduced referral verification time by 80%. As a Computer Vision Software Engineer at BYU, he achieved 99% accuracy in document layout analysis using image transformers, processing documents 64x faster and generating significant cost savings.

His technical versatility extends to full stack development, demonstrated through his work at ChoiceGuard Insurance Services where he built a HIPAA-compliant onboarding platform, and at Calisto Inc as a Founding Software Engineer, taking the company from zero software to a pilot with a major pest control company in just 5 months.

Ben's academic achievements are equally impressive, maintaining a 3.98 GPA and making the Dean's List four times. He co-authored a research paper published at the prestigious AAAI Conference on enhancing story comprehension for large language models through dynamic document-based knowledge graphs, which improved the quality of AI-generated text by up to 1.9x.

Beyond his tech career, Ben has an entirely separate professional identity as "The Bake King," one of the UK's most celebrated cake artists. He began his artistic journey as a graphic designer after studying Art & Design at Chester University, then worked as a tattoo artist before discovering his passion for creating hyper-realistic cakes. His transition to cake art began in 2014 when he made his first cake for his father, inspired by a design shown to him by a tattoo client's mother.

As The Bake King, Ben has won multiple gold awards at Cake International in 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019, and was named one of the UK's Top 10 Cake Artists at Cakemasters in 2019. His extraordinary talent for creating life-like edible sculptures has earned him celebrity clients like Rita Ora, appearances on Channel 4's "Extreme Cake Makers," and hundreds of thousands of followers across social media platforms. His work is particularly notable for making objects so realistic that they're often indistinguishable from the real items they represent.

Throughout both of his careers, Ben has demonstrated an exceptional ability to bridge technical innovation with artistic creativity and practical business applications, making him a uniquely versatile professional who excels in both technology and artistic fields.

suggested_people.name: Collin Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara with a minor in Mathematics, maintaining a 3.95 GPA. Currently serving as President of Alpha Kappa Psi. Collin has diverse software engineering experience across multiple industries, including Databricks, Amazon, Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory, and Intuitive. He excels in hackathons, having won first place in three competitive events.
suggested_people.long_description:
Collin Qian is a high-achieving fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara, complementing his technical studies with a minor in Mathematics. With an impressive 3.95/4.0 GPA and High Honors recognition, he demonstrates exceptional academic aptitude. His coursework includes Data Structures and Algorithms, Discrete Mathematics, Algorithms Engineering, Machine Learning, Object Oriented Design and Implementation, Computer Organization and Logic Design, Intelligent and Interactive Systems, Intro to Computational Science, Vector Calculus, Linear Algebra, and Differential Equations.

Collin has built a diverse portfolio of software engineering experience across multiple industries. He is currently at Databricks and is set to join their Multi Cloud Efficiency Team as a Software Engineer Intern in summer 2024. At Amazon, he implemented the Smart Home Widget using Alexa Presentation Language for an in-vehicle infotainment product, programmed the Weather Forecast APL Card feature for the Weather Widget leveraging APL Skill Connections, and produced a C++ Native App utilizing Yocto SDK for Widget rendering, improving rendering performance by 25%. He also contributed to 10+ code reviews, resulting in a 15% reduction in code defects. His previous experience includes working at Amazon's Smart Vehicles Team, contributing to marine conservation technology at the Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory on the WhaleSafe and SharkEye Projects, developing test automation at Rocket Lawyer, and supporting telepresence technology at Intuitive, a leader in surgical robotics.

Beyond his professional experience, Collin has demonstrated exceptional project development skills through hackathon competitions. He won first place at SB Hacks XI with SnapSell, a solution that automates the Facebook Marketplace selling process. He also secured first place in the 2024 Jumpstart Designathon, creating a wireframe for neurodivergent users to manage food waste, competing at the Intermediate+ level. Additionally, he won the Spring 2022 Blockchain Project Series, earning $3,750 for developing a web forum that incorporated cryptocurrency bounties for questions.

Collin is actively involved in campus leadership as the President of Alpha Kappa Psi, having previously served as VP of Internal Affairs, VP of Alumni Relations, and Philanthropy Director. He joined the fraternity during his freshman year and values the community of "intelligent and lively individuals" it has provided him.

Originally from Cupertino, CA, Collin's educational background includes international experience, having attended Shanghai High School International Division before completing his high school education at Monta Vista High School. He aspires to work in tech and possibly found his own company one day. In his free time, he enjoys playing sports like tennis, pickleball, volleyball, basketball, rock climbing, and weightlifting, as well as cooking new recipes.

Collin is an active GitHub user (CollinQ) with 12 followers and has contributed to numerous repositories, including projects for hackathons and university coursework. His combination of strong academic performance, diverse technical internships, leadership experience, and proven ability to develop innovative solutions in competitive environments positions him as a promising talent in the computer science field.

suggested_people.name: Thomaz Felipe Bonato
suggested_people.short_description: Brazilian AI researcher and entrepreneur studying at USC as a Trustee Scholar. Thomaz has excelled in hackathons, winning first place at HackMIT and second place at PennApps in 2024, while conducting AI research at USC Marshall School of Business focusing on educational applications and LLMs.
suggested_people.long_description:
Thomaz Felipe Bonato is a passionate engineer, researcher, and lifelong learner from Brazil currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence for Business at the University of Southern California as a prestigious Trustee Scholar with full tuition. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his National Merit Finalist status.

Thomaz has established himself as an exceptional hackathon competitor, securing first place at HackMIT 2024 with PalmLabs (focused on education) and second place at PennApps 2024 with Cypress MFA (addressing security and privacy challenges). He also won first place with Azalea, an eco-friendly AI model selector, demonstrating his commitment to sustainable AI solutions.

His professional experience spans multiple domains within AI and business. As an AI Research Assistant at USC Marshall School of Business since December 2023, he initially explored AI applications in education and has since expanded to researching LLMs and cluster-based probing techniques. Thomaz has entrepreneurial experience as a founder of a stealth startup focused on AI solutions for law firms, and currently serves as a Data Science Intern at Trudy and a Growth Strategist at Mercor.

Within the USC community, Thomaz has taken on leadership roles as the Director of Founder's Education at SEP (Student Entrepreneurship Program) and previously served as Director of External Relations for USC Business Technology Group. He was also a Student Founder at SEP, demonstrating his commitment to entrepreneurship education.

Thomaz is multilingual, with native proficiency in Portuguese and English, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. He is also a Management Leadership Tomorrow (MLT) Fellow, indicating his commitment to leadership development. His technical skills are evidenced by certifications in Linear Algebra for Machine Learning and Neural Networks and Deep Learning from DeepLearning.AI, as well as UX design skills certified by LinkedIn.

His contribution to policy is demonstrated through his publication "A Blueprint for Greece's AI Transformation" for the Special Secretariat for Foresight, Presidency of the Government, Hellenic Republic, showing his interest in AI governance and national strategy development.

It's important to note that there is another Thomaz Bonato who has had a distinguished career in the pharmaceutical industry, serving in various executive roles at AstraZeneca and Alexion. This Thomaz Bonato has held positions including US Chief Financial Officer and Vice President of Finance at AstraZeneca, Interim Country President of AstraZeneca Australia and New Zealand, and most recently as Global Head of Research Development & Medical Finance at Alexion. His career has included significant financial leadership roles across multiple countries including Brazil, Costa Rica, Australia, and the United States. However, this is a different individual than the USC student and AI researcher profiled here.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Arihan V.
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS student and accomplished ML researcher specializing in computer vision and LLM applications. With multiple hackathon wins and research experience at UNT's Computer Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Arihan has developed innovative solutions ranging from cropland optimization using neural networks to sign language interpretation systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arihan V. is a promising talent in the field of machine learning and AI, currently pursuing a Computer Science degree at Stanford University (Class of 2028). His technical journey began early, with exceptional academic performance at the Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science and Coppell High School.

As an Undergraduate Researcher at the University of North Texas Computer Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Arihan has worked on sophisticated projects funded by NASA, USGS, and Physmodo Inc. He also contributed to research at UNT's Functional Glass Materials and Modeling (FGMM) Laboratory as a TAMS student. His research contributions include developing bi-stream convolutional neural networks and deep learning autoencoders to identify cropland levees and optimize farming structures, as well as creating a novel human tracking method using point clouds and depth videos to improve pose estimation accuracy.

Arihan has demonstrated remarkable success in competitive environments, winning multiple hackathons with innovative AI solutions. His projects showcase versatility across different domains:
- Shush: A WhisperV3 model with Flash Attention v2 deployed on Modal via a NextJS app (197 GitHub stars)
- CoWorkr: An AI-powered team knowledge bot
- Koios GPT: A web application combining AI algorithms and LLMs to process research articles and PDFs (1st Place at HackLah! and Code4Good)
- Sign Ease: An app utilizing machine learning to interpret sign language gestures (Winner at MLH's Hack Your Portfolio)
- Transcribi: A web app leveraging OpenAI GPT, Whisper, and Langchain for audio transcription and analysis (1st Place Education Hack at PantherHack)
- SightSense: A wearable device using object detection and text-to-speech to aid visually impaired individuals (1st Place Generative AI at Treasure Hacks)
- ReadSpeak: A comprehensive app for improving reading and pronunciation skills (1st Place at LaunchHacks II)
- PromptGPT: A tool that generates efficient prompts using a custom, finetuned, opensource Dolly v2 model
- Zenset: An expressive writing and journaling app with rewards

His technical expertise spans Python, React, Next.js, TensorFlow, PyTorch, convolutional neural networks, machine learning, statistical analysis, and LLM applications. Arihan has also received recognition for his academic excellence, including the UNT President's List for a perfect 4.0 GPA and the TAMS Summer Scholarship for continued research work.

At Stanford, Arihan is part of the IRIS lab community, which focuses on robotics and machine learning research. He's also been selected as a National Security Innovation Scholar at the Gordian Knot Center for National Security Innovation.

Beyond his technical accomplishments, Arihan has demonstrated business acumen as a DECA Collegiate Business Ethics State Finalist and ICDC Qualifier. His multilingual capabilities include proficiency in English (native), Hindi, Telugu, and Spanish, reflecting his diverse skill set and global perspective.

name: william gao
short_description: Data Analyst at TikTok with expertise in AI and medical technology research. William combines his accounting background with advanced data science skills, having earned multiple technical certifications and recognition for his innovative work in AI-driven diagnostic systems for breast cancer detection.
long_description:
William Gao is a multifaceted professional currently working as a Data Analyst at TikTok, with an educational background from the University of California, Davis. He has developed a unique skill set that bridges accounting and data science, holding a CPA certification from the Washington State Board of Accountancy alongside numerous technical credentials.

William has built expertise in data analysis tools and programming languages, demonstrated by his impressive collection of certifications including AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner, Tableau Desktop Certified Associate, and various programming credentials in Java, Python, SQL, and data structures. His technical portfolio showcases his versatility across data visualization, cloud computing, and programming.

Beyond his professional work at TikTok, William has made significant contributions to scientific research. He developed an AI-driven diagnostic support and image analysis tool for metastatic breast cancer detection, which was recognized in the Regeneron Science Talent Search. His innovative system uses federated learning to analyze patient images without compromising privacy, making it particularly valuable for regions with limited access to skilled pathologists. This groundbreaking work was published in Cancer Informatics, where William served as first author.

During his time at Harvard University, William was affiliated with the Department of Molecular and Cell Biology, where he contributed to research on RNA structures. He was part of the Rivas Lab as an undergraduate researcher before pursuing MD/PhD studies at the University of Pennsylvania. His academic pursuits included work on Beta vulgaris mitovirus 1, demonstrating his versatility across different scientific domains.

William's professional approach is characterized by colleagues as elevating team performance. One recommendation notes that William "is one of those truly exceptional people that take your own abilities to another level by working with him," highlighting his mentorship abilities and technical coding skills. Another colleague praised his "rare mix of productivity, ambitions, and intellect" along with his unique and effective management style that fostered collaboration.

Beyond his academic and professional achievements, William is passionate about educational equity, having joined local board of education policy advisory committees to advocate for removing institutional barriers for underserved students. He is also a nationally ranked fencer who volunteers as an assistant youth coach. As a bilingual professional with fluency in English, Chinese, and Fuzhou Dialect, William brings a multicultural perspective to his work in data science, healthcare technology, and community service.

suggested_people.name: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta
suggested_people.short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

suggested_people.name: Zarif Azher
suggested_people.short_description: Bioengineering and Computer Science undergraduate at Caltech with extensive research experience in computational pathology and medical technology innovation. Published 10+ peer-reviewed papers in leading journals, focusing on applying AI and spatial transcriptomics to biomedical problems with the goal of expanding global healthcare access.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zarif Azher is an undergraduate student at Caltech pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Bioengineering and Computer Science (2024-2028). He is a passionate innovator and researcher at the intersection of AI and healthcare, with a particular focus on computational pathology, spatial transcriptomics, and medical technology development.

Zarif has an impressive research portfolio with over 10 peer-reviewed publications in prestigious journals and conferences, including the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing, BioData Mining, and the Journal of Pathology Informatics. His research spans innovative applications of AI in healthcare, such as inferring spatial transcriptomics from histological patterns, developing multimodal deep learning models for cancer prognostication, and creating interpretable AI systems for biomedical analysis.

His work has been cited over 60 times by researchers in the field, demonstrating the impact of his contributions to computational biology and medical AI. His recent projects include mapping three-dimensional tumor heterogeneity through deep learning inference of spatial transcriptomics from routine histopathology, and developing LLM-driven agent approaches to modeling legislative behavior.

Beyond his technical research, Zarif is committed to making healthcare more accessible globally. On his personal website, he states: "I want to use powerful technology to improve healthcare access and quality worldwide." He describes himself as a leader who organizes "people and things to accomplish ambitious goals" and a researcher developing "novel solutions to real-world issues – science for action, not observation."

Zarif's professional experience includes working in the Gao Research Group at Caltech and collaborating with researchers from institutions like Case Western Reserve University, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Dartmouth College. He has also been involved in projects to fight government corruption in Bangladesh, advocate for environmental justice in the USA, and deploy novel assistive technology for medical practitioners in underserved regions.

His interdisciplinary approach combines expertise in machine learning, bioinformatics, multimodal deep learning, cancer research, and pathology, positioning him as an emerging leader in the application of AI to solve complex healthcare challenges.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Diddi
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Diddi is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform bringing on-device AI solutions with a focus on privacy and accessibility. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, he specializes in Applied Machine Learning and has experience as an instructor at General Assembly. A graduate of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Dhruv combines technical expertise with entrepreneurial vision, particularly in healthcare AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Diddi is an engineer and entrepreneur based in the San Francisco Bay Area with specialized experience in Applied Machine Learning. He is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform that brings AI directly to users' devices, ensuring data privacy, personalized experiences, and accessibility without reliance on cloud infrastructure. Solo has particularly focused on healthcare applications, addressing challenges around data privacy (HIPAA compliance), accessibility in low-connectivity environments, and customization for specific healthcare scenarios.

Dhruv actively promotes Solo through his newsletter "Get Solo Tech" on Substack, where he discusses innovations like Solo Health, which aims to transform patient care through on-device AI that protects sensitive patient data while providing robust performance for diagnostics, patient monitoring, and workflow optimization.

As a tech community participant, Dhruv has been featured as a speaker and host at San Francisco tech events, including a panel discussion on "AI + Human Intelligence" where he presented Solo alongside other founders. He's also participated in hackathons, with his profile showing attendance at AI hackathon events.

Dhruv brings a strong educational foundation from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign where he was recognized as a James Scholar and made the Dean's List. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, including Machine Learning, Algorithms, Computer Architecture (Honors), Data Structures (Honors), Interactive Computer Graphics, and R Programming. His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English, Hindi, and Punjabi, along with working knowledge of French and Mandarin Chinese.

As an educator, Dhruv has received glowing recommendations for his work as an instructor at General Assembly's boot camp program. Former students praise his patience, extensive knowledge, and ability to break down complex concepts in accessible ways. His teaching style is described as easy-going yet effective, making him a favorite resource for students struggling with difficult concepts.

Dhruv maintains an active presence in the AI and tech community, regularly publishing his newsletter "So Essentially Weekly" that covers developments in the field. His project portfolio demonstrates versatility and practical application of his skills, including work with Illini Hyperloop, a Kaggle Challenge on Titanic Prediction, and various web and mobile applications like Flare, Anthem Web App, and a Dwolla Pebble App.

Dhruv's professional focus appears to be at the intersection of privacy-first AI applications and healthcare innovation, with an emphasis on bringing powerful machine learning capabilities directly to devices while protecting user data and ensuring accessibility regardless of internet connectivity.

name: rishi sai sadanandan
short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tan
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tan is a Stanford University alumnus and entrepreneur focused on democratizing career growth. With a strong background in computer science and data science from UC Berkeley, he has conducted research in stock market prediction using sentiment analysis and has been recognized with numerous academic honors including Phi Beta Kappa and the EECS Honors Program.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tan is an accomplished technologist and entrepreneur currently associated with Humans and Stanford University. He's working on democratizing access to career growth through his venture joinnova.co.

Andrew has an impressive academic background, having graduated from UC Berkeley where he was part of the EECS Honors Program and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa as a junior (top 20 students in his class). During his time at Berkeley, he excelled as a student instructor in the Data Science Department, earning recognition as an Outstanding Student Instructor.

His research interests include applying AI to financial markets, as evidenced by his publication "Sentiment Predictability for Stocks" where he explored stock market prediction using textual sentiment analysis tools and advanced prediction models like LSTMs and convolutional architectures.

Andrew has a strong entrepreneurial spirit, having been selected for the Pear VC Summer Fellowship which provided seed investment for his early-stage startup. He was also named a Jack Larson Scholar at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business, receiving a scholarship to pursue entrepreneurship in technology and research.

His technical talents were recognized early, being one of only 11 students nationwide awarded the Snap Research Scholarship for his academic performance, research experience, and ability to solve tough technical challenges. Before college, Andrew was the Salutatorian of his high school class and achieved success in both mathematics competitions (qualifying for AIME four times) and business competitions (placing 2nd at the DECA International Competition).

Andrew is bilingual, with native English proficiency and professional working proficiency in Chinese, adding to his versatile skill set that spans technology, research, and entrepreneurship.

It's important to note that there is another prominent Andrew Tan who is a Filipino billionaire businessman. This Andrew Tan is the chairman of Alliance Global Group, Inc., a major conglomerate with interests in real estate, food and beverage, gaming, and hospitality. Born in Fujian, China, he moved to Hong Kong at age 4 and later to the Philippines as a teenager. He graduated with a degree in accounting from the University of the East in Manila and built his fortune developing large apartment complexes around Manila. His company Megaworld Corporation pioneered the "live-work-play" concept in township development, and he also runs Emperador, the world's largest brandy company by sales volume. As of 2024, his net worth is estimated at $1.5 billion. This is a different individual from the Andrew Tan described in the main profile.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Tony Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, with a diverse portfolio spanning tech, venture capital, and public interest technology. He has research experience at Stanford AI Lab and Harvard Medical School, and has worked with companies like Amazon and Microsoft.
suggested_people.long_description:
Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University focusing on Artificial Intelligence. His professional experience spans multiple domains including venture capital, public interest technology, and software engineering.

At Stanford, Tony has taken on leadership roles as the Freshman Council President, where he managed $35,500 for over 1,700 students. He's also involved with TreeHacks as an Alumni Director and serves as the ACM ProCo Director.

Tony's venture capital experience includes positions as a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, a Scout at Soma Capital, and a Founder Fellow at RippleX Fellowship. His interest in public policy is evident through his work as a Fellow at Paragon Policy Fellowship and as a Co-Founder of the Public Interest Technology Lab at Stanford University, where he led the inaugural student govtech fellowship program.

His technical experience includes a software engineering internship at Amazon, contracting work for Swim England and Hypelist, and research at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) where he worked on deep learning to predict transcription factor binding motifs. He also conducted research at Harvard Medical School under the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Boston Children's Hospital.

Tony has received several prestigious recognitions, including being a Rise Fellow at Schmidt Futures, where he completed a fully-funded summer intensive in London/Oxford and founded the Rise North America Union. During his high school years at Amador Valley High School, he was the Salutatorian, a Coca-Cola Scholar, a National Merit Scholar, won two gold medals with Kungfu Team USA, and was an ISEF Finalist.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Tony has demonstrated a commitment to community service as the Founder and President of the Alameda County Science and Engineering Fair and as a Teaching Facilitator for Non-Trivial.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

name: samuel xie
short_description: Samuel Xie is a first-year Electrical Engineering & CS student at Caltech with a strong background in mathematics and computing. He contributes to Caltech's rocketry club by designing PWM control systems for rocket stabilization and conducts geophysics research modeling earthquakes using Python.
long_description:
Samuel Xie is a promising undergraduate student pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech), class of 2028. He previously attended The Lawrenceville School from 2020 to 2024.

Samuel currently serves as an Engineer for PARSEC, Caltech's Rocketry Club, where he contributes to the MARS/FAR Challenge aiming to launch a rocket to 45,000 ft with stable recovery. His technical contributions include designing and implementing PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) control systems to stabilize rockets during descent and developing control algorithms that integrate hardware/software systems for effective recovery dynamics.

Simultaneously, Samuel works as an Undergraduate Researcher at Caltech's Husker Lab, focusing on geophysics modeling of earthquakes using Python. His research involves analyzing seismic data, simulating earthquake behavior, and utilizing Python-based tools for numerical simulations, signal processing, and visualization of geophysical phenomena.

Samuel has demonstrated exceptional academic achievement, earning recognition as a National Merit Scholar Finalist and receiving the Hubert Alyea Award for excellence in Chemistry from the Princeton Section of the American Chemical Society. His computing skills are evidenced by his advancement to the USACO Gold Division in the USA Computing Olympiad. He has also qualified three times for the American Invitational Mathematics Exam between 2021 and 2023.

Beyond academics, Samuel is a talented athlete who earned the 2023 Scholastic All-American award from USA Swimming, which recognizes students who maintain a GPA of 3.5 or higher while achieving Winter Junior National Qualifying Times. This combination of technical aptitude, research experience, and athletic achievement demonstrates Samuel's well-rounded capabilities and potential for future contributions in engineering and computer science.

suggested_people.name: Alvin Zhang
suggested_people.short_description: Alvin Zhang is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at Caltech with diverse research interests spanning machine learning, statistical mechanics, and avionics. He balances academic pursuits with venture capital experience at New Era Ventures and leadership roles in Caltech's hackathon community while excelling as a competitive swimmer on Caltech's swim team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alvin Zhang is pursuing a BS in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at Caltech, where he has quickly established himself across multiple technical domains. His research portfolio demonstrates versatility and depth, currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher focused on enhancing LLM agents while simultaneously conducting research on long-range statistical mechanics models and simulations under Prof. Tom Hutchcroft's mentorship.

Beyond pure research, Alvin applies his technical skills in practical settings as an Avionics Engineer with PARSEC - Caltech Rocketry, where he develops hardware and software implementing rocket communication protocols. His interest in AI extends to his participation in the Caltech AI Alignment Machine Learning Fellowship, where he collaborates on novel AI research.

Alvin has also ventured into the entrepreneurial ecosystem as a Venture Fellow at New Era Ventures, where he focuses on early-stage investing. His community leadership is evident in his role as an Event Organizer for Hacktech, Caltech's annual hackathon, where he handles logistics and sponsorship sourcing.

As a student-athlete, Alvin is a valuable member of Caltech's Men's Swimming and Diving team, specializing in butterfly and breaststroke events. During the 2025 SCIAC Championships, he qualified for the championship final in the 100-yard butterfly, finishing in 7th place with a time of 49.90 seconds. His athletic achievements complement his academic pursuits, demonstrating his ability to excel in multiple demanding areas.

Prior to Caltech, Alvin attended Lakeside School (2020-2024) where he co-founded and served as Co-President of the Computer Science Club, organizing and directing club events. He was also a varsity swimmer, earning recognition as a 2022-23 NISCA Swimming and Diving All American and a member of the USA Swimming 2022-2023 Scholastic All-America Team. During his high school swimming career, he was a two-time Washington State Champion, winning the 50-yard freestyle and 100-yard butterfly events at the 2024 WIAA Boys 3A State Championship.

His other achievements include receiving the President's Volunteer Service Award (Silver) from AmeriCorps, qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) with Distinction four times, and being named a National Merit Scholarship Finalist. Alvin also demonstrated community service leadership as the Founder and Club President of an American Red Cross chapter from 2021 to 2024.

suggested_people.name: Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu
suggested_people.short_description: Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with diverse experience spanning aerospace, hardware engineering, and venture capital. Currently serving as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working at Amazon on ML quantization for embedded hardware and contributing to research at Stanford's PinCS Lab.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu is an Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University (2023-2027) with a remarkable breadth of technical and business experience. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, with a particular focus on the intersection of hardware and machine learning.

Currently, Yohannes serves as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working as a Hardware Engineer at Amazon in Sunnyvale, CA. At Amazon, he focuses on quantization of DNN models to be deployed on accelerators like NNA and MDLA for firmware applications such as Alexa. His work involves creating automated frameworks for NNA.3x aware training to avoid floating point numbers and transform to fixed point numbers, as well as extending frameworks to support TensorFlow model quantization and converting compatible audiotech models into firmware.

Yohannes is actively engaged in research at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, specifically in the PinCS Lab (Pedagogy in Computer Science Lab) where he works as an Undergraduate Researcher building drones. His aerospace interests extend to his earlier work as a Student Researcher at NASA, where he tested Aerogel insulation against radiation at 70,000 feet using weather balloon capsules.

His academic involvement at Stanford includes participation in the Leland Scholars Program, where he contributed to a research project titled "Equity in AI: Navigating Bias Through a Human-Centric Framework," analyzing approaches and implementing a paradigm shift for unbiased and ethical artificial intelligence.

Prior to Stanford, Yohannes worked as a Software Engineer at the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada, where he developed quantitative predictive modeling for city car crash data. He also conducted research at the University of Las Vegas Nevada for the International Science Fair, publishing work on "Analysis of Supersonic Parachutes On ReEntry" that examined crucial aspects of parachute design for rocket capsule reentry at supersonic speeds.

Yohannes possesses an impressive array of technical skills including machine learning frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras), programming languages (Python, C++, Java), hardware tools (Raspberry Pi, PCB design), robotics, computer vision (OpenCV), and data analysis tools (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Scikit-learn). His expertise also extends to aerospace engineering, mechatronics, embedded systems, and sensor fusion.

Based in both Palo Alto, CA and Las Vegas, NV, Yohannes represents a unique blend of technical depth across hardware engineering, aerospace, machine learning optimization, and venture capital experience - making him a versatile contributor to the AI and technology ecosystem.

suggested_people.name: Alan Wu
suggested_people.short_description: Alan Wu is a Caltech student and accomplished competitive programmer with a passion for AI research, particularly in large language models and autonomous driving. He has won multiple prestigious competitions including the Citadel Data Open Global Championship and has published research on LLM linearization and 3D semantic segmentation.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alan Wu is a junior studying Computer Science at Caltech, having transferred from Harvey Mudd College where he studied Computer Science and Mathematics from 2021 to 2023. His academic interests span across programming, mathematics, and artificial intelligence, with a particular focus on large language models and computer vision for autonomous driving.

Alan's research contributions include work on "LoLCATs: On Low-Rank Linearizing of Large Language Models" (ICLR 2025), which proposes a novel two-step approach to linearize LLMs while maintaining model quality, and "DenseFuseNet: Improve 3D Semantic Segmentation in the Context of Autonomous Driving with Dense Correspondence" (IEEE), which explores multi-modal perception systems for autonomous vehicles. His high school research on 3D semantic segmentation earned him the Bronze Prize (3rd place) in the prestigious S.-T Yau High School Science Award, competing against over 1000 global research projects.

Currently, Alan works with RSRG@Caltech on distributional robust reinforcement learning and uncertainty quantification. He has also conducted research on theoretical ML with Prof. George Montanez at the AMISTAD Lab, resulting in a paper published in ICAART 2024 titled "From Targets to Rewards: Continuous Target Sets in the Algorithmic Search Framework."

His competitive achievements are remarkable, having won first place in the Citadel Data Open Global Championship ($100,000 prize), first place in the Data Open 2021 West Coast ($10,000 prize), and the IMC Prosperity 2 trading challenge ($25,000 prize) with his team. He also placed 4th in the Terminal Global Championship 2022 and was among the top performers in the Berkeley Trading Competition.

Alan's professional experience includes internships at Jump Trading as a research intern (Summer 2024), Jane Street as a trading intern (Summer 2023), and Crabel Capital Management (part-time). He is also the founder and leader of the Caltech Quant Finance Club.

In 2021, Alan was selected for the prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, recognizing his potential to advance knowledge and benefit society. He describes himself as someone who "loves to meet and compete with the brightest minds," reflecting his passion for intellectual challenges and collaborative innovation.

In his free time, Alan enjoys playing badminton and table tennis, balancing his intense academic and professional pursuits with recreational activities.

suggested_people.name: Dylan Nguyen
suggested_people.short_description: MIT '28 undergraduate researcher integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for mRNA lipid nanoparticle manufacturing. Amazon Future Engineer Scholar with extensive experience in computational biology, neuroscience, and machine learning applications, having won multiple prestigious awards including 3rd Place at the International Science & Engineering Fair.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dylan Nguyen is a first-year undergraduate student at MIT (Class of 2028) with a remarkable background in computational biology, neuroscience, and AI research. Currently working as an Undergraduate Research Assistant at MIT Chemical Engineering, he's integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for manufacturing mRNA lipid nanoparticles in the Myerson Research Group.

Dylan's research experience is impressive for his age. He has worked as a Scientific Programming Intern at the Max Planck Florida Institute for Neuroscience and has completed several significant research projects, including modeling the Drosophila Melanogaster nerve cord using spiking neural networks, applying deep learning to predict cytokines in Sickle Cell Anemia patients, and exploring machine learning for morphological neuron classification in the neocortex.

His academic achievements are equally notable. Dylan is an Amazon Future Engineer Scholarship recipient, which provides $40,000 towards college tuition and a guaranteed paid internship at Amazon. He's also a Kovner Opportunity Scholarship recipient, supporting talented public high school students to attend selective universities.

In competitive programming, Dylan has reached the Gold Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO). His scientific research has earned him prestigious recognitions, including 3rd Place Grand Award in Biomedical and Health Sciences at the 2023 Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair, the Regeneron Biomedical Science Award, and finalist status at the National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium.

Currently, Dylan is also an AMP Scholar at Jane Street, where he's learning mathematics, computer programming, data analysis, and game theory. Previously, he participated in MIT's Introduction to Technology, Engineering, and Science (MITES) program, taking classes in Science Writing Communications and Regenerative Stem Cell Biology.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Dylan has ventured into entrepreneurship as a co-founder of Tally.AI, a startup that empowers researchers with AI-driven aggregation and analysis of scientific papers. Working alongside fellow MIT students and graduate students from other prestigious institutions, Tally.AI aims to prevent duplicative research efforts, enhance collaboration between research groups, and help researchers stay up-to-date with the latest works in their fields through features like similarity scoring, knowledge graphs, and real-time alerts.

Dylan's diverse projects demonstrate his versatility in applying computational methods across different domains, from neuroscience to financial trading, showcasing his ability to leverage AI and machine learning for solving complex problems in both research and entrepreneurial contexts.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

name: bill qian
short_description: Yale '26 computer science student in the BS/MS program with a background in competitive programming and mathematics. Currently researching LLMs and code generation, with experience in systems and machine learning. Incoming Software Engineering Intern at Citadel Securities with previous roles at The New York Times and Yale's Gerstein Laboratory. Also serves as Chairman of Cypher Capital, a prominent multi-strategy crypto investment firm.
long_description:
Bill Qian is a computer science student at Yale University (Class of 2026) pursuing a combined BS/MS degree. His technical foundation stems from competitive programming (USACO/ICPC) and mathematics (USAMO/Putnam), which has evolved into expertise in systems, machine learning, and full-stack development.

At Yale's Gerstein Laboratory, Bill has established himself as a researcher in Large Language Models and code generation, publishing multiple papers in natural language processing. His research contributions include work on "ToolLLM: Facilitating Large Language Models to Master 16000+ Real-world APIs" and "BioCoder: A Benchmark for Bioinformatics Code Generation with Contextual Pragmatic Knowledge." He has collaborated with researchers from prominent organizations including Google DeepMind.

Bill's professional experience spans diverse environments. He's secured an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Citadel Securities (New York) focusing on high-performance C++. Previously, he worked at The New York Times on their Research and Development team, exploring ethical applications of AI and LLMs in journalism. At DeepMedia, he designed and optimized algorithms for heterogeneous data analysis, creating a machine translation model with 10% better performance than competitors using Transformers, Python, PyTorch, and Rust.

His technical versatility extends to infrastructure development, having designed distributed computing systems using AWS, Azure, and on-premise hardware with Docker, Kubernetes, and SQS. At Thomas Ho Company, he applied neural networks to assess mortgage loan pricing models and implemented ETL pipelines that improved data processing efficiency by 30%.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Bill is actively involved in campus life as a Project Manager at the Student Technology Collaborative, where he manages knowledge base development and provides technical support across multiple operating systems. He balances his technical interests with creative outlets, singing with the Yale Glee Club and making short films.

In parallel to his academic career, Bill serves as the Chairman of Cypher Capital, a leading multi-strategy crypto investment firm based in the UAE. Before joining Cypher Capital in 2022, he was the Global Head of Fundraising, Binance Labs, and M&A for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency platform. Prior to that, he was Head of Investment for Fintech and Technology at JD.com, a leading Asian internet platform generating over $400 billion in annual gross merchandise volume.
