suggested_people.name: Arnav Adhikari
suggested_people.short_description: 19-year-old EECS and Finance student at MIT with a passion for building innovative solutions in fintech, robotics, and healthtech. First place winner at HackMIT 2024 with a nicotine cessation patch project, and currently working on semantic operators at MIT CSAIL while also running a stealth startup.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arnav Adhikari is a dynamic 19-year-old undergraduate at MIT pursuing a dual focus in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and Finance. His technical interests span across multiple domains including fintech (payments, wealth management, AI analysts), robotics (collaboration and control), healthtech (LLM-aided care), and productivity tools. He describes himself as a "big proponent of automating the mundane" and believes that jobs should be automated to redirect human attention toward tasks requiring ingenuity.

Arnav has built an impressive track record of achievements. Most notably, he and his team won the First Place Grand Prize at HackMIT 2024 with their algorithmically-driven nicotine cessation patch. He's currently working as a Builder at MIT's prestigious Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), focusing on semantic operators.

Entrepreneurially minded, Arnav is the Founder and CEO of a stealth startup that he's been running since January 2024. His previous experience includes work at Boston Consulting Group (BCM), Rice University, Stanford's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI), and Harvard Medical School, demonstrating his ability to collaborate with top-tier institutions across academia and industry.

Arnav's research work is particularly notable in healthcare technology. He has worked on cardiac imaging interpretability and standardized cardiac measurements at BCM, Texas Children's Hospital, and Stanford AIMI, with his work being featured in Circulation by the American Heart Association in November 2023. He has also analyzed teamwork synergy for AI Surgical Robotic Coaches at Rice HCAIR and Harvard Medical School, and developed smarter irrigation and water management systems for the City of Southside Place in Houston.

His technical background is further strengthened by his experience in robot motion planning and control at Rice RobotPI, and his achievements as a retired USAJMO winner and USACO Gold Medalist. Arnav is also an author, having written the Cubronix Competitive Math Practice Book for charity, which was featured in the Houston Chronicle in January 2022.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Arnav offers tutoring services in the Greater Houston area, specializing in math, science, engineering, and test preparation. He enjoys tennis, basketball, football, biking, the outdoors, and various forms of media entertainment.

Currently a freshman at MIT (class of 2028), Arnav graduated from Carnegie Vanguard High School in 2024 after previously attending Bellaire High School. He describes himself as someone who loves "learning and building fast," and is always open to discussing innovative ideas and groundbreaking technologies.

suggested_people.name: Om Shastri
suggested_people.short_description: Wharton student in the Management and Technology Program, former varsity wrestler, and Dorm Room Fund associate with a background in robotics research and astronomical instrumentation. Published researcher with experience in edge computing and polarimetry, balancing interests in technology, investment, and scientific research while serving as a student manager for Penn's wrestling team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Om Shastri is a student in the prestigious Management and Technology Program at The Wharton School and The School of Engineering and Applied Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing a triple major in Computer Science, Finance, and Entrepreneurship. He currently works with Dorm Room Fund, helping identify and invest in promising student-led startups.

His research experience is particularly impressive, having published in prestigious journals like Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society on high-precision polarimetry using CMOS image sensors, and in MDPI Sensors on edge-intelligent IoT systems for mosquito threat prediction (MOSQUITO EDGE). This demonstrates his technical versatility across astronomy and edge computing applications.

Om has been involved with several research institutions, including the GRASP Lab (likely focusing on robotics and automation) and the Monterey Institute for Research and Astronomy. His leadership experience includes serving as Co-CEO of X Academy Hephaestus Robotics and as a TMT Analyst for the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, showing his ability to bridge technical expertise with business acumen.

Before Penn, Om was a standout wrestler at Los Gatos High School in California, where he served as team captain and achieved impressive accomplishments including qualifying for the California State tournament, winning the CA World Challenge Championship, and earning titles as League and District champion. He was also recognized as the Bay Area Student Athlete of the Year and maintained high academic honors throughout his four years.

Currently, Om serves as a student manager for the University of Pennsylvania wrestling team after competing as a freshman during the 2023-24 season at 184/197 pounds. Though his competitive record was 0-6, he gained valuable experience participating in tournaments including the Keystone Classic, Patriot Open, and F&M Open.

Om's professional experience includes internships at NASA, the US Army, CLA, and Ripple Ventures, providing him with diverse exposure across government, consulting, and venture capital sectors. He's an active participant in the AI hackathon circuit, having competed in prestigious events including x.ai Hackathon, TreeHacks, HackMIT, HackHarvard, Microsoft Internal AI Hackathon, and PennApps.

His achievements include receiving the Congressional Gold Medal Award from the United States Congress in September 2022, recognizing his exceptional service and achievement. He has also completed certifications in Business Analysis, Data Analysis, and Generative AI through Microsoft and LinkedIn, showing his commitment to staying current with emerging technologies.

Om is the son of Medha and Parthesh Shastri, and his personal interests likely include following developments in AI, quantum computing, cybersecurity, and startup funding, particularly in the tech sector. This holistic profile presents Om as a multifaceted individual with strong technical foundations, research credentials, and business interests, positioned at the intersection of technology, finance, and scientific innovation.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

name: vatsal baherwani
short_description: Vatsal Baherwani is a computer science undergraduate at the University of Maryland focused on AI research, particularly in making AI more accessible, interpretable, and trustworthy. He is a research fellow at the Center for Human-Compatible AI, working to ensure AI systems align with human values and safety.
long_description:
Vatsal Baherwani is an undergraduate computer science student at the University of Maryland, set to graduate in 2025. His research interests center on making artificial intelligence more accessible, interpretable, and trustworthy. As a research fellow at the Center for Human-Compatible AI, he works on ensuring AI systems remain aligned with human values and safety considerations.

Vatsal's research portfolio includes several notable projects. He has investigated how video diffusion models encode motion information in early timesteps of the diffusion process, leading to a method for targeted video motion customization. He co-authored a paper on improving routing for sparsely-gated mixture-of-experts models that was accepted at NeurIPS 2024. Additionally, his work on racial and gender stereotypes encoded in CLIP representations was published at ICLR 2024 as a Tiny Paper.

Beyond his research, Vatsal is an active writer who shares his knowledge about AI concepts through his Medium blog. His articles include explanations of gradient descent in AI learning, perspectives on AI-proofing education, and philosophical reflections on finding passion. This demonstrates his commitment to making complex AI concepts accessible to broader audiences.

Vatsal has a strong technical foundation, having completed certifications in deep learning through Kaggle, machine learning through Stanford Online, and financial market concepts through Bloomberg. His GitHub profile showcases various projects including Shore-Defense, StudySession, PlayboardWeb, and Plannet - a platform for friends to collaboratively plan hangouts.

As an emerging researcher in the field of human-compatible artificial intelligence, Vatsal combines technical expertise with a focus on the ethical implications of AI development. His interdisciplinary approach and commitment to AI safety position him as a thoughtful contributor to the field of AI research.

suggested_people.name: Max Forsey
suggested_people.short_description: Max Forsey is an AI researcher at the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University who explores the fundamental nature of intelligence. As a co-founder of justbuild.ing and former Vice President of BYU's Artificial Intelligence Association, he actively organizes AI hackathons and community events while developing practical tools to advance the field.
suggested_people.long_description:
Max Forsey is a dedicated AI researcher affiliated with the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University, where he explores the fundamental nature of intelligence through artificial intelligence systems. His research has led to publications like "Gradient Sparse Autoencoders," which introduces novel approaches to extracting neural network features.

Max has taken on leadership roles in the AI community, serving as the Vice President of the BYU Artificial Intelligence Association, where he helped organize events and foster a community of AI enthusiasts. In November 2024, he co-founded "justbuild.ing," an initiative focused on building a community of AI developers and hosting collaborative events.

He is particularly active in organizing and participating in AI hackathons, recently working with Sameday through the justbuild community to host a 2-hour AI hackathon featuring Cerebras Systems. His involvement in these rapid development events demonstrates his commitment to practical AI application and innovation.

Beyond his research, Max is passionate about creating practical AI tools. He developed FreshSesh AI, a developer tool that uses local LLMs to provide personalized context summaries of previous work sessions, helping developers quickly get back into flow. He's also reimplemented Andrej Karpathy's nanoGPT, showing his hands-on approach to understanding AI systems.

Max maintains a personal website where he shares detailed resources for those looking to bridge the gap between using AI APIs and actually training models. His curated learning path includes visual resources, essential reading, and practical project suggestions for newcomers to the field. He emphasizes starting with fundamentals and learning through implementation, reflecting his own approach to AI development.

Outside of his professional interests, Max maintains a holistic approach to life, with detailed attention to health and longevity practices. He values deep friendships and community connections, having written thoughtfully about the nature of friendship and human connection. His background combines theoretical AI research with practical application, demonstrating a commitment to both advancing the field and making AI more accessible to others.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Aaquib Syed
suggested_people.short_description: AI researcher at Google with a focus on interpretability and language model behavior. Aaquib has published significant work on refusal mechanisms in LLMs, attribution patching for circuit discovery, and efficient pruning techniques for massive language models. A Banneker-Key Scholar at the University of Maryland with a strong competitive programming background.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aaquib Syed is an AI researcher currently working at Google while affiliated with the University of Maryland, where he is pursuing a CS and Math degree as a Banneker-Key Scholar (full merit scholarship for the top 0.5% of incoming class). His research focuses on understanding and improving large language models, with particular emphasis on interpretability and model behavior mechanisms.

His recent publication "Refusal in Language Models Is Mediated by a Single Direction" (NeurIPS 2024, Poster) has garnered significant attention with 98+ citations. This groundbreaking work demonstrates that refusal behavior in conversational LLMs is controlled by a one-dimensional subspace across multiple open-source chat models, providing important insights into how safety mechanisms function in these systems.

Aaquib has also made significant contributions to automated interpretability research with his work "Attribution Patching Outperforms Automated Circuit Discovery" (BlackboxNLP at EMNLP 2024), which has received 47+ citations. In this paper, he developed a simple yet powerful method based on attribution patching that outperforms existing approaches while requiring minimal computational resources - just two forward passes and a backward pass.

In the area of model efficiency, his research "Prune and Tune: Improving Efficient Pruning Techniques for Massive Language Models" (ICLR TinyPapers Workshop 2023, top 6%) advanced techniques for pruning large language models without extensive retraining, addressing critical compute expense issues in deploying massive models.

His most recent work includes "Mechanistic Unlearning: Robust Knowledge Unlearning and Editing via Mechanistic Localization" (2024), exploring techniques for targeted knowledge editing in language models.

Beyond pure AI research, Aaquib has applied machine learning to medical imaging, co-authoring a paper in PLOS ONE that uses XGBoost with MRI and non-imaging data to predict pathological complete response in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

As a student, Aaquib has received numerous prestigious recognitions, including the USA Computing Olympiad Gold rank and the National Merit Scholarship. He has also developed several projects including a Personal Distance Monitor, a Stress Level Manager for students with autism spectrum disorder, and a FIRST Robotics Competition Scouting system.

According to his GitHub profile, Aaquib describes himself as someone who enjoys "thinking about and solving problems in AI/ML and finance" with a current interest in "creating scalable methods to attribute and edit behaviors and knowledge in large language models." He also mentions a love for competitive programming, working with low-level languages, and creating infrastructure and trading strategies for financial markets.

His interests span AI/ML and finance, with a particular focus on solving complex problems at the intersection of these fields. Aaquib's combination of theoretical research and practical applications demonstrates his versatility and depth of expertise in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Liangze Li
suggested_people.short_description: Liangze Li is an AI researcher at Google DeepMind with a background from Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science. His research focuses on natural language processing and AI detection, with publications on distinguishing human from AI-generated content. He has demonstrated leadership through founding multiple organizations at CMU and is multilingual with proficiency in Mandarin, English, Cantonese, and Russian.
suggested_people.long_description:
Liangze Li is an AI researcher currently working at Google DeepMind, one of the world's leading artificial intelligence research labs. He joined DeepMind in 2024 after completing his education at Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science, where he earned his Master's degree in Language Technologies. His academic journey at CMU began in 2017 as an undergraduate student before continuing with graduate studies from 2022 to 2024.

Liangze's research focuses primarily on natural language processing and AI detection systems. He has published several notable papers in this field, including "GPT-Sentinel: Distinguishing Human and ChatGPT Generated Content" and "Token Prediction as Implicit Classification to Identify LLM-Generated Text," both published in 2023. These works have received significant attention in the academic community, with his GPT-Sentinel paper garnering over 70 citations. He has also contributed to research on referential games in NLP with his paper "Listener Model for the PhotoBook Referential Game with CLIPScores as Implicit Reference Chain."

During his time at Carnegie Mellon, Liangze demonstrated exceptional leadership and initiative by founding and presiding over several organizations. He was the Founder and President of the CMU Blackjack Society, as well as the Founder and Lecturer of the Carnegie Mellon University Student College. He also served as President of the Student College Executive Committee and as a Representative in the Graduate Student Assembly.

Before focusing on AI and natural language processing, Liangze had research interests in cryptography, with several publications between 2012-2014 on topics such as pairing computation on Edwards curves and Jacobi quartic curves with high-degree twists. This demonstrates his versatility and depth of knowledge across different areas of computer science.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Liangze has diverse interests in music, having played Alto Saxophone in both the Carnegie Mellon University Kiltie Band and the Pinghe Chamber Orchestra. His intellectual curiosity extends to philosophy as well, as evidenced by his founding of the Pinghe School Philosophy Club and his connection to CMU's Department of Philosophy.

Liangze is impressively multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Mandarin and English, full professional proficiency in Cantonese, and limited working proficiency in Russian. This linguistic versatility enhances his ability to collaborate in international research settings.

In his own words, Liangze describes himself as being "involved in AI research and startups," indicating his dual interests in both the theoretical advancement of AI and its practical applications in entrepreneurial contexts. His engagement with posts related to machine learning, AI development, and technology startups on LinkedIn further reflects his professional focus and interests in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

name: advait iyer
short_description: Computer Engineer with expertise in computer systems, specializing in hardware and software engineering. Currently a Software Engineer at Tesla with research experience in GPU-accelerated data analytics, and a published paper on overcoming memory capacity limitations in large-scale data analytics.
long_description:
Advait Iyer is a Computer Engineer with a strong focus on computer systems and hardware design. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a Bachelor of Science in Engineering in 2024. Advait has built an impressive career trajectory, currently working as a Software Engineer at Tesla while also contributing to academic research.

His technical expertise spans C/C++, Verilog/SystemVerilog, and Python, with a particular interest in computer architecture and systems design. At Tesla, Advait has worked on several significant projects including the revamped on-screen PRND gear slider for the 2024 Model 3 released in Europe and China, navigation and controls features, and a performance monitoring library for the infotainment system. He also contributed to the development of the new weather feature for the 2024 summer release.

As a Hardware Engineer at Aethero, Advait helped build space-rated edge AI computers, demonstrating his versatility across both software and hardware domains. His academic contributions include serving as an Instructional Assistant for Advanced Computer Architecture (EECS 470) and Digital Logic Design (EECS 270) at the University of Michigan. In the Computer Architecture course, he taught lab sections on hardware design using SystemVerilog and helped students design synthesizable out-of-order RISC-V processors. For the Logic Design course, he co-created and maintained the course's RTL DV platform deployed on autograder.io using Docker, which was used by approximately 300 computer engineering students per semester.

Advait's research as a Research Assistant in the CE Lab at the University of Michigan focused on GPU acceleration for heterogeneous LLM/DB workloads, resulting in a publication titled "Vortex: Overcoming Memory Capacity Limitations in GPU-Accelerated Large-Scale Data Analytics" accepted to VLDB 2025.

His impressive project portfolio includes a 94 MHz RISC-V CPU with P6 style renaming and N-way superscalar design, a foldable cloth piano, formal verification of a fault-tolerant cache coherence protocol, and various FPGA design projects. He has also worked on robotic planning and controls projects and numerous C/C++ projects including a RISC-V assembler, simulator, and linker.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Advait has explored entrepreneurship and venture capital as a Venture Partner at Contrary for over three years. He has also worked at Marathon Digital Holdings (MARA) as an Engineering Intern optimizing merged mining protocols, and contributed to Zepto (formerly KiranaKart, YC W21) in operations, growth, and engineering roles.

Advait has also written about the intersection of data science and spirituality, exploring how machine learning concepts can provide insights into human behavior and decision-making. His writing demonstrates his ability to connect technical concepts with broader philosophical ideas.

His academic achievements include being a runner-up in the APS History of Physics Essay Contest and winning the Gold Award in the Queen's Commonwealth Essay Competition. He is multilingual, with proficiency in English, French, Hindi, and Tamil, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Fengrui Zuo
suggested_people.short_description: Fengrui Zuo is a hardware specialist focusing on Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory. With a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, he brings specialized expertise in hardware acceleration for AI applications and serves as an Analog Design Co-Lead and Industry Outreach Officer at Open Source Silicon @ Stanford.
suggested_people.long_description:
Fengrui Zuo is a hardware engineer specializing in Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, which is operated by Stanford University. He currently holds dual positions as a Staff Engineer at SLAC and is pursuing his Master's degree in Electrical Engineering (MSEE) at Stanford University, which he began in Autumn 2023.

Fengrui has established himself as a leader in the open-source silicon community at Stanford, where he serves in multiple leadership roles. He is the Industry Outreach Officer for Open Source Silicon @ Stanford (OS3), helping to bridge academic research with industry applications. Additionally, he co-leads the Analog Design Subteam at OS3, where he focuses on designing and verifying analog components such as amplifiers, voltage references, and Power Management ICs (PMICs). His work involves device simulations, schematic generation and routing using both open-source and proprietary software, and conducting bench testing and verification.

His technical expertise spans across several domains including CUDA kernel optimization, autonomous systems, and chip design. Fengrui demonstrates particular interest in cutting-edge hardware developments such as NVIDIA's Jetson Orin Nano platform for edge AI applications, open-source chip design, and specialized motherboards with timing synchronization capabilities. His work at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory likely involves specialized hardware systems for scientific research and experimentation, integrating AI capabilities into high-performance computing environments for physics research.

Fengrui's professional address is at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, located at 2575 Sand Hill Rd, Menlo Park, California. His dual role as both a graduate student and staff engineer positions him uniquely at the intersection of academic research and practical engineering applications, particularly in the field of analog design for advanced computing systems.

suggested_people.name: Natnael Kahssay
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Engineering student at MIT with a unique blend of hardware expertise spanning RF systems, FPGA design, and nano-fabrication. Founder of Saverntronics technologies and researcher in bioelectronics, Natnael combines hands-on engineering with entrepreneurial vision.
suggested_people.long_description:
Natnael Kahssay is a Computer Science and Engineering student at MIT with an impressive breadth of technical expertise across hardware domains. His background spans RF systems, FPGA design, nano-fabrication, and hardware design, with proficiency in programming languages including Bluespec, C, and Python, as well as industry tools like Cadence and Vivado.

As an undergraduate researcher in MIT's Bioelectronics Group, Natnael works on cutting-edge optogenetic-based waveguide and neural implants used to study stress in addiction susceptibility, demonstrating his ability to apply engineering principles to neuroscience research. His academic contributions extend to teaching roles, where he serves as a Laboratory Teaching Assistant for Digital System Laboratory I (6.205), helping students implement digital design projects on Sparta-7 FPGAs.

Natnael's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Saverntronics technologies, where he led the development of an autonomous barbing machine, handling both digital modeling and actuator response characterization. This venture showcases his ability to take technical concepts from ideation to implementation.

His project portfolio reflects his diverse interests, including work on an 802.11a Physical layer on RFSoC, Nano MEMS Mirrors, and various software projects. On GitHub, he maintains several open-source projects, including "gestures" (a fluid gestures system for Linux with 68 stars), and extensions for GNOME window management. His GitHub profile, where he goes by "natask," emphasizes his philosophy that "Productivity is key. Planning is essential."

Natnael has also contributed to significant academic projects, including an HFT (High-Frequency Trading) Accelerator developed with his brother Endrias Kahssay and teammate Ziheng Wang as part of MIT's 6.111 (Digital Systems Laboratory) final project in Fall 2019. This project demonstrated his ability to work on complex, time-sensitive computational systems.

Currently, Natnael is set to join Etched, indicating his continued trajectory in the technology sector. His multidisciplinary background at the intersection of computer science, electrical engineering, and bioelectronics positions him uniquely in the field of hardware engineering and design.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Porvesh Balasubramanian
suggested_people.short_description: Porvesh is a fourth-year Computer Science student at the University of Michigan with a unique blend of expertise in systems engineering, robotics, and distributed computing. As a Founding Engineer at Bronco AI, he's developing AI agents for chip design and verification while simultaneously contributing to autonomous vehicle research and distributed systems validation.
suggested_people.long_description:
Porvesh Balasubramanian is a fourth-year Computer Science student at the University of Michigan who has carved out a distinctive path at the intersection of systems engineering, robotics, and AI. Currently serving as a Founding Engineer at Bronco AI, he's building cutting-edge AI agents for chip design and verification.

His technical versatility is evident through his diverse research experiences. At Michigan's Real Time Computing Lab, Porvesh built and raced F1Tenth autonomous vehicles, demonstrating his hands-on skills in robotics. Simultaneously, he contributed to OrderLab's distributed systems research, working on OathKeeper—a tool that validates distributed systems by detecting and enforcing semantic rules at runtime.

Porvesh's industry experience includes a role as a Mission System Software Intern at Northrop Grumman, where he automated boot image generation, reducing processing time from 5 weeks to just 3 minutes. He's also worked as a Software Intern at DealsPlus, implementing a Flask-based backend and enhancing user experience with the Quasar Framework.

His academic contributions extend beyond research. Porvesh serves as a grader for advanced courses like Embedded Systems and Advanced Data Structures, and works as an Engineering Center Tutor providing one-on-one assistance for upper-level EECS classes. Previously, he led study groups for introductory data structures and algorithms courses.

Porvesh's technical foundation is complemented by a strong educational background, with coursework spanning algorithms, computer architecture, embedded systems, operating systems, robotics, and deep learning. He's consistently maintained a 3.8/4.0 GPA, earning a place on the Dean's Honor List every semester.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Porvesh has demonstrated leadership through various roles, including as part of the "Cyber Safety Team" at the University of Michigan's Barger Leadership Institute, where he created a resource guide about cybersecurity for students. He's also an active developer with several GitHub repositories, including a personal game engine called "EnfieldEngine" written in C++ and contributions to real-time object detection for autonomous driving using deep learning.

Porvesh is also an accomplished cricket player, representing the University of Michigan in various tournaments including CACTUS 2024 and playing for teams like Detroit Challengers CC and Chicago Panthers. As an all-rounder, he has demonstrated skills in both batting and bowling across multiple T20 matches.

In 2022, he was part of a team that developed "Freshify," an application that uses artificial intelligence to track food expiration dates and provide tailored recipe recommendations, showcasing his interest in practical AI applications. His diverse interests and technical skills make him a versatile computer scientist with experience spanning from embedded systems to artificial intelligence.

name: zeyneb nahide kaya
short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese. Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

suggested_people.name: Trishala Neeraj
suggested_people.short_description: Trishala Neeraj is a Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube with a strong academic background from Cornell University. She specializes in computer vision and natural language processing, bringing technical expertise to cybersecurity analytics and has contributed to several influential AI research papers.
suggested_people.long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. She works with terabyte-scale data to develop models using Deep Learning and Matrix Factorization techniques, with a particular focus on language data and models.

Her academic foundation was built at Cornell University, where she graduated in 2018 after focusing on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing during her graduate studies. She also holds a Bachelor of Engineering degree from BITS Pilani, India, and spent time as a visiting research scholar at the Predictive Technology Lab at the University of Virginia.

Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022). Her work on "BigBIO: A Framework for Data-Centric Biomedical Natural Language Processing" (2022) has also gained recognition in the field.

Her professional experience includes a summer internship at BuzzFeed in 2017, where she worked on a project using K-Means Clustering to tag over 14,000 BuzzFeed quizzes, which she documented in a blog post on the BuzzFeed Tech Blog. She has also published research on "A Computational Approach to Perceived Trustworthiness of Airbnb Host Profiles" (2017) and "Longitudinal Analysis of Cyber-Related Articles" (2020).

Beyond her technical work, Trishala has been actively involved in the tech community. She represented the student body at the Cornell Tech Campus Dedication ceremony in August 2017 and moderated a conversation with Eric Schmidt in March 2018. She maintains a personal blog where she documents her research projects on topics like Weak Supervision, Feature-based Approaches with BERT, and Semantic Entailment.

Trishala is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Hindi, which enhances her ability to work in diverse teams and global environments. Her involvement with organizations like Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) demonstrates her commitment to the broader AI community and diversity in tech.

suggested_people.name: Liangze Li
suggested_people.short_description: Liangze Li is an AI researcher at Google DeepMind with a background from Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science. His research focuses on natural language processing and AI detection, with publications on distinguishing human from AI-generated content. He has demonstrated leadership through founding multiple organizations at CMU and is multilingual with proficiency in Mandarin, English, Cantonese, and Russian.
suggested_people.long_description:
Liangze Li is an AI researcher currently working at Google DeepMind, one of the world's leading artificial intelligence research labs. He joined DeepMind in 2024 after completing his education at Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science, where he earned his Master's degree in Language Technologies. His academic journey at CMU began in 2017 as an undergraduate student before continuing with graduate studies from 2022 to 2024.

Liangze's research focuses primarily on natural language processing and AI detection systems. He has published several notable papers in this field, including "GPT-Sentinel: Distinguishing Human and ChatGPT Generated Content" and "Token Prediction as Implicit Classification to Identify LLM-Generated Text," both published in 2023. These works have received significant attention in the academic community, with his GPT-Sentinel paper garnering over 70 citations. He has also contributed to research on referential games in NLP with his paper "Listener Model for the PhotoBook Referential Game with CLIPScores as Implicit Reference Chain."

During his time at Carnegie Mellon, Liangze demonstrated exceptional leadership and initiative by founding and presiding over several organizations. He was the Founder and President of the CMU Blackjack Society, as well as the Founder and Lecturer of the Carnegie Mellon University Student College. He also served as President of the Student College Executive Committee and as a Representative in the Graduate Student Assembly.

Before focusing on AI and natural language processing, Liangze had research interests in cryptography, with several publications between 2012-2014 on topics such as pairing computation on Edwards curves and Jacobi quartic curves with high-degree twists. This demonstrates his versatility and depth of knowledge across different areas of computer science.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Liangze has diverse interests in music, having played Alto Saxophone in both the Carnegie Mellon University Kiltie Band and the Pinghe Chamber Orchestra. His intellectual curiosity extends to philosophy as well, as evidenced by his founding of the Pinghe School Philosophy Club and his connection to CMU's Department of Philosophy.

Liangze is impressively multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Mandarin and English, full professional proficiency in Cantonese, and limited working proficiency in Russian. This linguistic versatility enhances his ability to collaborate in international research settings.

In his own words, Liangze describes himself as being "involved in AI research and startups," indicating his dual interests in both the theoretical advancement of AI and its practical applications in entrepreneurial contexts. His engagement with posts related to machine learning, AI development, and technology startups on LinkedIn further reflects his professional focus and interests in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Radostin Cholakov
suggested_people.short_description: Award-winning AI researcher, Stanford University undergraduate in Computer Science, and Forbes 30 Under 30 honoree specializing in natural language processing, quantization of large language models, and deep learning architectures for tabular data. Published author with significant contributions to efficient matrix multiplications for LLMs and task-oriented dialogue systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Radostin Cholakov is a distinguished young AI researcher currently pursuing undergraduate studies in Computer Science at Stanford University. His research focuses on innovative approaches to deep learning architectures, particularly for tabular data, dialogue systems, and large language model optimization.

As the author of "Distributional Quantization of Large Language Models," Radostin has developed novel methods for efficiently storing LLMs in 4-bit precision while maintaining performance comparable to full-precision models. His recent work on "Fast Matrix Multiplications for Lookup Table-Quantized LLMs" (2024) with collaborators from MIT and CMU introduces FLUTE, a flexible lookup table engine that can be 2-4x faster than existing GEMM kernels for LLM inference.

Radostin's contributions to task-oriented dialogue systems include developing models with auxiliary tasks for response selection, addressing limitations in text generation abilities of pre-trained language models. His paper "Efficient Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems with Response Selection as an Auxiliary Task" (2022) achieved state-of-the-art results on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset while using significantly fewer parameters than baseline models.

His work on the GatedTabTransformer has enhanced deep learning architectures for tabular modeling, showing significant improvements over existing solutions. Additionally, his research on "Transformers predicting the future" (2021) applies attention mechanisms to next-frame and time series forecasting, garnering significant citations in the field.

Radostin is also the creator of "AzBuki.ML," a machine learning platform for natural language processing specifically designed for Slavic languages.

His exceptional work has earned him numerous prestigious awards, including an Honorable Mention from AAAI and First Award by Mawhiba at Regeneron ISEF'23, Second Award at the European Contest For Young Scientists 2022, and Second award from ACM at Regeneron ISEF'22. In 2021, he was recognized in Forbes' "30 under 30" list and received the Presidential Award "John Atanasoff" for exceptional results in National IT Competitions.

Beyond his research, Radostin is actively involved in volunteer work with organizations like Google Developer Experts, Smile for Africa Foundation (where he serves as a Full-Stack Software Engineer), and Google Developers Group Sofia. His academic collaborations include work with prominent researchers from MIT, including Yoon Kim, Han Guo, and Jonathan Ragan-Kelley, as well as Eric Xing from CMU.

As the founder of RSG, Radostin continues to push boundaries in AI research while contributing to open-source projects and humanitarian causes.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Rex Liu
suggested_people.short_description: Undergraduate at Caltech pursuing Computer Science and Biology with a focus on Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. Research Fellow at Thomson Lab developing innovative AI systems including thalamus-inspired LLM routers and GNN-based spatial proteomics. Currently interning at NASA JPL for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft mission and competing on Caltech's Water Polo team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rex Liu is an undergraduate student at Caltech studying Computer Science and Biology, with a particular focus on the intersection of these fields through Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. As a Research Fellow at Caltech's Thomson Lab, Rex has developed several cutting-edge AI systems that demonstrate his innovative approach to machine learning.

His research portfolio includes a Thalamus-inspired LLM Router called "Herd" that creates scalable ensembles of small, open-source language models capable of outperforming larger proprietary models through Q-learning-based dynamic model selection. This work was presented at the NeurIPS Efficient Natural Language and Speech Processing Workshop. He's also worked on Hierarchical Chains with Multi-Level Abstention (HCMA), optimizing Black-box API deployments with uncertainty-based delegation and improved risk control, and published a paper on "Cost-Saving LLM Cascades with Early Abstention."

In the biomedical space, Rex has applied Graph Neural Networks to spatial proteomics, using counterfactual learning to identify tumor perturbations that enhance T-cell infiltration, with validated combinatorial therapies in collaboration with Cedars-Sinai. He's also worked on "Building Foundation Models to Characterize Cellular Interactions via Geometric Self-Supervised Learning on Spatial Genomics."

His most significant research contribution is on Functionally Invariant Path (FIP), a differential geometry-based framework that allows neural networks to adapt to secondary tasks without catastrophic forgetting. This groundbreaking work was published in Nature Machine Intelligence in 2024 and has already been cited by other researchers in the field. The FIP algorithm has wide-ranging applications from improving recommendations on online stores to fine-tuning self-driving cars.

Currently, Rex is interning at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, writing software for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft as part of the Mission Operations and Ground Data Systems team. He is also a member of Caltech's Men's Water Polo team, competing as an Attacker.

Prior to Caltech, Rex worked as a research assistant at National Taiwan University's Systems Biology Epithelia Lab, where he designed a lethal Zika virus-driven plasmid for transgenic mosquitoes, expressing a hybrid neurotoxin upon Zika infection. He also integrated a protein BLAST search engine to identify sequence alignments in the lab's online databases.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Rex has extensive experience in cybersecurity, having worked as a Security Researcher at HackerOne and a Bug Bounty Hunter at Bugcrowd for over five years. He has also served as a Teaching Assistant at Taipei American School, instructing students in Mechanical Engineering (CAD, CNC, water jet cutting, TIG welding) and Modern Topics in Computer Science (logic gates, quantum mechanics, deep learning).

Rex's multidisciplinary background, spanning AI, biology, cybersecurity, and aerospace, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving fields. He is fluent in Chinese and English, with working proficiency in Spanish and Japanese, further enhancing his ability to collaborate in global research environments. Outside of his academic and research work, Rex plays the violin and guitar.

suggested_people.name: Aaquib Syed
suggested_people.short_description: AI researcher at Google with a focus on interpretability and language model behavior. Aaquib has published significant work on refusal mechanisms in LLMs, attribution patching for circuit discovery, and efficient pruning techniques for massive language models. A Banneker-Key Scholar at the University of Maryland with a strong competitive programming background.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aaquib Syed is an AI researcher currently working at Google while affiliated with the University of Maryland, where he is pursuing a CS and Math degree as a Banneker-Key Scholar (full merit scholarship for the top 0.5% of incoming class). His research focuses on understanding and improving large language models, with particular emphasis on interpretability and model behavior mechanisms.

His recent publication "Refusal in Language Models Is Mediated by a Single Direction" (NeurIPS 2024, Poster) has garnered significant attention with 98+ citations. This groundbreaking work demonstrates that refusal behavior in conversational LLMs is controlled by a one-dimensional subspace across multiple open-source chat models, providing important insights into how safety mechanisms function in these systems.

Aaquib has also made significant contributions to automated interpretability research with his work "Attribution Patching Outperforms Automated Circuit Discovery" (BlackboxNLP at EMNLP 2024), which has received 47+ citations. In this paper, he developed a simple yet powerful method based on attribution patching that outperforms existing approaches while requiring minimal computational resources - just two forward passes and a backward pass.

In the area of model efficiency, his research "Prune and Tune: Improving Efficient Pruning Techniques for Massive Language Models" (ICLR TinyPapers Workshop 2023, top 6%) advanced techniques for pruning large language models without extensive retraining, addressing critical compute expense issues in deploying massive models.

His most recent work includes "Mechanistic Unlearning: Robust Knowledge Unlearning and Editing via Mechanistic Localization" (2024), exploring techniques for targeted knowledge editing in language models.

Beyond pure AI research, Aaquib has applied machine learning to medical imaging, co-authoring a paper in PLOS ONE that uses XGBoost with MRI and non-imaging data to predict pathological complete response in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

As a student, Aaquib has received numerous prestigious recognitions, including the USA Computing Olympiad Gold rank and the National Merit Scholarship. He has also developed several projects including a Personal Distance Monitor, a Stress Level Manager for students with autism spectrum disorder, and a FIRST Robotics Competition Scouting system.

According to his GitHub profile, Aaquib describes himself as someone who enjoys "thinking about and solving problems in AI/ML and finance" with a current interest in "creating scalable methods to attribute and edit behaviors and knowledge in large language models." He also mentions a love for competitive programming, working with low-level languages, and creating infrastructure and trading strategies for financial markets.

His interests span AI/ML and finance, with a particular focus on solving complex problems at the intersection of these fields. Aaquib's combination of theoretical research and practical applications demonstrates his versatility and depth of expertise in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya
suggested_people.short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese.
