Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

name: sathvik redrouthu
short_description: Sathvik Redrouthu is a tech innovator and entrepreneur who founded Procyon Photonics while in high school to develop photonic computing technology. Currently at Etched, he previously worked on chip design tooling through his startup Instachip. His research focuses on optical computing, photonic integrated circuits, and tensor algebra implementations for next-generation computing architectures.
long_description:
Sathvik Redrouthu is a forward-thinking technologist, entrepreneur, and researcher at the intersection of optoelectronics, hardware acceleration, and advanced computing architectures. Currently working at Etched and previously associated with Y Combinator, Sathvik has established himself as an innovator in specialized computing hardware despite his young age.

As the founder, CEO, and CTO of Procyon Photonics, Sathvik became the world's youngest CEO in the photonic and optical computing sector. Founded in 2021 while he was still in high school at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, Procyon develops revolutionary photon-based computing technology that aims to overcome the limitations of traditional electronic computing. The company's optical chips are designed to be significantly more energy-efficient than conventional processors, with prototypes reportedly 55,000 times more energy-efficient than the Intel i9 and over 100 times more efficient than Nvidia's A100 or Google's TPU. Procyon secured venture funding from Peter Thiel's 1517 Fund and has attracted interest from tech leaders like Sam Altman of OpenAI.

Before joining Etched, Sathvik founded Instachip, an EDA (Electronic Design Automation) startup focused on chip design tooling, and participated in Y Combinator. He is also conducting Formal Verification research with Dr. Mark Santolucito at Columbia University.

His research portfolio includes significant contributions to optical computing, with publications focused on optoelectronic hardware accelerators for tensor arithmetic. His work on "Tachyon," a programmable optoelectronic hardware accelerator, demonstrates his expertise in designing systems for ultrafast tensor operations. His team at Procyon was the first to run tensor algebra on an optical chip. Additionally, he has published on tensor algebra implementations for optoelectronic microchips and the use of interferometer-based photonic integrated circuits for rapid unitary transformations.

Sathvik's technical focus is on leveraging optical technologies to overcome limitations in traditional electronic computing, particularly for matrix multiplication and tensor operations critical for AI and machine learning workloads. His work on implementing unitary matrix transformations through Mach-Zehnder interferometers shows a deep understanding of how to harness photonic principles for computational advantage.

Beyond his professional work, Sathvik has developed numerous projects including AI chess engines, regex interpreters using Brzozowski derivatives, tensor algebra compilers with sparse tensor storage systems, and various AI applications. He is also skilled in hardware development, having created electric guitars and EMP generators from scratch.

Sathvik graduated high school in June 2024 but decided not to attend university, instead pursuing entrepreneurship and practical research. His vision is to someday "power the world with light" through photon-based computing, which he believes represents the next revolution in computing technology.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Suresh Nambi
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford University researcher specializing in hardware optimization for AI systems. Published author with expertise in efficient neural network design, approximate computing, and laser-induced graphitic carbon for electronics. Focused on developing low-power, high-performance hardware solutions for next-generation AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Suresh Nambi is a researcher at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, focusing on the development and implementation of efficient and effective hardware solutions for AI systems. His research interests span several specialized areas within hardware optimization, including approximate computing, FPGA-based neural network implementations, and novel materials for electronics.

Suresh has made significant contributions to the field through his publications in prestigious journals. His work on "ExPAN(N)D" explored the use of posits (an alternative to floating-point representation) for efficient neural network design in FPGA-based systems, demonstrating his expertise in hardware-optimized AI implementations. He also developed "DeBAM," a decoder-based approximate multiplier designed specifically for low-power applications, showcasing his innovation in energy-efficient computing architectures.

Beyond traditional computing hardware, Suresh has explored novel materials and fabrication techniques. His research on laser-induced graphitic carbon has led to breakthroughs in creating low-resistance conductors, including work on 3D-printed structures. This interdisciplinary approach bridges electronics, materials science, and advanced manufacturing.

Additionally, Suresh has ventured into sustainable energy applications, conducting performance analysis of submerged photovoltaic cells under varying water conditions, demonstrating his versatility and interest in environmentally conscious technologies.

His GitHub repository for the DeBAM project indicates his commitment to open-source contributions and knowledge sharing within the research community. At Stanford, he continues to push the boundaries of hardware design for AI applications, likely focusing on creating more efficient, powerful, and specialized computing solutions for the next generation of artificial intelligence systems.

suggested_people.name: Fengrui Zuo
suggested_people.short_description: Fengrui Zuo is a hardware specialist focusing on Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory. With a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, he brings specialized expertise in hardware acceleration for AI applications and serves as an Analog Design Co-Lead and Industry Outreach Officer at Open Source Silicon @ Stanford.
suggested_people.long_description:
Fengrui Zuo is a hardware engineer specializing in Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, which is operated by Stanford University. He currently holds dual positions as a Staff Engineer at SLAC and is pursuing his Master's degree in Electrical Engineering (MSEE) at Stanford University, which he began in Autumn 2023.

Fengrui has established himself as a leader in the open-source silicon community at Stanford, where he serves in multiple leadership roles. He is the Industry Outreach Officer for Open Source Silicon @ Stanford (OS3), helping to bridge academic research with industry applications. Additionally, he co-leads the Analog Design Subteam at OS3, where he focuses on designing and verifying analog components such as amplifiers, voltage references, and Power Management ICs (PMICs). His work involves device simulations, schematic generation and routing using both open-source and proprietary software, and conducting bench testing and verification.

His technical expertise spans across several domains including CUDA kernel optimization, autonomous systems, and chip design. Fengrui demonstrates particular interest in cutting-edge hardware developments such as NVIDIA's Jetson Orin Nano platform for edge AI applications, open-source chip design, and specialized motherboards with timing synchronization capabilities. His work at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory likely involves specialized hardware systems for scientific research and experimentation, integrating AI capabilities into high-performance computing environments for physics research.

Fengrui's professional address is at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, located at 2575 Sand Hill Rd, Menlo Park, California. His dual role as both a graduate student and staff engineer positions him uniquely at the intersection of academic research and practical engineering applications, particularly in the field of analog design for advanced computing systems.

suggested_people.name: Pavan Jayasinha
suggested_people.short_description: Pavan Jayasinha is a versatile technologist specializing in the intersection of machine learning, quantum computing, and low-level systems engineering. Currently a student at the University of Waterloo, he has contributed to cutting-edge research and development at organizations like Modular, Extropic AI, and the Institute for Quantum Computing, with particular expertise in GPU kernel optimization, quantum generative models, and robotics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Pavan Jayasinha is a multifaceted technologist pursuing a Bachelor of Applied Science at the University of Waterloo with an impressive 4.0 GPA. His technical expertise spans several specialized domains, with particular focus on machine learning, robotics, quantum computing, and low-level kernel development.

Pavan's professional experience demonstrates remarkable versatility across cutting-edge fields. At Modular, he worked as an AI GPU Engineering Intern, developing GPU kernels in Mojo language, optimizing end-to-end pipelines, and implementing multi-GPU tensor parallelism from scratch. His work at Extropic involved building high-performance JAX codebases for analog simulation of probabilistic ML models on hardware, conducting over 1000 Bayesian hyperparameter sweeps, and creating a state-of-the-art JAX library for tensor network simulation of quantum circuits on CUDA GPUs.

In the quantum computing space, Pavan has made significant contributions. At the Institute for Quantum Computing, he researched methods to realize the Bose-Hubbard Hamiltonian through Rydberg neutral atoms and built large-scale physics simulations. As an IBM Qiskit Advocate, he authored a chapter on Quantum Generative Adversarial Networks for the Qiskit Textbook QML course and mentored at the Qiskit Global Summer School. His quantum expertise extended to Zapata Computing, where he investigated quantum generative models and developed Orquestra codebase for QGANs.

Pavan has also contributed significantly to open-source projects, becoming the largest non-Google contributor to TensorFlow Quantum by implementing Bazel build infrastructure and cuQuantum SDK GPU kernels for quantum circuit simulation on heterogeneous devices. His project work includes developing a hybrid quantum graph neural network for particle trajectory reconstruction, which placed in the top 5 at QHack 2022, and building a quantum portfolio optimization project that placed in the 95th percentile at QHack 2021.

Pavan's academic achievements include being a Masason Scholar, selected as part of the 6th generation cohort by SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's foundation that supports youth with exceptional talents. He has received the President's Research Award and maintained Dean's Honours List status. He has earned multiple certifications in quantum computing, including becoming an IBM Certified Associate Developer for Quantum Computation using Qiskit.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Pavan has diverse experiences including serving as a lifeguard for the City of Toronto and working as a dog walker, demonstrating his well-rounded character and work ethic. His unique combination of expertise in quantum computing, machine learning, and low-level systems engineering positions him as a promising innovator at the intersection of these transformative technologies.

suggested_people.name: Mikael Haji
suggested_people.short_description: A pioneering 19-year-old electrical engineering student at University of Waterloo who leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility for under $10K. With extensive experience in neurotech, Mikael has worked with Prophetic on ultrasound technology, contributed to neuromorphic chip design at University of Toronto, and was the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech.
suggested_people.long_description:
Mikael Haji is an innovative 19-year-old electrical engineering student at the University of Waterloo and recipient of the prestigious $120K Schulich Leaders Scholarship. He currently leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab team, where he's building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility in Waterloo with the ambitious goal of creating a process for under $10K that can produce approximately 1,000 transistors.

His GitHub profile reveals his deep involvement in brain-computer interface (BCI) technology, with multiple repositories focused on EEG applications, including projects for motor imagery systems, P300 spellers, emotion classification, and artifact detection algorithms. He's currently working on burning a GPT-2 layer on silicon and has previously designed a TPU-like systolic array and a neuromorphic chip for neural implants, with a pending IEEE ISSCC paper.

His professional journey showcases remarkable depth in cutting-edge technology fields. At Prophetic, Mikael built an entire transcranial focused ultrasound infrastructure, deploying advanced optimization techniques and accelerating transducer prototyping while creating an $80K hydrophone for under $2K. Prior to this, he worked at the University of Toronto on the digital back-end of a novel neuromorphic chip design, integrating spiking neural networks for advanced neural implants with the Intelligent Sensory Microsystems Lab.

At just 15, Mikael joined WATOLINK as a system integration engineer, helping build a mind-controlled speech interface using SSVEP with GPT-3 integration, which won first place in the Neurotech X student competition. His early accomplishments include being hired as the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech, where he engineered custom circuitry enclosures and fabricated high-precision electrode arrays.

Mikael's expertise has earned him recognition beyond academia. He was flown to Dubai for the Global Citizen Forum Conference to discuss his neurotech work and was selected as a Villars Fellow to participate in the inaugural Villars Symposium in Geneva. His entrepreneurial potential was further validated by a $250K matching trust fund from Patrick Poirier at Dragon's Vault to fuel his work in the neurotech space.

His technical innovation began early, with the development of a novel Thermoelectric Generator using fluid technology that earned him the Worley Parsons Engineers of Tomorrow award in 2019. Mikael's unique combination of hardware expertise, neuromorphic computing knowledge, and entrepreneurial drive positions him at the forefront of emerging technologies in chip fabrication and neural interfaces.

One of his notable projects includes developing a highly efficient compression algorithm for Neuralink's N1 implant as part of their compression challenge, which has gained significant attention on GitHub. His diverse portfolio of projects demonstrates his commitment to advancing both hardware and software solutions in the field of neurotechnology and chip design.

name: alex fan
short_description: Alex Fan is a talented undergraduate at MIT studying Mathematics and Computer Science with a focus on AI research. A USACO Finalist in 2021 and 2022, he's currently working as a Research Engineer at Pika, tackling challenges in generative video and image models.
long_description:
Alex Fan is a promising talent in the AI field, currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023-2026). His academic journey includes rigorous coursework in graduate-level Machine Learning, Advanced Algorithms, Advances in Computer Vision, and Computational Cognitive Science, demonstrating his commitment to mastering both the theoretical foundations and cutting-edge applications of AI.

Alex's technical prowess was evident early on, as he was a USACO (USA Computing Olympiad) Finalist in both 2021 and 2022 during his time at Lexington High School. This competitive programming background has provided him with strong algorithmic thinking skills that complement his AI research interests.

Currently, Alex is working as a Research Engineer at Pika, where he focuses on solving engineering and research challenges related to generative video/image models and data curation. This practical experience in the rapidly evolving field of generative AI is giving him hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art techniques and real-world applications.

During his time at MIT, Alex has been involved in various research projects. In 2022, he participated in the PRIMES program where he collaborated on research leveraging statistical distributions for RNA sequencing across time, working with Prof. Gil Alterovitz. This experience demonstrates his interest in applying computational methods to biological data.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Alex is an active member of the MIT community. He lives in La Maison Française (MIT French House) where he embraces French culture and language. He's also involved in the performing arts, having performed in the MIT Musical Theatre Guild's Cabaret Night in Fall 2023 and cast as John Hinckley Jr. in their production of "Assassins" for Fall 2024.

Alex has diverse personal interests including cooking, baking, fermentation, Broadway musicals, and playing piano. He describes himself as a francophile who dreams of returning to Parisian cafes. In his spare time, he enjoys working on programming projects and writing blog posts, showcasing his passion for both technical and creative pursuits.

His engagement with the AI community is evident through his LinkedIn activity, where he follows developments in AI research, particularly in generative models and applications in various domains. Alex represents the next generation of AI researchers and engineers who are combining strong mathematical foundations with practical implementation skills to push the boundaries of what's possible in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Locke Cai
suggested_people.short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Ye
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford University undergraduate studying Mathematics and Computer Science with research focus on AI, particularly neural architectures and network compression. Published at NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with experience as a software engineering intern, teaching assistant, and visiting instructor.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Ye is a talented undergraduate student currently pursuing his B.S. in Mathematics and Computer Science at Stanford University, having transferred there in 2024. Prior to Stanford, Andrew studied at Case Western Reserve University from 2022 to 2024, also focusing on Mathematics and Computer Science.

Andrew has built an impressive research portfolio in artificial intelligence. Since June 2023, he has been working as an Undergraduate Researcher at the Case School of Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, collaborating with Dr. Shuai Xu, Dr. Vipin Chaudhary, and researchers at Rice AI and MIT. His research has led to publications at prestigious AI conferences including NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with his work "GNNs also deserve editing, and they need it more than once" receiving multiple citations.

Andrew's research interests span several areas of AI including neural architectures, human-computer interaction, probability/combinatorics, metacognition, and learning theory. He is particularly focused on addressing key questions in AI such as ensuring system faithfulness and security, balancing the scale-bloat tradeoff in neural networks, and understanding how neural networks fundamentally reason and learn. He founded quant@CWRU, a student-led research group supported by professors at Case Western Reserve University focused on integrating machine learning paradigms to solve complex financial tasks.

Beyond research, Andrew has gained practical industry experience as a Software Engineering Intern at Zventus from May to August 2023, where he worked with Angel Alban on healthcare technologies. He has also developed his teaching skills as a Teaching Assistant at Case Western Reserve University, where he assisted with courses in Algorithms and Discrete Mathematics from August 2023 to May 2024. Most recently, he served as a Visiting Instructor at DigiPen Institute of Technology, teaching Data Analytics and Statistics during the summer of 2024.

Andrew grew up in Seattle and Hong Kong and has diverse personal interests including solving puzzles, playing piano (with a particular fondness for Liszt), hiking with his dog, and writing on his blog. His commitment to community service is evident from his volunteer work with North Helpline from May 2021 to April 2022. His academic profile, research contributions, and diverse experiences showcase his versatility and dedication to advancing the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

name: vijay kumaravelrajan
short_description: Vijay is a junior at USC studying Math and Computer Science, where he serves as a Project Lead at USC's Center for AI in Society. His research spans inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, robotic manipulation, and 6G wireless technology. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's building an LLM-powered language learning Chrome extension.
long_description:
Vijay Kumaravelrajan is a junior at the University of Southern California pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics and Computer Science. As a Trustee Scholar and Viterbi Fellow, he has established himself as a multifaceted researcher and entrepreneur in the AI space.

At USC's Center for AI in Society (CAIS++), Vijay currently leads a team of five researchers focused on inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, where they're achieving superior pass@k performance under tighter inference budgets compared to larger models. His work involves implementing and analyzing various inference-time scaling strategies including best-of-n approaches, tree search with PRMs, and Chain of Thought with reinforcement learning. Previously at CAIS++, he conducted research in robotic manipulation through collaboration with USC's SLURM lab, implementing environment simulations using MuJoCo and ManiSkill with Gymnasium for reinforcement learning training. He has also served as a Curriculum Lead, mentoring underclassmen through practical ML projects and teaching comprehensive curriculum covering neural networks, classical ML, NLP, computer vision, transformers, and generative modeling.

Beyond his academic research, Vijay co-founded Jargon, a startup developing a Chrome extension that transforms everyday browsing into language learning opportunities powered by large language models. His entrepreneurial venture demonstrates his ability to apply AI technologies to practical educational tools.

Since August 2022, Vijay has been a Directed Researcher at USC's WiDES Lab, where he collaborates with PhD leads and a team of graduate and undergraduate researchers. His work includes designing and optimizing ray tracers for 6G wireless installations and using convolutional neural networks alongside traditional algorithms to detect edges in point cloud data. He implements C++ libraries in Python and MATLAB, showcasing his versatility across programming languages.

Earlier in his academic career, Vijay worked as a Research Assistant at Scholar Launch, conducting research on open star clusters under the guidance of a professor from UT Austin. He created generalizable algorithms for determining the age of any star cluster of interest using Python.

Vijay has demonstrated his programming skills in competitive settings, participating in the Fall 2024 USC Programming Contest where he successfully solved the "5-Mile Hike" problem using Python. He also contributed to the "Gen-AI for Multi-Agent Deformable Object Manipulation" project at CAIS++, working alongside other researchers to advance robotic manipulation of deformable objects like bread and clothing. This project integrated various robotic platforms including ALOHA and Baxter into the MuJoCo simulation environment using Robosuite, setting up bimanual configurations to explore different arm controllers.

Outside of his AI and computer science pursuits, Vijay is involved with USC's Rocket Propulsion Lab as a General Member focusing on simulations. He achieved the rank of Eagle Scout with Boy Scout Troop 1776 and graduated with an IB Diploma, demonstrating his well-rounded capabilities and leadership potential.

Vijay's personal website (jaykr.dev) features his projects and writing, reflecting his passion for discovering and building new technologies at the intersection of mathematics, computer science, and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: David Bai
suggested_people.short_description: David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at USC with diverse research experience in AI alignment, multi-agent robotic planning, and reinforcement learning for legged robots. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's developing language learning tools while also working on innovative projects like brain-controlled drones and GPS-denied navigation systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at the University of Southern California (2023-2027), where he serves as a USC Presidential Scholar. His academic journey is marked by a deep commitment to artificial intelligence research across multiple domains.

Currently, David is a Research Fellow at the Supervised Program for Alignment Research, where he investigates reasoning and AI agents from capabilities and security perspectives. Simultaneously, he works as a Research Assistant at USC Viterbi School of Engineering's GLAMOR Lab through the CURVE Fellowship, focusing on multi-agent robotic planning at the intersection of LLMs and symbolic planners.

David's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of Jargon, where he's building a language learning Chrome extension. His technical versatility extends to his work with USC Makers, where he manages projects involving brain-controlled drones using electroencephalography, having previously contributed to an autonomous greenhouse with computer vision.

His professional experience includes a Machine Learning & Computer Vision Internship at Rhoman Aerospace, enabling GPS-denied navigation through VIO and building simulation/SLAM pipelines. David has also served as a Research Assistant at the Dynamic Robotics and Control Laboratory, where he augmented model predictive control for legged robots with reinforcement learning.

In the academic community, David is active with USC's Center for AI in Society's Student Branch (CAIS++), where he contributes to research and projects in artificial intelligence with social impact applications. He is part of the Fall 2024 cohort, demonstrating his commitment to applying AI for societal benefit.

David is also involved with the USC Computational Aerospace Lab, where he works on projects related to BCD (Binary Collision Detection), showcasing his interdisciplinary approach to engineering challenges. This involvement highlights his ability to apply computational methods to aerospace applications.

Prior to USC, David demonstrated academic excellence at Cambridge University, where he compiled comprehensive lecture notes across various mathematical disciplines, indicating his strong foundation in theoretical concepts that underpin his current technical work.

David's commitment to social impact is demonstrated through his volunteer work with the Cheyenne River Youth Project and Friends of Children with Special Needs, where he developed educational courses. His multidisciplinary approach to AI research, combined with his technical skills and social consciousness, positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Wanzin Yazar
suggested_people.short_description: AI researcher at d-Matrix and UC Berkeley alumnus specializing in LLM optimization. Published work on quantized LLMs and attention span acceleration for inference. Award-winning hackathon participant with expertise in cloud computing, deep learning, and healthcare AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Wanzin Yazar is a Staff ML Research Engineer at d-Matrix, a company focused on in-memory compute architecture for AI applications, and is an alumnus of the University of California, Berkeley, where they earned a Bachelor's degree in Applied Mathematics with a focus on AI. Their research focuses on optimizing large language models (LLMs) for more efficient inference and deployment.

Wanzin has published several significant papers in the field of AI optimization, including "Post Training Quantization of Large Language Models with Microscaling Formats" (2024), "Self-Selected Attention Span for Accelerating Large Language Model Inference" (2024), "Understanding the difficulty of low-precision post-training quantization of large language models" (2024), and "Scaling laws for post-training quantized large language models" (2024). Their work demonstrates expertise in model quantization and inference acceleration techniques, which are critical for deploying AI models in resource-constrained environments.

Beyond LLM optimization, Wanzin has also contributed to research in healthcare AI applications, with publications like "Through the Looking Glass: Unraveling the Stage-Shift of Acute Rejection in Renal Allografts" (2022) and "The self-upgrading mobile application for the automatic malaria detection" (2020). At Nephrosant, Inc., they developed productionized machine learning models from large healthcare datasets, showing versatility in applying AI to solve real-world problems in the medical field.

Wanzin previously worked as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Division of Computing, Data Science, and Society, focusing on deep learning-based recommender systems and student enrollment predictions using clustering practices and regression models. They also gained experience at Advancers.ai before joining d-Matrix.

Wanzin has an impressive track record in hackathons, winning the Grand Prize at AngelHack Silicon Valley 2019, Best Mobile Hack at SF HACK 2019, and the Best Asian Pacific Quest in the 2019 IBM Call For Code Global Challenge. These achievements highlight their ability to rapidly prototype and implement AI solutions.

Their professional certifications include Google Cloud Certified Data Engineer (issued January 2020), the Deep Learning Specialization from deeplearning.ai (issued January 2018), and Full Stack Machine Learning on AWS from AI Camp. These certifications demonstrate Wanzin's comprehensive understanding of cloud infrastructure, deep learning fundamentals, and practical implementation of machine learning systems.

Wanzin's research has been cited by other scholars in the field, with their papers on LLM optimization and healthcare applications receiving recognition in the academic community. Their expertise spans machine learning, pattern recognition, image processing, neural networks, computer vision, data mining, computational intelligence, statistical learning, and data analysis.

suggested_people.name: Vineeth Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Arihant Choudhary
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley with extensive research experience across AI, cryptography, and computational game theory. Currently working as a Software Intern at Intel and Lead Undergraduate Researcher at UC Berkeley, focusing on multi-agent systems, AI applications, and CS education.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arihant Choudhary is a multifaceted Computer Science, Data Science, and Applied Mathematics student at UC Berkeley with a remarkable research portfolio spanning diverse technical domains. His research journey includes work at Stanford University on multi-agent systems for inference, reasoning, and planning, as well as climate data analysis using CMIP-6 models.

At UC Berkeley, Arihant has made significant contributions across multiple research labs. He serves as a Lead Undergraduate Researcher in two labs under Prof. Dan Garcia - the Computational Game Theory Lab (GamesCrafters) and the CS Education Lab (ACE Lab). In the ACE Lab, he authored papers on dynamic animated feedback for randomized graph problems (accepted at SIGCSE 2024) and co-authored work on personalized reminders for mastery learning (AutoRemind, accepted at SIGCSE 2025). His work in the Computational Game Theory Lab involved developing solvers for games like Quick Cross and Euclid's Game, researching pure draw theory, and creating human-robot interaction systems.

Professionally, Arihant is currently working as a Software Intern at Intel Corporation, implementing cutting-edge research and building products for Intel Foundry. His previous role as a Research Intern at Intel focused on text-to-video research and building Intel's Personal Educator (IPED) using large language models and text-to-speech libraries to support employee training. He also serves as a Dean's Engineering Ambassador at UC Berkeley's College of Engineering, working on programs for high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.

Arihant's journey to UC Berkeley is particularly inspiring. After being rejected from all colleges in his first application cycle, he took a gap year in 2020 and pursued multiple projects, including a significant climate change research project through Polygence. Working with his mentor Tristan Ballard, a Stanford PhD in earth systems science, Arihant analyzed a petabyte of climate data to study monsoons in Kolkata and assess climate change impacts on agriculture. This experience not only built his technical skills but also helped him secure admission to UC Berkeley on his second attempt.

Arihant's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Berkeley Social, a platform he developed to help incoming UC Berkeley students connect with peers sharing similar interests. He also co-founded Yindu & Zhongguo Inc, which included the Bangla Machinery Bank, an AgriTech enterprise providing efficient farm machinery to farmers in West Bengal.

His academic pursuits extend beyond UC Berkeley, with coursework at Stanford University in CS224G: Apps with LLMs Inside. Arihant's technical expertise spans AI, machine learning, cryptography, and data science, complemented by his multilingual proficiency in English, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, and Marwari.

Through his diverse experiences in research, entrepreneurship, and community service, Arihant demonstrates a commitment to leveraging technology for social impact and educational advancement. Expected to graduate in Spring 2025, he is now interested in pursuing a graduate degree and a career in artificial intelligence/machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Prady Saligram
suggested_people.short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

name: ricardo skewes zorrilla
short_description: A multilingual Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard with exceptional achievements in quantum computing and international physics competitions. Ricardo combines technical expertise with diplomatic skills, having led international relations organizations and conducted research spanning solid-state physics, ESG consulting, and quantum algorithm development across multiple languages.
long_description:
Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla is a Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard University with a remarkable blend of technical expertise and international perspective. His academic journey is distinguished by significant achievements in quantum computing, where he serves as Vice President of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantum Computing Association (HUQCA) and won 2nd place at MIT's Quantum Computing Hackathon 2024, developing theoretical error bounds for quantum algorithms.

Ricardo's technical prowess extends beyond quantum computing to solid-state physics research, where he worked with 2D transition metal dichalcogenides and Van der Waals heterostructures under Professor Hongkun Park. His computational skills have been recognized through multiple hackathon victories, including Microsoft's Student Hackathon 2021 and CdCMx 2020, where he developed mathematical models for COVID-19 comorbidity analysis.

In the quantum computing field, Ricardo has demonstrated exceptional talent, helping to grow HUQCA to over 300 members. At the MIT Interdisciplinary Quantum Hackathon (iQuHACK), his team created an "experimental harness" that allowed them to run quantum simulations at scale and efficiently collect data, earning them second place. As Ricardo noted, "It's one thing to learn something in a classroom, and another to try to code one and see if it runs. That's different, and I think it adds an extra layer to fully mastering the concepts."

What sets Ricardo apart is his exceptional international background and linguistic abilities. Fluent in six languages (Spanish, English, French, Chinese, Russian, and German), he has leveraged these skills in various leadership roles. As Co-President of Harvard International Relations on Campus and in his work with the Harvard International Relations Council, he has bridged cultural divides and facilitated international dialogue. His language proficiency earned him first place in Harvard's Chinese Poetry Recitation Contest and supported his research for a Radcliffe Fellow's project on underground economies in Greater China.

Ricardo's professional experience spans diverse sectors, from ESG consulting at PwC China, where he spearheaded sustainable design strategies for LEED-certified real estate projects, to his upcoming role as a Business Analyst at Alibaba Group. During his internship at PwC Shanghai through the Harvard China Fund Student Internship Program, he significantly improved his professional Chinese language skills while working on technical projects. As Ricardo reflected, "My biggest achievement from this experience was the consolidation of my Chinese speaking, reading and writing skills at the professional level."

His commitment to diplomacy and international cooperation is evident in his work with the United Nations Information Center, where he led a conference commemorating the UN's 75th anniversary with 500+ Latin American students.

His academic excellence is further demonstrated by his impressive collection of medals from international physics competitions, including the International Physics Olympiad, European Physics Olympiad, and Mexican Physics Olympiad. Ricardo's multidisciplinary approach combines rigorous scientific training with global perspective, positioning him uniquely at the intersection of technology, diplomacy, and sustainable development.

suggested_people.name: Harshil Avlani
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Physics student at MIT with award-winning research in quantum computing. Former Research Intern at MIT's Quanta Group and Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab, focusing on quantum error characterization and quantum machine learning applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Harshil Avlani is a dual-major student in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), with an exceptional research background in quantum computing and physics. His academic journey showcases a consistent focus on quantum technologies and computational physics.

Currently, Harshil serves as a Research Intern with the Quanta Group at MIT's Research Laboratory of Electronics, where he applies his interdisciplinary knowledge to cutting-edge quantum research. Prior to this, he gained valuable experience as a Research Intern at Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab under Dr. Houlong Zhuang for over a year, developing expertise in quantum mechanical applications and quantum machine learning.

Harshil has achieved remarkable recognition for his research. His project "Analyzing the Effect of Mid-Circuit Measurement (MCM) on Spectator Qubits" earned him first place in the Systems Software category at the International Science Fair and qualified him as a finalist in the prestigious 2024 Regeneron Science Talent Search, where he received a $25,000 academic scholarship. This groundbreaking work identified a previously uncharacterized type of quantum error and revealed significant deficiencies in current quantum simulators.

His research portfolio includes collaborative work on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) for solving combinatorial optimization problems, documented in his GitHub repository. He has also worked with the Hauser Research Group at the University of Alabama, where he spent 9 months contributing to physics research projects, and gained experience in computer security at Arizona State University's SEFCOM Lab.

In 2022, Harshil participated in the MIT Beaver Works Summer Institute as a Quantum Software Student, further enhancing his skills in quantum computing applications. He has also co-founded the Quantum Beavers hackathon group, which tied for first place in the IBM Quantum Explorers Hackathon.

Harshil has already begun contributing to scientific literature, with a publication in Data in Brief journal on "Dataset on density functional theory investigation of ternary Heusler alloys" in February 2024. More recently, he has been exploring the intersection of quantum computing and transformer models in machine learning, with applications in mitigating misinformation through quantum-enhanced GAN architectures.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Harshil is an accomplished pianist and has a passion for aviation, being able to identify most major aircraft models by sight. His diverse research experiences across multiple institutions highlight his versatility and dedication to advancing the fields of quantum computing and physics through rigorous academic inquiry and practical applications.

suggested_people.name: Pavan Jayasinha
suggested_people.short_description: Pavan Jayasinha is a versatile technologist specializing in the intersection of machine learning, quantum computing, and low-level systems engineering. Currently a student at the University of Waterloo, he has contributed to cutting-edge research and development at organizations like Modular, Extropic AI, and the Institute for Quantum Computing, with particular expertise in GPU kernel optimization, quantum generative models, and robotics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Pavan Jayasinha is a multifaceted technologist pursuing a Bachelor of Applied Science at the University of Waterloo with an impressive 4.0 GPA. His technical expertise spans several specialized domains, with particular focus on machine learning, robotics, quantum computing, and low-level kernel development.

Pavan's professional experience demonstrates remarkable versatility across cutting-edge fields. At Modular, he worked as an AI GPU Engineering Intern, developing GPU kernels in Mojo language, optimizing end-to-end pipelines, and implementing multi-GPU tensor parallelism from scratch. His work at Extropic involved building high-performance JAX codebases for analog simulation of probabilistic ML models on hardware, conducting over 1000 Bayesian hyperparameter sweeps, and creating a state-of-the-art JAX library for tensor network simulation of quantum circuits on CUDA GPUs.

In the quantum computing space, Pavan has made significant contributions. At the Institute for Quantum Computing, he researched methods to realize the Bose-Hubbard Hamiltonian through Rydberg neutral atoms and built large-scale physics simulations. As an IBM Qiskit Advocate, he authored a chapter on Quantum Generative Adversarial Networks for the Qiskit Textbook QML course and mentored at the Qiskit Global Summer School. His quantum expertise extended to Zapata Computing, where he investigated quantum generative models and developed Orquestra codebase for QGANs.

Pavan has also contributed significantly to open-source projects, becoming the largest non-Google contributor to TensorFlow Quantum by implementing Bazel build infrastructure and cuQuantum SDK GPU kernels for quantum circuit simulation on heterogeneous devices. His project work includes developing a hybrid quantum graph neural network for particle trajectory reconstruction, which placed in the top 5 at QHack 2022, and building a quantum portfolio optimization project that placed in the 95th percentile at QHack 2021.

Pavan's academic achievements include being a Masason Scholar, selected as part of the 6th generation cohort by SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's foundation that supports youth with exceptional talents. He has received the President's Research Award and maintained Dean's Honours List status. He has earned multiple certifications in quantum computing, including becoming an IBM Certified Associate Developer for Quantum Computation using Qiskit.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Pavan has diverse experiences including serving as a lifeguard for the City of Toronto and working as a dog walker, demonstrating his well-rounded character and work ethic. His unique combination of expertise in quantum computing, machine learning, and low-level systems engineering positions him as a promising innovator at the intersection of these transformative technologies.

suggested_people.name: Leo Nagel
suggested_people.short_description: Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with expertise in GPU optimization, quantitative finance, and physics. Former Chief Executive at Global Society of Young Physicists and published researcher with a focus on computational efficiency and mathematical modeling.
suggested_people.long_description:
Leo Nagel is an Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley who combines technical expertise with leadership experience to drive technological innovation. His academic focus spans GPU kernel optimization, quantitative finance, computing theory, mathematics, and physics.

Currently, Leo is deeply involved in several cutting-edge projects that showcase his technical abilities. He collaborated with Bradley Hsu to develop cuBogo, the fastest bogosort implementation ever run on a single device, optimizing custom CUDA (C++) kernels for the Nvidia H100. He's also working on cuDream, rewriting DreamCoder to leverage GPU optimizations, and cuPrimes, a custom kernel implementing the Fermat test of pseudo-primality using the Schönhage-Strassen algorithm and optimized Fast Fourier Transform with Nvidia H100 tensor cores.

Leo's leadership capabilities are evident through his role as Chief Executive at the Global Society of Young Physicists (2022-2024), where he founded a physics nonprofit that organizes summer programs and publishes a journal. Prior to this, he served as a Curriculum Developer at Mad for Stem, creating interdisciplinary courses spanning economics, computer science, data science, and technology.

His academic achievements include placing first out of 130+ participants in the Berkeley Trading Invitational 2024, demonstrating his aptitude for quantitative finance. Leo has also published research, including a paper on "Derivation of a Function for Velocity for Falling Objects with Non-Negligible Air Resistance," showcasing his mathematical modeling skills.

Leo's educational background includes studies at UC Berkeley, a visiting undergraduate experience at The University of Hong Kong, and participation in specialized programs like the Quantum Cryptography School for Young Students at the University of Waterloo. He graduated from Dulwich College Shanghai Pudong with an International Baccalaureate score of 44/45.

With a multicultural background having lived in Germany (8 years), China (10 years), and the United States (2 years), Leo brings a global perspective to his work. He is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and German, and elementary proficiency in Chinese and Latin. Beyond academics, he enjoys chess and hiking in the Berkeley Hills, particularly at night.

Leo's unique combination of technical expertise in GPU optimization, research experience, leadership skills, and interdisciplinary knowledge positions him as a promising innovator in the fields of computer science and electrical engineering.

suggested_people.name: Vishal Nandakumar
suggested_people.short_description: Vishal Nandakumar is a freshman student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with research experience in quantum physics, specifically in hydrodynamic quantum field theory analogs. He graduated from Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, one of the nation's premier STEM-focused high schools.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vishal Nandakumar is currently pursuing his undergraduate studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he enrolled in 2024 and is expected to graduate in 2027. Prior to MIT, Vishal attended Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology from 2020 to 2024, which is widely recognized as one of the top STEM-focused high schools in the United States.

During his time at Thomas Jefferson, Vishal demonstrated exceptional aptitude in physics and quantum mechanics. He was involved in a significant research project at the Q Lab focused on "Hydrodynamic Quantum Field Theory Analogs" alongside collaborators Pranav Panicker and Kai Wang. This project explored hydrodynamic quantum field theory, a model of quantum dynamics inspired by Louis de Broglie's double-solution pilot wave theory. Their research involved physically modeling superwalking droplets and pilot wave theory in a silicone oil bath, and extending the two-dimensional form of the hydrodynamic pilot wave to three dimensions by exploring free particles, harmonic oscillators, and other quantum analogs. They also investigated the possible link between non-Markovian dynamics of physical pilot wave systems and nonlocality in quantum systems.

As a developer, Vishal maintains a GitHub presence where he has contributed to projects including "konnecthru" (a JavaScript project) and "Formalin_Predictions_in_Fruits" (a Python project). These repositories demonstrate his programming skills across different languages and domains.

At MIT, Vishal is continuing to build on his strong foundation in STEM fields, particularly in physics and quantum mechanics. His research experience and technical skills position him well for further exploration in quantum physics, computational modeling, and related fields that align with MIT's strengths in these areas.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

name: catherine lee
short_description: Catherine Lee is a machine learning professional currently working at Lamini. She has developed expertise in LSTM networks and boosting algorithms, with award-winning projects focused on data usability and practical applications of AI, particularly in transportation safety and fraud detection. She is also an accomplished UX designer with experience optimizing user experiences for startups and enterprise clients.
long_description:
Catherine Lee is a machine learning professional currently working at Lamini, an AI company. She has demonstrated a strong foundation in machine learning, having completed the Machine Learning Specialization from DeepLearning.AI and Stanford University in January 2024.

Catherine has authored research publications including "Predicting the Number of Accidents in Different Weather Conditions in Barcelona Using Long Short Term Memory" (2019) and "Adtracking Fraud Detection Using Boosting Algorithms and Neural Networks" (2019), showing her expertise in applying advanced ML techniques to real-world problems.

Her project portfolio showcases diverse applications of AI and technology. Notable projects include "Bikeable," which won the Best Data Usability Hack at PennApps 2019 for using machine learning to generate safer bicycle routes based on accident data. She also worked on "PictRNNary," which earned the Best Use of Microsoft Azure Hack at Cal Hacks 5.0 in 2018, and "Place It," which won Best Under Construction Hack at LA Hacks 2020.

Catherine is also an accomplished UX designer with experience working with both startups and enterprise clients. Her design portfolio includes work for companies like Thoughtful, J.P. Morgan, Northwestern Mutual, and Masse, where she focused on optimizing user experiences and operational efficiency. Her design approach is methodical, using both data and qualitative user research to inform her designs. According to Elizabeth Cordry Shaffer, Co-Founder & CEO at Thoughtful, "She produces incredibly thoughtful work quickly, and handles feedback very well from team members. Communication and presentation of her ideas is a core strength of hers."

Catherine has participated in prestigious tech programs including the Google CodeU Program and JP Morgan Code for Good, demonstrating her commitment to applying technology for positive impact. Her recent project "Ayna" (November 2023) indicates her continued involvement in innovative tech development.

She is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Cantonese, and elementary proficiency in French, which enhances her ability to work in diverse environments. Catherine's consistent recognition through hackathon awards highlights her technical skills and ability to develop practical, impactful solutions using AI, machine learning, and user-centered design.

suggested_people.name: Trishala Neeraj
suggested_people.short_description: Trishala Neeraj is a Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube with a strong academic background from Cornell University. She specializes in computer vision and natural language processing, bringing technical expertise to cybersecurity analytics and has contributed to several influential AI research papers.
suggested_people.long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. She works with terabyte-scale data to develop models using Deep Learning and Matrix Factorization techniques, with a particular focus on language data and models.

Her academic foundation was built at Cornell University, where she graduated in 2018 after focusing on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing during her graduate studies. She also holds a Bachelor of Engineering degree from BITS Pilani, India, and spent time as a visiting research scholar at the Predictive Technology Lab at the University of Virginia.

Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022).
