suggested_people.name: Arnav Adhikari
suggested_people.short_description: 19-year-old EECS and Finance student at MIT with a passion for building innovative solutions in fintech, robotics, and healthtech. First place winner at HackMIT 2024 with a nicotine cessation patch project, and currently working on semantic operators at MIT CSAIL while also running a stealth startup.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arnav Adhikari is a dynamic 19-year-old undergraduate at MIT pursuing a dual focus in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and Finance. His technical interests span across multiple domains including fintech (payments, wealth management, AI analysts), robotics (collaboration and control), healthtech (LLM-aided care), and productivity tools. He describes himself as a "big proponent of automating the mundane" and believes that jobs should be automated to redirect human attention toward tasks requiring ingenuity.

Arnav has built an impressive track record of achievements. Most notably, he and his team won the First Place Grand Prize at HackMIT 2024 with their algorithmically-driven nicotine cessation patch. He's currently working as a Builder at MIT's prestigious Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), focusing on semantic operators.

Entrepreneurially minded, Arnav is the Founder and CEO of a stealth startup that he's been running since January 2024. His previous experience includes work at Boston Consulting Group (BCM), Rice University, Stanford's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI), and Harvard Medical School, demonstrating his ability to collaborate with top-tier institutions across academia and industry.

Arnav's research work is particularly notable in healthcare technology. He has worked on cardiac imaging interpretability and standardized cardiac measurements at BCM, Texas Children's Hospital, and Stanford AIMI, with his work being featured in Circulation by the American Heart Association in November 2023. He has also analyzed teamwork synergy for AI Surgical Robotic Coaches at Rice HCAIR and Harvard Medical School, and developed smarter irrigation and water management systems for the City of Southside Place in Houston.

His technical background is further strengthened by his experience in robot motion planning and control at Rice RobotPI, and his achievements as a retired USAJMO winner and USACO Gold Medalist. Arnav is also an author, having written the Cubronix Competitive Math Practice Book for charity, which was featured in the Houston Chronicle in January 2022.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Arnav offers tutoring services in the Greater Houston area, specializing in math, science, engineering, and test preparation. He enjoys tennis, basketball, football, biking, the outdoors, and various forms of media entertainment.

Currently a freshman at MIT (class of 2028), Arnav graduated from Carnegie Vanguard High School in 2024 after previously attending Bellaire High School. He describes himself as someone who loves "learning and building fast," and is always open to discussing innovative ideas and groundbreaking technologies.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

suggested_people.name: Tony Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, with a diverse portfolio spanning tech, venture capital, and public interest technology. He has research experience at Stanford AI Lab and Harvard Medical School, and has worked with companies like Amazon and Microsoft.
suggested_people.long_description:
Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University focusing on Artificial Intelligence. His professional experience spans multiple domains including venture capital, public interest technology, and software engineering.

At Stanford, Tony has taken on leadership roles as the Freshman Council President, where he managed $35,500 for over 1,700 students. He's also involved with TreeHacks as an Alumni Director and serves as the ACM ProCo Director.

Tony's venture capital experience includes positions as a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, a Scout at Soma Capital, and a Founder Fellow at RippleX Fellowship. His interest in public policy is evident through his work as a Fellow at Paragon Policy Fellowship and as a Co-Founder of the Public Interest Technology Lab at Stanford University, where he led the inaugural student govtech fellowship program.

His technical experience includes a software engineering internship at Amazon, contracting work for Swim England and Hypelist, and research at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) where he worked on deep learning to predict transcription factor binding motifs. He also conducted research at Harvard Medical School under the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Boston Children's Hospital.

Tony has received several prestigious recognitions, including being a Rise Fellow at Schmidt Futures, where he completed a fully-funded summer intensive in London/Oxford and founded the Rise North America Union. During his high school years at Amador Valley High School, he was the Salutatorian, a Coca-Cola Scholar, a National Merit Scholar, won two gold medals with Kungfu Team USA, and was an ISEF Finalist.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Tony has demonstrated a commitment to community service as the Founder and President of the Alameda County Science and Engineering Fair and as a Teaching Facilitator for Non-Trivial.

name: audrey chen
short_description: Serial hackathon winner (21 wins) and tech entrepreneur with a passion for AI innovation. Co-founder of VC-backed nosu.io, Software Engineering Intern at Intuit, and content creator with 68K Instagram followers. Currently pursuing Computer Engineering at Michigan State University while balancing multiple tech roles including NASA USRC research and Intel AI projects.
long_description:
Audrey Chen is a dynamic force in the tech world, particularly known for her exceptional track record of winning 21 hackathons with a 70% win rate, accumulating over $20,000 in prizes. Her technical prowess spans multiple domains within AI and software engineering, demonstrated through her diverse professional experiences.

As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Niya Ma
suggested_people.short_description: Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI with a strong background in hackathons, having won multiple awards and served as Director of Hack@Davidson. She graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics, and has experience in machine learning, automation, and full-stack development.
suggested_people.long_description:
Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI who graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics. Her technical journey showcases a diverse range of experiences across machine learning, software development, and leadership roles.

As the former Director of Hack@Davidson, Niya has deep roots in the hackathon community, both as an organizer and participant. Her impressive track record includes winning multiple hackathon awards, such as 2nd Place at the Twilio LLM Hackathon, Best project using Wolfram API at Stanford LLM x Law Hackathon, and awards for sustainability, security, and automation at various other competitions.

Niya's professional experience includes software engineering internships at major tech companies. At Oracle, she pioneered a Python script that accelerated network traffic simulation by 250x and engineered MySQL database and Grafana dashboard integration. At Qualtrics, she worked on the Developer Experience team, creating efficient updating mechanisms for services and making substantial open-source contributions to the Backstage project.

Her academic background includes coursework in Natural Language Processing, Concurrent & Parallel Computing, Deep Learning, Operating Systems, and Applied Cryptography. She also took CS229 - Machine Learning at Stanford University.

At Oracle, Niya has been working with OCI Landing Zones, contributing to enterprise cloud infrastructure deployment solutions. Her GitHub profile shows involvement with Oracle's cloud infrastructure projects, including forking and working with the oracle-enterprise-landingzone repository, which focuses on deploying typical architecture used by enterprise customers in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.

Beyond technical skills, Niya demonstrated leadership as President of the Association For Women In Mathematics at Davidson College and was involved in campus activities including Davidson Chorale and the Residence Life Office. She is bilingual in English and Mandarin, adding a multicultural dimension to her skill set.

Niya's combination of technical expertise, leadership experience, and hackathon success positions her as a versatile software engineer with particular strengths in machine learning applications, cloud infrastructure, and automation.

suggested_people.name: Ally Nakamura
suggested_people.short_description: Recent Stanford graduate currently building at PearX and involved with Catapult AI. Ally has a background in deep learning, AI, and scientific research, with notable achievements including a gold medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, selection as a Masason Foundation Scholar, and research on Chinese censorship.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ally Nakamura is a recent Stanford University graduate with BS/MS degrees in Computer Science with a focus on AI. She is currently building at PearX while also being involved with Catapult AI, where she's working on helping medical device companies deploy AI to make their workflows easier.

Her academic journey has been complemented by her deep interest in artificial intelligence and healthcare technology. She holds a Neural Networks and Deep Learning certification from deeplearning.ai and has worked with Stanford's Open Virtual Assistant Lab to build EHR-Xamine, a virtual assistant for electronic clinical health records designed to reduce physician burnout.

Ally has demonstrated exceptional scientific aptitude, having published research on Fluorescence-Guided Surgery in Frontiers in Oncology, where she reviewed applications of fluorescent probes in defining tumor locations during surgical procedures. Her scientific excellence was recognized internationally when she represented the United States at the International Earth Science Olympiad, earning a gold medal and ranking among the top 15 students out of nearly 400 participants from over 30 countries.

Her technical accomplishments include leading an AI-enabled email client at DoNotPay that was featured by Forbes and Wired, and building a voice agent to automatically handle reference checks for healthcare staffing agencies. She also enjoys participating in hackathons, where she has built AI dating apps and launched an AI crypto coin that scaled to $15M market cap.

Beyond her technical work, Ally has conducted significant research on Chinese censorship. Working with Jeffrey Shen, she created CensorScout and the Weibo Censorship Dashboard, two applications that increase transparency into censorship on Weibo. Their published paper on SSRN made daily top-tens in several sections and was in the top 10% of authors by downloads in the year following publication. This project was completed as part of Digital Propaganda & Censorship, an Independent Project at Phillips Academy.

Her entrepreneurial spirit is evident through her involvement with various organizations at Stanford, including co-founding the Stanford Chapter of Scholar of Finance and being a member of the Asia-Pacific Student Entrepreneurship Society. She also served as an intern at Stanford Women in Business, showcasing her interest in the intersection of business and technology.

Ally was selected as one of just 42 students to join the prestigious Masason Foundation after a rigorous three-round admissions process, further highlighting her exceptional potential. During her high school years, she contributed to STEM education as an Event Coordinator for Techstravaganza with Tomorrow's Women in Science and Technology.

She is bilingual in English and Japanese with limited working proficiency in German, giving her a global perspective that complements her technical skills and entrepreneurial mindset. In her free time, she enjoys hiking, attending DJ sets, eating sushi, and playing poker with friends.

suggested_people.name: Aidan Gollan
suggested_people.short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

name: porvesh balasubramanian
short_description: Porvesh is a fourth-year Computer Science student at the University of Michigan with a unique blend of expertise in systems engineering, robotics, and distributed computing. As a Founding Engineer at Bronco AI, he's developing AI agents for chip design and verification while simultaneously contributing to autonomous vehicle research and distributed systems validation.
long_description:
Porvesh Balasubramanian is a fourth-year Computer Science student at the University of Michigan who has carved out a distinctive path at the intersection of systems engineering, robotics, and AI. Currently serving as a Founding Engineer at Bronco AI, he's building cutting-edge AI agents for chip design and verification.

His technical versatility is evident through his diverse research experiences. At Michigan's Real Time Computing Lab, Porvesh built and raced F1Tenth autonomous vehicles, demonstrating his hands-on skills in robotics. Simultaneously, he contributed to OrderLab's distributed systems research, working on OathKeeper—a tool that validates distributed systems by detecting and enforcing semantic rules at runtime.

Porvesh's industry experience includes a role as a Mission System Software Intern at Northrop Grumman, where he automated boot image generation, reducing processing time from 5 weeks to just 3 minutes. He's also worked as a Software Intern at DealsPlus, implementing a Flask-based backend and enhancing user experience with the Quasar Framework.

His academic contributions extend beyond research. Porvesh serves as a grader for advanced courses like Embedded Systems and Advanced Data Structures, and works as an Engineering Center Tutor providing one-on-one assistance for upper-level EECS classes. Previously, he led study groups for introductory data structures and algorithms courses.

Porvesh's technical foundation is complemented by a strong educational background, with coursework spanning algorithms, computer architecture, embedded systems, operating systems, robotics, and deep learning. He's consistently maintained a 3.8/4.0 GPA, earning a place on the Dean's Honor List every semester.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Porvesh has demonstrated leadership through various roles, including as part of the "Cyber Safety Team" at the University of Michigan's Barger Leadership Institute, where he created a resource guide about cybersecurity for students. He's also an active developer with several GitHub repositories, including a personal game engine called "EnfieldEngine" written in C++ and contributions to real-time object detection for autonomous driving using deep learning.

Porvesh is also an accomplished cricket player, representing the University of Michigan in various tournaments including CACTUS 2024 and playing for teams like Detroit Challengers CC and Chicago Panthers. As an all-rounder, he has demonstrated skills in both batting and bowling across multiple T20 matches.

In 2022, he was part of a team that developed "Freshify," an application that uses artificial intelligence to track food expiration dates and provide tailored recipe recommendations, showcasing his interest in practical AI applications. His diverse interests and technical skills make him a versatile computer scientist with experience spanning from embedded systems to artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Advait Iyer
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Engineer with expertise in computer systems, specializing in hardware and software engineering. Currently a Software Engineer at Tesla with research experience in GPU-accelerated data analytics, and a published paper on overcoming memory capacity limitations in large-scale data analytics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Advait Iyer is a Computer Engineer with a strong focus on computer systems and hardware design. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a Bachelor of Science in Engineering in 2024. Advait has built an impressive career trajectory, currently working as a Software Engineer at Tesla while also contributing to academic research.

His technical expertise spans C/C++, Verilog/SystemVerilog, and Python, with a particular interest in computer architecture and systems design. At Tesla, Advait has worked on several significant projects including the revamped on-screen PRND gear slider for the 2024 Model 3 released in Europe and China, navigation and controls features, and a performance monitoring library for the infotainment system. He also contributed to the development of the new weather feature for the 2024 summer release.

As a Hardware Engineer at Aethero, Advait helped build space-rated edge AI computers, demonstrating his versatility across both software and hardware domains. His academic contributions include serving as an Instructional Assistant for Advanced Computer Architecture (EECS 470) and Digital Logic Design (EECS 270) at the University of Michigan. In the Computer Architecture course, he taught lab sections on hardware design using SystemVerilog and helped students design synthesizable out-of-order RISC-V processors. For the Logic Design course, he co-created and maintained the course's RTL DV platform deployed on autograder.io using Docker, which was used by approximately 300 computer engineering students per semester.

Advait's research as a Research Assistant in the CE Lab at the University of Michigan focused on GPU acceleration for heterogeneous LLM/DB workloads, resulting in a publication titled "Vortex: Overcoming Memory Capacity Limitations in GPU-Accelerated Large-Scale Data Analytics" accepted to VLDB 2025.

His impressive project portfolio includes a 94 MHz RISC-V CPU with P6 style renaming and N-way superscalar design, a foldable cloth piano, formal verification of a fault-tolerant cache coherence protocol, and various FPGA design projects. He has also worked on robotic planning and controls projects and numerous C/C++ projects including a RISC-V assembler, simulator, and linker.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Advait has explored entrepreneurship and venture capital as a Venture Partner at Contrary for over three years. He has also worked at Marathon Digital Holdings (MARA) as an Engineering Intern optimizing merged mining protocols, and contributed to Zepto (formerly KiranaKart, YC W21) in operations, growth, and engineering roles.

Advait has also written about the intersection of data science and spirituality, exploring how machine learning concepts can provide insights into human behavior and decision-making. His writing demonstrates his ability to connect technical concepts with broader philosophical ideas.

His academic achievements include being a runner-up in the APS History of Physics Essay Contest and winning the Gold Award in the Queen's Commonwealth Essay Competition. He is multilingual, with proficiency in English, French, Hindi, and Tamil, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills.

suggested_people.name: David Bai
suggested_people.short_description: David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at USC with diverse research experience in AI alignment, multi-agent robotic planning, and reinforcement learning for legged robots. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's developing language learning tools while also working on innovative projects like brain-controlled drones and GPS-denied navigation systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at the University of Southern California (2023-2027), where he serves as a USC Presidential Scholar. His academic journey is marked by a deep commitment to artificial intelligence research across multiple domains.

Currently, David is a Research Fellow at the Supervised Program for Alignment Research, where he investigates reasoning and AI agents from capabilities and security perspectives. Simultaneously, he works as a Research Assistant at USC Viterbi School of Engineering's GLAMOR Lab through the CURVE Fellowship, focusing on multi-agent robotic planning at the intersection of LLMs and symbolic planners.

David's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of Jargon, where he's building a language learning Chrome extension. His technical versatility extends to his work with USC Makers, where he manages projects involving brain-controlled drones using electroencephalography, having previously contributed to an autonomous greenhouse with computer vision.

His professional experience includes a Machine Learning & Computer Vision Internship at Rhoman Aerospace, enabling GPS-denied navigation through VIO and building simulation/SLAM pipelines. David has also served as a Research Assistant at the Dynamic Robotics and Control Laboratory, where he augmented model predictive control for legged robots with reinforcement learning.

In the academic community, David is active with USC's Center for AI in Society's Student Branch (CAIS++), where he contributes to research and projects in artificial intelligence with social impact applications. He is part of the Fall 2024 cohort, demonstrating his commitment to applying AI for societal benefit.

David is also involved with the USC Computational Aerospace Lab, where he works on projects related to BCD (Binary Collision Detection), showcasing his interdisciplinary approach to engineering challenges. This involvement highlights his ability to apply computational methods to aerospace applications.

Prior to USC, David demonstrated academic excellence at Cambridge University, where he compiled comprehensive lecture notes across various mathematical disciplines, indicating his strong foundation in theoretical concepts that underpin his current technical work.

David's commitment to social impact is demonstrated through his volunteer work with the Cheyenne River Youth Project and Friends of Children with Special Needs, where he developed educational courses. His multidisciplinary approach to AI research, combined with his technical skills and social consciousness, positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Anirudh Kotamraju
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

name: fengrui zuo
short_description: Fengrui Zuo is a hardware specialist focusing on Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory. With a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, he brings specialized expertise in hardware acceleration for AI applications and serves as an Analog Design Co-Lead and Industry Outreach Officer at Open Source Silicon @ Stanford.
long_description:
Fengrui Zuo is a hardware engineer specializing in Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, which is operated by Stanford University. He currently holds dual positions as a Staff Engineer at SLAC and is pursuing his Master's degree in Electrical Engineering (MSEE) at Stanford University, which he began in Autumn 2023.

Fengrui has established himself as a leader in the open-source silicon community at Stanford, where he serves in multiple leadership roles. He is the Industry Outreach Officer for Open Source Silicon @ Stanford (OS3), helping to bridge academic research with industry applications. Additionally, he co-leads the Analog Design Subteam at OS3, where he focuses on designing and verifying analog components such as amplifiers, voltage references, and Power Management ICs (PMICs). His work involves device simulations, schematic generation and routing using both open-source and proprietary software, and conducting bench testing and verification.

His technical expertise spans across several domains including CUDA kernel optimization, autonomous systems, and chip design. Fengrui demonstrates particular interest in cutting-edge hardware developments such as NVIDIA's Jetson Orin Nano platform for edge AI applications, open-source chip design, and specialized motherboards with timing synchronization capabilities. His work at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory likely involves specialized hardware systems for scientific research and experimentation, integrating AI capabilities into high-performance computing environments for physics research.

Fengrui's professional address is at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, located at 2575 Sand Hill Rd, Menlo Park, California. His dual role as both a graduate student and staff engineer positions him uniquely at the intersection of academic research and practical engineering applications, particularly in the field of analog design for advanced computing systems.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Sathvik Redrouthu
suggested_people.short_description: Sathvik Redrouthu is a tech innovator and entrepreneur who founded Procyon Photonics while in high school to develop photonic computing technology. Currently at Etched, he previously worked on chip design tooling through his startup Instachip. His research focuses on optical computing, photonic integrated circuits, and tensor algebra implementations for next-generation computing architectures.
suggested_people.long_description:
Sathvik Redrouthu is a forward-thinking technologist, entrepreneur, and researcher at the intersection of optoelectronics, hardware acceleration, and advanced computing architectures. Currently working at Etched and previously associated with Y Combinator, Sathvik has established himself as an innovator in specialized computing hardware despite his young age.

As the founder, CEO, and CTO of Procyon Photonics, Sathvik became the world's youngest CEO in the photonic and optical computing sector. Founded in 2021 while he was still in high school at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, Procyon develops revolutionary photon-based computing technology that aims to overcome the limitations of traditional electronic computing. The company's optical chips are designed to be significantly more energy-efficient than conventional processors, with prototypes reportedly 55,000 times more energy-efficient than the Intel i9 and over 100 times more efficient than Nvidia's A100 or Google's TPU. Procyon secured venture funding from Peter Thiel's 1517 Fund and has attracted interest from tech leaders like Sam Altman of OpenAI.

Before joining Etched, Sathvik founded Instachip, an EDA (Electronic Design Automation) startup focused on chip design tooling, and participated in Y Combinator. He is also conducting Formal Verification research with Dr. Mark Santolucito at Columbia University.

His research portfolio includes significant contributions to optical computing, with publications focused on optoelectronic hardware accelerators for tensor arithmetic. His work on "Tachyon," a programmable optoelectronic hardware accelerator, demonstrates his expertise in designing systems for ultrafast tensor operations. His team at Procyon was the first to run tensor algebra on an optical chip. Additionally, he has published on tensor algebra implementations for optoelectronic microchips and the use of interferometer-based photonic integrated circuits for rapid unitary transformations.

Sathvik's technical focus is on leveraging optical technologies to overcome limitations in traditional electronic computing, particularly for matrix multiplication and tensor operations critical for AI and machine learning workloads. His work on implementing unitary matrix transformations through Mach-Zehnder interferometers shows a deep understanding of how to harness photonic principles for computational advantage.

Beyond his professional work, Sathvik has developed numerous projects including AI chess engines, regex interpreters using Brzozowski derivatives, tensor algebra compilers with sparse tensor storage systems, and various AI applications. He is also skilled in hardware development, having created electric guitars and EMP generators from scratch.

Sathvik graduated high school in June 2024 but decided not to attend university, instead pursuing entrepreneurship and practical research. His vision is to someday "power the world with light" through photon-based computing, which he believes represents the next revolution in computing technology.

suggested_people.name: Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu
suggested_people.short_description: Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with diverse experience spanning aerospace, hardware engineering, and venture capital. Currently serving as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working at Amazon on ML quantization for embedded hardware and contributing to research at Stanford's PinCS Lab.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu is an Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University (2023-2027) with a remarkable breadth of technical and business experience. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, with a particular focus on the intersection of hardware and machine learning.

Currently, Yohannes serves as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working as a Hardware Engineer at Amazon in Sunnyvale, CA. At Amazon, he focuses on quantization of DNN models to be deployed on accelerators like NNA and MDLA for firmware applications such as Alexa. His work involves creating automated frameworks for NNA.3x aware training to avoid floating point numbers and transform to fixed point numbers, as well as extending frameworks to support TensorFlow model quantization and converting compatible audiotech models into firmware.

Yohannes is actively engaged in research at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, specifically in the PinCS Lab (Pedagogy in Computer Science Lab) where he works as an Undergraduate Researcher building drones. His aerospace interests extend to his earlier work as a Student Researcher at NASA, where he tested Aerogel insulation against radiation at 70,000 feet using weather balloon capsules.

His academic involvement at Stanford includes participation in the Leland Scholars Program, where he contributed to a research project titled "Equity in AI: Navigating Bias Through a Human-Centric Framework," analyzing approaches and implementing a paradigm shift for unbiased and ethical artificial intelligence.

Prior to Stanford, Yohannes worked as a Software Engineer at the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada, where he developed quantitative predictive modeling for city car crash data. He also conducted research at the University of Las Vegas Nevada for the International Science Fair, publishing work on "Analysis of Supersonic Parachutes On ReEntry" that examined crucial aspects of parachute design for rocket capsule reentry at supersonic speeds.

Yohannes possesses an impressive array of technical skills including machine learning frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras), programming languages (Python, C++, Java), hardware tools (Raspberry Pi, PCB design), robotics, computer vision (OpenCV), and data analysis tools (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Scikit-learn). His expertise also extends to aerospace engineering, mechatronics, embedded systems, and sensor fusion.

Based in both Palo Alto, CA and Las Vegas, NV, Yohannes represents a unique blend of technical depth across hardware engineering, aerospace, machine learning optimization, and venture capital experience - making him a versatile contributor to the AI and technology ecosystem.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

suggested_people.name: Advait Iyer
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Engineer with expertise in computer systems, specializing in hardware and software engineering. Currently a Software Engineer at Tesla with research experience in GPU-accelerated data analytics, and a published paper on overcoming memory capacity limitations in large-scale data analytics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Advait Iyer is a Computer Engineer with a strong focus on computer systems and hardware design. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a Bachelor of Science in Engineering in 2024. Advait has built an impressive career trajectory, currently working as a Software Engineer at Tesla while also contributing to academic research.

His technical expertise spans C/C++, Verilog/SystemVerilog, and Python, with a particular interest in computer architecture and systems design. At Tesla, Advait has worked on several significant projects including the revamped on-screen PRND gear slider for the 2024 Model 3 released in Europe and China, navigation and controls features, and a performance monitoring library for the infotainment system. He also contributed to the development of the new weather feature for the 2024 summer release.

As a Hardware Engineer at Aethero, Advait helped build space-rated edge AI computers, demonstrating his versatility across both software and hardware domains. His academic contributions include serving as an Instructional Assistant for Advanced Computer Architecture (EECS 470) and Digital Logic Design (EECS 270) at the University of Michigan. In the Computer Architecture course, he taught lab sections on hardware design using SystemVerilog and helped students design synthesizable out-of-order RISC-V processors. For the Logic Design course, he co-created and maintained the course's RTL DV platform deployed on autograder.io using Docker, which was used by approximately 300 computer engineering students per semester.

Advait's research as a Research Assistant in the CE Lab at the University of Michigan focused on GPU acceleration for heterogeneous LLM/DB workloads, resulting in a publication titled "Vortex: Overcoming Memory Capacity Limitations in GPU-Accelerated Large-Scale Data Analytics" accepted to VLDB 2025.

His impressive project portfolio includes a 94 MHz RISC-V CPU with P6 style renaming and N-way superscalar design, a foldable cloth piano, formal verification of a fault-tolerant cache coherence protocol, and various FPGA design projects. He has also worked on robotic planning and controls projects and numerous C/C++ projects including a RISC-V assembler, simulator, and linker.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Advait has explored entrepreneurship and venture capital as a Venture Partner at Contrary for over three years. He has also worked at Marathon Digital Holdings (MARA) as an Engineering Intern optimizing merged mining protocols, and contributed to Zepto (formerly KiranaKart, YC W21) in operations, growth, and engineering roles.

Advait has also written about the intersection of data science and spirituality, exploring how machine learning concepts can provide insights into human behavior and decision-making. His writing demonstrates his ability to connect technical concepts with broader philosophical ideas.

His academic achievements include being a runner-up in the APS History of Physics Essay Contest and winning the Gold Award in the Queen's Commonwealth Essay Competition. He is multilingual, with proficiency in English, French, Hindi, and Tamil, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills.

name: eduardo pontes reis
short_description: Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher specializing in radiology and AI applications in healthcare. Currently affiliated with Stanford University and Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein, he focuses on developing AI tools for medical imaging and clinical documentation. His research has been cited over 1,200 times, with significant contributions to medical text summarization, chest X-ray interpretation, and multimodal medical AI systems.
long_description:
Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher at the intersection of medicine and artificial intelligence, currently serving as a Visiting Scholar at Stanford University's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI) and as a researcher at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil.

His educational background includes an MD from State of Sao Paulo University (UNESP) in 2013, followed by a Radiology Residency at UNICAMP in 2017, and Neuroradiology specialization at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in 2018. This clinical foundation has informed his research focus on applying AI to healthcare challenges.

Eduardo's research has gained significant recognition in the field of medical AI. According to Google Scholar, his work has been cited over 1,200 times, with an h-index of 13. His research contributions span several important areas:

1. Medical Text Summarization: He co-authored a groundbreaking study published in Nature Medicine demonstrating that adapted large language models can outperform medical experts in clinical text summarization, potentially reducing documentation burden for clinicians.

2. Medical Imaging AI: He has contributed to multiple projects involving AI applications in radiology, including the development of BRAX (Brazilian labeled chest X-ray dataset), and participated in the creation of ChexAgent, a foundation model for chest X-ray interpretation.

3. Multimodal Medical AI: His work includes contributions to Med-Flamingo (a multimodal medical few-shot learner) and Merlin (a vision-language foundation model for 3D computed tomography).

4. Clinical Applications: Eduardo's research focuses on practical applications that can improve healthcare delivery, including automated contrast phase detection in abdominal CT and AI tools for radiology report generation.

At Stanford, Eduardo is part of the Machine Intelligence for Medical Imaging (MIMI) research group led by Dr. Akshay Chaudhari, where his research focuses on developing AI tools to improve healthcare, particularly in radiology and medical records. His specific interests include methods that use pairs of images and reports to teach radiology to computers, and applying large language models to reduce documentation burden for medical professionals.

Eduardo is an advocate for open data in healthcare when safe and feasible, contributing to the development of open-source datasets and tools. His professional affiliations include membership in the Sociedade Paulista de Radiologia (São Paulo Radiology Society), Colégio Brasileiro de Radiologia (Brazilian College of Radiology), and CREMESP (Regional Council of Medicine of the State of São Paulo).

Beyond his professional pursuits, Eduardo enjoys tennis, music (particularly playing the piano), and hiking. He is fluent in Portuguese (native) and English (professional proficiency), enabling him to engage with international research and collaboration opportunities in his field.

suggested_people.name: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta
suggested_people.short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

suggested_people.name: Zarif Azher
suggested_people.short_description: Bioengineering and Computer Science undergraduate at Caltech with extensive research experience in computational pathology and medical technology innovation. Published 10+ peer-reviewed papers in leading journals, focusing on applying AI and spatial transcriptomics to biomedical problems with the goal of expanding global healthcare access.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zarif Azher is an undergraduate student at Caltech pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Bioengineering and Computer Science (2024-2028). He is a passionate innovator and researcher at the intersection of AI and healthcare, with a particular focus on computational pathology, spatial transcriptomics, and medical technology development.

Zarif has an impressive research portfolio with over 10 peer-reviewed publications in prestigious journals and conferences, including the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing, BioData Mining, and the Journal of Pathology Informatics. His research spans innovative applications of AI in healthcare, such as inferring spatial transcriptomics from histological patterns, developing multimodal deep learning models for cancer prognostication, and creating interpretable AI systems for biomedical analysis.

His work has been cited over 60 times by researchers in the field, demonstrating the impact of his contributions to computational biology and medical AI. His recent projects include mapping three-dimensional tumor heterogeneity through deep learning inference of spatial transcriptomics from routine histopathology, and developing LLM-driven agent approaches to modeling legislative behavior.

Beyond his technical research, Zarif is committed to making healthcare more accessible globally. On his personal website, he states: "I want to use powerful technology to improve healthcare access and quality worldwide." He describes himself as a leader who organizes "people and things to accomplish ambitious goals" and a researcher developing "novel solutions to real-world issues – science for action, not observation."

Zarif's professional experience includes working in the Gao Research Group at Caltech and collaborating with researchers from institutions like Case Western Reserve University, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Dartmouth College. He has also been involved in projects to fight government corruption in Bangladesh, advocate for environmental justice in the USA, and deploy novel assistive technology for medical practitioners in underserved regions.

His interdisciplinary approach combines expertise in machine learning, bioinformatics, multimodal deep learning, cancer research, and pathology, positioning him as an emerging leader in the application of AI to solve complex healthcare challenges.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tran
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tran is a junior at Yale University with a strong focus on computer science, particularly in molecular AI research. He has contributed to MolLM, a unified language model integrating biomedical text with 2D and 3D molecular representations, and has experience at Hudson River Trading. His coursework spans deep learning, natural language processing, and graph-structured data.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tran is an undergraduate junior at Yale University pursuing computer science with specialized interests in computational biology and AI. His research work is evidenced by his contribution to MolLM, a sophisticated unified language model that integrates biomedical text with both 2D and 3D molecular representations. This project, presented at ISMB 2024, demonstrates his capability in developing advanced AI systems for molecular modeling.

Andrew has professional experience at Hudson River Trading, a quantitative trading firm known for its algorithmic trading strategies and high-performance computing infrastructure. This suggests his skills extend to financial technology applications of computer science.

His academic foundation is robust, with coursework covering both theoretical computer science (Compilers and Interpreters, Computer Architecture, Operating Systems, Discrete Mathematics) and cutting-edge AI topics (Deep Learning on Graph-Structured Data, Natural Language Processing, Probabilistic Machine Learning). This diverse technical background positions him well at the intersection of traditional computer science and modern AI applications.

Andrew's interest in molecular AI research, as shown by his publication work, indicates his potential to contribute to the growing field of AI applications in healthcare and drug discovery. His engagement with content related to diffusion models, geometry problem-solving AI, and other technical developments (as seen in his LinkedIn activity) suggests he stays current with the latest advancements in artificial intelligence.

It's important to note that there are several other professionals named Andrew Tran in different fields, including an investigative data reporter at The Washington Post (who won a Pulitzer Prize), an orthopedic surgeon specializing in sports medicine, a UCLA law lecturer, and a visual effects artist who has worked on major films like The Hunger Games and Avengers: Infinity War. Our Andrew Tran is specifically the Yale computer science student focused on molecular AI research.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Chandra Suda
suggested_people.short_description: CS and Math student at Stanford University and Rise Global Fellow with a passion for social impact through technology.
