suggested_people.name: Locke Cai
suggested_people.short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Alex Fan
suggested_people.short_description: Alex Fan is a talented undergraduate at MIT studying Mathematics and Computer Science with a focus on AI research. A USACO Finalist in 2021 and 2022, he's currently working as a Research Engineer at Pika, tackling challenges in generative video and image models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alex Fan is a promising talent in the AI field, currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023-2026). His academic journey includes rigorous coursework in graduate-level Machine Learning, Advanced Algorithms, Advances in Computer Vision, and Computational Cognitive Science, demonstrating his commitment to mastering both the theoretical foundations and cutting-edge applications of AI.

Alex's technical prowess was evident early on, as he was a USACO (USA Computing Olympiad) Finalist in both 2021 and 2022 during his time at Lexington High School. This competitive programming background has provided him with strong algorithmic thinking skills that complement his AI research interests.

Currently, Alex is working as a Research Engineer at Pika, where he focuses on solving engineering and research challenges related to generative video/image models and data curation. This practical experience in the rapidly evolving field of generative AI is giving him hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art techniques and real-world applications.

During his time at MIT, Alex has been involved in various research projects. In 2022, he participated in the PRIMES program where he collaborated on research leveraging statistical distributions for RNA sequencing across time, working with Prof. Gil Alterovitz. This experience demonstrates his interest in applying computational methods to biological data.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Alex is an active member of the MIT community. He lives in La Maison Française (MIT French House) where he embraces French culture and language. He's also involved in the performing arts, having performed in the MIT Musical Theatre Guild's Cabaret Night in Fall 2023 and cast as John Hinckley Jr. in their production of "Assassins" for Fall 2024.

Alex has diverse personal interests including cooking, baking, fermentation, Broadway musicals, and playing piano. He describes himself as a francophile who dreams of returning to Parisian cafes. In his spare time, he enjoys working on programming projects and writing blog posts, showcasing his passion for both technical and creative pursuits.

His engagement with the AI community is evident through his LinkedIn activity, where he follows developments in AI research, particularly in generative models and applications in various domains. Alex represents the next generation of AI researchers and engineers who are combining strong mathematical foundations with practical implementation skills to push the boundaries of what's possible in artificial intelligence.

This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Rex Liu
suggested_people.short_description: Undergraduate at Caltech pursuing Computer Science and Biology with a focus on Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. Research Fellow at Thomson Lab developing innovative AI systems including thalamus-inspired LLM routers and GNN-based spatial proteomics. Currently interning at NASA JPL for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft mission and competing on Caltech's Water Polo team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rex Liu is an undergraduate student at Caltech studying Computer Science and Biology, with a particular focus on the intersection of these fields through Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. As a Research Fellow at Caltech's Thomson Lab, Rex has developed several cutting-edge AI systems that demonstrate his innovative approach to machine learning.

His research portfolio includes a Thalamus-inspired LLM Router called "Herd" that creates scalable ensembles of small, open-source language models capable of outperforming larger proprietary models through Q-learning-based dynamic model selection. This work was presented at the NeurIPS Efficient Natural Language and Speech Processing Workshop. He's also worked on Hierarchical Chains with Multi-Level Abstention (HCMA), optimizing Black-box API deployments with uncertainty-based delegation and improved risk control, and published a paper on "Cost-Saving LLM Cascades with Early Abstention."

In the biomedical space, Rex has applied Graph Neural Networks to spatial proteomics, using counterfactual learning to identify tumor perturbations that enhance T-cell infiltration, with validated combinatorial therapies in collaboration with Cedars-Sinai. He's also worked on "Building Foundation Models to Characterize Cellular Interactions via Geometric Self-Supervised Learning on Spatial Genomics."

His most significant research contribution is on Functionally Invariant Path (FIP), a differential geometry-based framework that allows neural networks to adapt to secondary tasks without catastrophic forgetting. This groundbreaking work was published in Nature Machine Intelligence in 2024 and has already been cited by other researchers in the field. The FIP algorithm has wide-ranging applications from improving recommendations on online stores to fine-tuning self-driving cars.

Currently, Rex is interning at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, writing software for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft as part of the Mission Operations and Ground Data Systems team. He is also a member of Caltech's Men's Water Polo team, competing as an Attacker.

Prior to Caltech, Rex worked as a research assistant at National Taiwan University's Systems Biology Epithelia Lab, where he designed a lethal Zika virus-driven plasmid for transgenic mosquitoes, expressing a hybrid neurotoxin upon Zika infection. He also integrated a protein BLAST search engine to identify sequence alignments in the lab's online databases.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Rex has extensive experience in cybersecurity, having worked as a Security Researcher at HackerOne and a Bug Bounty Hunter at Bugcrowd for over five years. He has also served as a Teaching Assistant at Taipei American School, instructing students in Mechanical Engineering (CAD, CNC, water jet cutting, TIG welding) and Modern Topics in Computer Science (logic gates, quantum mechanics, deep learning).

Rex's multidisciplinary background, spanning AI, biology, cybersecurity, and aerospace, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving fields. He is fluent in Chinese and English, with working proficiency in Spanish and Japanese, further enhancing his ability to collaborate in global research environments. Outside of his academic and research work, Rex plays the violin and guitar.

name: olsen b.
short_description: Software Engineer at Affirm and MLH Top 50 recipient with expertise in workflow orchestration infrastructure and LLMs. Founded Hack@Davidson, Davidson College's first student-led hackathon, and has won multiple hackathon awards including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech. Currently consulting for Cognition to help improve Devin AI.
long_description:
Olsen B. (Oğuzhan Budanur) is a Software Engineer at Affirm working on the Workflow Orchestration Infrastructure Team, where he manages distributed systems integrating Airflow, Luigi, Spark, and Kubernetes that handle over 1,000,000 actions monthly. He developed a high-performance gRPC server in Kotlin and built a Slack bot leveraging semantic search and LLMs for efficient triage.

With a strong entrepreneurial spirit, Olsen founded and served as President of Hack@Davidson, organizing Davidson College's first student-led hackathon that raised over $6,000 and accommodated 90+ participants. His leadership extended to founding Competitive Coding at Davidson (C-CAD), which prepares members for software engineering jobs and internships. Under his guidance, the team won 11 prizes across 7 hackathons, including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech.

Olsen's professional experience includes working as a Software Consultant for Cognition AI Labs, helping to improve Devin AI, and founding Motate LLC, a boutique software contracting firm that secured multiple contracts and achieved quarterly revenue of ~$20,000. He also interned at Aptos Labs, where he created a 7,000-line open-source Python CLI for Kubernetes deployments that saved $70,000 through multithreading optimizations.

His technical expertise spans workflow orchestration, distributed systems, Kubernetes, Python, Kotlin, Java, C++, Firebase, and LLMs. Olsen is particularly passionate about building AI-powered tools, as demonstrated by his work on semantic search systems and LLM applications. He's recognized as part of the MLH Top 50 and has received multiple academic scholarships and hackathon awards, including wins for projects like WaitFree DMV, ImmiGrace, SusEats, BlockAide, and CodeViolet.

Olsen grew up in the DC Metro Area and discovered his passion for coding in middle school, starting with VisualBasic's GUI-based desktop apps. His love for technology was truly ignited at his first hackathon, VTHacks 7, in 2019. He studied Computer Science at Davidson College after transferring from Virginia Tech, where he was pursuing a double major in Computer Science and Computational Modeling & Data Analytics. He maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA in his major courses and served as a Teaching Assistant for a Blockchains class at Davidson College.

Beyond his technical work, Olsen enjoys exploring new technologies, participating in hackathons, and building innovative projects. His personal website at olsenbudanur.com showcases his portfolio of work and technical achievements.

suggested_people.name: Niya Ma
suggested_people.short_description: Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI with a strong background in hackathons, having won multiple awards and served as Director of Hack@Davidson. She graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics, and has experience in machine learning, automation, and full-stack development.
suggested_people.long_description:
Niya Ma is a Software Engineer at Oracle OCI who graduated Magna Cum Laude from Davidson College with a double major in Computer Science and Mathematics. Her technical journey showcases a diverse range of experiences across machine learning, software development, and leadership roles.

As the former Director of Hack@Davidson, Niya has deep roots in the hackathon community, both as an organizer and participant. Her impressive track record includes winning multiple hackathon awards, such as 2nd Place at the Twilio LLM Hackathon, Best project using Wolfram API at Stanford LLM x Law Hackathon, and awards for sustainability, security, and automation at various other competitions.

Niya's professional experience includes software engineering internships at major tech companies. At Oracle, she pioneered a Python script that accelerated network traffic simulation by 250x and engineered MySQL database and Grafana dashboard integration. At Qualtrics, she worked on the Developer Experience team, creating efficient updating mechanisms for services and making substantial open-source contributions to the Backstage project.

Her academic background includes coursework in Natural Language Processing, Concurrent & Parallel Computing, Deep Learning, Operating Systems, and Applied Cryptography. She also took CS229 - Machine Learning at Stanford University.

At Oracle, Niya has been working with OCI Landing Zones, contributing to enterprise cloud infrastructure deployment solutions. Her GitHub profile shows involvement with Oracle's cloud infrastructure projects, including forking and working with the oracle-enterprise-landingzone repository, which focuses on deploying typical architecture used by enterprise customers in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.

Beyond technical skills, Niya demonstrated leadership as President of the Association For Women In Mathematics at Davidson College and was involved in campus activities including Davidson Chorale and the Residence Life Office. She is bilingual in English and Mandarin, adding a multicultural dimension to her skill set.

Niya's combination of technical expertise, leadership experience, and hackathon success positions her as a versatile software engineer with particular strengths in machine learning applications, cloud infrastructure, and automation.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Audrey Chen
suggested_people.short_description: Serial hackathon winner (21 wins) and tech entrepreneur with a passion for AI innovation. Co-founder of VC-backed nosu.io, Software Engineering Intern at Intuit, and content creator with 68K Instagram followers. Currently pursuing Computer Engineering at Michigan State University while balancing multiple tech roles including NASA USRC research and Intel AI projects.
suggested_people.long_description:
Audrey Chen is a dynamic force in the tech world, particularly known for her exceptional track record of winning 21 hackathons with a 70% win rate, accumulating over $20,000 in prizes. Her technical prowess spans multiple domains within AI and software engineering, demonstrated through her diverse professional experiences.

As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

suggested_people.name: Yeabsera Afework
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with extensive game development experience. Co-founder of 646 Studios and former Software Engineer at Microsoft, specializing in user authentication systems and facial recognition technology. First-generation college student from Ethiopia with a passion for technology and community service.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yeabsera Afework is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with a diverse background spanning game development, software engineering, and entrepreneurship. As the co-founder of 646 Studios, Yeabsera has developed three successful video games that amassed over 200,000 community members and achieved 9,000+ concurrent players on release. This entrepreneurial venture led to contracts with major brands like Gen G and Crocs, where Yeabsera's work boosted concurrent players by 5,000+.

At Microsoft, Yeabsera worked as a Software Engineer designing the backend client for the company's first in-house user authentication system, leveraging facial recognition and AI-based liveness verification to enhance security protocols. The role also involved developing secure clients in C# and creating metric dashboards in KustoQL to help on-call engineers identify bugs and outages.

Yeabsera's game development expertise extends to RB Battles LLC, where they designed immersive 3D environments using Blender and Adobe Substance Painter, leading a team of 3D artists to create game elements that attracted over 100,000 concurrent players. Their implementation of efficient workflow strategies accelerated project completion by 20%.

Originally from Ethiopia, Yeabsera moved to Spokane, Washington at the age of 10 and attended All Saints Catholic School before graduating from Gonzaga Preparatory School. At Gonzaga Prep, Yeabsera was recognized as a Salutatorian, placing in the second-highest academic group in the graduating class. He was also a recipient of the Mike Shanks scholarship, which supported his education at Gonzaga Prep.

Yeabsera has been actively involved in community service through Gonzaga Prep's Knights of the Leash program, particularly providing after-school tutoring at his former elementary school, All Saints Catholic School. His AP calculus teacher, Stephen Manfred, described him as an outgoing student with a great personality who "brings joy to the people around him" and "interacts with his peers really well."

As a first-generation university student, Yeabsera is involved with ColorStack, a tech nonprofit that creates academic and professional opportunities for Black and Latinx students entering STEM fields. At Stanford, he benefits from programs designed to support first-generation, low-income (FLI) students in their transition to college life.

Academically, Yeabsera has taken courses in Computer Systems, Design and Analysis of Algorithms, Infrastructure at Scale, Mathematical Foundations of Computer Science, Operating System Principles, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Programming Abstractions and Methodologies at Stanford.

Yeabsera has also participated in selective development programs, including the HeadStart Fellowship for diverse students with outstanding leadership potential, and Jane Street's UNBOXED Scholar program, where they gained experience in quantitative trading through probability, statistics, and game theory challenges.

Currently, Yeabsera is set to join LinkedIn as a Software Engineer for Summer 2025, continuing to build on their impressive technical foundation and entrepreneurial spirit with the long-term goal of establishing a career in the tech industry.

suggested_people.name: Aidan Gollan
suggested_people.short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

name: debajyoti (debo) datta
short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

suggested_people.name: Eduardo Pontes Reis
suggested_people.short_description: Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher specializing in radiology and AI applications in healthcare. Currently affiliated with Stanford University and Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein, he focuses on developing AI tools for medical imaging and clinical documentation. His research has been cited over 1,200 times, with significant contributions to medical text summarization, chest X-ray interpretation, and multimodal medical AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher at the intersection of medicine and artificial intelligence, currently serving as a Visiting Scholar at Stanford University's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI) and as a researcher at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil.

His educational background includes an MD from State of Sao Paulo University (UNESP) in 2013, followed by a Radiology Residency at UNICAMP in 2017, and Neuroradiology specialization at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in 2018. This clinical foundation has informed his research focus on applying AI to healthcare challenges.

Eduardo's research has gained significant recognition in the field of medical AI. According to Google Scholar, his work has been cited over 1,200 times, with an h-index of 13. His research contributions span several important areas:

1. Medical Text Summarization: He co-authored a groundbreaking study published in Nature Medicine demonstrating that adapted large language models can outperform medical experts in clinical text summarization, potentially reducing documentation burden for clinicians.

2. Medical Imaging AI: He has contributed to multiple projects involving AI applications in radiology, including the development of BRAX (Brazilian labeled chest X-ray dataset), and participated in the creation of ChexAgent, a foundation model for chest X-ray interpretation.

3. Multimodal Medical AI: His work includes contributions to Med-Flamingo (a multimodal medical few-shot learner) and Merlin (a vision-language foundation model for 3D computed tomography).

4. Clinical Applications: Eduardo's research focuses on practical applications that can improve healthcare delivery, including automated contrast phase detection in abdominal CT and AI tools for radiology report generation.

At Stanford, Eduardo is part of the Machine Intelligence for Medical Imaging (MIMI) research group led by Dr. Akshay Chaudhari, where his research focuses on developing AI tools to improve healthcare, particularly in radiology and medical records. His specific interests include methods that use pairs of images and reports to teach radiology to computers, and applying large language models to reduce documentation burden for medical professionals.

Eduardo is an advocate for open data in healthcare when safe and feasible, contributing to the development of open-source datasets and tools. His professional affiliations include membership in the Sociedade Paulista de Radiologia (São Paulo Radiology Society), Colégio Brasileiro de Radiologia (Brazilian College of Radiology), and CREMESP (Regional Council of Medicine of the State of São Paulo).

Beyond his professional pursuits, Eduardo enjoys tennis, music (particularly playing the piano), and hiking. He is fluent in Portuguese (native) and English (professional proficiency), enabling him to engage with international research and collaboration opportunities in his field.

suggested_people.name: Trishala Neeraj
suggested_people.short_description: Trishala Neeraj is a Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube with a strong academic background from Cornell University. She specializes in computer vision and natural language processing, bringing technical expertise to cybersecurity analytics and has contributed to several influential AI research papers.
suggested_people.long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. She works with terabyte-scale data to develop models using Deep Learning and Matrix Factorization techniques, with a particular focus on language data and models.

Her academic foundation was built at Cornell University, where she graduated in 2018 after focusing on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing during her graduate studies. She also holds a Bachelor of Engineering degree from BITS Pilani, India, and spent time as a visiting research scholar at the Predictive Technology Lab at the University of Virginia.

Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022). Her work on "BigBIO: A Framework for Data-Centric Biomedical Natural Language Processing" (2022) has also gained recognition in the field.

Her professional experience includes a summer internship at BuzzFeed in 2017, where she worked on a project using K-Means Clustering to tag over 14,000 BuzzFeed quizzes, which she documented in a blog post on the BuzzFeed Tech Blog. She has also published research on "A Computational Approach to Perceived Trustworthiness of Airbnb Host Profiles" (2017) and "Longitudinal Analysis of Cyber-Related Articles" (2020).

Beyond her technical work, Trishala has been actively involved in the tech community. She represented the student body at the Cornell Tech Campus Dedication ceremony in August 2017 and moderated a conversation with Eric Schmidt in March 2018. She maintains a personal blog where she documents her research projects on topics like Weak Supervision, Feature-based Approaches with BERT, and Semantic Entailment.

Trishala is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Hindi, which enhances her ability to work in diverse teams and global environments. Her involvement with organizations like Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) demonstrates her commitment to the broader AI community and diversity in tech.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Diddi
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Diddi is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform bringing on-device AI solutions with a focus on privacy and accessibility. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, he specializes in Applied Machine Learning and has experience as an instructor at General Assembly. A graduate of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Dhruv combines technical expertise with entrepreneurial vision, particularly in healthcare AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Diddi is an engineer and entrepreneur based in the San Francisco Bay Area with specialized experience in Applied Machine Learning. He is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform that brings AI directly to users' devices, ensuring data privacy, personalized experiences, and accessibility without reliance on cloud infrastructure. Solo has particularly focused on healthcare applications, addressing challenges around data privacy (HIPAA compliance), accessibility in low-connectivity environments, and customization for specific healthcare scenarios.

Dhruv actively promotes Solo through his newsletter "Get Solo Tech" on Substack, where he discusses innovations like Solo Health, which aims to transform patient care through on-device AI that protects sensitive patient data while providing robust performance for diagnostics, patient monitoring, and workflow optimization.

As a tech community participant, Dhruv has been featured as a speaker and host at San Francisco tech events, including a panel discussion on "AI + Human Intelligence" where he presented Solo alongside other founders. He's also participated in hackathons, with his profile showing attendance at AI hackathon events.

Dhruv brings a strong educational foundation from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign where he was recognized as a James Scholar and made the Dean's List. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, including Machine Learning, Algorithms, Computer Architecture (Honors), Data Structures (Honors), Interactive Computer Graphics, and R Programming. His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English, Hindi, and Punjabi, along with working knowledge of French and Mandarin Chinese.

As an educator, Dhruv has received glowing recommendations for his work as an instructor at General Assembly's boot camp program. Former students praise his patience, extensive knowledge, and ability to break down complex concepts in accessible ways. His teaching style is described as easy-going yet effective, making him a favorite resource for students struggling with difficult concepts.

Dhruv maintains an active presence in the AI and tech community, regularly publishing his newsletter "So Essentially Weekly" that covers developments in the field. His project portfolio demonstrates versatility and practical application of his skills, including work with Illini Hyperloop, a Kaggle Challenge on Titanic Prediction, and various web and mobile applications like Flare, Anthem Web App, and a Dwolla Pebble App.

Dhruv's professional focus appears to be at the intersection of privacy-first AI applications and healthcare innovation, with an emphasis on bringing powerful machine learning capabilities directly to devices while protecting user data and ensuring accessibility regardless of internet connectivity.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

name: chandra suda
short_description: CS and Math student at Stanford University and Rise Global Fellow with a passion for social impact through technology. Specializes in AI applications in healthcare, with research experience at Harvard Medical School and innovative work on tuberculosis detection through cough audio analysis.
long_description:
Chandra Suda is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2024-2028) and a Rise Global Fellow with the Rhodes Trust, an initiative that selects 100 promising teens worldwide to support them as they work to solve humanity's most pressing problems.

With a strong focus on the intersection of AI and healthcare, Chandra has conducted significant research in applying machine learning to medical diagnostics. His most notable project involves developing an innovative app for early detection of tuberculosis using cough audio analysis. The app allows users to record a one-second cough segment and receive a diagnostic output, with plans to integrate healthcare provider notifications to help reduce disease spread. This work earned him recognition at the International Science & Engineering Fair, where he received a Grand Award in 2023.

Before attending Stanford, Chandra was a standout student at Bentonville High School in Arkansas, where he was accepted to multiple prestigious universities including Harvard, Princeton, Cornell, University of Pennsylvania, Johns Hopkins, Berkeley, Columbia, and Carnegie Mellon. His teachers describe him as intelligent, determined, studious, and notably humble, always expressing gratitude to educators who supported his journey.

Chandra currently serves as a Student Researcher at Harvard Medical School in AI and Medicine, and has previous experience as a Machine Learning Intern at Walmart Global Tech, where he worked on optimizing retail environment supply and inventory systems. He's also gaining experience in the AI startup ecosystem as a Founder Fellow at On Deck and Strategy Intern at Mercor, while working with Anthropic as a Stanford ambassador to strategize product growth efforts for Claude. Additionally, he serves as a Campus Strategist for Perplexity AI.

His technical achievements are complemented by leadership roles, including serving as the Red Cross Hub-Club President for the Missouri-Arkansas Region and leading the MissingMaps team to optimize disaster relief through geographical data mapping. At 16, he founded Aimate, a STEM education nonprofit, and has received US Presidential and Congressional Award recognitions for his humanitarian volunteer work.

As a published researcher with works on "Early Diagnosis and Predictive Treatment Monitoring of Tuberculosis With Novel Machine Learning Cough Analysis" and "Improving Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis Using MRI Scans-Based Artificial Neural Networks," Chandra demonstrates a commitment to leveraging AI for meaningful social impact, particularly in healthcare accessibility and diagnostics for underserved communities.

suggested_people.name: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta
suggested_people.short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

suggested_people.name: Eduardo Pontes Reis
suggested_people.short_description: Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher specializing in radiology and AI applications in healthcare. Currently affiliated with Stanford University and Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein, he focuses on developing AI tools for medical imaging and clinical documentation. His research has been cited over 1,200 times, with significant contributions to medical text summarization, chest X-ray interpretation, and multimodal medical AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher at the intersection of medicine and artificial intelligence, currently serving as a Visiting Scholar at Stanford University's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI) and as a researcher at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil.

His educational background includes an MD from State of Sao Paulo University (UNESP) in 2013, followed by a Radiology Residency at UNICAMP in 2017, and Neuroradiology specialization at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in 2018. This clinical foundation has informed his research focus on applying AI to healthcare challenges.

Eduardo's research has gained significant recognition in the field of medical AI. According to Google Scholar, his work has been cited over 1,200 times, with an h-index of 13. His research contributions span several important areas:

1. Medical Text Summarization: He co-authored a groundbreaking study published in Nature Medicine demonstrating that adapted large language models can outperform medical experts in clinical text summarization, potentially reducing documentation burden for clinicians.

2. Medical Imaging AI: He has contributed to multiple projects involving AI applications in radiology, including the development of BRAX (Brazilian labeled chest X-ray dataset), and participated in the creation of ChexAgent, a foundation model for chest X-ray interpretation.

3. Multimodal Medical AI: His work includes contributions to Med-Flamingo (a multimodal medical few-shot learner) and Merlin (a vision-language foundation model for 3D computed tomography).

4. Clinical Applications: Eduardo's research focuses on practical applications that can improve healthcare delivery, including automated contrast phase detection in abdominal CT and AI tools for radiology report generation.

At Stanford, Eduardo is part of the Machine Intelligence for Medical Imaging (MIMI) research group led by Dr. Akshay Chaudhari, where his research focuses on developing AI tools to improve healthcare, particularly in radiology and medical records. His specific interests include methods that use pairs of images and reports to teach radiology to computers, and applying large language models to reduce documentation burden for medical professionals.

Eduardo is an advocate for open data in healthcare when safe and feasible, contributing to the development of open-source datasets and tools. His professional affiliations include membership in the Sociedade Paulista de Radiologia (São Paulo Radiology Society), Colégio Brasileiro de Radiologia (Brazilian College of Radiology), and CREMESP (Regional Council of Medicine of the State of São Paulo).

Beyond his professional pursuits, Eduardo enjoys tennis, music (particularly playing the piano), and hiking. He is fluent in Portuguese (native) and English (professional proficiency), enabling him to engage with international research and collaboration opportunities in his field.

suggested_people.name: Ally Nakamura
suggested_people.short_description: Recent Stanford graduate currently building at PearX and involved with Catapult AI. Ally has a background in deep learning, AI, and scientific research, with notable achievements including a gold medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, selection as a Masason Foundation Scholar, and research on Chinese censorship.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ally Nakamura is a recent Stanford University graduate with BS/MS degrees in Computer Science with a focus on AI. She is currently building at PearX while also being involved with Catapult AI, where she's working on helping medical device companies deploy AI to make their workflows easier.

Her academic journey has been complemented by her deep interest in artificial intelligence and healthcare technology. She holds a Neural Networks and Deep Learning certification from deeplearning.ai and has worked with Stanford's Open Virtual Assistant Lab to build EHR-Xamine, a virtual assistant for electronic clinical health records designed to reduce physician burnout.

Ally has demonstrated exceptional scientific aptitude, having published research on Fluorescence-Guided Surgery in Frontiers in Oncology, where she reviewed applications of fluorescent probes in defining tumor locations during surgical procedures. Her scientific excellence was recognized internationally when she represented the United States at the International Earth Science Olympiad, earning a gold medal and ranking among the top 15 students out of nearly 400 participants from over 30 countries.

Her technical accomplishments include leading an AI-enabled email client at DoNotPay that was featured by Forbes and Wired, and building a voice agent to automatically handle reference checks for healthcare staffing agencies. She also enjoys participating in hackathons, where she has built AI dating apps and launched an AI crypto coin that scaled to $15M market cap.

Beyond her technical work, Ally has conducted significant research on Chinese censorship. Working with Jeffrey Shen, she created CensorScout and the Weibo Censorship Dashboard, two applications that increase transparency into censorship on Weibo. Their published paper on SSRN made daily top-tens in several sections and was in the top 10% of authors by downloads in the year following publication. This project was completed as part of Digital Propaganda & Censorship, an Independent Project at Phillips Academy.

Her entrepreneurial spirit is evident through her involvement with various organizations at Stanford, including co-founding the Stanford Chapter of Scholar of Finance and being a member of the Asia-Pacific Student Entrepreneurship Society. She also served as an intern at Stanford Women in Business, showcasing her interest in the intersection of business and technology.

Ally was selected as one of just 42 students to join the prestigious Masason Foundation after a rigorous three-round admissions process, further highlighting her exceptional potential. During her high school years, she contributed to STEM education as an Event Coordinator for Techstravaganza with Tomorrow's Women in Science and Technology.

She is bilingual in English and Japanese with limited working proficiency in German, giving her a global perspective that complements her technical skills and entrepreneurial mindset. In her free time, she enjoys hiking, attending DJ sets, eating sushi, and playing poker with friends.

suggested_people.name: Anirudh Kotamraju
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

name: soham vasanawala
short_description: Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics student at Stanford University with a strong focus on the intersection of AI and healthcare. He has co-founded two startups, including Intratalent AI and Gains Coach LLC, where he's developing AI-powered coaching platforms. His research experience spans medical mixed reality and algorithm development for medical procedures, with notable presentations at ISMRM 2023.
long_description:
Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics undergraduate at Stanford University with entrepreneurial drive and technical expertise in AI applications for healthcare and biotech.

As a co-founder of Intratalent AI (since November 2024) and Gains Coach LLC (since December 2021), Soham demonstrates his entrepreneurial spirit. At Gains Coach, he's developing a real-time, AI-powered coaching platform for various physical movements including physiotherapy, sports, fitness, and dance.

His research experience is impressive for his age. During his internship at Stanford University School of Medicine, he worked with the Incubator for Medical Mixed and Extended Reality, developing a real-time augmented-reality visualization of knee motion from MRI data for the HoloLens2. At Stanford University School of Engineering, he designed and conducted research that led to a time-saving algorithm for a medical procedure, which he presented at Stanford BioX 2022 and ISMRM 2023.

Notably, at ISMRM 2023, he presented research on "Predicting MR Image Quality from Breathing Patterns" where he demonstrated that detected breathing patterns could be utilized to predict whether adequate MR image quality would be obtained. Using a K-means clustering algorithm, his work showed that 9 in 10 forty-second breathing waveforms could be correctly predicted as either resulting in high or low image quality, potentially saving time from unnecessary scans.

Soham has also gained industry experience as a Software Engineer at Turboprop, a fintech startup in Menlo Park. His academic background includes a Bachelor of Science degree from Stanford University (2023-2027) and previous education at Henry M. Gunn High School.

Beyond his technical work, Soham has contributed to a publication titled "Essays and Interviews with Bay Area Entrepreneurs" (September 2022), showing his interest in entrepreneurship. He is also a member of The International Society for Magnetic Resonance in Medicine, further demonstrating his commitment to the medical technology field.

Soham is proficient in English (native) and has limited working proficiency in French. His diverse experiences in AI, healthcare technology, and entrepreneurship position him uniquely at the intersection of technology and medicine, with a particular focus on using AI to solve real-world healthcare challenges.

He appears to be related to Shreyas Vasanawala, MD/PhD, who serves as the William R. Brody Professor of Pediatric Radiology and Child Health at Stanford Medicine, suggesting a family connection that may have influenced his interest in medical technology.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.
