Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Ally Nakamura
suggested_people.short_description: Recent Stanford graduate currently building at PearX and involved with Catapult AI. Ally has a background in deep learning, AI, and scientific research, with notable achievements including a gold medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, selection as a Masason Foundation Scholar, and research on Chinese censorship.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ally Nakamura is a recent Stanford University graduate with BS/MS degrees in Computer Science with a focus on AI. She is currently building at PearX while also being involved with Catapult AI, where she's working on helping medical device companies deploy AI to make their workflows easier.

Her academic journey has been complemented by her deep interest in artificial intelligence and healthcare technology. She holds a Neural Networks and Deep Learning certification from deeplearning.ai and has worked with Stanford's Open Virtual Assistant Lab to build EHR-Xamine, a virtual assistant for electronic clinical health records designed to reduce physician burnout.

Ally has demonstrated exceptional scientific aptitude, having published research on Fluorescence-Guided Surgery in Frontiers in Oncology, where she reviewed applications of fluorescent probes in defining tumor locations during surgical procedures. Her scientific excellence was recognized internationally when she represented the United States at the International Earth Science Olympiad, earning a gold medal and ranking among the top 15 students out of nearly 400 participants from over 30 countries.

Her technical accomplishments include leading an AI-enabled email client at DoNotPay that was featured by Forbes and Wired, and building a voice agent to automatically handle reference checks for healthcare staffing agencies. She also enjoys participating in hackathons, where she has built AI dating apps and launched an AI crypto coin that scaled to $15M market cap.

Beyond her technical work, Ally has conducted significant research on Chinese censorship. Working with Jeffrey Shen, she created CensorScout and the Weibo Censorship Dashboard, two applications that increase transparency into censorship on Weibo. Their published paper on SSRN made daily top-tens in several sections and was in the top 10% of authors by downloads in the year following publication. This project was completed as part of Digital Propaganda & Censorship, an Independent Project at Phillips Academy.

Her entrepreneurial spirit is evident through her involvement with various organizations at Stanford, including co-founding the Stanford Chapter of Scholar of Finance and being a member of the Asia-Pacific Student Entrepreneurship Society. She also served as an intern at Stanford Women in Business, showcasing her interest in the intersection of business and technology.

Ally was selected as one of just 42 students to join the prestigious Masason Foundation after a rigorous three-round admissions process, further highlighting her exceptional potential. During her high school years, she contributed to STEM education as an Event Coordinator for Techstravaganza with Tomorrow's Women in Science and Technology.

She is bilingual in English and Japanese with limited working proficiency in German, giving her a global perspective that complements her technical skills and entrepreneurial mindset. In her free time, she enjoys hiking, attending DJ sets, eating sushi, and playing poker with friends.

name: rex liu
short_description: Undergraduate at Caltech pursuing Computer Science and Biology with a focus on Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. Research Fellow at Thomson Lab developing innovative AI systems including thalamus-inspired LLM routers and GNN-based spatial proteomics. Currently interning at NASA JPL for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft mission and competing on Caltech's Water Polo team.
long_description:
Rex Liu is an undergraduate student at Caltech studying Computer Science and Biology, with a particular focus on the intersection of these fields through Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. As a Research Fellow at Caltech's Thomson Lab, Rex has developed several cutting-edge AI systems that demonstrate his innovative approach to machine learning.

His research portfolio includes a Thalamus-inspired LLM Router called "Herd" that creates scalable ensembles of small, open-source language models capable of outperforming larger proprietary models through Q-learning-based dynamic model selection. This work was presented at the NeurIPS Efficient Natural Language and Speech Processing Workshop. He's also worked on Hierarchical Chains with Multi-Level Abstention (HCMA), optimizing Black-box API deployments with uncertainty-based delegation and improved risk control, and published a paper on "Cost-Saving LLM Cascades with Early Abstention."

In the biomedical space, Rex has applied Graph Neural Networks to spatial proteomics, using counterfactual learning to identify tumor perturbations that enhance T-cell infiltration, with validated combinatorial therapies in collaboration with Cedars-Sinai. He's also worked on "Building Foundation Models to Characterize Cellular Interactions via Geometric Self-Supervised Learning on Spatial Genomics."

His most significant research contribution is on Functionally Invariant Path (FIP), a differential geometry-based framework that allows neural networks to adapt to secondary tasks without catastrophic forgetting. This groundbreaking work was published in Nature Machine Intelligence in 2024 and has already been cited by other researchers in the field. The FIP algorithm has wide-ranging applications from improving recommendations on online stores to fine-tuning self-driving cars.

Currently, Rex is interning at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, writing software for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft as part of the Mission Operations and Ground Data Systems team. He is also a member of Caltech's Men's Water Polo team, competing as an Attacker.

Prior to Caltech, Rex worked as a research assistant at National Taiwan University's Systems Biology Epithelia Lab, where he designed a lethal Zika virus-driven plasmid for transgenic mosquitoes, expressing a hybrid neurotoxin upon Zika infection. He also integrated a protein BLAST search engine to identify sequence alignments in the lab's online databases.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Rex has extensive experience in cybersecurity, having worked as a Security Researcher at HackerOne and a Bug Bounty Hunter at Bugcrowd for over five years. He has also served as a Teaching Assistant at Taipei American School, instructing students in Mechanical Engineering (CAD, CNC, water jet cutting, TIG welding) and Modern Topics in Computer Science (logic gates, quantum mechanics, deep learning).

Rex's multidisciplinary background, spanning AI, biology, cybersecurity, and aerospace, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving fields. He is fluent in Chinese and English, with working proficiency in Spanish and Japanese, further enhancing his ability to collaborate in global research environments. Outside of his academic and research work, Rex plays the violin and guitar.

suggested_people.name: Zarif Azher
suggested_people.short_description: Bioengineering and Computer Science undergraduate at Caltech with extensive research experience in computational pathology and medical technology innovation. Published 10+ peer-reviewed papers in leading journals, focusing on applying AI and spatial transcriptomics to biomedical problems with the goal of expanding global healthcare access.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zarif Azher is an undergraduate student at Caltech pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Bioengineering and Computer Science (2024-2028). He is a passionate innovator and researcher at the intersection of AI and healthcare, with a particular focus on computational pathology, spatial transcriptomics, and medical technology development.

Zarif has an impressive research portfolio with over 10 peer-reviewed publications in prestigious journals and conferences, including the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing, BioData Mining, and the Journal of Pathology Informatics. His research spans innovative applications of AI in healthcare, such as inferring spatial transcriptomics from histological patterns, developing multimodal deep learning models for cancer prognostication, and creating interpretable AI systems for biomedical analysis.

His work has been cited over 60 times by researchers in the field, demonstrating the impact of his contributions to computational biology and medical AI. His recent projects include mapping three-dimensional tumor heterogeneity through deep learning inference of spatial transcriptomics from routine histopathology, and developing LLM-driven agent approaches to modeling legislative behavior.

Beyond his technical research, Zarif is committed to making healthcare more accessible globally. On his personal website, he states: "I want to use powerful technology to improve healthcare access and quality worldwide." He describes himself as a leader who organizes "people and things to accomplish ambitious goals" and a researcher developing "novel solutions to real-world issues – science for action, not observation."

Zarif's professional experience includes working in the Gao Research Group at Caltech and collaborating with researchers from institutions like Case Western Reserve University, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Dartmouth College. He has also been involved in projects to fight government corruption in Bangladesh, advocate for environmental justice in the USA, and deploy novel assistive technology for medical practitioners in underserved regions.

His interdisciplinary approach combines expertise in machine learning, bioinformatics, multimodal deep learning, cancer research, and pathology, positioning him as an emerging leader in the application of AI to solve complex healthcare challenges.

suggested_people.name: Aaquib Syed
suggested_people.short_description: AI researcher at Google with a focus on interpretability and language model behavior. Aaquib has published significant work on refusal mechanisms in LLMs, attribution patching for circuit discovery, and efficient pruning techniques for massive language models. A Banneker-Key Scholar at the University of Maryland with a strong competitive programming background.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aaquib Syed is an AI researcher currently working at Google while affiliated with the University of Maryland, where he is pursuing a CS and Math degree as a Banneker-Key Scholar (full merit scholarship for the top 0.5% of incoming class). His research focuses on understanding and improving large language models, with particular emphasis on interpretability and model behavior mechanisms.

His recent publication "Refusal in Language Models Is Mediated by a Single Direction" (NeurIPS 2024, Poster) has garnered significant attention with 98+ citations. This groundbreaking work demonstrates that refusal behavior in conversational LLMs is controlled by a one-dimensional subspace across multiple open-source chat models, providing important insights into how safety mechanisms function in these systems.

Aaquib has also made significant contributions to automated interpretability research with his work "Attribution Patching Outperforms Automated Circuit Discovery" (BlackboxNLP at EMNLP 2024), which has received 47+ citations. In this paper, he developed a simple yet powerful method based on attribution patching that outperforms existing approaches while requiring minimal computational resources - just two forward passes and a backward pass.

In the area of model efficiency, his research "Prune and Tune: Improving Efficient Pruning Techniques for Massive Language Models" (ICLR TinyPapers Workshop 2023, top 6%) advanced techniques for pruning large language models without extensive retraining, addressing critical compute expense issues in deploying massive models.

His most recent work includes "Mechanistic Unlearning: Robust Knowledge Unlearning and Editing via Mechanistic Localization" (2024), exploring techniques for targeted knowledge editing in language models.

Beyond pure AI research, Aaquib has applied machine learning to medical imaging, co-authoring a paper in PLOS ONE that uses XGBoost with MRI and non-imaging data to predict pathological complete response in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

As a student, Aaquib has received numerous prestigious recognitions, including the USA Computing Olympiad Gold rank and the National Merit Scholarship. He has also developed several projects including a Personal Distance Monitor, a Stress Level Manager for students with autism spectrum disorder, and a FIRST Robotics Competition Scouting system.

According to his GitHub profile, Aaquib describes himself as someone who enjoys "thinking about and solving problems in AI/ML and finance" with a current interest in "creating scalable methods to attribute and edit behaviors and knowledge in large language models." He also mentions a love for competitive programming, working with low-level languages, and creating infrastructure and trading strategies for financial markets.

His interests span AI/ML and finance, with a particular focus on solving complex problems at the intersection of these fields. Aaquib's combination of theoretical research and practical applications demonstrates his versatility and depth of expertise in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tran
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tran is a junior at Yale University with a strong focus on computer science, particularly in molecular AI research. He has contributed to MolLM, a unified language model integrating biomedical text with 2D and 3D molecular representations, and has experience at Hudson River Trading. His coursework spans deep learning, natural language processing, and graph-structured data.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tran is an undergraduate junior at Yale University pursuing computer science with specialized interests in computational biology and AI. His research work is evidenced by his contribution to MolLM, a sophisticated unified language model that integrates biomedical text with both 2D and 3D molecular representations. This project, presented at ISMB 2024, demonstrates his capability in developing advanced AI systems for molecular modeling.

Andrew has professional experience at Hudson River Trading, a quantitative trading firm known for its algorithmic trading strategies and high-performance computing infrastructure. This suggests his skills extend to financial technology applications of computer science.

His academic foundation is robust, with coursework covering both theoretical computer science (Compilers and Interpreters, Computer Architecture, Operating Systems, Discrete Mathematics) and cutting-edge AI topics (Deep Learning on Graph-Structured Data, Natural Language Processing, Probabilistic Machine Learning). This diverse technical background positions him well at the intersection of traditional computer science and modern AI applications.

Andrew's interest in molecular AI research, as shown by his publication work, indicates his potential to contribute to the growing field of AI applications in healthcare and drug discovery. His engagement with content related to diffusion models, geometry problem-solving AI, and other technical developments (as seen in his LinkedIn activity) suggests he stays current with the latest advancements in artificial intelligence.

It's important to note that there are several other professionals named Andrew Tran in different fields, including an investigative data reporter at The Washington Post (who won a Pulitzer Prize), an orthopedic surgeon specializing in sports medicine, a UCLA law lecturer, and a visual effects artist who has worked on major films like The Hunger Games and Avengers: Infinity War. Our Andrew Tran is specifically the Yale computer science student focused on molecular AI research.

suggested_people.name: Vivek Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vivek Vajipey is a Computer Science student at Stanford University pursuing both Bachelor's and Master's degrees with a minor in Geophysics. His research at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) focuses on reasoning in large language models, while his previous work applied machine learning to agricultural remote sensing. He has developed innovative AI applications including ExplainAI, CriticAL, and WorldDex, winning awards at major hackathons like PennApps XXIV and Cal Hacks 10.0.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vivek Vajipey is pursuing both a Bachelor's and Master's degree in Computer Science at Stanford University, with a minor in Geophysics. His academic journey reflects a deep interest in the intersection of artificial intelligence and practical applications.

At the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL), Vivek researches reasoning capabilities in large language models through the Computation & Cognition Lab. His work in AI extends beyond theoretical research - he has recently co-authored "CriticAL: Critic Automation with Language Models," demonstrating his contribution to advancing LLM technologies.

Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

suggested_people.name: Joe Qiaoyun Li
suggested_people.short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

name: arnav adhikari
short_description: 19-year-old EECS and Finance student at MIT with a passion for building innovative solutions in fintech, robotics, and healthtech. First place winner at HackMIT 2024 with a nicotine cessation patch project, and currently working on semantic operators at MIT CSAIL while also running a stealth startup.
long_description:
Arnav Adhikari is a dynamic 19-year-old undergraduate at MIT pursuing a dual focus in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and Finance. His technical interests span across multiple domains including fintech (payments, wealth management, AI analysts), robotics (collaboration and control), healthtech (LLM-aided care), and productivity tools. He describes himself as a "big proponent of automating the mundane" and believes that jobs should be automated to redirect human attention toward tasks requiring ingenuity.

Arnav has built an impressive track record of achievements. Most notably, he and his team won the First Place Grand Prize at HackMIT 2024 with their algorithmically-driven nicotine cessation patch. He's currently working as a Builder at MIT's prestigious Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), focusing on semantic operators.

Entrepreneurially minded, Arnav is the Founder and CEO of a stealth startup that he's been running since January 2024. His previous experience includes work at Boston Consulting Group (BCM), Rice University, Stanford's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI), and Harvard Medical School, demonstrating his ability to collaborate with top-tier institutions across academia and industry.

Arnav's research work is particularly notable in healthcare technology. He has worked on cardiac imaging interpretability and standardized cardiac measurements at BCM, Texas Children's Hospital, and Stanford AIMI, with his work being featured in Circulation by the American Heart Association in November 2023. He has also analyzed teamwork synergy for AI Surgical Robotic Coaches at Rice HCAIR and Harvard Medical School, and developed smarter irrigation and water management systems for the City of Southside Place in Houston.

His technical background is further strengthened by his experience in robot motion planning and control at Rice RobotPI, and his achievements as a retired USAJMO winner and USACO Gold Medalist. Arnav is also an author, having written the Cubronix Competitive Math Practice Book for charity, which was featured in the Houston Chronicle in January 2022.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Arnav offers tutoring services in the Greater Houston area, specializing in math, science, engineering, and test preparation. He enjoys tennis, basketball, football, biking, the outdoors, and various forms of media entertainment.

Currently a freshman at MIT (class of 2028), Arnav graduated from Carnegie Vanguard High School in 2024 after previously attending Bellaire High School. He describes himself as someone who loves "learning and building fast," and is always open to discussing innovative ideas and groundbreaking technologies.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

suggested_people.name: Aadit Juneja
suggested_people.short_description: Aadit Juneja is a student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Finance from Wharton and Computer Science from Penn Engineering. He has research experience in multimodal language models for tumor contouring at Penn Medicine and is preparing for a quantitative trading internship at Five Rings while actively publishing technical articles on AI and language models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aadit Juneja is an ambitious undergraduate student in the highly selective Jerome Fisher Management & Technology (M&T) Program at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing dual degrees in Finance from The Wharton School and Computer Science from Penn Engineering.

His professional experience demonstrates a strong interest in the intersection of finance and technology. Aadit is preparing for a Quantitative Trading Internship at Five Rings in New York (January-February 2025) and recently completed a Fall Private Equity Analyst role at Leo Legacy in Philadelphia (August-October 2024). 

What sets Aadit apart is his research experience in artificial intelligence applications in healthcare. During Summer 2024, he worked as a Research Assistant at Penn Medicine, University of Pennsylvania Health System, focusing on multimodal language models for tumor contouring. This experience highlights his ability to apply advanced AI techniques to solve complex medical problems.

Academically, Aadit maintains a perfect 4.0 GPA and is actively involved in several finance and analytics-focused student organizations, including the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, Wharton Analytics Fellows, and Wharton Undergraduate Distressed Investing Group.

Aadit is also a prolific technical writer, regularly publishing articles on his personal website about cutting-edge AI topics. His recent publications include "A Distributed Inference Engine for SmolLM with Rust and gRPC," "RL for Training Multiple Decoding Heads -- An Inference Acceleration Method in Language Models," and "Frequency Based Constrained Decoding for Language Model Watermarks." He has also written about practical AI applications like "Agent for Seamless Meeting Scheduling" and financial analysis with "Tempus AI Short Recommendation."

As a developer, Aadit maintains an active GitHub profile (ajuneja23) with repositories focused on AI, machine learning, and practical applications. His projects include implementations of Monte Carlo integration, PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization) algorithms from scratch, and an Agentic Meeting Scheduler, demonstrating his technical skills in both finance and computer science domains.

His contact information includes his email (aadit@aaditjuneja.com) and phone number (224-443-2889), making him accessible for professional and academic opportunities.

Aadit's dual expertise in finance and computer science, combined with his research experience in healthcare AI applications and technical writing skills, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving domains.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Dylan Nguyen
suggested_people.short_description: MIT '28 undergraduate researcher integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for mRNA lipid nanoparticle manufacturing. Amazon Future Engineer Scholar with extensive experience in computational biology, neuroscience, and machine learning applications, having won multiple prestigious awards including 3rd Place at the International Science & Engineering Fair.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dylan Nguyen is a first-year undergraduate student at MIT (Class of 2028) with a remarkable background in computational biology, neuroscience, and AI research. Currently working as an Undergraduate Research Assistant at MIT Chemical Engineering, he's integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for manufacturing mRNA lipid nanoparticles in the Myerson Research Group.

Dylan's research experience is impressive for his age. He has worked as a Scientific Programming Intern at the Max Planck Florida Institute for Neuroscience and has completed several significant research projects, including modeling the Drosophila Melanogaster nerve cord using spiking neural networks, applying deep learning to predict cytokines in Sickle Cell Anemia patients, and exploring machine learning for morphological neuron classification in the neocortex.

His academic achievements are equally notable. Dylan is an Amazon Future Engineer Scholarship recipient, which provides $40,000 towards college tuition and a guaranteed paid internship at Amazon. He's also a Kovner Opportunity Scholarship recipient, supporting talented public high school students to attend selective universities.

In competitive programming, Dylan has reached the Gold Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO). His scientific research has earned him prestigious recognitions, including 3rd Place Grand Award in Biomedical and Health Sciences at the 2023 Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair, the Regeneron Biomedical Science Award, and finalist status at the National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium.

Currently, Dylan is also an AMP Scholar at Jane Street, where he's learning mathematics, computer programming, data analysis, and game theory. Previously, he participated in MIT's Introduction to Technology, Engineering, and Science (MITES) program, taking classes in Science Writing Communications and Regenerative Stem Cell Biology.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Dylan has ventured into entrepreneurship as a co-founder of Tally.AI, a startup that empowers researchers with AI-driven aggregation and analysis of scientific papers. Working alongside fellow MIT students and graduate students from other prestigious institutions, Tally.AI aims to prevent duplicative research efforts, enhance collaboration between research groups, and help researchers stay up-to-date with the latest works in their fields through features like similarity scoring, knowledge graphs, and real-time alerts.

Dylan's diverse projects demonstrate his versatility in applying computational methods across different domains, from neuroscience to financial trading, showcasing his ability to leverage AI and machine learning for solving complex problems in both research and entrepreneurial contexts.

suggested_people.name: Chandra Suda
suggested_people.short_description: CS and Math student at Stanford University and Rise Global Fellow with a passion for social impact through technology. Specializes in AI applications in healthcare, with research experience at Harvard Medical School and innovative work on tuberculosis detection through cough audio analysis.
suggested_people.long_description:
Chandra Suda is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2024-2028) and a Rise Global Fellow with the Rhodes Trust, an initiative that selects 100 promising teens worldwide to support them as they work to solve humanity's most pressing problems.

With a strong focus on the intersection of AI and healthcare, Chandra has conducted significant research in applying machine learning to medical diagnostics. His most notable project involves developing an innovative app for early detection of tuberculosis using cough audio analysis. The app allows users to record a one-second cough segment and receive a diagnostic output, with plans to integrate healthcare provider notifications to help reduce disease spread. This work earned him recognition at the International Science & Engineering Fair, where he received a Grand Award in 2023.

Before attending Stanford, Chandra was a standout student at Bentonville High School in Arkansas, where he was accepted to multiple prestigious universities including Harvard, Princeton, Cornell, University of Pennsylvania, Johns Hopkins, Berkeley, Columbia, and Carnegie Mellon. His teachers describe him as intelligent, determined, studious, and notably humble, always expressing gratitude to educators who supported his journey.

Chandra currently serves as a Student Researcher at Harvard Medical School in AI and Medicine, and has previous experience as a Machine Learning Intern at Walmart Global Tech, where he worked on optimizing retail environment supply and inventory systems. He's also gaining experience in the AI startup ecosystem as a Founder Fellow at On Deck and Strategy Intern at Mercor, while working with Anthropic as a Stanford ambassador to strategize product growth efforts for Claude. Additionally, he serves as a Campus Strategist for Perplexity AI.

His technical achievements are complemented by leadership roles, including serving as the Red Cross Hub-Club President for the Missouri-Arkansas Region and leading the MissingMaps team to optimize disaster relief through geographical data mapping. At 16, he founded Aimate, a STEM education nonprofit, and has received US Presidential and Congressional Award recognitions for his humanitarian volunteer work.

As a published researcher with works on "Early Diagnosis and Predictive Treatment Monitoring of Tuberculosis With Novel Machine Learning Cough Analysis" and "Improving Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis Using MRI Scans-Based Artificial Neural Networks," Chandra demonstrates a commitment to leveraging AI for meaningful social impact, particularly in healthcare accessibility and diagnostics for underserved communities.

name: andrew ye
short_description: Stanford University undergraduate studying Mathematics and Computer Science with research focus on AI, particularly neural architectures and network compression. Published at NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with experience as a software engineering intern, teaching assistant, and visiting instructor.
long_description:
Andrew Ye is a talented undergraduate student currently pursuing his B.S. in Mathematics and Computer Science at Stanford University, having transferred there in 2024. Prior to Stanford, Andrew studied at Case Western Reserve University from 2022 to 2024, also focusing on Mathematics and Computer Science.

Andrew has built an impressive research portfolio in artificial intelligence. Since June 2023, he has been working as an Undergraduate Researcher at the Case School of Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, collaborating with Dr. Shuai Xu, Dr. Vipin Chaudhary, and researchers at Rice AI and MIT. His research has led to publications at prestigious AI conferences including NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with his work "GNNs also deserve editing, and they need it more than once" receiving multiple citations.

Andrew's research interests span several areas of AI including neural architectures, human-computer interaction, probability/combinatorics, metacognition, and learning theory. He is particularly focused on addressing key questions in AI such as ensuring system faithfulness and security, balancing the scale-bloat tradeoff in neural networks, and understanding how neural networks fundamentally reason and learn. He founded quant@CWRU, a student-led research group supported by professors at Case Western Reserve University focused on integrating machine learning paradigms to solve complex financial tasks.

Beyond research, Andrew has gained practical industry experience as a Software Engineering Intern at Zventus from May to August 2023, where he worked with Angel Alban on healthcare technologies. He has also developed his teaching skills as a Teaching Assistant at Case Western Reserve University, where he assisted with courses in Algorithms and Discrete Mathematics from August 2023 to May 2024. Most recently, he served as a Visiting Instructor at DigiPen Institute of Technology, teaching Data Analytics and Statistics during the summer of 2024.

Andrew grew up in Seattle and Hong Kong and has diverse personal interests including solving puzzles, playing piano (with a particular fondness for Liszt), hiking with his dog, and writing on his blog. His commitment to community service is evident from his volunteer work with North Helpline from May 2021 to April 2022. His academic profile, research contributions, and diverse experiences showcase his versatility and dedication to advancing the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Liangze Li
suggested_people.short_description: Liangze Li is an AI researcher at Google DeepMind with a background from Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science. His research focuses on natural language processing and AI detection, with publications on distinguishing human from AI-generated content. He has demonstrated leadership through founding multiple organizations at CMU and is multilingual with proficiency in Mandarin, English, Cantonese, and Russian.
suggested_people.long_description:
Liangze Li is an AI researcher currently working at Google DeepMind, one of the world's leading artificial intelligence research labs. He joined DeepMind in 2024 after completing his education at Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science, where he earned his Master's degree in Language Technologies. His academic journey at CMU began in 2017 as an undergraduate student before continuing with graduate studies from 2022 to 2024.

Liangze's research focuses primarily on natural language processing and AI detection systems. He has published several notable papers in this field, including "GPT-Sentinel: Distinguishing Human and ChatGPT Generated Content" and "Token Prediction as Implicit Classification to Identify LLM-Generated Text," both published in 2023. These works have received significant attention in the academic community, with his GPT-Sentinel paper garnering over 70 citations. He has also contributed to research on referential games in NLP with his paper "Listener Model for the PhotoBook Referential Game with CLIPScores as Implicit Reference Chain."

During his time at Carnegie Mellon, Liangze demonstrated exceptional leadership and initiative by founding and presiding over several organizations. He was the Founder and President of the CMU Blackjack Society, as well as the Founder and Lecturer of the Carnegie Mellon University Student College. He also served as President of the Student College Executive Committee and as a Representative in the Graduate Student Assembly.

Before focusing on AI and natural language processing, Liangze had research interests in cryptography, with several publications between 2012-2014 on topics such as pairing computation on Edwards curves and Jacobi quartic curves with high-degree twists. This demonstrates his versatility and depth of knowledge across different areas of computer science.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Liangze has diverse interests in music, having played Alto Saxophone in both the Carnegie Mellon University Kiltie Band and the Pinghe Chamber Orchestra. His intellectual curiosity extends to philosophy as well, as evidenced by his founding of the Pinghe School Philosophy Club and his connection to CMU's Department of Philosophy.

Liangze is impressively multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Mandarin and English, full professional proficiency in Cantonese, and limited working proficiency in Russian. This linguistic versatility enhances his ability to collaborate in international research settings.

In his own words, Liangze describes himself as being "involved in AI research and startups," indicating his dual interests in both the theoretical advancement of AI and its practical applications in entrepreneurial contexts. His engagement with posts related to machine learning, AI development, and technology startups on LinkedIn further reflects his professional focus and interests in the field of artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Aadit Juneja
suggested_people.short_description: Aadit Juneja is a student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Finance from Wharton and Computer Science from Penn Engineering. He has research experience in multimodal language models for tumor contouring at Penn Medicine and is preparing for a quantitative trading internship at Five Rings while actively publishing technical articles on AI and language models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aadit Juneja is an ambitious undergraduate student in the highly selective Jerome Fisher Management & Technology (M&T) Program at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing dual degrees in Finance from The Wharton School and Computer Science from Penn Engineering.

His professional experience demonstrates a strong interest in the intersection of finance and technology. Aadit is preparing for a Quantitative Trading Internship at Five Rings in New York (January-February 2025) and recently completed a Fall Private Equity Analyst role at Leo Legacy in Philadelphia (August-October 2024). 

What sets Aadit apart is his research experience in artificial intelligence applications in healthcare. During Summer 2024, he worked as a Research Assistant at Penn Medicine, University of Pennsylvania Health System, focusing on multimodal language models for tumor contouring. This experience highlights his ability to apply advanced AI techniques to solve complex medical problems.

Academically, Aadit maintains a perfect 4.0 GPA and is actively involved in several finance and analytics-focused student organizations, including the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, Wharton Analytics Fellows, and Wharton Undergraduate Distressed Investing Group.

Aadit is also a prolific technical writer, regularly publishing articles on his personal website about cutting-edge AI topics. His recent publications include "A Distributed Inference Engine for SmolLM with Rust and gRPC," "RL for Training Multiple Decoding Heads -- An Inference Acceleration Method in Language Models," and "Frequency Based Constrained Decoding for Language Model Watermarks." He has also written about practical AI applications like "Agent for Seamless Meeting Scheduling" and financial analysis with "Tempus AI Short Recommendation."

As a developer, Aadit maintains an active GitHub profile (ajuneja23) with repositories focused on AI, machine learning, and practical applications. His projects include implementations of Monte Carlo integration, PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization) algorithms from scratch, and an Agentic Meeting Scheduler, demonstrating his technical skills in both finance and computer science domains.

His contact information includes his email (aadit@aaditjuneja.com) and phone number (224-443-2889), making him accessible for professional and academic opportunities.

Aadit's dual expertise in finance and computer science, combined with his research experience in healthcare AI applications and technical writing skills, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving domains.

suggested_people.name: Alex Fan
suggested_people.short_description: Alex Fan is a talented undergraduate at MIT studying Mathematics and Computer Science with a focus on AI research. A USACO Finalist in 2021 and 2022, he's currently working as a Research Engineer at Pika, tackling challenges in generative video and image models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alex Fan is a promising talent in the AI field, currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023-2026). His academic journey includes rigorous coursework in graduate-level Machine Learning, Advanced Algorithms, Advances in Computer Vision, and Computational Cognitive Science, demonstrating his commitment to mastering both the theoretical foundations and cutting-edge applications of AI.

Alex's technical prowess was evident early on, as he was a USACO (USA Computing Olympiad) Finalist in both 2021 and 2022 during his time at Lexington High School. This competitive programming background has provided him with strong algorithmic thinking skills that complement his AI research interests.

Currently, Alex is working as a Research Engineer at Pika, where he focuses on solving engineering and research challenges related to generative video/image models and data curation. This practical experience in the rapidly evolving field of generative AI is giving him hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art techniques and real-world applications.

During his time at MIT, Alex has been involved in various research projects. In 2022, he participated in the PRIMES program where he collaborated on research leveraging statistical distributions for RNA sequencing across time, working with Prof. Gil Alterovitz. This experience demonstrates his interest in applying computational methods to biological data.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Alex is an active member of the MIT community. He lives in La Maison Française (MIT French House) where he embraces French culture and language. He's also involved in the performing arts, having performed in the MIT Musical Theatre Guild's Cabaret Night in Fall 2023 and cast as John Hinckley Jr. in their production of "Assassins" for Fall 2024.

Alex has diverse personal interests including cooking, baking, fermentation, Broadway musicals, and playing piano. He describes himself as a francophile who dreams of returning to Parisian cafes. In his spare time, he enjoys working on programming projects and writing blog posts, showcasing his passion for both technical and creative pursuits.

His engagement with the AI community is evident through his LinkedIn activity, where he follows developments in AI research, particularly in generative models and applications in various domains. Alex represents the next generation of AI researchers and engineers who are combining strong mathematical foundations with practical implementation skills to push the boundaries of what's possible in artificial intelligence.

name: yohannes tenagashaw aklilu
short_description: Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with diverse experience spanning aerospace, hardware engineering, and venture capital. Currently serving as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working at Amazon on ML quantization for embedded hardware and contributing to research at Stanford's PinCS Lab.
long_description:
Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu is an Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University (2023-2027) with a remarkable breadth of technical and business experience. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, with a particular focus on the intersection of hardware and machine learning.

Currently, Yohannes serves as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working as a Hardware Engineer at Amazon in Sunnyvale, CA. At Amazon, he focuses on quantization of DNN models to be deployed on accelerators like NNA and MDLA for firmware applications such as Alexa. His work involves creating automated frameworks for NNA.3x aware training to avoid floating point numbers and transform to fixed point numbers, as well as extending frameworks to support TensorFlow model quantization and converting compatible audiotech models into firmware.

Yohannes is actively engaged in research at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, specifically in the PinCS Lab (Pedagogy in Computer Science Lab) where he works as an Undergraduate Researcher building drones. His aerospace interests extend to his earlier work as a Student Researcher at NASA, where he tested Aerogel insulation against radiation at 70,000 feet using weather balloon capsules.

His academic involvement at Stanford includes participation in the Leland Scholars Program, where he contributed to a research project titled "Equity in AI: Navigating Bias Through a Human-Centric Framework," analyzing approaches and implementing a paradigm shift for unbiased and ethical artificial intelligence.

Prior to Stanford, Yohannes worked as a Software Engineer at the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada, where he developed quantitative predictive modeling for city car crash data. He also conducted research at the University of Las Vegas Nevada for the International Science Fair, publishing work on "Analysis of Supersonic Parachutes On ReEntry" that examined crucial aspects of parachute design for rocket capsule reentry at supersonic speeds.

Yohannes possesses an impressive array of technical skills including machine learning frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras), programming languages (Python, C++, Java), hardware tools (Raspberry Pi, PCB design), robotics, computer vision (OpenCV), and data analysis tools (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Scikit-learn). His expertise also extends to aerospace engineering, mechatronics, embedded systems, and sensor fusion.

Based in both Palo Alto, CA and Las Vegas, NV, Yohannes represents a unique blend of technical depth across hardware engineering, aerospace, machine learning optimization, and venture capital experience - making him a versatile contributor to the AI and technology ecosystem.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Joe Qiaoyun Li
suggested_people.short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Fengrui Zuo
suggested_people.short_description: Fengrui Zuo is a hardware specialist focusing on Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory. With a Master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, he brings specialized expertise in hardware acceleration for AI applications and serves as an Analog Design Co-Lead and Industry Outreach Officer at Open Source Silicon @ Stanford.
suggested_people.long_description:
Fengrui Zuo is a hardware engineer specializing in Analog, RF, High Speed Design, and Edge AI at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, which is operated by Stanford University. He currently holds dual positions as a Staff Engineer at SLAC and is pursuing his Master's degree in Electrical Engineering (MSEE) at Stanford University, which he began in Autumn 2023.

Fengrui has established himself as a leader in the open-source silicon community at Stanford, where he serves in multiple leadership roles. He is the Industry Outreach Officer for Open Source Silicon @ Stanford (OS3), helping to bridge academic research with industry applications. Additionally, he co-leads the Analog Design Subteam at OS3, where he focuses on designing and verifying analog components such as amplifiers, voltage references, and Power Management ICs (PMICs). His work involves device simulations, schematic generation and routing using both open-source and proprietary software, and conducting bench testing and verification.

His technical expertise spans across several domains including CUDA kernel optimization, autonomous systems, and chip design. Fengrui demonstrates particular interest in cutting-edge hardware developments such as NVIDIA's Jetson Orin Nano platform for edge AI applications, open-source chip design, and specialized motherboards with timing synchronization capabilities. His work at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory likely involves specialized hardware systems for scientific research and experimentation, integrating AI capabilities into high-performance computing environments for physics research.

Fengrui's professional address is at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, located at 2575 Sand Hill Rd, Menlo Park, California. His dual role as both a graduate student and staff engineer positions him uniquely at the intersection of academic research and practical engineering applications, particularly in the field of analog design for advanced computing systems.

name: wanzin yazar
short_description: AI researcher at d-Matrix and UC Berkeley alumnus specializing in LLM optimization. Published work on quantized LLMs and attention span acceleration for inference. Award-winning hackathon participant with expertise in cloud computing, deep learning, and healthcare AI applications.
long_description:
Wanzin Yazar is a Staff ML Research Engineer at d-Matrix, a company focused on in-memory compute architecture for AI applications, and is an alumnus of the University of California, Berkeley, where they earned a Bachelor's degree in Applied Mathematics with a focus on AI. Their research focuses on optimizing large language models (LLMs) for more efficient inference and deployment.

Wanzin has published several significant papers in the field of AI optimization, including "Post Training Quantization of Large Language Models with Microscaling Formats" (2024), "Self-Selected Attention Span for Accelerating Large Language Model Inference" (2024), "Understanding the difficulty of low-precision post-training quantization of large language models" (2024), and "Scaling laws for post-training quantized large language models" (2024). Their work demonstrates expertise in model quantization and inference acceleration techniques, which are critical for deploying AI models in resource-constrained environments.

Beyond LLM optimization, Wanzin has also contributed to research in healthcare AI applications, with publications like "Through the Looking Glass: Unraveling the Stage-Shift of Acute Rejection in Renal Allografts" (2022) and "The self-upgrading mobile application for the automatic malaria detection" (2020). At Nephrosant, Inc., they developed productionized machine learning models from large healthcare datasets, showing versatility in applying AI to solve real-world problems in the medical field.

Wanzin previously worked as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Division of Computing, Data Science, and Society, focusing on deep learning-based recommender systems and student enrollment predictions using clustering practices and regression models. They also gained experience at Advancers.ai before joining d-Matrix.

Wanzin has an impressive track record in hackathons, winning the Grand Prize at AngelHack Silicon Valley 2019, Best Mobile Hack at SF HACK 2019, and the Best Asian Pacific Quest in the 2019 IBM Call For Code Global Challenge. These achievements highlight their ability to rapidly prototype and implement AI solutions.

Their professional certifications include Google Cloud Certified Data Engineer (issued January 2020), the Deep Learning Specialization from deeplearning.ai (issued January 2018), and Full Stack Machine Learning on AWS from AI Camp. These certifications demonstrate Wanzin's comprehensive understanding of cloud infrastructure, deep learning fundamentals, and practical implementation of machine learning systems.

Wanzin's research has been cited by other scholars in the field, with their papers on LLM optimization and healthcare applications receiving recognition in the academic community. Their expertise spans machine learning, pattern recognition, image processing, neural networks, computer vision, data mining, computational intelligence, statistical learning, and data analysis.

suggested_people.name: Radostin Cholakov
suggested_people.short_description: Award-winning AI researcher, Stanford University undergraduate in Computer Science, and Forbes 30 Under 30 honoree specializing in natural language processing, quantization of large language models, and deep learning architectures for tabular data. Published author with significant contributions to efficient matrix multiplications for LLMs and task-oriented dialogue systems.
