As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Catherine Lee
suggested_people.short_description: Catherine Lee is a machine learning professional currently working at Lamini. She has developed expertise in LSTM networks and boosting algorithms, with award-winning projects focused on data usability and practical applications of AI, particularly in transportation safety and fraud detection. She is also an accomplished UX designer with experience optimizing user experiences for startups and enterprise clients.
suggested_people.long_description:
Catherine Lee is a machine learning professional currently working at Lamini, an AI company. She has demonstrated a strong foundation in machine learning, having completed the Machine Learning Specialization from DeepLearning.AI and Stanford University in January 2024.

Catherine has authored research publications including "Predicting the Number of Accidents in Different Weather Conditions in Barcelona Using Long Short Term Memory" (2019) and "Adtracking Fraud Detection Using Boosting Algorithms and Neural Networks" (2019), showing her expertise in applying advanced ML techniques to real-world problems.

Her project portfolio showcases diverse applications of AI and technology. Notable projects include "Bikeable," which won the Best Data Usability Hack at PennApps 2019 for using machine learning to generate safer bicycle routes based on accident data. She also worked on "PictRNNary," which earned the Best Use of Microsoft Azure Hack at Cal Hacks 5.0 in 2018, and "Place It," which won Best Under Construction Hack at LA Hacks 2020.

Catherine is also an accomplished UX designer with experience working with both startups and enterprise clients. Her design portfolio includes work for companies like Thoughtful, J.P. Morgan, Northwestern Mutual, and Masse, where she focused on optimizing user experiences and operational efficiency. Her design approach is methodical, using both data and qualitative user research to inform her designs. According to Elizabeth Cordry Shaffer, Co-Founder & CEO at Thoughtful, "She produces incredibly thoughtful work quickly, and handles feedback very well from team members. Communication and presentation of her ideas is a core strength of hers."

Catherine has participated in prestigious tech programs including the Google CodeU Program and JP Morgan Code for Good, demonstrating her commitment to applying technology for positive impact. Her recent project "Ayna" (November 2023) indicates her continued involvement in innovative tech development.

She is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Cantonese, and elementary proficiency in French, which enhances her ability to work in diverse environments. Catherine's consistent recognition through hackathon awards highlights her technical skills and ability to develop practical, impactful solutions using AI, machine learning, and user-centered design.

suggested_people.name: Anirudh Kotamraju
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

name: ryan zhijie rong
short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Bill Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Yale '26 computer science student in the BS/MS program with a background in competitive programming and mathematics. Currently researching LLMs and code generation, with experience in systems and machine learning. Incoming Software Engineering Intern at Citadel Securities with previous roles at The New York Times and Yale's Gerstein Laboratory. Also serves as Chairman of Cypher Capital, a prominent multi-strategy crypto investment firm.
suggested_people.long_description:
Bill Qian is a computer science student at Yale University (Class of 2026) pursuing a combined BS/MS degree. His technical foundation stems from competitive programming (USACO/ICPC) and mathematics (USAMO/Putnam), which has evolved into expertise in systems, machine learning, and full-stack development.

At Yale's Gerstein Laboratory, Bill has established himself as a researcher in Large Language Models and code generation, publishing multiple papers in natural language processing. His research contributions include work on "ToolLLM: Facilitating Large Language Models to Master 16000+ Real-world APIs" and "BioCoder: A Benchmark for Bioinformatics Code Generation with Contextual Pragmatic Knowledge." He has collaborated with researchers from prominent organizations including Google DeepMind.

Bill's professional experience spans diverse environments. He's secured an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Citadel Securities (New York) focusing on high-performance C++. Previously, he worked at The New York Times on their Research and Development team, exploring ethical applications of AI and LLMs in journalism. At DeepMedia, he designed and optimized algorithms for heterogeneous data analysis, creating a machine translation model with 10% better performance than competitors using Transformers, Python, PyTorch, and Rust.

His technical versatility extends to infrastructure development, having designed distributed computing systems using AWS, Azure, and on-premise hardware with Docker, Kubernetes, and SQS. At Thomas Ho Company, he applied neural networks to assess mortgage loan pricing models and implemented ETL pipelines that improved data processing efficiency by 30%.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Bill is actively involved in campus life as a Project Manager at the Student Technology Collaborative, where he manages knowledge base development and provides technical support across multiple operating systems. He balances his technical interests with creative outlets, singing with the Yale Glee Club and making short films.

In parallel to his academic career, Bill serves as the Chairman of Cypher Capital, a leading multi-strategy crypto investment firm based in the UAE. Before joining Cypher Capital in 2022, he was the Global Head of Fundraising, Binance Labs, and M&A for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency platform. Prior to that, he was Head of Investment for Fintech and Technology at JD.com, a leading Asian internet platform generating over $400 billion in annual gross merchandise volume.

Throughout his career in the blockchain and cryptocurrency sectors, Bill has deployed and managed over $30 billion in investments across AI, cryptocurrency, and fintech. He has successfully invested in prominent blockchain projects including Solana, Mysten Labs (Sui), Ton, Sei, and Bouncebit. He also serves on the board of the TON Foundation and is Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer of Phoenix Group (ADX: PHX), the first cryptocurrency company to go public in the Middle East.

Bill holds a Bachelor of Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, an MSc in Finance from Nanyang Technological University, and an MBA from the University of Toronto. He is also an executive committee member of the Hillhouse Value Investing Institution.

His unique combination of deep technical expertise in computer science, extensive experience in blockchain investment, and leadership in the cryptocurrency industry positions him as a multifaceted contributor across both academic and professional domains.

suggested_people.name: Joe Qiaoyun Li
suggested_people.short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Arihant Choudhary
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley with extensive research experience across AI, cryptography, and computational game theory. Currently working as a Software Intern at Intel and Lead Undergraduate Researcher at UC Berkeley, focusing on multi-agent systems, AI applications, and CS education.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arihant Choudhary is a multifaceted Computer Science, Data Science, and Applied Mathematics student at UC Berkeley with a remarkable research portfolio spanning diverse technical domains. His research journey includes work at Stanford University on multi-agent systems for inference, reasoning, and planning, as well as climate data analysis using CMIP-6 models.

At UC Berkeley, Arihant has made significant contributions across multiple research labs. He serves as a Lead Undergraduate Researcher in two labs under Prof. Dan Garcia - the Computational Game Theory Lab (GamesCrafters) and the CS Education Lab (ACE Lab). In the ACE Lab, he authored papers on dynamic animated feedback for randomized graph problems (accepted at SIGCSE 2024) and co-authored work on personalized reminders for mastery learning (AutoRemind, accepted at SIGCSE 2025). His work in the Computational Game Theory Lab involved developing solvers for games like Quick Cross and Euclid's Game, researching pure draw theory, and creating human-robot interaction systems.

Professionally, Arihant is currently working as a Software Intern at Intel Corporation, implementing cutting-edge research and building products for Intel Foundry. His previous role as a Research Intern at Intel focused on text-to-video research and building Intel's Personal Educator (IPED) using large language models and text-to-speech libraries to support employee training. He also serves as a Dean's Engineering Ambassador at UC Berkeley's College of Engineering, working on programs for high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.

Arihant's journey to UC Berkeley is particularly inspiring. After being rejected from all colleges in his first application cycle, he took a gap year in 2020 and pursued multiple projects, including a significant climate change research project through Polygence. Working with his mentor Tristan Ballard, a Stanford PhD in earth systems science, Arihant analyzed a petabyte of climate data to study monsoons in Kolkata and assess climate change impacts on agriculture. This experience not only built his technical skills but also helped him secure admission to UC Berkeley on his second attempt.

Arihant's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Berkeley Social, a platform he developed to help incoming UC Berkeley students connect with peers sharing similar interests. He also co-founded Yindu & Zhongguo Inc, which included the Bangla Machinery Bank, an AgriTech enterprise providing efficient farm machinery to farmers in West Bengal.

His academic pursuits extend beyond UC Berkeley, with coursework at Stanford University in CS224G: Apps with LLMs Inside. Arihant's technical expertise spans AI, machine learning, cryptography, and data science, complemented by his multilingual proficiency in English, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, and Marwari.

Through his diverse experiences in research, entrepreneurship, and community service, Arihant demonstrates a commitment to leveraging technology for social impact and educational advancement. Expected to graduate in Spring 2025, he is now interested in pursuing a graduate degree and a career in artificial intelligence/machine learning.

name: timofey obraztsov
short_description: Timofey Obraztsov is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine with a passion for entrepreneurship and AI. As CTO at Atoma Media and Co-Founder of a stealth startup in MIT's StartHouse cohort, he's an accomplished hackathon winner who has developed multiple award-winning projects including EasyPC, Mammo, and CleanASF while contributing to AI initiatives on campus.
long_description:
Timofey Obraztsov's journey into computer science began with a C++ for Dummies book his mother encouraged him to read. Growing up in Moscow with a vision to explore computer science, he has since built expertise across software engineering, full-stack development, and data analytics.

Currently pursuing a Computer Science degree at UC Irvine (expected 2027), Timofey is deeply involved in the AI and entrepreneurship ecosystem. He serves as the CTO at Atoma Media (previously Aurora Media), where he functions as the technical architect behind the company's core systems, specializing in AI/ML systems and scalable infrastructure. Simultaneously, he's co-founding a stealth startup that's part of the MIT StartHouse 2024 cohort, focusing on redefining commercial real estate due diligence standards by creating an AI Copilot for real estate agents and investors.

Timofey has established himself as a prolific hackathon participant and winner. His GitHub profile (timobraz) showcases numerous projects, including EasyPC (1st place at Calhacks 10.0), a state-of-the-art PC-building AI assistant; Mammo, an AI-driven healthcare application for women; and Geoflare, a collaborative wildfire response system. Other notable projects include Laila (web automation tool), Earthlytics (corporate sustainability platform), compatible.ai (AI-enabled personality matching), and CleanASF (an environmental initiative for San Francisco).

On campus, Timofey holds multiple leadership positions, including roles as an Executive at Artificial Intelligence at UCI and a Developer for the UCI ICS Student Council. He recently completed a Software Engineer Internship at Corent Technology and has worked as a Software Engineer Researcher at UC Irvine.

His technical versatility spans multiple languages and frameworks, with specializations in React, Express.js, MongoDB, Rust, Go, TypeScript, Python, Machine Learning, React Native, and Swift. This diverse skill set has enabled him to develop industry-standard software that increased loading speed by 30%, create efficient web crawling bots for social media metrics analysis, and work on various applications.

Before UC Irvine, Timofey attended Peninsula High School in Rolling Hills Estates, CA, where he was part of the Boys Varsity Football team, graduating in 2023. His multidisciplinary approach and entrepreneurial mindset position him as an emerging innovator at the intersection of AI, software development, and business, with a growing community of followers on GitHub and an impressive portfolio of award-winning projects.

suggested_people.name: Spike O'Carroll
suggested_people.short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
suggested_people.long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Audrey Chen
suggested_people.short_description: Serial hackathon winner (21 wins) and tech entrepreneur with a passion for AI innovation. Co-founder of VC-backed nosu.io, Software Engineering Intern at Intuit, and content creator with 68K Instagram followers. Currently pursuing Computer Engineering at Michigan State University while balancing multiple tech roles including NASA USRC research and Intel AI projects.
suggested_people.long_description:
Audrey Chen is a dynamic force in the tech world, particularly known for her exceptional track record of winning 21 hackathons with a 70% win rate, accumulating over $20,000 in prizes. Her technical prowess spans multiple domains within AI and software engineering, demonstrated through her diverse professional experiences.

As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

suggested_people.name: Aidan Gollan
suggested_people.short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

suggested_people.name: Nikita Mounier
suggested_people.short_description: Nikita Mounier is a trilingual student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Finance. With experience as a software engineering intern at Ramp and a track record of winning hackathons, including PennApps XXIII and placing 2nd at TreeHacks 2025, Nikita demonstrates exceptional technical skills and entrepreneurial drive.
suggested_people.long_description:
Nikita Mounier is a talented computer science and finance student in the Jerome Fisher Management & Technology Program at the University of Pennsylvania, maintaining an impressive 3.91/4.00 GPA. His technical expertise is demonstrated through his role as an App Developer at Penn Labs and as a Teaching Assistant for both undergraduate and graduate-level computer science courses, including Machine Learning (CIS 5200) and Programming Languages & Techniques (CIS 1200).

Nikita has a strong track record in competitive programming and hackathons, with notable achievements including 2nd place overall at TreeHacks 2025 with project "Supernova," 2nd place at PennApps XXV with "Rally AI," and 1st place at PennApps XXIII with "Cointree," a blockchain platform promoting sustainability through carbon offsets. His project work demonstrates versatility across iOS development, web applications, blockchain technologies, and AI.

Professionally, Nikita has secured a Software Engineering Internship at Ramp, a fintech unicorn, for Summer 2024. He also contributes to Penn Undergraduate Capital Partners in a sourcing role, showing his interest in the intersection of technology and finance.

Nikita is exceptionally multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in English, French, and Russian, plus working knowledge of Spanish. His educational background includes attending the Lycée Français Charles de Gaulle in London, where he completed the French Baccalauréat with highest honors (19.33/20) in Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics.

Beyond his technical accomplishments, Nikita has developed several notable personal projects, including "Tap It," an innovative iOS application that allows users to share social media details by simply placing one phone on top of another. This privacy-centric app, which has garnered 34 stars on GitHub, uses advanced technologies including SwiftUI, The Composable Architecture, Combine, Network Framework, Core Location, and Core Bluetooth. The project demonstrates his expertise in iOS development and his commitment to creating practical solutions to everyday problems.

Nikita is also an active contributor to the tech community, having given a talk about The Composable Architecture at NSLondon in November 2022. His GitHub profile showcases various other projects, including "Turkey-To-Go," "bridging-the-gap" (a website for a tutoring charity where he serves as head of Computer Science), and "swift-expression" (a micro-library for Swift). He has also shared numerous code snippets and implementations of programming patterns through GitHub Gists, including a French translation of The Composable Architecture's documentation.

His diverse skill set spans software engineering, machine learning, blockchain technology, financial analysis, and iOS development, positioning him as a versatile talent at the intersection of technology and business with a particular strength in Swift and iOS development.

suggested_people.name: Arnav Adhikari
suggested_people.short_description: 19-year-old EECS and Finance student at MIT with a passion for building innovative solutions in fintech, robotics, and healthtech. First place winner at HackMIT 2024 with a nicotine cessation patch project, and currently working on semantic operators at MIT CSAIL while also running a stealth startup.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arnav Adhikari is a dynamic 19-year-old undergraduate at MIT pursuing a dual focus in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and Finance. His technical interests span across multiple domains including fintech (payments, wealth management, AI analysts), robotics (collaboration and control), healthtech (LLM-aided care), and productivity tools. He describes himself as a "big proponent of automating the mundane" and believes that jobs should be automated to redirect human attention toward tasks requiring ingenuity.

Arnav has built an impressive track record of achievements. Most notably, he and his team won the First Place Grand Prize at HackMIT 2024 with their algorithmically-driven nicotine cessation patch. He's currently working as a Builder at MIT's prestigious Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), focusing on semantic operators.

Entrepreneurially minded, Arnav is the Founder and CEO of a stealth startup that he's been running since January 2024. His previous experience includes work at Boston Consulting Group (BCM), Rice University, Stanford's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI), and Harvard Medical School, demonstrating his ability to collaborate with top-tier institutions across academia and industry.

Arnav's research work is particularly notable in healthcare technology. He has worked on cardiac imaging interpretability and standardized cardiac measurements at BCM, Texas Children's Hospital, and Stanford AIMI, with his work being featured in Circulation by the American Heart Association in November 2023. He has also analyzed teamwork synergy for AI Surgical Robotic Coaches at Rice HCAIR and Harvard Medical School, and developed smarter irrigation and water management systems for the City of Southside Place in Houston.

His technical background is further strengthened by his experience in robot motion planning and control at Rice RobotPI, and his achievements as a retired USAJMO winner and USACO Gold Medalist. Arnav is also an author, having written the Cubronix Competitive Math Practice Book for charity, which was featured in the Houston Chronicle in January 2022.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Arnav offers tutoring services in the Greater Houston area, specializing in math, science, engineering, and test preparation. He enjoys tennis, basketball, football, biking, the outdoors, and various forms of media entertainment.

Currently a freshman at MIT (class of 2028), Arnav graduated from Carnegie Vanguard High School in 2024 after previously attending Bellaire High School. He describes himself as someone who loves "learning and building fast," and is always open to discussing innovative ideas and groundbreaking technologies.

name: shaurya agrawal
short_description: Shaurya Agrawal is a first-year student at MIT pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Physics. He is a promising young researcher with accomplishments in scientific research, having participated in prestigious programs like Research Science Institute (RSI) and the International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF).
long_description:
Shaurya Agrawal is a talented young scientist and researcher currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), class of 2028. Prior to MIT, he graduated from Stevenson High School in Lincolnshire, Illinois.

Shaurya has already built an impressive research portfolio at a young age, as evidenced by his participation in prestigious scientific programs. He was selected for the Research Science Institute (RSI) in 2023, an elite summer research program for high school students hosted at MIT. He also competed in the International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF) in both 2022 and 2024, one of the world's largest pre-college science competitions.

In 2023, Shaurya was recognized as a BioGENEius winner, suggesting his research excellence in biotechnology. He was also part of the ZFellows program in 2023, which supports young entrepreneurs and innovators.

It's important to note that Shaurya Agrawal (the MIT student) should not be confused with Dr. Shaurya Agarwal, who is an Associate Professor at the University of Central Florida specializing in civil engineering, smart cities, and transportation systems. The professor appears in the scraped website information but is a different individual with a similar name.

Based on his activity and interests on LinkedIn, Shaurya shows a keen interest in cutting-edge technologies including artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and computational physics. He has engaged with content related to advanced AI research, quantum technologies, and scientific breakthroughs, indicating his multidisciplinary approach to science and technology.

His background combining computer science and physics, along with his demonstrated excellence in research competitions, positions him as a promising young researcher at the intersection of computational methods and physical sciences. Shaurya appears to be particularly interested in the application of computational approaches to solve complex scientific problems.

suggested_people.name: Harshil Avlani
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Physics student at MIT with award-winning research in quantum computing. Former Research Intern at MIT's Quanta Group and Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab, focusing on quantum error characterization and quantum machine learning applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Harshil Avlani is a dual-major student in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), with an exceptional research background in quantum computing and physics. His academic journey showcases a consistent focus on quantum technologies and computational physics.

Currently, Harshil serves as a Research Intern with the Quanta Group at MIT's Research Laboratory of Electronics, where he applies his interdisciplinary knowledge to cutting-edge quantum research. Prior to this, he gained valuable experience as a Research Intern at Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab under Dr. Houlong Zhuang for over a year, developing expertise in quantum mechanical applications and quantum machine learning.

Harshil has achieved remarkable recognition for his research. His project "Analyzing the Effect of Mid-Circuit Measurement (MCM) on Spectator Qubits" earned him first place in the Systems Software category at the International Science Fair and qualified him as a finalist in the prestigious 2024 Regeneron Science Talent Search, where he received a $25,000 academic scholarship. This groundbreaking work identified a previously uncharacterized type of quantum error and revealed significant deficiencies in current quantum simulators.

His research portfolio includes collaborative work on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) for solving combinatorial optimization problems, documented in his GitHub repository. He has also worked with the Hauser Research Group at the University of Alabama, where he spent 9 months contributing to physics research projects, and gained experience in computer security at Arizona State University's SEFCOM Lab.

In 2022, Harshil participated in the MIT Beaver Works Summer Institute as a Quantum Software Student, further enhancing his skills in quantum computing applications. He has also co-founded the Quantum Beavers hackathon group, which tied for first place in the IBM Quantum Explorers Hackathon.

Harshil has already begun contributing to scientific literature, with a publication in Data in Brief journal on "Dataset on density functional theory investigation of ternary Heusler alloys" in February 2024. More recently, he has been exploring the intersection of quantum computing and transformer models in machine learning, with applications in mitigating misinformation through quantum-enhanced GAN architectures.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Harshil is an accomplished pianist and has a passion for aviation, being able to identify most major aircraft models by sight. His diverse research experiences across multiple institutions highlight his versatility and dedication to advancing the fields of quantum computing and physics through rigorous academic inquiry and practical applications.

suggested_people.name: Locke Cai
suggested_people.short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Dylan Nguyen
suggested_people.short_description: MIT '28 undergraduate researcher integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for mRNA lipid nanoparticle manufacturing. Amazon Future Engineer Scholar with extensive experience in computational biology, neuroscience, and machine learning applications, having won multiple prestigious awards including 3rd Place at the International Science & Engineering Fair.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dylan Nguyen is a first-year undergraduate student at MIT (Class of 2028) with a remarkable background in computational biology, neuroscience, and AI research. Currently working as an Undergraduate Research Assistant at MIT Chemical Engineering, he's integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for manufacturing mRNA lipid nanoparticles in the Myerson Research Group.

Dylan's research experience is impressive for his age. He has worked as a Scientific Programming Intern at the Max Planck Florida Institute for Neuroscience and has completed several significant research projects, including modeling the Drosophila Melanogaster nerve cord using spiking neural networks, applying deep learning to predict cytokines in Sickle Cell Anemia patients, and exploring machine learning for morphological neuron classification in the neocortex.

His academic achievements are equally notable. Dylan is an Amazon Future Engineer Scholarship recipient, which provides $40,000 towards college tuition and a guaranteed paid internship at Amazon. He's also a Kovner Opportunity Scholarship recipient, supporting talented public high school students to attend selective universities.

In competitive programming, Dylan has reached the Gold Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO). His scientific research has earned him prestigious recognitions, including 3rd Place Grand Award in Biomedical and Health Sciences at the 2023 Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair, the Regeneron Biomedical Science Award, and finalist status at the National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium.

Currently, Dylan is also an AMP Scholar at Jane Street, where he's learning mathematics, computer programming, data analysis, and game theory. Previously, he participated in MIT's Introduction to Technology, Engineering, and Science (MITES) program, taking classes in Science Writing Communications and Regenerative Stem Cell Biology.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Dylan has ventured into entrepreneurship as a co-founder of Tally.AI, a startup that empowers researchers with AI-driven aggregation and analysis of scientific papers. Working alongside fellow MIT students and graduate students from other prestigious institutions, Tally.AI aims to prevent duplicative research efforts, enhance collaboration between research groups, and help researchers stay up-to-date with the latest works in their fields through features like similarity scoring, knowledge graphs, and real-time alerts.

Dylan's diverse projects demonstrate his versatility in applying computational methods across different domains, from neuroscience to financial trading, showcasing his ability to leverage AI and machine learning for solving complex problems in both research and entrepreneurial contexts.

suggested_people.name: Arjun Melwani
suggested_people.short_description: Arjun Melwani is an Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and Physics student at MIT and researcher at the MIT Media Lab. He is an accomplished hackathon winner, having secured first place at HackMIT with his team's innovative project. Arjun combines his technical expertise with entrepreneurial experience, having previously owned Techabyte3d and worked in product development at Articulate Labs.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arjun Melwani is a multifaceted technologist currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2024-2028). As a researcher at the MIT Media Lab, he is positioned at the forefront of innovative technological research.

Arjun has already demonstrated exceptional technical capabilities and entrepreneurial spirit. Most notably, he and his team won first place at HackMIT, one of the most prestigious hackathons in the academic world. His team's project, HarmoNIC, was recognized not only as the overall grand prize winner but also won the TerraAPI track, showcasing his ability to develop cutting-edge solutions in competitive environments.

Prior to his academic journey at MIT, Arjun gained valuable industry experience through his work in product development at Articulate Labs from July 2021 to January 2024. During this 2.5-year tenure, he contributed to the development of medical technology solutions in the Dallas, Texas area.

Arjun also demonstrated his entrepreneurial acumen as the owner of Techabyte3d from May 2016 to January 2024, a venture he successfully managed for nearly 8 years. This experience highlights his ability to balance business operations with technical innovation from a young age.

His educational background includes attending Greenhill School from 2008 to 2024 before enrolling at MIT. Arjun's activities on LinkedIn reflect his keen interest in AI innovation, entrepreneurship, and technological advancement, particularly in areas where hardware and software intersect.

Arjun comes from a family with strong business and academic connections. His father, Andy Wu, serves as the Arjun and Minoo Melwani Family Associate Professor of Business Administration at Harvard Business School, suggesting the professorship may be named after Arjun and his family. This connection to Harvard Business School provides Arjun with unique exposure to business strategy and entrepreneurship from an academic perspective.

Arjun's combination of formal education, research experience, entrepreneurial background, and demonstrated excellence in competitive technical challenges positions him as a promising talent in the fields of electrical engineering, computer science, and physics, with particular strengths in applied technology development and innovation.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

name: eric mao
short_description: Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), former MasterChef Australia contestant, and UPenn M&T student with a strong background in AI research. Eric has worked on diverse projects from carbon sequestration estimation to cognitive status prediction using machine learning, and is currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's accelerator program.
long_description:
Eric Mao is a multifaceted entrepreneur and researcher at the intersection of technology, business, and culinary arts. As the Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), he's currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's prestigious accelerator program. His product has shown impressive early traction, with 18,000 users spending over 1,350 hours on the site within 48 hours of launch.

Eric was previously enrolled in the Jerome Fisher Program in Management & Technology (M&T) at the University of Pennsylvania, pursuing a dual degree in Computer Science and Business Administration at Wharton. He's currently on leave to focus on his startup.

His research experience spans multiple AI applications. He has worked on machine learning approaches for carbon credit accuracy, deep learning for 3D printing reliability enhancement, cognitive status prediction from fMRI data, and mind-controlled wheelchairs for ALS patients. His research on carbon sequestration earned him the Best Research Poster award at the International Conference on Climate Change in 2024.

Eric gained national recognition as a contestant on Season 13 of MasterChef Australia at the age of 21. As one of the youngest competitors, he showcased his passion for regional Chinese cuisine and Pan-Asian cooking. His culinary journey began early - he had previously auditioned for Junior MasterChef Australia at age 10. With roots in Wuxi, Eastern China, Eric's cooking is deeply influenced by his heritage and family traditions. During the competition, he created signature dishes including Shanghai Chive Pancake with Black Garlic Prawns, Three Treasure Wonton, and Strange Flavour Chicken.

Before MasterChef, Eric was a medical student at the University of New South Wales, where he made the difficult decision to defer his studies to pursue his culinary passion. His dream has been to create a pop-up restaurant that brings regional Chinese cuisine into a modern Australian setting.

Eric was also selected as a Fellow at Telora, where he worked on Iris, an improved file management system for video editors. His entrepreneurial journey includes participation in Z Fellows, a program for founders and builders.

During his high school years at Crescent School, Eric demonstrated exceptional talent in physics and computer science, representing Team Canada in the International Young Physicists' Tournament, earning a Gold Medal in the Canadian Young Physicists' Tournament, winning the High School Big Data Challenge, and reaching the Platinum Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO).

Eric combines technical expertise in AI and machine learning with business acumen, entrepreneurial drive, and culinary creativity, focusing on creating practical solutions to real-world problems across multiple disciplines.

suggested_people.name: Thomaz Felipe Bonato
suggested_people.short_description: Brazilian AI researcher and entrepreneur studying at USC as a Trustee Scholar. Thomaz has excelled in hackathons, winning first place at HackMIT and second place at PennApps in 2024, while conducting AI research at USC Marshall School of Business focusing on educational applications and LLMs.
suggested_people.long_description:
Thomaz Felipe Bonato is a passionate engineer, researcher, and lifelong learner from Brazil currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence for Business at the University of Southern California as a prestigious Trustee Scholar with full tuition. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his National Merit Finalist status.

Thomaz has established himself as an exceptional hackathon competitor, securing first place at HackMIT 2024 with PalmLabs (focused on education) and second place at PennApps 2024 with Cypress MFA (addressing security and privacy challenges). He also won first place with Azalea, an eco-friendly AI model selector, demonstrating his commitment to sustainable AI solutions.

His professional experience spans multiple domains within AI and business. As an AI Research Assistant at USC Marshall School of Business since December 2023, he initially explored AI applications in education and has since expanded to researching LLMs and cluster-based probing techniques. Thomaz has entrepreneurial experience as a founder of a stealth startup focused on AI solutions for law firms, and currently serves as a Data Science Intern at Trudy and a Growth Strategist at Mercor.

Within the USC community, Thomaz has taken on leadership roles as the Director of Founder's Education at SEP (Student Entrepreneurship Program) and previously served as Director of External Relations for USC Business Technology Group. He was also a Student Founder at SEP, demonstrating his commitment to entrepreneurship education.

Thomaz is multilingual, with native proficiency in Portuguese and English, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. He is also a Management Leadership Tomorrow (MLT) Fellow, indicating his commitment to leadership development. His technical skills are evidenced by certifications in Linear Algebra for Machine Learning and Neural Networks and Deep Learning from DeepLearning.AI, as well as UX design skills certified by LinkedIn.

His contribution to policy is demonstrated through his publication "A Blueprint for Greece's AI Transformation" for the Special Secretariat for Foresight, Presidency of the Government, Hellenic Republic, showing his interest in AI governance and national strategy development.

It's important to note that there is another Thomaz Bonato who has had a distinguished career in the pharmaceutical industry, serving in various executive roles at AstraZeneca and Alexion. This Thomaz Bonato has held positions including US Chief Financial Officer and Vice President of Finance at AstraZeneca, Interim Country President of AstraZeneca Australia and New Zealand, and most recently as Global Head of Research Development & Medical Finance at Alexion. His career has included significant financial leadership roles across multiple countries including Brazil, Costa Rica, Australia, and the United States. However, this is a different individual than the USC student and AI researcher profiled here.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone.
