Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Om Shastri
suggested_people.short_description: Wharton student in the Management and Technology Program, former varsity wrestler, and Dorm Room Fund associate with a background in robotics research and astronomical instrumentation. Published researcher with experience in edge computing and polarimetry, balancing interests in technology, investment, and scientific research while serving as a student manager for Penn's wrestling team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Om Shastri is a student in the prestigious Management and Technology Program at The Wharton School and The School of Engineering and Applied Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing a triple major in Computer Science, Finance, and Entrepreneurship. He currently works with Dorm Room Fund, helping identify and invest in promising student-led startups.

His research experience is particularly impressive, having published in prestigious journals like Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society on high-precision polarimetry using CMOS image sensors, and in MDPI Sensors on edge-intelligent IoT systems for mosquito threat prediction (MOSQUITO EDGE). This demonstrates his technical versatility across astronomy and edge computing applications.

Om has been involved with several research institutions, including the GRASP Lab (likely focusing on robotics and automation) and the Monterey Institute for Research and Astronomy. His leadership experience includes serving as Co-CEO of X Academy Hephaestus Robotics and as a TMT Analyst for the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, showing his ability to bridge technical expertise with business acumen.

Before Penn, Om was a standout wrestler at Los Gatos High School in California, where he served as team captain and achieved impressive accomplishments including qualifying for the California State tournament, winning the CA World Challenge Championship, and earning titles as League and District champion. He was also recognized as the Bay Area Student Athlete of the Year and maintained high academic honors throughout his four years.

Currently, Om serves as a student manager for the University of Pennsylvania wrestling team after competing as a freshman during the 2023-24 season at 184/197 pounds. Though his competitive record was 0-6, he gained valuable experience participating in tournaments including the Keystone Classic, Patriot Open, and F&M Open.

Om's professional experience includes internships at NASA, the US Army, CLA, and Ripple Ventures, providing him with diverse exposure across government, consulting, and venture capital sectors. He's an active participant in the AI hackathon circuit, having competed in prestigious events including x.ai Hackathon, TreeHacks, HackMIT, HackHarvard, Microsoft Internal AI Hackathon, and PennApps.

His achievements include receiving the Congressional Gold Medal Award from the United States Congress in September 2022, recognizing his exceptional service and achievement. He has also completed certifications in Business Analysis, Data Analysis, and Generative AI through Microsoft and LinkedIn, showing his commitment to staying current with emerging technologies.

Om is the son of Medha and Parthesh Shastri, and his personal interests likely include following developments in AI, quantum computing, cybersecurity, and startup funding, particularly in the tech sector. This holistic profile presents Om as a multifaceted individual with strong technical foundations, research credentials, and business interests, positioned at the intersection of technology, finance, and scientific innovation.

suggested_people.name: Aadit Juneja
suggested_people.short_description: Aadit Juneja is a student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Finance from Wharton and Computer Science from Penn Engineering. He has research experience in multimodal language models for tumor contouring at Penn Medicine and is preparing for a quantitative trading internship at Five Rings while actively publishing technical articles on AI and language models.
suggested_people.long_description:

His professional experience demonstrates a strong interest in the intersection of finance and technology. Academically, Aadit maintains a perfect 4.0 GPA and is actively involved in several finance and analytics-focused student organizations, including the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, Wharton Analytics Fellows, and Wharton Undergraduate Distressed Investing Group.

Aadit is also a prolific technical writer, regularly publishing articles on his personal website about cutting-edge AI topics. His recent publications include "A Distributed Inference Engine for SmolLM with Rust and gRPC," "RL for Training Multiple Decoding Heads -- An Inference Acceleration Method in Language Models," and "Frequency Based Constrained Decoding for Language Model Watermarks." He has also written about practical AI applications like "Agent for Seamless Meeting Scheduling" and financial analysis with "Tempus AI Short Recommendation."

As a developer, Aadit maintains an active GitHub profile (ajuneja23) with repositories focused on AI, machine learning, and practical applications. His projects include implementations of Monte Carlo integration, PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization) algorithms from scratch, and an Agentic Meeting Scheduler, demonstrating his technical skills in both finance and computer science domains.

His contact information includes his email (aadit@aaditjuneja.com) and phone number (224-443-2889), making him accessible for professional and academic opportunities.

Aadit's dual expertise in finance and computer science, combined with his research experience in healthcare AI applications and technical writing skills, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving domains.

name: matthew law
short_description: Multifaceted talent working as a researcher at Stanford HAI, backend lead at a stealth AI startup, and accomplished filmmaker/actor with roles in Abbott Elementary, Ahsoka, and other productions. Award-winning hackathon champion bridging technology, neuroscience, and creative storytelling.
long_description:
Matthew Law is a uniquely versatile professional who balances multiple successful careers across technology and entertainment. As a researcher at Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI), he applies his expertise in computational neuroscience to advance human-centered AI systems. His technical prowess is further demonstrated by his impressive record of winning 16 hackathons and his role as Backend Lead at a stealth AI startup in Palo Alto.

Parallel to his tech career, Matthew has established himself as an accomplished filmmaker, actor, and activist. Originally from Seattle, where he attended Ballard High School, he credits the film program there for giving him his foundation in filmmaking. He later studied at Temple University in Philadelphia, an experience that helped shape his creative vision.

As an actor, Matthew has secured notable roles in popular productions including ABC's "Abbott Elementary" (as O'Shon, the school district IT rep), Disney+'s "Star Wars: Ahsoka" (as Captain Porter), and Tyler Perry's "The Oval" (as Kareem Richardson). He's also appeared in Jennifer Lopez's "This Is Me... Now" and "Can't Get Enough" music video, as well as recurring roles in "Based on a True Story" on Peacock.

Behind the camera, Matthew has written and directed multiple short films in his "True Story" series, which explores mental health issues through a noir therapy drama format. His short film "True Story: God Tells Bad Jokes" won the award for best short narrative at the 2023 Pan African Film & Arts Festival, qualifying it for Academy Awards consideration. He has also created immersive cinematic experiences combining film, live theater, and music that have sold out multiple shows in Los Angeles.

Matthew's activity on LinkedIn reveals his engagement with various AI communities and events, including defense hackathons, agent-based AI systems, and vector databases. He frequently collaborates with other talented individuals in both the AI and entertainment spaces.

As a cousin of actress Tamala Jones, Matthew continues to build on his family's legacy in entertainment while forging his own unique path at the intersection of technology, neuroscience, and creative storytelling. His dual careers position him as an innovative voice bridging the worlds of artificial intelligence and human expression.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Ian Lim
suggested_people.short_description: Ian Lim is a Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. He co-founded Stanford BCI and has been recognized as one of MinneInno's 25 Under 25 rising entrepreneurs and technologists in Minnesota.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ian Lim is a talented Stanford University student studying computer science and neuroscience, currently working as a product intern at Tesla. His technical interests focus on brain-computer interfaces (BCI), as evidenced by his co-founding of Stanford BCI, an organization dedicated to advancing cutting-edge technology that connects neural activity with computing systems.

Ian has been involved with TreeHacks as an organizer, Stanford's premier hackathon that brings together students to collaborate on technological solutions to real-world problems. His entrepreneurial talent was recognized early when he was named to MinneInno's 25 Under 25 List in September 2018, highlighting him as one of Minnesota's most promising young entrepreneurs and technologists. He hails from Overland Park, Kansas, as indicated by his profile at the University of Kansas School of Engineering.

Despite his relatively early career stage, Ian has already built a substantial professional network with over 500 connections and 3,000 followers on LinkedIn, suggesting his influence in tech and entrepreneurial circles. His activity on LinkedIn shows engagement with content related to AI in education, talent development, and leadership, indicating his broader interests in how technology can transform learning and organizational development.

It's worth noting that there are several other professionals named Ian Lim in different fields, including a Senior Lecturer at Monash University specializing in computer science and data science, and a character portrayed by actor James Chen in the TV series "FBI" as an intelligence analyst. Our Ian Lim maintains a personal website at ianlim.com and is active on Twitter under the handle @ianclim, where he likely shares insights about his work and interests in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

name: neil movva
short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Sathvik Redrouthu
suggested_people.short_description: Sathvik Redrouthu is a tech innovator and entrepreneur who founded Procyon Photonics while in high school to develop photonic computing technology. Currently at Etched, he previously worked on chip design tooling through his startup Instachip. His research focuses on optical computing, photonic integrated circuits, and tensor algebra implementations for next-generation computing architectures.
suggested_people.long_description:
Sathvik Redrouthu is a forward-thinking technologist, entrepreneur, and researcher at the intersection of optoelectronics, hardware acceleration, and advanced computing architectures. Currently working at Etched and previously associated with Y Combinator, Sathvik has established himself as an innovator in specialized computing hardware despite his young age.

As the founder, CEO, and CTO of Procyon Photonics, Sathvik became the world's youngest CEO in the photonic and optical computing sector. Founded in 2021 while he was still in high school at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, Procyon develops revolutionary photon-based computing technology that aims to overcome the limitations of traditional electronic computing. The company's optical chips are designed to be significantly more energy-efficient than conventional processors, with prototypes reportedly 55,000 times more energy-efficient than the Intel i9 and over 100 times more efficient than Nvidia's A100 or Google's TPU. Procyon secured venture funding from Peter Thiel's 1517 Fund and has attracted interest from tech leaders like Sam Altman of OpenAI.

Before joining Etched, Sathvik founded Instachip, an EDA (Electronic Design Automation) startup focused on chip design tooling, and participated in Y Combinator. He is also conducting Formal Verification research with Dr. Mark Santolucito at Columbia University.

His research portfolio includes significant contributions to optical computing, with publications focused on optoelectronic hardware accelerators for tensor arithmetic. His work on "Tachyon," a programmable optoelectronic hardware accelerator, demonstrates his expertise in designing systems for ultrafast tensor operations. His team at Procyon was the first to run tensor algebra on an optical chip. Additionally, he has published on tensor algebra implementations for optoelectronic microchips and the use of interferometer-based photonic integrated circuits for rapid unitary transformations.

Sathvik's technical focus is on leveraging optical technologies to overcome limitations in traditional electronic computing, particularly for matrix multiplication and tensor operations critical for AI and machine learning workloads. His work on implementing unitary matrix transformations through Mach-Zehnder interferometers shows a deep understanding of how to harness photonic principles for computational advantage.

Beyond his professional work, Sathvik has developed numerous projects including AI chess engines, regex interpreters using Brzozowski derivatives, tensor algebra compilers with sparse tensor storage systems, and various AI applications. He is also skilled in hardware development, having created electric guitars and EMP generators from scratch.

Sathvik graduated high school in June 2024 but decided not to attend university, instead pursuing entrepreneurship and practical research. His vision is to someday "power the world with light" through photon-based computing, which he believes represents the next revolution in computing technology.

suggested_people.name: Yuwei Qin
suggested_people.short_description: A results-driven AI hardware specialist currently at d-Matrix with a strong background in computational electromagnetics and machine learning. Yuwei holds a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University and has extensive research experience in applying deep neural networks to data detection and electromagnetic analysis.
suggested_people.long_description:
Yuwei Qin is a technical professional specializing in AI hardware optimization, currently working at d-Matrix, a company focused on AI compute platforms for inference. With a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University's Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Yuwei has developed expertise at the intersection of hardware engineering and machine learning.

Yuwei's research contributions are particularly notable in the fields of computational electromagnetics, machine learning applications for hardware, and magnetic recording technologies. His publication record includes over 20 papers with more than 150 citations, demonstrating significant impact in his field. His most cited work includes "Machine learning based method of moments (ML-MoM)" (46 citations) and "Deep Neural Network: Data Detection Channel for Hard Disk Drives by Learning" (22 citations).

His research has focused on applying deep neural networks and machine learning to improve data detection in storage systems, particularly for hard disk drives. Notable achievements include developing a CNN-based read channel for hard disk drives that achieved a 30% error rate reduction and 200Mbits/s throughput in 28nm CMOS technology. This work represents a significant advancement in storage system performance through the application of machine learning techniques.

Yuwei has also made contributions to computational electromagnetics, developing machine learning-based approaches for electromagnetic compatibility analysis and parasitic capacitance extractions. His work on electrically tunable polarizers based on graphene-loaded plasmonic cross antennas demonstrates his expertise in applied physics and device modeling.

In the field of heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), Yuwei has conducted research on improving recording performance through micromagnetic modeling and analysis of thermal profiles, contributing to advancements in storage technology.

Throughout his career, Yuwei has collaborated with researchers from institutions including the University of Hong Kong, Western Digital, and Zhejiang University, building a strong professional network in the field of AI hardware and computational electromagnetics.

His technical expertise spans computer engineering, deep learning, storage systems, device modeling, semiconductor device physics, and applied physics, making him a versatile professional at the cutting edge of AI hardware optimization and machine learning applications for hardware systems.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Advait Iyer
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Engineer with expertise in computer systems, specializing in hardware and software engineering. Currently a Software Engineer at Tesla with research experience in GPU-accelerated data analytics, and a published paper on overcoming memory capacity limitations in large-scale data analytics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Advait Iyer is a Computer Engineer with a strong focus on computer systems and hardware design. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a Bachelor of Science in Engineering in 2024. Advait has built an impressive career trajectory, currently working as a Software Engineer at Tesla while also contributing to academic research.

His technical expertise spans C/C++, Verilog/SystemVerilog, and Python, with a particular interest in computer architecture and systems design. At Tesla, Advait has worked on several significant projects including the revamped on-screen PRND gear slider for the 2024 Model 3 released in Europe and China, navigation and controls features, and a performance monitoring library for the infotainment system. He also contributed to the development of the new weather feature for the 2024 summer release.

As a Hardware Engineer at Aethero, Advait helped build space-rated edge AI computers, demonstrating his versatility across both software and hardware domains. His academic contributions include serving as an Instructional Assistant for Advanced Computer Architecture (EECS 470) and Digital Logic Design (EECS 270) at the University of Michigan. In the Computer Architecture course, he taught lab sections on hardware design using SystemVerilog and helped students design synthesizable out-of-order RISC-V processors. For the Logic Design course, he co-created and maintained the course's RTL DV platform deployed on autograder.io using Docker, which was used by approximately 300 computer engineering students per semester.

Advait's research as a Research Assistant in the CE Lab at the University of Michigan focused on GPU acceleration for heterogeneous LLM/DB workloads, resulting in a publication titled "Vortex: Overcoming Memory Capacity Limitations in GPU-Accelerated Large-Scale Data Analytics" accepted to VLDB 2025.

His impressive project portfolio includes a 94 MHz RISC-V CPU with P6 style renaming and N-way superscalar design, a foldable cloth piano, formal verification of a fault-tolerant cache coherence protocol, and various FPGA design projects. He has also worked on robotic planning and controls projects and numerous C/C++ projects including a RISC-V assembler, simulator, and linker.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Advait has explored entrepreneurship and venture capital as a Venture Partner at Contrary for over three years. He has also worked at Marathon Digital Holdings (MARA) as an Engineering Intern optimizing merged mining protocols, and contributed to Zepto (formerly KiranaKart, YC W21) in operations, growth, and engineering roles.

Advait has also written about the intersection of data science and spirituality, exploring how machine learning concepts can provide insights into human behavior and decision-making. His writing demonstrates his ability to connect technical concepts with broader philosophical ideas.

His academic achievements include being a runner-up in the APS History of Physics Essay Contest and winning the Gold Award in the Queen's Commonwealth Essay Competition. He is multilingual, with proficiency in English, French, Hindi, and Tamil, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills.

suggested_people.name: Pavan Jayasinha
suggested_people.short_description: Pavan Jayasinha is a versatile technologist specializing in the intersection of machine learning, quantum computing, and low-level systems engineering. Currently a student at the University of Waterloo, he has contributed to cutting-edge research and development at organizations like Modular, Extropic AI, and the Institute for Quantum Computing, with particular expertise in GPU kernel optimization, quantum generative models, and robotics.
suggested_people.long_description:
Pavan Jayasinha is a multifaceted technologist pursuing a Bachelor of Applied Science at the University of Waterloo with an impressive 4.0 GPA. His technical expertise spans several specialized domains, with particular focus on machine learning, robotics, quantum computing, and low-level kernel development.

Pavan's professional experience demonstrates remarkable versatility across cutting-edge fields. At Modular, he worked as an AI GPU Engineering Intern, developing GPU kernels in Mojo language, optimizing end-to-end pipelines, and implementing multi-GPU tensor parallelism from scratch. His work at Extropic involved building high-performance JAX codebases for analog simulation of probabilistic ML models on hardware, conducting over 1000 Bayesian hyperparameter sweeps, and creating a state-of-the-art JAX library for tensor network simulation of quantum circuits on CUDA GPUs.

In the quantum computing space, Pavan has made significant contributions. At the Institute for Quantum Computing, he researched methods to realize the Bose-Hubbard Hamiltonian through Rydberg neutral atoms and built large-scale physics simulations. As an IBM Qiskit Advocate, he authored a chapter on Quantum Generative Adversarial Networks for the Qiskit Textbook QML course and mentored at the Qiskit Global Summer School. His quantum expertise extended to Zapata Computing, where he investigated quantum generative models and developed Orquestra codebase for QGANs.

Pavan has also contributed significantly to open-source projects, becoming the largest non-Google contributor to TensorFlow Quantum by implementing Bazel build infrastructure and cuQuantum SDK GPU kernels for quantum circuit simulation on heterogeneous devices. His project work includes developing a hybrid quantum graph neural network for particle trajectory reconstruction, which placed in the top 5 at QHack 2022, and building a quantum portfolio optimization project that placed in the 95th percentile at QHack 2021.

Pavan's academic achievements include being a Masason Scholar, selected as part of the 6th generation cohort by SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's foundation that supports youth with exceptional talents. He has received the President's Research Award and maintained Dean's Honours List status. He has earned multiple certifications in quantum computing, including becoming an IBM Certified Associate Developer for Quantum Computation using Qiskit.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Pavan has diverse experiences including serving as a lifeguard for the City of Toronto and working as a dog walker, demonstrating his well-rounded character and work ethic. His unique combination of expertise in quantum computing, machine learning, and low-level systems engineering positions him as a promising innovator at the intersection of these transformative technologies.

name: dhruv gautam
short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

suggested_people.name: Alicia Li
suggested_people.short_description: MIT CS/AI & Math double major with a strong research background in robot learning and reinforcement learning. First author on a NeurIPS 2024 workshop paper and incoming ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics. Founded Watch To Donate, raising over $6,000 for various causes while reaching millions of people.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alicia Li is a talented undergraduate at MIT pursuing a double major in Computer Science/AI (specifically course 6-4: AI and Decision Making) and Mathematics (2023-2027). Her research interests span robot learning, planning, and reinforcement learning, with particular focus on safe RL applications.

As an undergraduate researcher at MIT CSAIL's Learning & Intelligent Systems Group, she works on robot learning and planning, and is the first author on a paper accepted to the NeurIPS 2024 Open-World Agents Workshop titled "Learning to Bridge the Gap: Efficient Novelty Recovery with Planning and Reinforcement Learning." She's also researching safe reinforcement learning for power grid optimization at MIT's Donti Lab, where she was listed as a past member in 2024.

Alicia has an impressive publication record for her career stage, with multiple published papers including work on adversarial attacks against online reinforcement learning agents (as part of MIT PRIMES research project 2022-2023), magic SET squares classification, the Post Correspondence Problem, and coin weighing problems. Her academic excellence is further demonstrated by her coursework in graduate-level subjects including Advanced Algorithms, Inference and Information, and Sensorimotor Learning.

Beyond her academic pursuits, Alicia founded and served as CEO of Watch To Donate from 2020 to 2023, an international student organization that donates revenue from social media videos, mobile apps, and business collaborations. Under her leadership, the organization raised over $6,000 for 27 causes, reached over 6 million people, and developed apps with 9,000+ downloads. She also created a Family Fund to help their online community of 50,000 in need. Additionally, she developed "Play To Donate," an app that leverages ad revenue to enable users to donate to charity by playing games.

Alicia is active in MIT's campus life, participating in MIT Asian Dance Team and Ridonkulous (MIT's competitive hip hop dance team), and was previously on Fixation (MIT's competitive contemporary dance team). She also enjoys figure skating and watching movies with friends in her free time.

She is currently preparing for her upcoming role as an ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics, where she'll likely apply her expertise in AI and mathematics to challenges in the therapeutic development space.

suggested_people.name: Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at UMD with diverse expertise in computer vision, high-performance computing, and quantitative finance. Currently researching LLMs under Dr. Tom Goldstein while interning at Scale AI for code reasoning models. Published work on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models at ICLR 2023.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan is a Computer Science and Mathematics double major at the University of Maryland with a multifaceted background in AI research and software engineering. His technical interests span computer vision, concurrent and high-performance computing, networks, quantitative finance, and large model efficiency.

Currently, Vijaykaarti serves as a Technical Advisor Intern at Scale AI, where he works on code reasoning models for Olympiad-level competitive programming problems. Simultaneously, he conducts research on Large Language Models under Dr. Tom Goldstein at UMD. His research contributions include a notable paper on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models, recognized as a Notable TinyPaper at ICLR 2023, which has been cited 13 times since publication.

Vijaykaarti's professional experience is extensive for a student. He completed a software engineering internship at Uber, focusing on networking infrastructure with Envoy proxy. He also worked as a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory and at NonExomics, where he developed deep learning models for cancer prediction over a two-year period.

Within the UMD community, Vijaykaarti serves as Senior Quantitative Analyst and Lead Architect for the Smith Investment Fund's automated trading platform. He previously conducted computer vision research under Dr. Jia-Bin Huang. He has also contributed to social impact initiatives as a Software Engineer at Hack4Impact, developing web applications for nonprofit organizations.

His technical prowess is further evidenced by his competitive programming achievements, including participation in the ICPC NA South Division 2024 as part of the UMD GOATS team alongside Mazin Karjikar and Spencer Lutz. He has also competed at the ICPC Mid-Atlantic Regionals, where he previously placed 7th.

Beyond technical skills, Vijaykaarti is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Tamil, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. His academic excellence is reflected in his numerous accolades, including being a Presidential Scholar Candidate, National Merit Finalist, and recipient of the UKG Global Scholarship. His community engagement is demonstrated through his Eagle Scout achievement and multiple Silver President's Volunteer Service Awards for significant community service hours.

name: aadit juneja
short_description: Aadit Juneja is a student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Finance from Wharton and Computer Science from Penn Engineering. He has research experience in multimodal language models for tumor contouring at Penn Medicine and is preparing for a quantitative trading internship at Five Rings while actively publishing technical articles on AI and language models.
long_description:
Aadit Juneja is an ambitious undergraduate student in the highly selective Jerome Fisher Management & Technology (M&T) Program at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing dual degrees in Finance from The Wharton School and Computer Science from Penn Engineering.

His professional experience demonstrates a strong interest in the intersection of finance and technology. Aadit is preparing for a Quantitative Trading Internship at Five Rings in New York (January-February 2025) and recently completed a Fall Private Equity Analyst role at Leo Legacy in Philadelphia (August-October 2024). 

What sets Aadit apart is his research experience in artificial intelligence applications in healthcare. During Summer 2024, he worked as a Research Assistant at Penn Medicine, University of Pennsylvania Health System, focusing on multimodal language models for tumor contouring. This experience highlights his ability to apply advanced AI techniques to solve complex medical problems.

Academically, Aadit maintains a perfect 4.0 GPA and is actively involved in several finance and analytics-focused student organizations, including the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, Wharton Analytics Fellows, and Wharton Undergraduate Distressed Investing Group.

Aadit is also a prolific technical writer, regularly publishing articles on his personal website about cutting-edge AI topics. His recent publications include "A Distributed Inference Engine for SmolLM with Rust and gRPC," "RL for Training Multiple Decoding Heads -- An Inference Acceleration Method in Language Models," and "Frequency Based Constrained Decoding for Language Model Watermarks." He has also written about practical AI applications like "Agent for Seamless Meeting Scheduling" and financial analysis with "Tempus AI Short Recommendation."

As a developer, Aadit maintains an active GitHub profile (ajuneja23) with repositories focused on AI, machine learning, and practical applications. His projects include implementations of Monte Carlo integration, PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization) algorithms from scratch, and an Agentic Meeting Scheduler, demonstrating his technical skills in both finance and computer science domains.

His contact information includes his email (aadit@aaditjuneja.com) and phone number (224-443-2889), making him accessible for professional and academic opportunities.

Aadit's dual expertise in finance and computer science, combined with his research experience in healthcare AI applications and technical writing skills, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving domains.

suggested_people.name: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta
suggested_people.short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

suggested_people.name: Zarif Azher
suggested_people.short_description: Bioengineering and Computer Science undergraduate at Caltech with extensive research experience in computational pathology and medical technology innovation. Published 10+ peer-reviewed papers in leading journals, focusing on applying AI and spatial transcriptomics to biomedical problems with the goal of expanding global healthcare access.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zarif Azher is an undergraduate student at Caltech pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Bioengineering and Computer Science (2024-2028). He is a passionate innovator and researcher at the intersection of AI and healthcare, with a particular focus on computational pathology, spatial transcriptomics, and medical technology development.

Zarif has an impressive research portfolio with over 10 peer-reviewed publications in prestigious journals and conferences, including the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing, BioData Mining, and the Journal of Pathology Informatics. His research spans innovative applications of AI in healthcare, such as inferring spatial transcriptomics from histological patterns, developing multimodal deep learning models for cancer prognostication, and creating interpretable AI systems for biomedical analysis.

His work has been cited over 60 times by researchers in the field, demonstrating the impact of his contributions to computational biology and medical AI. His recent projects include mapping three-dimensional tumor heterogeneity through deep learning inference of spatial transcriptomics from routine histopathology, and developing LLM-driven agent approaches to modeling legislative behavior.

Beyond his technical research, Zarif is committed to making healthcare more accessible globally. On his personal website, he states: "I want to use powerful technology to improve healthcare access and quality worldwide." He describes himself as a leader who organizes "people and things to accomplish ambitious goals" and a researcher developing "novel solutions to real-world issues – science for action, not observation."

Zarif's professional experience includes working in the Gao Research Group at Caltech and collaborating with researchers from institutions like Case Western Reserve University, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Dartmouth College. He has also been involved in projects to fight government corruption in Bangladesh, advocate for environmental justice in the USA, and deploy novel assistive technology for medical practitioners in underserved regions.

His interdisciplinary approach combines expertise in machine learning, bioinformatics, multimodal deep learning, cancer research, and pathology, positioning him as an emerging leader in the application of AI to solve complex healthcare challenges.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tran
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tran is a junior at Yale University with a strong focus on computer science, particularly in molecular AI research. He has contributed to MolLM, a unified language model integrating biomedical text with 2D and 3D molecular representations, and has experience at Hudson River Trading. His coursework spans deep learning, natural language processing, and graph-structured data.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tran is an undergraduate junior at Yale University pursuing computer science with specialized interests in computational biology and AI. His research work is evidenced by his contribution to MolLM, a sophisticated unified language model that integrates biomedical text with both 2D and 3D molecular representations. This project, presented at ISMB 2024, demonstrates his capability in developing advanced AI systems for molecular modeling.

Andrew has professional experience at Hudson River Trading, a quantitative trading firm known for its algorithmic trading strategies and high-performance computing infrastructure. This suggests his skills extend to financial technology applications of computer science.

His academic foundation is robust, with coursework covering both theoretical computer science (Compilers and Interpreters, Computer Architecture, Operating Systems, Discrete Mathematics) and cutting-edge AI topics (Deep Learning on Graph-Structured Data, Natural Language Processing, Probabilistic Machine Learning). This diverse technical background positions him well at the intersection of traditional computer science and modern AI applications.

Andrew's interest in molecular AI research, as shown by his publication work, indicates his potential to contribute to the growing field of AI applications in healthcare and drug discovery. His engagement with content related to diffusion models, geometry problem-solving AI, and other technical developments (as seen in his LinkedIn activity) suggests he stays current with the latest advancements in artificial intelligence.

It's important to note that there are several other professionals named Andrew Tran in different fields, including an investigative data reporter at The Washington Post (who won a Pulitzer Prize), an orthopedic surgeon specializing in sports medicine, a UCLA law lecturer, and a visual effects artist who has worked on major films like The Hunger Games and Avengers: Infinity War. Our Andrew Tran is specifically the Yale computer science student focused on molecular AI research.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong

Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:

His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers).
