suggested_people.name: Om Shastri
suggested_people.short_description: Wharton student in the Management and Technology Program, former varsity wrestler, and Dorm Room Fund associate with a background in robotics research and astronomical instrumentation. Published researcher with experience in edge computing and polarimetry, balancing interests in technology, investment, and scientific research while serving as a student manager for Penn's wrestling team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Om Shastri is a student in the prestigious Management and Technology Program at The Wharton School and The School of Engineering and Applied Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing a triple major in Computer Science, Finance, and Entrepreneurship. He currently works with Dorm Room Fund, helping identify and invest in promising student-led startups.

His research experience is particularly impressive, having published in prestigious journals like Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society on high-precision polarimetry using CMOS image sensors, and in MDPI Sensors on edge-intelligent IoT systems for mosquito threat prediction (MOSQUITO EDGE). This demonstrates his technical versatility across astronomy and edge computing applications.

Om has been involved with several research institutions, including the GRASP Lab (likely focusing on robotics and automation) and the Monterey Institute for Research and Astronomy. His leadership experience includes serving as Co-CEO of X Academy Hephaestus Robotics and as a TMT Analyst for the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, showing his ability to bridge technical expertise with business acumen.

Before Penn, Om was a standout wrestler at Los Gatos High School in California, where he served as team captain and achieved impressive accomplishments including qualifying for the California State tournament, winning the CA World Challenge Championship, and earning titles as League and District champion. He was also recognized as the Bay Area Student Athlete of the Year and maintained high academic honors throughout his four years.

Currently, Om serves as a student manager for the University of Pennsylvania wrestling team after competing as a freshman during the 2023-24 season at 184/197 pounds. Though his competitive record was 0-6, he gained valuable experience participating in tournaments including the Keystone Classic, Patriot Open, and F&M Open.

Om's professional experience includes internships at NASA, the US Army, CLA, and Ripple Ventures, providing him with diverse exposure across government, consulting, and venture capital sectors. He's an active participant in the AI hackathon circuit, having competed in prestigious events including x.ai Hackathon, TreeHacks, HackMIT, HackHarvard, Microsoft Internal AI Hackathon, and PennApps.

His achievements include receiving the Congressional Gold Medal Award from the United States Congress in September 2022, recognizing his exceptional service and achievement. He has also completed certifications in Business Analysis, Data Analysis, and Generative AI through Microsoft and LinkedIn, showing his commitment to staying current with emerging technologies.

Om is the son of Medha and Parthesh Shastri, and his personal interests likely include following developments in AI, quantum computing, cybersecurity, and startup funding, particularly in the tech sector. This holistic profile presents Om as a multifaceted individual with strong technical foundations, research credentials, and business interests, positioned at the intersection of technology, finance, and scientific innovation.

name: aaquib syed
short_description: AI researcher at Google with a focus on interpretability and language model behavior. Aaquib has published significant work on refusal mechanisms in LLMs, attribution patching for circuit discovery, and efficient pruning techniques for massive language models. A Banneker-Key Scholar at the University of Maryland with a strong competitive programming background.
long_description:
Aaquib Syed is an AI researcher currently working at Google while affiliated with the University of Maryland, where he is pursuing a CS and Math degree as a Banneker-Key Scholar (full merit scholarship for the top 0.5% of incoming class). His research focuses on understanding and improving large language models, with particular emphasis on interpretability and model behavior mechanisms.

His recent publication "Refusal in Language Models Is Mediated by a Single Direction" (NeurIPS 2024, Poster) has garnered significant attention with 98+ citations. This groundbreaking work demonstrates that refusal behavior in conversational LLMs is controlled by a one-dimensional subspace across multiple open-source chat models, providing important insights into how safety mechanisms function in these systems.

Aaquib has also made significant contributions to automated interpretability research with his work "Attribution Patching Outperforms Automated Circuit Discovery" (BlackboxNLP at EMNLP 2024), which has received 47+ citations. In this paper, he developed a simple yet powerful method based on attribution patching that outperforms existing approaches while requiring minimal computational resources - just two forward passes and a backward pass.

In the area of model efficiency, his research "Prune and Tune: Improving Efficient Pruning Techniques for Massive Language Models" (ICLR TinyPapers Workshop 2023, top 6%) advanced techniques for pruning large language models without extensive retraining, addressing critical compute expense issues in deploying massive models.

His most recent work includes "Mechanistic Unlearning: Robust Knowledge Unlearning and Editing via Mechanistic Localization" (2024), exploring techniques for targeted knowledge editing in language models.

Beyond pure AI research, Aaquib has applied machine learning to medical imaging, co-authoring a paper in PLOS ONE that uses XGBoost with MRI and non-imaging data to predict pathological complete response in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

As a student, Aaquib has received numerous prestigious recognitions, including the USA Computing Olympiad Gold rank and the National Merit Scholarship. He has also developed several projects including a Personal Distance Monitor, a Stress Level Manager for students with autism spectrum disorder, and a FIRST Robotics Competition Scouting system.

According to his GitHub profile, Aaquib describes himself as someone who enjoys "thinking about and solving problems in AI/ML and finance" with a current interest in "creating scalable methods to attribute and edit behaviors and knowledge in large language models." He also mentions a love for competitive programming, working with low-level languages, and creating infrastructure and trading strategies for financial markets.

His interests span AI/ML and finance, with a particular focus on solving complex problems at the intersection of these fields. Aaquib's combination of theoretical research and practical applications demonstrates his versatility and depth of expertise in artificial intelligence.

suggested_people.name: Evan Wang
suggested_people.short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

suggested_people.name: Radostin Cholakov
suggested_people.short_description: Award-winning AI researcher, Stanford University undergraduate in Computer Science, and Forbes 30 Under 30 honoree specializing in natural language processing, quantization of large language models, and deep learning architectures for tabular data. Published author with significant contributions to efficient matrix multiplications for LLMs and task-oriented dialogue systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Radostin Cholakov is a distinguished young AI researcher currently pursuing undergraduate studies in Computer Science at Stanford University. His research focuses on innovative approaches to deep learning architectures, particularly for tabular data, dialogue systems, and large language model optimization.

As the author of "Distributional Quantization of Large Language Models," Radostin has developed novel methods for efficiently storing LLMs in 4-bit precision while maintaining performance comparable to full-precision models. His recent work on "Fast Matrix Multiplications for Lookup Table-Quantized LLMs" (2024) with collaborators from MIT and CMU introduces FLUTE, a flexible lookup table engine that can be 2-4x faster than existing GEMM kernels for LLM inference.

Radostin's contributions to task-oriented dialogue systems include developing models with auxiliary tasks for response selection, addressing limitations in text generation abilities of pre-trained language models. His paper "Efficient Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems with Response Selection as an Auxiliary Task" (2022) achieved state-of-the-art results on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset while using significantly fewer parameters than baseline models.

His work on the GatedTabTransformer has enhanced deep learning architectures for tabular modeling, showing significant improvements over existing solutions. Additionally, his research on "Transformers predicting the future" (2021) applies attention mechanisms to next-frame and time series forecasting, garnering significant citations in the field.

Radostin is also the creator of "AzBuki.ML," a machine learning platform for natural language processing specifically designed for Slavic languages.

His exceptional work has earned him numerous prestigious awards, including an Honorable Mention from AAAI and First Award by Mawhiba at Regeneron ISEF'23, Second Award at the European Contest For Young Scientists 2022, and Second award from ACM at Regeneron ISEF'22. In 2021, he was recognized in Forbes' "30 under 30" list and received the Presidential Award "John Atanasoff" for exceptional results in National IT Competitions.

Beyond his research, Radostin is actively involved in volunteer work with organizations like Google Developer Experts, Smile for Africa Foundation (where he serves as a Full-Stack Software Engineer), and Google Developers Group Sofia. His academic collaborations include work with prominent researchers from MIT, including Yoon Kim, Han Guo, and Jonathan Ragan-Kelley, as well as Eric Xing from CMU.

As the founder of RSG, Radostin continues to push boundaries in AI research while contributing to open-source projects and humanitarian causes.

suggested_people.name: Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at UMD with diverse expertise in computer vision, high-performance computing, and quantitative finance. Currently researching LLMs under Dr. Tom Goldstein while interning at Scale AI for code reasoning models. Published work on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models at ICLR 2023.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan is a Computer Science and Mathematics double major at the University of Maryland with a multifaceted background in AI research and software engineering. His technical interests span computer vision, concurrent and high-performance computing, networks, quantitative finance, and large model efficiency.

Currently, Vijaykaarti serves as a Technical Advisor Intern at Scale AI, where he works on code reasoning models for Olympiad-level competitive programming problems. Simultaneously, he conducts research on Large Language Models under Dr. Tom Goldstein at UMD. His research contributions include a notable paper on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models, recognized as a Notable TinyPaper at ICLR 2023, which has been cited 13 times since publication.

Vijaykaarti's professional experience is extensive for a student. He completed a software engineering internship at Uber, focusing on networking infrastructure with Envoy proxy. He also worked as a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory and at NonExomics, where he developed deep learning models for cancer prediction over a two-year period.

Within the UMD community, Vijaykaarti serves as Senior Quantitative Analyst and Lead Architect for the Smith Investment Fund's automated trading platform. He previously conducted computer vision research under Dr. Jia-Bin Huang. He has also contributed to social impact initiatives as a Software Engineer at Hack4Impact, developing web applications for nonprofit organizations.

His technical prowess is further evidenced by his competitive programming achievements, including participation in the ICPC NA South Division 2024 as part of the UMD GOATS team alongside Mazin Karjikar and Spencer Lutz. He has also competed at the ICPC Mid-Atlantic Regionals, where he previously placed 7th.

Beyond technical skills, Vijaykaarti is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Tamil, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. His academic excellence is reflected in his numerous accolades, including being a Presidential Scholar Candidate, National Merit Finalist, and recipient of the UKG Global Scholarship. His community engagement is demonstrated through his Eagle Scout achievement and multiple Silver President's Volunteer Service Awards for significant community service hours.

suggested_people.name: Wanzin Yazar
suggested_people.short_description: AI researcher at d-Matrix and UC Berkeley alumnus specializing in LLM optimization. Published work on quantized LLMs and attention span acceleration for inference. Award-winning hackathon participant with expertise in cloud computing, deep learning, and healthcare AI applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Wanzin Yazar is a Staff ML Research Engineer at d-Matrix, a company focused on in-memory compute architecture for AI applications, and is an alumnus of the University of California, Berkeley, where they earned a Bachelor's degree in Applied Mathematics with a focus on AI. Their research focuses on optimizing large language models (LLMs) for more efficient inference and deployment.

Wanzin has published several significant papers in the field of AI optimization, including "Post Training Quantization of Large Language Models with Microscaling Formats" (2024), "Self-Selected Attention Span for Accelerating Large Language Model Inference" (2024), "Understanding the difficulty of low-precision post-training quantization of large language models" (2024), and "Scaling laws for post-training quantized large language models" (2024). Their work demonstrates expertise in model quantization and inference acceleration techniques, which are critical for deploying AI models in resource-constrained environments.

Beyond LLM optimization, Wanzin has also contributed to research in healthcare AI applications, with publications like "Through the Looking Glass: Unraveling the Stage-Shift of Acute Rejection in Renal Allografts" (2022) and "The self-upgrading mobile application for the automatic malaria detection" (2020). At Nephrosant, Inc., they developed productionized machine learning models from large healthcare datasets, showing versatility in applying AI to solve real-world problems in the medical field.

Wanzin previously worked as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Division of Computing, Data Science, and Society, focusing on deep learning-based recommender systems and student enrollment predictions using clustering practices and regression models. They also gained experience at Advancers.ai before joining d-Matrix.

Wanzin has an impressive track record in hackathons, winning the Grand Prize at AngelHack Silicon Valley 2019, Best Mobile Hack at SF HACK 2019, and the Best Asian Pacific Quest in the 2019 IBM Call For Code Global Challenge. These achievements highlight their ability to rapidly prototype and implement AI solutions.

Their professional certifications include Google Cloud Certified Data Engineer (issued January 2020), the Deep Learning Specialization from deeplearning.ai (issued January 2018), and Full Stack Machine Learning on AWS from AI Camp. These certifications demonstrate Wanzin's comprehensive understanding of cloud infrastructure, deep learning fundamentals, and practical implementation of machine learning systems.

Wanzin's research has been cited by other scholars in the field, with their papers on LLM optimization and healthcare applications receiving recognition in the academic community. Their expertise spans machine learning, pattern recognition, image processing, neural networks, computer vision, data mining, computational intelligence, statistical learning, and data analysis.

suggested_people.name: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya
suggested_people.short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese. Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

name: ally nakamura
short_description: Recent Stanford graduate currently building at PearX and involved with Catapult AI. Ally has a background in deep learning, AI, and scientific research, with notable achievements including a gold medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, selection as a Masason Foundation Scholar, and research on Chinese censorship.
long_description:
Ally Nakamura is a recent Stanford University graduate with BS/MS degrees in Computer Science with a focus on AI. She is currently building at PearX while also being involved with Catapult AI, where she's working on helping medical device companies deploy AI to make their workflows easier.

Her academic journey has been complemented by her deep interest in artificial intelligence and healthcare technology. She holds a Neural Networks and Deep Learning certification from deeplearning.ai and has worked with Stanford's Open Virtual Assistant Lab to build EHR-Xamine, a virtual assistant for electronic clinical health records designed to reduce physician burnout.

Ally has demonstrated exceptional scientific aptitude, having published research on Fluorescence-Guided Surgery in Frontiers in Oncology, where she reviewed applications of fluorescent probes in defining tumor locations during surgical procedures. Her scientific excellence was recognized internationally when she represented the United States at the International Earth Science Olympiad, earning a gold medal and ranking among the top 15 students out of nearly 400 participants from over 30 countries.

Her technical accomplishments include leading an AI-enabled email client at DoNotPay that was featured by Forbes and Wired, and building a voice agent to automatically handle reference checks for healthcare staffing agencies. She also enjoys participating in hackathons, where she has built AI dating apps and launched an AI crypto coin that scaled to $15M market cap.

Beyond her technical work, Ally has conducted significant research on Chinese censorship. Working with Jeffrey Shen, she created CensorScout and the Weibo Censorship Dashboard, two applications that increase transparency into censorship on Weibo. Their published paper on SSRN made daily top-tens in several sections and was in the top 10% of authors by downloads in the year following publication. This project was completed as part of Digital Propaganda & Censorship, an Independent Project at Phillips Academy.

Her entrepreneurial spirit is evident through her involvement with various organizations at Stanford, including co-founding the Stanford Chapter of Scholar of Finance and being a member of the Asia-Pacific Student Entrepreneurship Society. She also served as an intern at Stanford Women in Business, showcasing her interest in the intersection of business and technology.

Ally was selected as one of just 42 students to join the prestigious Masason Foundation after a rigorous three-round admissions process, further highlighting her exceptional potential. During her high school years, she contributed to STEM education as an Event Coordinator for Techstravaganza with Tomorrow's Women in Science and Technology.

She is bilingual in English and Japanese with limited working proficiency in German, giving her a global perspective that complements her technical skills and entrepreneurial mindset. In her free time, she enjoys hiking, attending DJ sets, eating sushi, and playing poker with friends.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Zifei Xu
suggested_people.short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

suggested_people.name: Trishala Neeraj
suggested_people.short_description: Trishala Neeraj is a Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube with a strong academic background from Cornell University. She specializes in computer vision and natural language processing, bringing technical expertise to cybersecurity analytics and has contributed to several influential AI research papers.
suggested_people.long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. She works with terabyte-scale data to develop models using Deep Learning and Matrix Factorization techniques, with a particular focus on language data and models.

Her academic foundation was built at Cornell University, where she graduated in 2018 after focusing on Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing during her graduate studies. She also holds a Bachelor of Engineering degree from BITS Pilani, India, and spent time as a visiting research scholar at the Predictive Technology Lab at the University of Virginia.

Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022). Her work on "BigBIO: A Framework for Data-Centric Biomedical Natural Language Processing" (2022) has also gained recognition in the field.

Her professional experience includes a summer internship at BuzzFeed in 2017, where she worked on a project using K-Means Clustering to tag over 14,000 BuzzFeed quizzes, which she documented in a blog post on the BuzzFeed Tech Blog. She has also published research on "A Computational Approach to Perceived Trustworthiness of Airbnb Host Profiles" (2017) and "Longitudinal Analysis of Cyber-Related Articles" (2020).

Beyond her technical work, Trishala has been actively involved in the tech community. She represented the student body at the Cornell Tech Campus Dedication ceremony in August 2017 and moderated a conversation with Eric Schmidt in March 2018. She maintains a personal blog where she documents her research projects on topics like Weak Supervision, Feature-based Approaches with BERT, and Semantic Entailment.

Trishala is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Hindi, which enhances her ability to work in diverse teams and global environments. Her involvement with organizations like Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) demonstrates her commitment to the broader AI community and diversity in tech.

suggested_people.name: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta
suggested_people.short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

name: prady saligram
short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

suggested_people.name: Bill Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Yale '26 computer science student in the BS/MS program with a background in competitive programming and mathematics. Currently researching LLMs and code generation, with experience in systems and machine learning. Incoming Software Engineering Intern at Citadel Securities with previous roles at The New York Times and Yale's Gerstein Laboratory. Also serves as Chairman of Cypher Capital, a prominent multi-strategy crypto investment firm.
suggested_people.long_description:
Bill Qian is a computer science student at Yale University (Class of 2026) pursuing a combined BS/MS degree. His technical foundation stems from competitive programming (USACO/ICPC) and mathematics (USAMO/Putnam), which has evolved into expertise in systems, machine learning, and full-stack development.

At Yale's Gerstein Laboratory, Bill has established himself as a researcher in Large Language Models and code generation, publishing multiple papers in natural language processing. His research contributions include work on "ToolLLM: Facilitating Large Language Models to Master 16000+ Real-world APIs" and "BioCoder: A Benchmark for Bioinformatics Code Generation with Contextual Pragmatic Knowledge." He has collaborated with researchers from prominent organizations including Google DeepMind.

Bill's professional experience spans diverse environments. He's secured an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Citadel Securities (New York) focusing on high-performance C++. Previously, he worked at The New York Times on their Research and Development team, exploring ethical applications of AI and LLMs in journalism. At DeepMedia, he designed and optimized algorithms for heterogeneous data analysis, creating a machine translation model with 10% better performance than competitors using Transformers, Python, PyTorch, and Rust.

His technical versatility extends to infrastructure development, having designed distributed computing systems using AWS, Azure, and on-premise hardware with Docker, Kubernetes, and SQS. At Thomas Ho Company, he applied neural networks to assess mortgage loan pricing models and implemented ETL pipelines that improved data processing efficiency by 30%.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Bill is actively involved in campus life as a Project Manager at the Student Technology Collaborative, where he manages knowledge base development and provides technical support across multiple operating systems. He balances his technical interests with creative outlets, singing with the Yale Glee Club and making short films.

In parallel to his academic career, Bill serves as the Chairman of Cypher Capital, a leading multi-strategy crypto investment firm based in the UAE. Before joining Cypher Capital in 2022, he was the Global Head of Fundraising, Binance Labs, and M&A for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency platform. Prior to that, he was Head of Investment for Fintech and Technology at JD.com, a leading Asian internet platform generating over $400 billion in annual gross merchandise volume.

Throughout his career in the blockchain and cryptocurrency sectors, Bill has deployed and managed over $30 billion in investments across AI, cryptocurrency, and fintech. He has successfully invested in prominent blockchain projects including Solana, Mysten Labs (Sui), Ton, Sei, and Bouncebit. He also serves on the board of the TON Foundation and is Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer of Phoenix Group (ADX: PHX), the first cryptocurrency company to go public in the Middle East.

Bill holds a Bachelor of Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, an MSc in Finance from Nanyang Technological University, and an MBA from the University of Toronto. He is also an executive committee member of the Hillhouse Value Investing Institution.

His unique combination of deep technical expertise in computer science, extensive experience in blockchain investment, and leadership in the cryptocurrency industry positions him as a multifaceted contributor across both academic and professional domains.

suggested_people.name: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya
suggested_people.short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
suggested_people.long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese. Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

suggested_people.name: Vivek Vajipey
suggested_people.short_description: Vivek Vajipey is a Computer Science student at Stanford University pursuing both Bachelor's and Master's degrees with a minor in Geophysics. His research at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) focuses on reasoning in large language models, while his previous work applied machine learning to agricultural remote sensing. He has developed innovative AI applications including ExplainAI, CriticAL, and WorldDex, winning awards at major hackathons like PennApps XXIV and Cal Hacks 10.0.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vivek Vajipey is pursuing both a Bachelor's and Master's degree in Computer Science at Stanford University, with a minor in Geophysics. His academic journey reflects a deep interest in the intersection of artificial intelligence and practical applications.

At the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL), Vivek researches reasoning capabilities in large language models through the Computation & Cognition Lab. His work in AI extends beyond theoretical research - he has recently co-authored "CriticAL: Critic Automation with Language Models," demonstrating his contribution to advancing LLM technologies.

Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Jay Khemchandani
suggested_people.short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

name: joe qiaoyun li
short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

suggested_people.name: Locke Cai
suggested_people.short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.
