Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

suggested_people.name: Alicia Li
suggested_people.short_description: MIT CS/AI & Math double major with a strong research background in robot learning and reinforcement learning. First author on a NeurIPS 2024 workshop paper and incoming ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics. Founded Watch To Donate, raising over $6,000 for various causes while reaching millions of people.
suggested_people.long_description:
Alicia Li is a talented undergraduate at MIT pursuing a double major in Computer Science/AI (specifically course 6-4: AI and Decision Making) and Mathematics (2023-2027). Her research interests span robot learning, planning, and reinforcement learning, with particular focus on safe RL applications.

As an undergraduate researcher at MIT CSAIL's Learning & Intelligent Systems Group, she works on robot learning and planning, and is the first author on a paper accepted to the NeurIPS 2024 Open-World Agents Workshop titled "Learning to Bridge the Gap: Efficient Novelty Recovery with Planning and Reinforcement Learning." She's also researching safe reinforcement learning for power grid optimization at MIT's Donti Lab, where she was listed as a past member in 2024.

Alicia has an impressive publication record for her career stage, with multiple published papers including work on adversarial attacks against online reinforcement learning agents (as part of MIT PRIMES research project 2022-2023), magic SET squares classification, the Post Correspondence Problem, and coin weighing problems. Her academic excellence is further demonstrated by her coursework in graduate-level subjects including Advanced Algorithms, Inference and Information, and Sensorimotor Learning.

Beyond her academic pursuits, Alicia founded and served as CEO of Watch To Donate from 2020 to 2023, an international student organization that donates revenue from social media videos, mobile apps, and business collaborations. Under her leadership, the organization raised over $6,000 for 27 causes, reached over 6 million people, and developed apps with 9,000+ downloads. She also created a Family Fund to help their online community of 50,000 in need. Additionally, she developed "Play To Donate," an app that leverages ad revenue to enable users to donate to charity by playing games.

Alicia is active in MIT's campus life, participating in MIT Asian Dance Team and Ridonkulous (MIT's competitive hip hop dance team), and was previously on Fixation (MIT's competitive contemporary dance team). She also enjoys figure skating and watching movies with friends in her free time.

She is currently preparing for her upcoming role as an ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics, where she'll likely apply her expertise in AI and mathematics to challenges in the therapeutic development space.

suggested_people.name: Dhruv Gautam
suggested_people.short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

name: max li
short_description: Max Li is a professional at Jane Street with a background from Harvard University. He has demonstrated exceptional skills in debate, reaching the Tournament of Champions Top 16 and excelling in economics competitions, placing 2nd at the Harvard Pre-Collegiate Economics Challenge.
long_description:
Max Li is currently working at Jane Street, a quantitative trading firm known for hiring top talent in mathematics, computer science, and quantitative fields. He received his education from Harvard University, bringing strong academic credentials to his professional work.

Max has a distinguished background in competitive debate, achieving impressive results including Tournament of Champions Top 16 (Gold Public Forum) in April 2020, International Public Policy Forum Top 16 in March 2020, and Harvard National Forensics Tournament Top 5 and #1 seed in February 2019. His debate accomplishments also include Princeton Classic Top 5 in December 2018 and Grand Nationals Top 16 in May 2018.

Beyond debate, Max demonstrated strong aptitude in economics by placing 2nd individually at the Harvard Pre-Collegiate Economics Challenge in April 2019. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his recognition as a National Merit Scholar and National AP Scholar.

Max's combination of quantitative skills, debate experience, and economics knowledge suggests he has strong analytical abilities and communication skills that would be valuable in AI development and implementation contexts. His background indicates he likely brings a unique perspective that combines technical expertise with the ability to articulate complex concepts effectively.

suggested_people.name: Mav L.
suggested_people.short_description: Harvard applied mathematics student with a diverse background spanning quantitative trading, angel investing, and chess mastery. A former researcher in the Arctic and at Harvard's School of Engineering, Mav holds both Candidate Master and Women's Candidate Master titles in chess and represented the US in international chess competitions.
suggested_people.long_description:
Mav L. is a multifaceted individual currently studying Applied Mathematics at Harvard University while actively exploring opportunities in the tech and finance sectors. Their professional journey showcases remarkable versatility, having worked as a Quantitative Trader at prestigious firms like Jane Street and BlackEdge Capital, and as a Crypto Trader at Galaxy.

Beyond traditional finance, Mav has established themselves as an Angel Investor in multiple startups including Haize Labs, Etched, XOUL, and nosu, demonstrating a keen eye for emerging technologies and business opportunities. Their academic pursuits have included undergraduate research at Harvard's School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, as well as participating in a unique student researcher program in the Arctic through the School for International Training in Iceland.

Mav has also shown leadership capabilities as a Program Lead for the Harvard Undergraduate Clean Energy Group and as a Principal at Harvard Undergraduate Capital Partners, indicating their interest in sustainable energy and investment strategies.

A distinguished chess player, Mav holds both Candidate Master (CM) and Women's Candidate Master (WCM) titles. Their chess achievements include representing the United States at the World Youth Chess Championships, securing 3rd place at the National Girls Tournament of Champions, and winning the Illinois State Female Chess Championship three times.

Additionally, Mav has excelled in academic competitions, particularly in Earth Science, qualifying for a Gold Medal Score at the International Earth Science Olympiad (IESO) in South Korea, placing among the top 30 students globally. They were also among the top 8 students in the US to qualify for the International Earth Science Olympiad and among the top 36 in the US Earth Science Olympiad.

Mav is multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Chinese and English, and limited working proficiency in Spanish. They currently volunteer as an Alumni Interviewer for Harvard University and as an Alumni National Science Bowl Volunteer for the U.S. Department of Energy, giving back to educational communities that helped shape their path.

Mav is also passionate about diversity in computer science and technology. As evidenced by their involvement with organizations like Girls Who Code and Game Development Club, they advocate for greater representation of women and underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Mav has demonstrated leadership in creating inclusive spaces for learning computer science and game development, helping to address the gender gap in these fields.

suggested_people.name: Justin Ji
suggested_people.short_description: Junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University with a focus on AI interpretability research. Justin is active in multiple campus organizations including Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders and Book Club @ Harvard, which he founded. He balances academic pursuits with interests in volleyball, reading, and community leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Justin Ji (also known as Juji) is a junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University (class of 2026). His academic focus has evolved toward AI interpretability research—understanding how AI models work internally to make them safer and more trustworthy for society. During his junior year, he collaborated with the Harvard Kempner Institute on a project investigating how language models adopt "personas" and designing interventions to influence them.

Justin's technical background includes competitive programming and mathematics in high school, where he reached USACO Platinum level and qualified for AIME. At Harvard, he has pursued a rigorous computer science curriculum including graduate-level coursework in Deep Learning (MIT 6.S898), Sensorimotor Learning (MIT 6.8200), and Training Foundation Models (CS 2281R). He has also conducted supervised research (CS 91R) and participated in the Kempner REU summer research program focused on AI interpretability.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Justin is deeply involved in campus life. He founded Book Club @ Harvard and serves on the board of Startups @ Harvard. He is also the Social Chair for Harvard Men's Club Volleyball, Director of Engagement for Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders, and a member of several other organizations including the Harvard AI Safety Student Team, Harvard College Christian Students, and the Taiwanese Cultural Society.

Before Harvard, Justin served as the Whitney High School Middle School Branch and Online Director for Math Matters 4 All, demonstrating his early leadership abilities. His digital creativity was previously showcased through projects like his participation in the Chipotle + David Dobrik TikTok Contest in May 2020.

Justin is an avid reader with diverse literary interests. His favorite books include "The Three-Body Problem" by Cixin Liu, "The Book Thief" by Markus Zusak, and "All the Light We Cannot See" by Anthony Doerr. He maintains an active Goodreads profile and encourages connections through his social media channels.

In his free time, Justin enjoys playing volleyball, reading, and eating at Chipotle. He welcomes connections via LinkedIn or email and is "always happy to meet new people," reflecting his collaborative and community-oriented approach to both his academic and personal pursuits.

suggested_people.name: Leo Nagel
suggested_people.short_description: Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with expertise in GPU optimization, quantitative finance, and physics. Former Chief Executive at Global Society of Young Physicists and published researcher with a focus on computational efficiency and mathematical modeling.
suggested_people.long_description:
Leo Nagel is an Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley who combines technical expertise with leadership experience to drive technological innovation. His academic focus spans GPU kernel optimization, quantitative finance, computing theory, mathematics, and physics.

Currently, Leo is deeply involved in several cutting-edge projects that showcase his technical abilities. He collaborated with Bradley Hsu to develop cuBogo, the fastest bogosort implementation ever run on a single device, optimizing custom CUDA (C++) kernels for the Nvidia H100. He's also working on cuDream, rewriting DreamCoder to leverage GPU optimizations, and cuPrimes, a custom kernel implementing the Fermat test of pseudo-primality using the Schönhage-Strassen algorithm and optimized Fast Fourier Transform with Nvidia H100 tensor cores.

Leo's leadership capabilities are evident through his role as Chief Executive at the Global Society of Young Physicists (2022-2024), where he founded a physics nonprofit that organizes summer programs and publishes a journal. Prior to this, he served as a Curriculum Developer at Mad for Stem, creating interdisciplinary courses spanning economics, computer science, data science, and technology.

His academic achievements include placing first out of 130+ participants in the Berkeley Trading Invitational 2024, demonstrating his aptitude for quantitative finance. Leo has also published research, including a paper on "Derivation of a Function for Velocity for Falling Objects with Non-Negligible Air Resistance," showcasing his mathematical modeling skills.

Leo's educational background includes studies at UC Berkeley, a visiting undergraduate experience at The University of Hong Kong, and participation in specialized programs like the Quantum Cryptography School for Young Students at the University of Waterloo. He graduated from Dulwich College Shanghai Pudong with an International Baccalaureate score of 44/45.

With a multicultural background having lived in Germany (8 years), China (10 years), and the United States (2 years), Leo brings a global perspective to his work. He is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and German, and elementary proficiency in Chinese and Latin. Beyond academics, he enjoys chess and hiking in the Berkeley Hills, particularly at night.

Leo's unique combination of technical expertise in GPU optimization, research experience, leadership skills, and interdisciplinary knowledge positions him as a promising innovator in the fields of computer science and electrical engineering.

suggested_people.name: Joe Qiaoyun Li
suggested_people.short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

name: spike o'carroll
short_description: CS student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems with impressive entrepreneurial achievements. Creator of Libreddit (4M+ monthly users) and co-founder of Dispatch AI, an emergency response AI solution. Multiple hackathon winner with over $120k in total winnings and incoming SWE intern at Ramp.
long_description:
Spike O'Carroll is a Computer Science student at UC Irvine specializing in Intelligent Systems (AI/ML) with a 3.95 GPA. He has established himself as both a talented software engineer and successful entrepreneur.

As the creator of Libreddit (now Redlib), Spike built a private and customizable Reddit client that grew to over 4 million monthly active users, garnered 5k+ GitHub stars, and is hosted on 20+ instances globally. He also developed Peacock Browser, which achieved 30,000 downloads.

Spike's entrepreneurial ventures include co-founding Dispatch AI, an AI-powered 911 operator system that uses empathy-driven emergency response to transform how critical emergencies are triaged. This venture won the $50,000 Grand Prize at the 2024 UC Berkeley AI Hackathon and was accepted into Berkeley Skydeck's Pad-13 Program (1% acceptance rate). The project has received grants from OpenAI, Intel, Skydeck, and Mistral AI.

His hackathon success is remarkable, with multiple first-place finishes including UC Berkeley AI Hackathon (2024), LAHacks Google Company Challenge (2024), UCI Stella Zhang New Venture Competition (2024), UCI Butterworth Product Design Competition (2024), and UCI AI Innovation Challenge in Student Experience (2024). He also placed 2nd in the SoCal Super Pitch Competition (2024). These achievements have resulted in over $120,000 in total winnings.

Professionally, Spike has worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Portal, where he shipped 80+ features to an AI web browser serving 30,000 users monthly, built a high-performance vector database in Rust, and launched a conversational voice AI with web agent capabilities. He's also run his own freelance web development business (Spike Designs) since 2021, creating high-converting websites and branding for businesses.

Spike is set to join Ramp as a Backend SWE Intern in Summer 2025, further expanding his experience in the tech industry. His diverse skill set spans software engineering, UI/UX design, and entrepreneurship, with technical proficiency in languages like Rust, Python, TypeScript, and React.

His GitHub profile (spikecodes) showcases his open-source contributions and personal projects, including Stotra (a stock trading simulator) and Peafox (a Firefox privacy configuration). Spike is passionate about building high-impact products and continues to explore new opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Audrey Chen
suggested_people.short_description: Serial hackathon winner (21 wins) and tech entrepreneur with a passion for AI innovation. Co-founder of VC-backed nosu.io, Software Engineering Intern at Intuit, and content creator with 68K Instagram followers. Currently pursuing Computer Engineering at Michigan State University while balancing multiple tech roles including NASA USRC research and Intel AI projects.
suggested_people.long_description:
Audrey Chen is a dynamic force in the tech world, particularly known for her exceptional track record of winning 21 hackathons with a 70% win rate, accumulating over $20,000 in prizes. Her technical prowess spans multiple domains within AI and software engineering, demonstrated through her diverse professional experiences.

As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

suggested_people.name: Olsen B.
suggested_people.short_description: Software Engineer at Affirm and MLH Top 50 recipient with expertise in workflow orchestration infrastructure and LLMs. Founded Hack@Davidson, Davidson College's first student-led hackathon, and has won multiple hackathon awards including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech. Currently consulting for Cognition to help improve Devin AI.
suggested_people.long_description:
Olsen B. (Oğuzhan Budanur) is a Software Engineer at Affirm working on the Workflow Orchestration Infrastructure Team, where he manages distributed systems integrating Airflow, Luigi, Spark, and Kubernetes that handle over 1,000,000 actions monthly. He developed a high-performance gRPC server in Kotlin and built a Slack bot leveraging semantic search and LLMs for efficient triage.

With a strong entrepreneurial spirit, Olsen founded and served as President of Hack@Davidson, organizing Davidson College's first student-led hackathon that raised over $6,000 and accommodated 90+ participants. His leadership extended to founding Competitive Coding at Davidson (C-CAD), which prepares members for software engineering jobs and internships. Under his guidance, the team won 11 prizes across 7 hackathons, including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech.

Olsen's professional experience includes working as a Software Consultant for Cognition AI Labs, helping to improve Devin AI, and founding Motate LLC, a boutique software contracting firm that secured multiple contracts and achieved quarterly revenue of ~$20,000. He also interned at Aptos Labs, where he created a 7,000-line open-source Python CLI for Kubernetes deployments that saved $70,000 through multithreading optimizations.

His technical expertise spans workflow orchestration, distributed systems, Kubernetes, Python, Kotlin, Java, C++, Firebase, and LLMs. Olsen is particularly passionate about building AI-powered tools, as demonstrated by his work on semantic search systems and LLM applications. He's recognized as part of the MLH Top 50 and has received multiple academic scholarships and hackathon awards, including wins for projects like WaitFree DMV, ImmiGrace, SusEats, BlockAide, and CodeViolet.

Olsen grew up in the DC Metro Area and discovered his passion for coding in middle school, starting with VisualBasic's GUI-based desktop apps. His love for technology was truly ignited at his first hackathon, VTHacks 7, in 2019. He studied Computer Science at Davidson College after transferring from Virginia Tech, where he was pursuing a double major in Computer Science and Computational Modeling & Data Analytics. He maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA in his major courses and served as a Teaching Assistant for a Blockchains class at Davidson College.

Beyond his technical work, Olsen enjoys exploring new technologies, participating in hackathons, and building innovative projects. His personal website at olsenbudanur.com showcases his portfolio of work and technical achievements.

suggested_people.name: Aidan Gollan
suggested_people.short_description: Co-founder of nosu.io and a versatile builder with a passion for turning creative ideas into shareable products. Computer Science and Mathematics student at Michigan State University, with experience at Auto-Owners Insurance and SampleServe, and creator of projects like Weird Spotify and Notello.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aidan Gollan is an entrepreneurial technologist and builder who thrives on transforming creative concepts into tangible products that connect people. As the co-founder of nosu.io, he's focused on "hacking hackathons" and creating innovative solutions in the AI space.

Currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Mathematics at Michigan State University (expected graduation: May 2025), Aidan balances theoretical knowledge with practical application. He serves as a Project Director at the AI Club at MSU, where he helps guide and develop AI initiatives among students, including contributing to the club's website.

Aidan's professional experience includes software engineering roles at Auto-Owners Insurance (May 2024 - Present) and SampleServe (December 2023 - May 2024), where he honed his technical skills in real-world environments. He was also the founder of DataLume (formerly Lume Analytics), an innovative data analytics platform designed to empower local business owners with simplified, data-driven solutions. This venture was inspired by his father's struggles with complex data systems as the owner of Common Good Bakery.

What sets Aidan apart is his enthusiasm for building unique, user-centric applications. His projects include Weird Spotify (weirdspotify.com) and Notello.ai, reflecting his creativity and desire to create experiences that resonate with users. He's been coding since age 12, initially creating programs to automate his homework, and has maintained that playful innovation spirit throughout his career.

Aidan's approach to technology is refreshingly human-centered. In his own words, he likes to "turn fun ideas into things you can share with others," highlighting his understanding that technology is ultimately about connecting people and enhancing experiences. This philosophy guides his work across various projects and ventures, making him a distinctive voice in the tech and AI community.

His technical skills include Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript, which he showcases through various repositories on GitHub, including personal projects and contributions to open-source initiatives.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Anirudh Kotamraju
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

name: mav l.
short_description: Harvard applied mathematics student with a diverse background spanning quantitative trading, angel investing, and chess mastery. A former researcher in the Arctic and at Harvard's School of Engineering, Mav holds both Candidate Master and Women's Candidate Master titles in chess and represented the US in international chess competitions.
long_description:
Mav L. is a multifaceted individual currently studying Applied Mathematics at Harvard University while actively exploring opportunities in the tech and finance sectors. Their professional journey showcases remarkable versatility, having worked as a Quantitative Trader at prestigious firms like Jane Street and BlackEdge Capital, and as a Crypto Trader at Galaxy.

Beyond traditional finance, Mav has established themselves as an Angel Investor in multiple startups including Haize Labs, Etched, XOUL, and nosu, demonstrating a keen eye for emerging technologies and business opportunities. Their academic pursuits have included undergraduate research at Harvard's School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, as well as participating in a unique student researcher program in the Arctic through the School for International Training in Iceland.

Mav has also shown leadership capabilities as a Program Lead for the Harvard Undergraduate Clean Energy Group and as a Principal at Harvard Undergraduate Capital Partners, indicating their interest in sustainable energy and investment strategies.

A distinguished chess player, Mav holds both Candidate Master (CM) and Women's Candidate Master (WCM) titles. Their chess achievements include representing the United States at the World Youth Chess Championships, securing 3rd place at the National Girls Tournament of Champions, and winning the Illinois State Female Chess Championship three times.

Additionally, Mav has excelled in academic competitions, particularly in Earth Science, qualifying for a Gold Medal Score at the International Earth Science Olympiad (IESO) in South Korea, placing among the top 30 students globally. They were also among the top 8 students in the US to qualify for the International Earth Science Olympiad and among the top 36 in the US Earth Science Olympiad.

Mav is multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Chinese and English, and limited working proficiency in Spanish. They currently volunteer as an Alumni Interviewer for Harvard University and as an Alumni National Science Bowl Volunteer for the U.S. Department of Energy, giving back to educational communities that helped shape their path.

Mav is also passionate about diversity in computer science and technology. As evidenced by their involvement with organizations like Girls Who Code and Game Development Club, they advocate for greater representation of women and underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Mav has demonstrated leadership in creating inclusive spaces for learning computer science and game development, helping to address the gender gap in these fields.

suggested_people.name: Max Li
suggested_people.short_description: Max Li is a professional at Jane Street with a background from Harvard University. He has demonstrated exceptional skills in debate, reaching the Tournament of Champions Top 16 and excelling in economics competitions, placing 2nd at the Harvard Pre-Collegiate Economics Challenge.
suggested_people.long_description:
Max Li is currently working at Jane Street, a quantitative trading firm known for hiring top talent in mathematics, computer science, and quantitative fields. He received his education from Harvard University, bringing strong academic credentials to his professional work.

Max has a distinguished background in competitive debate, achieving impressive results including Tournament of Champions Top 16 (Gold Public Forum) in April 2020, International Public Policy Forum Top 16 in March 2020, and Harvard National Forensics Tournament Top 5 and #1 seed in February 2019. His debate accomplishments also include Princeton Classic Top 5 in December 2018 and Grand Nationals Top 16 in May 2018.

Beyond debate, Max demonstrated strong aptitude in economics by placing 2nd individually at the Harvard Pre-Collegiate Economics Challenge in April 2019. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his recognition as a National Merit Scholar and National AP Scholar.

Max's combination of quantitative skills, debate experience, and economics knowledge suggests he has strong analytical abilities and communication skills that would be valuable in AI development and implementation contexts. His background indicates he likely brings a unique perspective that combines technical expertise with the ability to articulate complex concepts effectively.

suggested_people.name: Thomaz Felipe Bonato
suggested_people.short_description: Brazilian AI researcher and entrepreneur studying at USC as a Trustee Scholar. Thomaz has excelled in hackathons, winning first place at HackMIT and second place at PennApps in 2024, while conducting AI research at USC Marshall School of Business focusing on educational applications and LLMs.
suggested_people.long_description:
Thomaz Felipe Bonato is a passionate engineer, researcher, and lifelong learner from Brazil currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence for Business at the University of Southern California as a prestigious Trustee Scholar with full tuition. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his National Merit Finalist status.

Thomaz has established himself as an exceptional hackathon competitor, securing first place at HackMIT 2024 with PalmLabs (focused on education) and second place at PennApps 2024 with Cypress MFA (addressing security and privacy challenges). He also won first place with Azalea, an eco-friendly AI model selector, demonstrating his commitment to sustainable AI solutions.

His professional experience spans multiple domains within AI and business. As an AI Research Assistant at USC Marshall School of Business since December 2023, he initially explored AI applications in education and has since expanded to researching LLMs and cluster-based probing techniques. Thomaz has entrepreneurial experience as a founder of a stealth startup focused on AI solutions for law firms, and currently serves as a Data Science Intern at Trudy and a Growth Strategist at Mercor.

Within the USC community, Thomaz has taken on leadership roles as the Director of Founder's Education at SEP (Student Entrepreneurship Program) and previously served as Director of External Relations for USC Business Technology Group. He was also a Student Founder at SEP, demonstrating his commitment to entrepreneurship education.

Thomaz is multilingual, with native proficiency in Portuguese and English, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. He is also a Management Leadership Tomorrow (MLT) Fellow, indicating his commitment to leadership development. His technical skills are evidenced by certifications in Linear Algebra for Machine Learning and Neural Networks and Deep Learning from DeepLearning.AI, as well as UX design skills certified by LinkedIn.

His contribution to policy is demonstrated through his publication "A Blueprint for Greece's AI Transformation" for the Special Secretariat for Foresight, Presidency of the Government, Hellenic Republic, showing his interest in AI governance and national strategy development.

It's important to note that there is another Thomaz Bonato who has had a distinguished career in the pharmaceutical industry, serving in various executive roles at AstraZeneca and Alexion. This Thomaz Bonato has held positions including US Chief Financial Officer and Vice President of Finance at AstraZeneca, Interim Country President of AstraZeneca Australia and New Zealand, and most recently as Global Head of Research Development & Medical Finance at Alexion. His career has included significant financial leadership roles across multiple countries including Brazil, Costa Rica, Australia, and the United States. However, this is a different individual than the USC student and AI researcher profiled here.

suggested_people.name: Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla
suggested_people.short_description: A multilingual Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard with exceptional achievements in quantum computing and international physics competitions. Ricardo combines technical expertise with diplomatic skills, having led international relations organizations and conducted research spanning solid-state physics, ESG consulting, and quantum algorithm development across multiple languages.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla is a Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard University with a remarkable blend of technical expertise and international perspective. His academic journey is distinguished by significant achievements in quantum computing, where he serves as Vice President of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantum Computing Association (HUQCA) and won 2nd place at MIT's Quantum Computing Hackathon 2024, developing theoretical error bounds for quantum algorithms.

Ricardo's technical prowess extends beyond quantum computing to solid-state physics research, where he worked with 2D transition metal dichalcogenides and Van der Waals heterostructures under Professor Hongkun Park. His computational skills have been recognized through multiple hackathon victories, including Microsoft's Student Hackathon 2021 and CdCMx 2020, where he developed mathematical models for COVID-19 comorbidity analysis.

In the quantum computing field, Ricardo has demonstrated exceptional talent, helping to grow HUQCA to over 300 members. At the MIT Interdisciplinary Quantum Hackathon (iQuHACK), his team created an "experimental harness" that allowed them to run quantum simulations at scale and efficiently collect data, earning them second place. As Ricardo noted, "It's one thing to learn something in a classroom, and another to try to code one and see if it runs. That's different, and I think it adds an extra layer to fully mastering the concepts."

What sets Ricardo apart is his exceptional international background and linguistic abilities. Fluent in six languages (Spanish, English, French, Chinese, Russian, and German), he has leveraged these skills in various leadership roles. As Co-President of Harvard International Relations on Campus and in his work with the Harvard International Relations Council, he has bridged cultural divides and facilitated international dialogue. His language proficiency earned him first place in Harvard's Chinese Poetry Recitation Contest and supported his research for a Radcliffe Fellow's project on underground economies in Greater China.

Ricardo's professional experience spans diverse sectors, from ESG consulting at PwC China, where he spearheaded sustainable design strategies for LEED-certified real estate projects, to his upcoming role as a Business Analyst at Alibaba Group. During his internship at PwC Shanghai through the Harvard China Fund Student Internship Program, he significantly improved his professional Chinese language skills while working on technical projects. As Ricardo reflected, "My biggest achievement from this experience was the consolidation of my Chinese speaking, reading and writing skills at the professional level."

His commitment to diplomacy and international cooperation is evident in his work with the United Nations Information Center, where he led a conference commemorating the UN's 75th anniversary with 500+ Latin American students.

His academic excellence is further demonstrated by his impressive collection of medals from international physics competitions, including the International Physics Olympiad, European Physics Olympiad, and Mexican Physics Olympiad. Ricardo's multidisciplinary approach combines rigorous scientific training with global perspective, positioning him uniquely at the intersection of technology, diplomacy, and sustainable development.

suggested_people.name: Justin Ji
suggested_people.short_description: Junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University with a focus on AI interpretability research. Justin is active in multiple campus organizations including Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders and Book Club @ Harvard, which he founded. He balances academic pursuits with interests in volleyball, reading, and community leadership.
suggested_people.long_description:
Justin Ji (also known as Juji) is a junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University (class of 2026). His academic focus has evolved toward AI interpretability research—understanding how AI models work internally to make them safer and more trustworthy for society. During his junior year, he collaborated with the Harvard Kempner Institute on a project investigating how language models adopt "personas" and designing interventions to influence them.

Justin's technical background includes competitive programming and mathematics in high school, where he reached USACO Platinum level and qualified for AIME. At Harvard, he has pursued a rigorous computer science curriculum including graduate-level coursework in Deep Learning (MIT 6.S898), Sensorimotor Learning (MIT 6.8200), and Training Foundation Models (CS 2281R). He has also conducted supervised research (CS 91R) and participated in the Kempner REU summer research program focused on AI interpretability.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Justin is deeply involved in campus life. He founded Book Club @ Harvard and serves on the board of Startups @ Harvard. He is also the Social Chair for Harvard Men's Club Volleyball, Director of Engagement for Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders, and a member of several other organizations including the Harvard AI Safety Student Team, Harvard College Christian Students, and the Taiwanese Cultural Society.

Before Harvard, Justin served as the Whitney High School Middle School Branch and Online Director for Math Matters 4 All, demonstrating his early leadership abilities. His digital creativity was previously showcased through projects like his participation in the Chipotle + David Dobrik TikTok Contest in May 2020.

Justin is an avid reader with diverse literary interests. His favorite books include "The Three-Body Problem" by Cixin Liu, "The Book Thief" by Markus Zusak, and "All the Light We Cannot See" by Anthony Doerr. He maintains an active Goodreads profile and encourages connections through his social media channels.

In his free time, Justin enjoys playing volleyball, reading, and eating at Chipotle. He welcomes connections via LinkedIn or email and is "always happy to meet new people," reflecting his collaborative and community-oriented approach to both his academic and personal pursuits.

suggested_people.name: Om Shastri
suggested_people.short_description: Wharton student in the Management and Technology Program, former varsity wrestler, and Dorm Room Fund associate with a background in robotics research and astronomical instrumentation. Published researcher with experience in edge computing and polarimetry, balancing interests in technology, investment, and scientific research while serving as a student manager for Penn's wrestling team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Om Shastri is a student in the prestigious Management and Technology Program at The Wharton School and The School of Engineering and Applied Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing a triple major in Computer Science, Finance, and Entrepreneurship. He currently works with Dorm Room Fund, helping identify and invest in promising student-led startups.

His research experience is particularly impressive, having published in prestigious journals like Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society on high-precision polarimetry using CMOS image sensors, and in MDPI Sensors on edge-intelligent IoT systems for mosquito threat prediction (MOSQUITO EDGE). This demonstrates his technical versatility across astronomy and edge computing applications.

Om has been involved with several research institutions, including the GRASP Lab (likely focusing on robotics and automation) and the Monterey Institute for Research and Astronomy. His leadership experience includes serving as Co-CEO of X Academy Hephaestus Robotics and as a TMT Analyst for the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, showing his ability to bridge technical expertise with business acumen.

Before Penn, Om was a standout wrestler at Los Gatos High School in California, where he served as team captain and achieved impressive accomplishments including qualifying for the California State tournament, winning the CA World Challenge Championship, and earning titles as League and District champion. He was also recognized as the Bay Area Student Athlete of the Year and maintained high academic honors throughout his four years.

Currently, Om serves as a student manager for the University of Pennsylvania wrestling team after competing as a freshman during the 2023-24 season at 184/197 pounds. Though his competitive record was 0-6, he gained valuable experience participating in tournaments including the Keystone Classic, Patriot Open, and F&M Open.

Om's professional experience includes internships at NASA, the US Army, CLA, and Ripple Ventures, providing him with diverse exposure across government, consulting, and venture capital sectors. He's an active participant in the AI hackathon circuit, having competed in prestigious events including x.ai Hackathon, TreeHacks, HackMIT, HackHarvard, Microsoft Internal AI Hackathon, and PennApps.

His achievements include receiving the Congressional Gold Medal Award from the United States Congress in September 2022, recognizing his exceptional service and achievement. He has also completed certifications in Business Analysis, Data Analysis, and Generative AI through Microsoft and LinkedIn, showing his commitment to staying current with emerging technologies.

Om is the son of Medha and Parthesh Shastri, and his personal interests likely include following developments in AI, quantum computing, cybersecurity, and startup funding, particularly in the tech sector. This holistic profile presents Om as a multifaceted individual with strong technical foundations, research credentials, and business interests, positioned at the intersection of technology, finance, and scientific innovation.

suggested_people.name: Arnav Adhikari
suggested_people.short_description: 19-year-old EECS and Finance student at MIT with a passion for building innovative solutions in fintech, robotics, and healthtech. First place winner at HackMIT 2024 with a nicotine cessation patch project, and currently working on semantic operators at MIT CSAIL while also running a stealth startup.
suggested_people.long_description:
Arnav Adhikari is a dynamic 19-year-old undergraduate at MIT pursuing a dual focus in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and Finance. His technical interests span across multiple domains including fintech (payments, wealth management, AI analysts), robotics (collaboration and control), healthtech (LLM-aided care), and productivity tools. He describes himself as a "big proponent of automating the mundane" and believes that jobs should be automated to redirect human attention toward tasks requiring ingenuity.

Arnav has built an impressive track record of achievements. Most notably, he and his team won the First Place Grand Prize at HackMIT 2024 with their algorithmically-driven nicotine cessation patch. He's currently working as a Builder at MIT's prestigious Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), focusing on semantic operators.

Entrepreneurially minded, Arnav is the Founder and CEO of a stealth startup that he's been running since January 2024. His previous experience includes work at Boston Consulting Group (BCM), Rice University, Stanford's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI), and Harvard Medical School, demonstrating his ability to collaborate with top-tier institutions across academia and industry.

Arnav's research work is particularly notable in healthcare technology. He has worked on cardiac imaging interpretability and standardized cardiac measurements at BCM, Texas Children's Hospital, and Stanford AIMI, with his work being featured in Circulation by the American Heart Association in November 2023. He has also analyzed teamwork synergy for AI Surgical Robotic Coaches at Rice HCAIR and Harvard Medical School, and developed smarter irrigation and water management systems for the City of Southside Place in Houston.

His technical background is further strengthened by his experience in robot motion planning and control at Rice RobotPI, and his achievements as a retired USAJMO winner and USACO Gold Medalist. Arnav is also an author, having written the Cubronix Competitive Math Practice Book for charity, which was featured in the Houston Chronicle in January 2022.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Arnav offers tutoring services in the Greater Houston area, specializing in math, science, engineering, and test preparation. He enjoys tennis, basketball, football, biking, the outdoors, and various forms of media entertainment.

Currently a freshman at MIT (class of 2028), Arnav graduated from Carnegie Vanguard High School in 2024 after previously attending Bellaire High School. He describes himself as someone who loves "learning and building fast," and is always open to discussing innovative ideas and groundbreaking technologies.

suggested_people.name: Nikita Mounier
suggested_people.short_description: Nikita Mounier is a trilingual student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Finance. With experience as a software engineering intern at Ramp and a track record of winning hackathons, including PennApps XXIII and placing 2nd at TreeHacks 2025, Nikita demonstrates exceptional technical skills and entrepreneurial drive.
suggested_people.long_description:
Nikita Mounier is a talented computer science and finance student in the Jerome Fisher Management & Technology Program at the University of Pennsylvania, maintaining an impressive 3.91/4.00 GPA. His technical expertise is demonstrated through his role as an App Developer at Penn Labs and as a Teaching Assistant for both undergraduate and graduate-level computer science courses, including Machine Learning (CIS 5200) and Programming Languages & Techniques (CIS 1200).

Nikita has a strong track record in competitive programming and hackathons, with notable achievements including 2nd place overall at TreeHacks 2025 with project "Supernova," 2nd place at PennApps XXV with "Rally AI," and 1st place at PennApps XXIII with "Cointree," a blockchain platform promoting sustainability through carbon offsets. His project work demonstrates versatility across iOS development, web applications, blockchain technologies, and AI.

Professionally, Nikita has secured a Software Engineering Internship at Ramp, a fintech unicorn, for Summer 2024. He also contributes to Penn Undergraduate Capital Partners in a sourcing role, showing his interest in the intersection of technology and finance.

Nikita is exceptionally multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in English, French, and Russian, plus working knowledge of Spanish. His educational background includes attending the Lycée Français Charles de Gaulle in London, where he completed the French Baccalauréat with highest honors (19.33/20) in Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics.

Beyond his technical accomplishments, Nikita has developed several notable personal projects, including "Tap It," an innovative iOS application that allows users to share social media details by simply placing one phone on top of another. This privacy-centric app, which has garnered 34 stars on GitHub, uses advanced technologies including SwiftUI, The Composable Architecture, Combine, Network Framework, Core Location, and Core Bluetooth. The project demonstrates his expertise in iOS development and his commitment to creating practical solutions to everyday problems.

Nikita is also an active contributor to the tech community, having given a talk about The Composable Architecture at NSLondon in November 2022. His GitHub profile showcases various other projects, including "Turkey-To-Go," "bridging-the-gap" (a website for a tutoring charity where he serves as head of Computer Science), and "swift-expression" (a micro-library for Swift). He has also shared numerous code snippets and implementations of programming patterns through GitHub Gists, including a French translation of The Composable Architecture's documentation.

His diverse skill set spans software engineering, machine learning, blockchain technology, financial analysis, and iOS development, positioning him as a versatile talent at the intersection of technology and business with a particular strength in Swift and iOS development.

suggested_people.name: Aadit Juneja
suggested_people.short_description: Aadit Juneja is a student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Finance from Wharton and Computer Science from Penn Engineering. He has research experience in multimodal language models for tumor contouring at Penn Medicine and is preparing for a quantitative trading internship at Five Rings while actively publishing technical articles on AI and language models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aadit Juneja is an ambitious undergraduate student in the highly selective Jerome Fisher Management & Technology (M&T) Program at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing dual degrees in Finance from The Wharton School and Computer Science from Penn Engineering.

His professional experience demonstrates a strong interest in the intersection of finance and technology. Aadit is preparing for a Quantitative Trading Internship at Five Rings in New York (January-February 2025) and recently completed a Fall Private Equity Analyst role at Leo Legacy in Philadelphia (August-October 2024). 

What sets Aadit apart is his research experience in artificial intelligence applications in healthcare. During Summer 2024, he worked as a Research Assistant at Penn Medicine, University of Pennsylvania Health System, focusing on multimodal language models for tumor contouring. This experience highlights his ability to apply advanced AI techniques to solve complex medical problems.

Academically, Aadit maintains a perfect 4.0 GPA and is actively involved in several finance and analytics-focused student organizations, including the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, Wharton Analytics Fellows, and Wharton Undergraduate Distressed Investing Group.

Aadit is also a prolific technical writer, regularly publishing articles on his personal website about cutting-edge AI topics. His recent publications include "A Distributed Inference Engine for SmolLM with Rust and gRPC," "RL for Training Multiple Decoding Heads -- An Inference Acceleration Method in Language Models," and "Frequency Based Constrained Decoding for Language Model Watermarks." He has also written about practical AI applications like "Agent for Seamless Meeting Scheduling" and financial analysis with "Tempus AI Short Recommendation."

As a developer, Aadit maintains an active GitHub profile (ajuneja23) with repositories focused on AI, machine learning, and practical applications. His projects include implementations of Monte Carlo integration, PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization) algorithms from scratch, and an Agentic Meeting Scheduler, demonstrating his technical skills in both finance and computer science domains.

His contact information includes his email (aadit@aaditjuneja.com) and phone number (224-443-2889), making him accessible for professional and academic opportunities.

Aadit's dual expertise in finance and computer science, combined with his research experience in healthcare AI applications and technical writing skills, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving domains.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

suggested_people.name: George Cheng
suggested_people.short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
suggested_people.long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

name: nikita mounier
short_description: Nikita Mounier is a trilingual student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Finance. With experience as a software engineering intern at Ramp and a track record of winning hackathons, including PennApps XXIII and placing 2nd at TreeHacks 2025, Nikita demonstrates exceptional technical skills and entrepreneurial drive.
long_description:
Nikita Mounier is a talented computer science and finance student in the Jerome Fisher Management & Technology Program at the University of Pennsylvania, maintaining an impressive 3.91/4.00 GPA. His technical expertise is demonstrated through his role as an App Developer at Penn Labs and as a Teaching Assistant for both undergraduate and graduate-level computer science courses, including Machine Learning (CIS 5200) and Programming Languages & Techniques (CIS 1200).

Nikita has a strong track record in competitive programming and hackathons, with notable achievements including 2nd place overall at TreeHacks 2025 with project "Supernova," 2nd place at PennApps XXV with "Rally AI," and 1st place at PennApps XXIII with "Cointree," a blockchain platform promoting sustainability through carbon offsets. His project work demonstrates versatility across iOS development, web applications, blockchain technologies, and AI.

Professionally, Nikita has secured a Software Engineering Internship at Ramp, a fintech unicorn, for Summer 2024. He also contributes to Penn Undergraduate Capital Partners in a sourcing role, showing his interest in the intersection of technology and finance.

Nikita is exceptionally multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in English, French, and Russian, plus working knowledge of Spanish.
