His educational background includes attending the Lycée Français Charles de Gaulle in London, where he completed the French Baccalauréat with highest honors (19.33/20) in Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics.

Beyond his technical accomplishments, Nikita has developed several notable personal projects, including "Tap It," an innovative iOS application that allows users to share social media details by simply placing one phone on top of another. This privacy-centric app, which has garnered 34 stars on GitHub, uses advanced technologies including SwiftUI, The Composable Architecture, Combine, Network Framework, Core Location, and Core Bluetooth. The project demonstrates his expertise in iOS development and his commitment to creating practical solutions to everyday problems.

Nikita is also an active contributor to the tech community, having given a talk about The Composable Architecture at NSLondon in November 2022. His GitHub profile showcases various other projects, including "Turkey-To-Go," "bridging-the-gap" (a website for a tutoring charity where he serves as head of Computer Science), and "swift-expression" (a micro-library for Swift). He has also shared numerous code snippets and implementations of programming patterns through GitHub Gists, including a French translation of The Composable Architecture's documentation.

His diverse skill set spans software engineering, machine learning, blockchain technology, financial analysis, and iOS development, positioning him as a versatile talent at the intersection of technology and business with a particular strength in Swift and iOS development.

suggested_people.name: Om Shastri
suggested_people.short_description: Wharton student in the Management and Technology Program, former varsity wrestler, and Dorm Room Fund associate with a background in robotics research and astronomical instrumentation. Published researcher with experience in edge computing and polarimetry, balancing interests in technology, investment, and scientific research while serving as a student manager for Penn's wrestling team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Om Shastri is a student in the prestigious Management and Technology Program at The Wharton School and The School of Engineering and Applied Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing a triple major in Computer Science, Finance, and Entrepreneurship. He currently works with Dorm Room Fund, helping identify and invest in promising student-led startups.

His research experience is particularly impressive, having published in prestigious journals like Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society on high-precision polarimetry using CMOS image sensors, and in MDPI Sensors on edge-intelligent IoT systems for mosquito threat prediction (MOSQUITO EDGE). This demonstrates his technical versatility across astronomy and edge computing applications.

Om has been involved with several research institutions, including the GRASP Lab (likely focusing on robotics and automation) and the Monterey Institute for Research and Astronomy. His leadership experience includes serving as Co-CEO of X Academy Hephaestus Robotics and as a TMT Analyst for the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, showing his ability to bridge technical expertise with business acumen.

Before Penn, Om was a standout wrestler at Los Gatos High School in California, where he served as team captain and achieved impressive accomplishments including qualifying for the California State tournament, winning the CA World Challenge Championship, and earning titles as League and District champion. He was also recognized as the Bay Area Student Athlete of the Year and maintained high academic honors throughout his four years.

Currently, Om serves as a student manager for the University of Pennsylvania wrestling team after competing as a freshman during the 2023-24 season at 184/197 pounds. Though his competitive record was 0-6, he gained valuable experience participating in tournaments including the Keystone Classic, Patriot Open, and F&M Open.

Om's professional experience includes internships at NASA, the US Army, CLA, and Ripple Ventures, providing him with diverse exposure across government, consulting, and venture capital sectors. He's an active participant in the AI hackathon circuit, having competed in prestigious events including x.ai Hackathon, TreeHacks, HackMIT, HackHarvard, Microsoft Internal AI Hackathon, and PennApps.

His achievements include receiving the Congressional Gold Medal Award from the United States Congress in September 2022, recognizing his exceptional service and achievement. He has also completed certifications in Business Analysis, Data Analysis, and Generative AI through Microsoft and LinkedIn, showing his commitment to staying current with emerging technologies.

Om is the son of Medha and Parthesh Shastri, and his personal interests likely include following developments in AI, quantum computing, cybersecurity, and startup funding, particularly in the tech sector. This holistic profile presents Om as a multifaceted individual with strong technical foundations, research credentials, and business interests, positioned at the intersection of technology, finance, and scientific innovation.

suggested_people.name: Aadit Juneja
suggested_people.short_description: Aadit Juneja is a student in the prestigious Jerome Fisher M&T Program at UPenn, pursuing dual degrees in Finance from Wharton and Computer Science from Penn Engineering. He has research experience in multimodal language models for tumor contouring at Penn Medicine and is preparing for a quantitative trading internship at Five Rings while actively publishing technical articles on AI and language models.
suggested_people.long_description:
Aadit Juneja is an ambitious undergraduate student in the highly selective Jerome Fisher Management & Technology (M&T) Program at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is pursuing dual degrees in Finance from The Wharton School and Computer Science from Penn Engineering.

His professional experience demonstrates a strong interest in the intersection of finance and technology. Aadit is preparing for a Quantitative Trading Internship at Five Rings in New York (January-February 2025) and recently completed a Fall Private Equity Analyst role at Leo Legacy in Philadelphia (August-October 2024). 

What sets Aadit apart is his research experience in artificial intelligence applications in healthcare. During Summer 2024, he worked as a Research Assistant at Penn Medicine, University of Pennsylvania Health System, focusing on multimodal language models for tumor contouring. This experience highlights his ability to apply advanced AI techniques to solve complex medical problems.

Academically, Aadit maintains a perfect 4.0 GPA and is actively involved in several finance and analytics-focused student organizations, including the Wharton Investment and Trading Group, Wharton Analytics Fellows, and Wharton Undergraduate Distressed Investing Group.

Aadit is also a prolific technical writer, regularly publishing articles on his personal website about cutting-edge AI topics. His recent publications include "A Distributed Inference Engine for SmolLM with Rust and gRPC," "RL for Training Multiple Decoding Heads -- An Inference Acceleration Method in Language Models," and "Frequency Based Constrained Decoding for Language Model Watermarks." He has also written about practical AI applications like "Agent for Seamless Meeting Scheduling" and financial analysis with "Tempus AI Short Recommendation."

As a developer, Aadit maintains an active GitHub profile (ajuneja23) with repositories focused on AI, machine learning, and practical applications. His projects include implementations of Monte Carlo integration, PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization) algorithms from scratch, and an Agentic Meeting Scheduler, demonstrating his technical skills in both finance and computer science domains.

His contact information includes his email (aadit@aaditjuneja.com) and phone number (224-443-2889), making him accessible for professional and academic opportunities.

Aadit's dual expertise in finance and computer science, combined with his research experience in healthcare AI applications and technical writing skills, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving domains.

suggested_people.name: Bill Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Yale '26 computer science student in the BS/MS program with a background in competitive programming and mathematics. Currently researching LLMs and code generation, with experience in systems and machine learning. Incoming Software Engineering Intern at Citadel Securities with previous roles at The New York Times and Yale's Gerstein Laboratory. Also serves as Chairman of Cypher Capital, a prominent multi-strategy crypto investment firm.
suggested_people.long_description:
Bill Qian is a computer science student at Yale University (Class of 2026) pursuing a combined BS/MS degree. His technical foundation stems from competitive programming (USACO/ICPC) and mathematics (USAMO/Putnam), which has evolved into expertise in systems, machine learning, and full-stack development.

At Yale's Gerstein Laboratory, Bill has established himself as a researcher in Large Language Models and code generation, publishing multiple papers in natural language processing. His research contributions include work on "ToolLLM: Facilitating Large Language Models to Master 16000+ Real-world APIs" and "BioCoder: A Benchmark for Bioinformatics Code Generation with Contextual Pragmatic Knowledge." He has collaborated with researchers from prominent organizations including Google DeepMind.

Bill's professional experience spans diverse environments. He's secured an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Citadel Securities (New York) focusing on high-performance C++. Previously, he worked at The New York Times on their Research and Development team, exploring ethical applications of AI and LLMs in journalism. At DeepMedia, he designed and optimized algorithms for heterogeneous data analysis, creating a machine translation model with 10% better performance than competitors using Transformers, Python, PyTorch, and Rust.

His technical versatility extends to infrastructure development, having designed distributed computing systems using AWS, Azure, and on-premise hardware with Docker, Kubernetes, and SQS. At Thomas Ho Company, he applied neural networks to assess mortgage loan pricing models and implemented ETL pipelines that improved data processing efficiency by 30%.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Bill is actively involved in campus life as a Project Manager at the Student Technology Collaborative, where he manages knowledge base development and provides technical support across multiple operating systems. He balances his technical interests with creative outlets, singing with the Yale Glee Club and making short films.

In parallel to his academic career, Bill serves as the Chairman of Cypher Capital, a leading multi-strategy crypto investment firm based in the UAE. Before joining Cypher Capital in 2022, he was the Global Head of Fundraising, Binance Labs, and M&A for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency platform. Prior to that, he was Head of Investment for Fintech and Technology at JD.com, a leading Asian internet platform generating over $400 billion in annual gross merchandise volume.

Throughout his career in the blockchain and cryptocurrency sectors, Bill has deployed and managed over $30 billion in investments across AI, cryptocurrency, and fintech. He has successfully invested in prominent blockchain projects including Solana, Mysten Labs (Sui), Ton, Sei, and Bouncebit. He also serves on the board of the TON Foundation and is Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer of Phoenix Group (ADX: PHX), the first cryptocurrency company to go public in the Middle East.

Bill holds a Bachelor of Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, an MSc in Finance from Nanyang Technological University, and an MBA from the University of Toronto. He is also an executive committee member of the Hillhouse Value Investing Institution.

His unique combination of deep technical expertise in computer science, extensive experience in blockchain investment, and leadership in the cryptocurrency industry positions him as a multifaceted contributor across both academic and professional domains.

suggested_people.name: Anirudh Kotamraju
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
suggested_people.long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

suggested_people.name: Collin Qian
suggested_people.short_description: Fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara with a minor in Mathematics, maintaining a 3.95 GPA. Currently serving as President of Alpha Kappa Psi. Collin has diverse software engineering experience across multiple industries, including Databricks, Amazon, Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory, and Intuitive. He excels in hackathons, having won first place in three competitive events.
suggested_people.long_description:
Collin Qian is a high-achieving fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara, complementing his technical studies with a minor in Mathematics. With an impressive 3.95/4.0 GPA and High Honors recognition, he demonstrates exceptional academic aptitude. His coursework includes Data Structures and Algorithms, Discrete Mathematics, Algorithms Engineering, Machine Learning, Object Oriented Design and Implementation, Computer Organization and Logic Design, Intelligent and Interactive Systems, Intro to Computational Science, Vector Calculus, Linear Algebra, and Differential Equations.

Collin has built a diverse portfolio of software engineering experience across multiple industries. He is currently at Databricks and is set to join their Multi Cloud Efficiency Team as a Software Engineer Intern in summer 2024. At Amazon, he implemented the Smart Home Widget using Alexa Presentation Language for an in-vehicle infotainment product, programmed the Weather Forecast APL Card feature for the Weather Widget leveraging APL Skill Connections, and produced a C++ Native App utilizing Yocto SDK for Widget rendering, improving rendering performance by 25%. He also contributed to 10+ code reviews, resulting in a 15% reduction in code defects. His previous experience includes working at Amazon's Smart Vehicles Team, contributing to marine conservation technology at the Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory on the WhaleSafe and SharkEye Projects, developing test automation at Rocket Lawyer, and supporting telepresence technology at Intuitive, a leader in surgical robotics.

Beyond his professional experience, Collin has demonstrated exceptional project development skills through hackathon competitions. He won first place at SB Hacks XI with SnapSell, a solution that automates the Facebook Marketplace selling process. He also secured first place in the 2024 Jumpstart Designathon, creating a wireframe for neurodivergent users to manage food waste, competing at the Intermediate+ level. Additionally, he won the Spring 2022 Blockchain Project Series, earning $3,750 for developing a web forum that incorporated cryptocurrency bounties for questions.

Collin is actively involved in campus leadership as the President of Alpha Kappa Psi, having previously served as VP of Internal Affairs, VP of Alumni Relations, and Philanthropy Director. He joined the fraternity during his freshman year and values the community of "intelligent and lively individuals" it has provided him.

Originally from Cupertino, CA, Collin's educational background includes international experience, having attended Shanghai High School International Division before completing his high school education at Monta Vista High School. He aspires to work in tech and possibly found his own company one day. In his free time, he enjoys playing sports like tennis, pickleball, volleyball, basketball, rock climbing, and weightlifting, as well as cooking new recipes.

Collin is an active GitHub user (CollinQ) with 12 followers and has contributed to numerous repositories, including projects for hackathons and university coursework. His combination of strong academic performance, diverse technical internships, leadership experience, and proven ability to develop innovative solutions in competitive environments positions him as a promising talent in the computer science field.

name: kevin f.
short_description: Product professional at Replo (YC S21) with a unique background in space technology, having led teams for NASA proposals and worked on the smallest and lightest rover to reach space. Carnegie Mellon graduate with dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration, Kevin also hosts the Product Valley podcast and leads the CMU Tech & Entrepreneurship community.
long_description:
Kevin F. is a multifaceted product professional currently working at Replo (YC S21), where he brings his technical and business expertise to the startup environment. A recent graduate from Carnegie Mellon University with dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration, Kevin has built an impressive portfolio spanning space technology, product management, and community leadership.

His space technology experience is particularly notable, having worked on mission operations for both the Iris Lunar Rover and MoonRanger projects at Carnegie Mellon. Kevin led teams for NASA proposals and contributed to building what he describes as "the smallest and lightest rover to reach space" - a significant achievement in aerospace engineering.

Kevin's professional journey includes product roles at several startups and companies. Before joining Replo, he worked in Cloud & Digital at PwC, managed Product Growth at Expii for over a year, served as a Quantitative Analyst at Paratus Capital, and held Product Manager positions at both Stayflexi and TruePlan.io. His recommendation from Daniel Green at TruePlan highlights his ability to "pick up context quickly and add value from day one" while helping rebuild their website, analyzing customer usage patterns, and supporting sales efforts.

Beyond his professional work, Kevin is deeply involved in the tech and entrepreneurship community. He serves as the Community Lead for CMU Tech & Entrepreneurship (cmute.io) and produces and hosts the Product Valley podcast through Product@CMU. His leadership extends to his role as Activities Board Finance Chair at Carnegie Mellon and as President of The Triple Helix.

Kevin is bilingual in English and Mandarin Chinese, and his academic achievements include making the Dean's List, being a National Merit Scholarship Award Finalist, and winning the FBLA National Championship. This combination of technical knowledge, business acumen, and leadership experience positions Kevin as a versatile professional at the intersection of product development, technology, and entrepreneurship.

suggested_people.name: Evelyn T.
suggested_people.short_description: Evelyn is a multi-faceted entrepreneur and AI researcher focused on fraud prevention technology. As a UC Berkeley Computer Science and Business Administration student, she has founded multiple startups, including one acquired by Intuit Ventures, and is currently building AI solutions for the retail industry through various prestigious programs including Stanford StartX and Pear VC.
suggested_people.long_description:
Evelyn T. is an accomplished entrepreneur and machine learning researcher with a strong focus on AI applications for fraud prevention. Currently pursuing dual degrees in Computer Science and Business Administration at UC Berkeley with a minor in Material Science Engineering, she has already established herself as a formidable presence in the startup ecosystem.

Her entrepreneurial journey includes co-founding multiple ventures, most notably a startup that was acquired by Intuit Ventures in June 2022. She is currently building AI solutions targeting the $35B retail fraud industry as a Founder in Residence at Foundation Capital and a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, where she was selected as one of the top 20 engineering students across Stanford, Berkeley, and Harvard.

Evelyn's technical expertise has earned her a position as an ML Researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Labs and UC Berkeley's FAVE Lab, and she has been accepted into prestigious programs including Stanford StartX's S24 cohort, which provides equity-free funding for her venture TouchStone. Her product management experience includes an internship at Intuit and consulting work with international companies entering the US market.

During her time at UC Berkeley, Evelyn has been actively involved in entrepreneurial courses and projects. She was part of the WorkerBee team in the "Connected Life: How Mobile/AI/Internet of Things Will Improve Our Lives" course, developing a platform to connect skilled hospitality professionals with flexible on-demand work to address the severe worker shortage in the industry.

Beyond her technical and business achievements, Evelyn demonstrates a deep commitment to mental health advocacy. As a Gold Award recipient in Girl Scouts (one of the top honors in California), she created a project to break the stigma surrounding mental health in the Asian American community. Drawing from her personal experience with trichotillomania (an obsessive hair-pulling disorder), she networked with experts and nonprofits like Active Minds and National Alliance on Mental Illness to create lasting change at her high school, including revamping student ID cards to optimize access to mental health resources.

Evelyn brings a unique perspective to AI development with her diverse background, which includes running a successful fitness business that reached $15k MRR and working in retail management. She is bilingual in English and Vietnamese, with limited working proficiency in Spanish, further enhancing her ability to connect across cultures and markets. As a twin sister to Emily Tran (who attends Stanford), Evelyn has also co-hosted podcasts focusing on entrepreneurship and mental health awareness.

suggested_people.name: Andrew Tan
suggested_people.short_description: Andrew Tan is a Stanford University alumnus and entrepreneur focused on democratizing career growth. With a strong background in computer science and data science from UC Berkeley, he has conducted research in stock market prediction using sentiment analysis and has been recognized with numerous academic honors including Phi Beta Kappa and the EECS Honors Program.
suggested_people.long_description:
Andrew Tan is an accomplished technologist and entrepreneur currently associated with Humans and Stanford University. He's working on democratizing access to career growth through his venture joinnova.co.

Andrew has an impressive academic background, having graduated from UC Berkeley where he was part of the EECS Honors Program and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa as a junior (top 20 students in his class). During his time at Berkeley, he excelled as a student instructor in the Data Science Department, earning recognition as an Outstanding Student Instructor.

His research interests include applying AI to financial markets, as evidenced by his publication "Sentiment Predictability for Stocks" where he explored stock market prediction using textual sentiment analysis tools and advanced prediction models like LSTMs and convolutional architectures.

Andrew has a strong entrepreneurial spirit, having been selected for the Pear VC Summer Fellowship which provided seed investment for his early-stage startup. He was also named a Jack Larson Scholar at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business, receiving a scholarship to pursue entrepreneurship in technology and research.

His technical talents were recognized early, being one of only 11 students nationwide awarded the Snap Research Scholarship for his academic performance, research experience, and ability to solve tough technical challenges. Before college, Andrew was the Salutatorian of his high school class and achieved success in both mathematics competitions (qualifying for AIME four times) and business competitions (placing 2nd at the DECA International Competition).

Andrew is bilingual, with native English proficiency and professional working proficiency in Chinese, adding to his versatile skill set that spans technology, research, and entrepreneurship.

It's important to note that there is another prominent Andrew Tan who is a Filipino billionaire businessman. This Andrew Tan is the chairman of Alliance Global Group, Inc., a major conglomerate with interests in real estate, food and beverage, gaming, and hospitality. Born in Fujian, China, he moved to Hong Kong at age 4 and later to the Philippines as a teenager. He graduated with a degree in accounting from the University of the East in Manila and built his fortune developing large apartment complexes around Manila. His company Megaworld Corporation pioneered the "live-work-play" concept in township development, and he also runs Emperador, the world's largest brandy company by sales volume. As of 2024, his net worth is estimated at $1.5 billion. This is a different individual from the Andrew Tan described in the main profile.

suggested_people.name: Rishi Sai Sadanandan
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

suggested_people.name: Jalen Xing
suggested_people.short_description: Venture Fellow at General Catalyst with a strong technical background in AI and software engineering. UC Berkeley EECS graduate with experience at Meta, Capital One, and AWS, specializing in semantic search, large language models, and machine learning image classification.
suggested_people.long_description:
Jalen Xing is a Venture Fellow at General Catalyst, where he focuses on scouting and investing in promising student startups. With a solid foundation in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from UC Berkeley, Jalen has built an impressive technical background through various software engineering roles at leading tech companies.

His professional experience includes working at Meta on Facebook Search's Vertical Ranking team, developing semantic search and large language model applications at Capital One, and implementing machine learning image classification and search solutions at Amazon Web Services (AWS). He also gained experience in compliance and equity technology during his time at Balyasny Asset Management.

Jalen's academic credentials include a Master's degree from UC Berkeley with an exceptional 3.95/4.00 GPA, where he was involved with Codebase and received the Fung Excellence Scholarship. Prior to Berkeley, he completed his Bachelor of Science at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign with a near-perfect 3.98/4.00 GPA, where he also worked as a Research Assistant under Professor Bao.

His unique combination of technical expertise in AI, particularly in semantic search and large language models, along with his current focus on venture capital, positions him at the intersection of cutting-edge technology and investment. Jalen actively seeks connections with student entrepreneurs and innovators, offering his expertise to help them build and grow their startups.

Note: The scraped website information appears to reference different individuals with similar surnames (Xing Wu, Galen Xing, and Xin Xing) who are not related to Jalen Xing. These individuals have different academic and professional backgrounds, including positions at Berkeley in integrative biology, computational biology, and mathematics/quantum chemistry research.

suggested_people.name: Audrey Chen
suggested_people.short_description: Serial hackathon winner (21 wins) and tech entrepreneur with a passion for AI innovation. Co-founder of VC-backed nosu.io, Software Engineering Intern at Intuit, and content creator with 68K Instagram followers. Currently pursuing Computer Engineering at Michigan State University while balancing multiple tech roles including NASA USRC research and Intel AI projects.
suggested_people.long_description:
Audrey Chen is a dynamic force in the tech world, particularly known for her exceptional track record of winning 21 hackathons with a 70% win rate, accumulating over $20,000 in prizes. Her technical prowess spans multiple domains within AI and software engineering, demonstrated through her diverse professional experiences.

As the co-founder and CEO of nosu.io, Audrey has successfully raised $100,000 in venture capital funding and grown the platform to over 7,800 users. The company focuses on AI organization software for hackathons and developers, addressing communication challenges between AI companies and low-code users. Her entrepreneurial venture is backed by notable investors including Boost VC, Earthling VC, and 13 angels.

Professionally, Audrey has secured impressive roles including an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Intuit where she'll work on predictive AI for the Lead Management & Planning team. She's currently engaged with Intel's AI PC Pilot Program, where she developed a machine learning model for diabetic retinopathy diagnosis that improved accuracy from 67% to 80%. As a NASA USRC Drone Research Software Engineer, she contributes to the Laser Energized Aerial Drone System (LEADS) project aimed at monitoring wildfires.

Her technical versatility extends to DevOps/SRE work through her Meta Fellowship, where she developed web applications using Python, Flask, Jinja, MySQL, Docker, and NGINX, while implementing CI/CD pipelines and configuring system monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana.

Beyond her technical work, Audrey has built a significant online presence as a content creator with 68,000 followers on Instagram (@jia.seed), generating over 10 million views across her educational content about technology and hackathons. She's also a musician with over 140,000 streams on Spotify.

At Michigan State University, where she's pursuing a Bachelor of Engineering with a minor in Economics, Audrey serves as Co-director of SpartaHack and Workshop Coordinator for the AI Club, delivering presentations to audiences of up to 300 attendees on advanced AI topics.

Her entrepreneurial spirit manifested early with ventures like SheeshSeaglass, where she grew $17.99 to $2,100 in sales revenue with a 65% net profit margin. Audrey's technical certifications include oneAPI Ambassador Level 1 from Intel Corporation, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning in emerging technologies.

It's worth noting that Audrey is also a talented musician, with classical training in cello beginning at age 8 and voice at age 11. While her primary focus is on technology and entrepreneurship, her musical background adds another dimension to her multifaceted talents. This musical training likely contributes to her creative approach to problem-solving in the tech space.

name: zarif azher
short_description: Bioengineering and Computer Science undergraduate at Caltech with extensive research experience in computational pathology and medical technology innovation. Published 10+ peer-reviewed papers in leading journals, focusing on applying AI and spatial transcriptomics to biomedical problems with the goal of expanding global healthcare access.
long_description:
Zarif Azher is an undergraduate student at Caltech pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Bioengineering and Computer Science (2024-2028). He is a passionate innovator and researcher at the intersection of AI and healthcare, with a particular focus on computational pathology, spatial transcriptomics, and medical technology development.

Zarif has an impressive research portfolio with over 10 peer-reviewed publications in prestigious journals and conferences, including the Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing, BioData Mining, and the Journal of Pathology Informatics. His research spans innovative applications of AI in healthcare, such as inferring spatial transcriptomics from histological patterns, developing multimodal deep learning models for cancer prognostication, and creating interpretable AI systems for biomedical analysis.

His work has been cited over 60 times by researchers in the field, demonstrating the impact of his contributions to computational biology and medical AI. His recent projects include mapping three-dimensional tumor heterogeneity through deep learning inference of spatial transcriptomics from routine histopathology, and developing LLM-driven agent approaches to modeling legislative behavior.

Beyond his technical research, Zarif is committed to making healthcare more accessible globally. On his personal website, he states: "I want to use powerful technology to improve healthcare access and quality worldwide." He describes himself as a leader who organizes "people and things to accomplish ambitious goals" and a researcher developing "novel solutions to real-world issues – science for action, not observation."

Zarif's professional experience includes working in the Gao Research Group at Caltech and collaborating with researchers from institutions like Case Western Reserve University, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Dartmouth College. He has also been involved in projects to fight government corruption in Bangladesh, advocate for environmental justice in the USA, and deploy novel assistive technology for medical practitioners in underserved regions.

His interdisciplinary approach combines expertise in machine learning, bioinformatics, multimodal deep learning, cancer research, and pathology, positioning him as an emerging leader in the application of AI to solve complex healthcare challenges.

suggested_people.name: Eduardo Pontes Reis
suggested_people.short_description: Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher specializing in radiology and AI applications in healthcare. Currently affiliated with Stanford University and Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein, he focuses on developing AI tools for medical imaging and clinical documentation. His research has been cited over 1,200 times, with significant contributions to medical text summarization, chest X-ray interpretation, and multimodal medical AI systems.
suggested_people.long_description:
Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher at the intersection of medicine and artificial intelligence, currently serving as a Visiting Scholar at Stanford University's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI) and as a researcher at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil.

His educational background includes an MD from State of Sao Paulo University (UNESP) in 2013, followed by a Radiology Residency at UNICAMP in 2017, and Neuroradiology specialization at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in 2018. This clinical foundation has informed his research focus on applying AI to healthcare challenges.

Eduardo's research has gained significant recognition in the field of medical AI. According to Google Scholar, his work has been cited over 1,200 times, with an h-index of 13. His research contributions span several important areas:

1. Medical Text Summarization: He co-authored a groundbreaking study published in Nature Medicine demonstrating that adapted large language models can outperform medical experts in clinical text summarization, potentially reducing documentation burden for clinicians.

2. Medical Imaging AI: He has contributed to multiple projects involving AI applications in radiology, including the development of BRAX (Brazilian labeled chest X-ray dataset), and participated in the creation of ChexAgent, a foundation model for chest X-ray interpretation.

3. Multimodal Medical AI: His work includes contributions to Med-Flamingo (a multimodal medical few-shot learner) and Merlin (a vision-language foundation model for 3D computed tomography).

4. Clinical Applications: Eduardo's research focuses on practical applications that can improve healthcare delivery, including automated contrast phase detection in abdominal CT and AI tools for radiology report generation.

At Stanford, Eduardo is part of the Machine Intelligence for Medical Imaging (MIMI) research group led by Dr. Akshay Chaudhari, where his research focuses on developing AI tools to improve healthcare, particularly in radiology and medical records. His specific interests include methods that use pairs of images and reports to teach radiology to computers, and applying large language models to reduce documentation burden for medical professionals.

Eduardo is an advocate for open data in healthcare when safe and feasible, contributing to the development of open-source datasets and tools. His professional affiliations include membership in the Sociedade Paulista de Radiologia (São Paulo Radiology Society), Colégio Brasileiro de Radiologia (Brazilian College of Radiology), and CREMESP (Regional Council of Medicine of the State of São Paulo).

Beyond his professional pursuits, Eduardo enjoys tennis, music (particularly playing the piano), and hiking. He is fluent in Portuguese (native) and English (professional proficiency), enabling him to engage with international research and collaboration opportunities in his field.

suggested_people.name: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta
suggested_people.short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
suggested_people.long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

suggested_people.name: Rex Liu
suggested_people.short_description: Undergraduate at Caltech pursuing Computer Science and Biology with a focus on Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. Research Fellow at Thomson Lab developing innovative AI systems including thalamus-inspired LLM routers and GNN-based spatial proteomics. Currently interning at NASA JPL for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft mission and competing on Caltech's Water Polo team.
suggested_people.long_description:
Rex Liu is an undergraduate student at Caltech studying Computer Science and Biology, with a particular focus on the intersection of these fields through Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. As a Research Fellow at Caltech's Thomson Lab, Rex has developed several cutting-edge AI systems that demonstrate his innovative approach to machine learning.

His research portfolio includes a Thalamus-inspired LLM Router called "Herd" that creates scalable ensembles of small, open-source language models capable of outperforming larger proprietary models through Q-learning-based dynamic model selection. This work was presented at the NeurIPS Efficient Natural Language and Speech Processing Workshop. He's also worked on Hierarchical Chains with Multi-Level Abstention (HCMA), optimizing Black-box API deployments with uncertainty-based delegation and improved risk control, and published a paper on "Cost-Saving LLM Cascades with Early Abstention."

In the biomedical space, Rex has applied Graph Neural Networks to spatial proteomics, using counterfactual learning to identify tumor perturbations that enhance T-cell infiltration, with validated combinatorial therapies in collaboration with Cedars-Sinai. He's also worked on "Building Foundation Models to Characterize Cellular Interactions via Geometric Self-Supervised Learning on Spatial Genomics."

His most significant research contribution is on Functionally Invariant Path (FIP), a differential geometry-based framework that allows neural networks to adapt to secondary tasks without catastrophic forgetting. This groundbreaking work was published in Nature Machine Intelligence in 2024 and has already been cited by other researchers in the field. The FIP algorithm has wide-ranging applications from improving recommendations on online stores to fine-tuning self-driving cars.

Currently, Rex is interning at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, writing software for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft as part of the Mission Operations and Ground Data Systems team. He is also a member of Caltech's Men's Water Polo team, competing as an Attacker.

Prior to Caltech, Rex worked as a research assistant at National Taiwan University's Systems Biology Epithelia Lab, where he designed a lethal Zika virus-driven plasmid for transgenic mosquitoes, expressing a hybrid neurotoxin upon Zika infection. He also integrated a protein BLAST search engine to identify sequence alignments in the lab's online databases.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Rex has extensive experience in cybersecurity, having worked as a Security Researcher at HackerOne and a Bug Bounty Hunter at Bugcrowd for over five years. He has also served as a Teaching Assistant at Taipei American School, instructing students in Mechanical Engineering (CAD, CNC, water jet cutting, TIG welding) and Modern Topics in Computer Science (logic gates, quantum mechanics, deep learning).

Rex's multidisciplinary background, spanning AI, biology, cybersecurity, and aerospace, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving fields. He is fluent in Chinese and English, with working proficiency in Spanish and Japanese, further enhancing his ability to collaborate in global research environments. Outside of his academic and research work, Rex plays the violin and guitar.

suggested_people.name: Ryan Zhijie Rong
suggested_people.short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

suggested_people.name: Ally Nakamura
suggested_people.short_description: Recent Stanford graduate currently building at PearX and involved with Catapult AI. Ally has a background in deep learning, AI, and scientific research, with notable achievements including a gold medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, selection as a Masason Foundation Scholar, and research on Chinese censorship.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ally Nakamura is a recent Stanford University graduate with BS/MS degrees in Computer Science with a focus on AI. She is currently building at PearX while also being involved with Catapult AI, where she's working on helping medical device companies deploy AI to make their workflows easier.

Her academic journey has been complemented by her deep interest in artificial intelligence and healthcare technology. She holds a Neural Networks and Deep Learning certification from deeplearning.ai and has worked with Stanford's Open Virtual Assistant Lab to build EHR-Xamine, a virtual assistant for electronic clinical health records designed to reduce physician burnout.

Ally has demonstrated exceptional scientific aptitude, having published research on Fluorescence-Guided Surgery in Frontiers in Oncology, where she reviewed applications of fluorescent probes in defining tumor locations during surgical procedures. Her scientific excellence was recognized internationally when she represented the United States at the International Earth Science Olympiad, earning a gold medal and ranking among the top 15 students out of nearly 400 participants from over 30 countries.

Her technical accomplishments include leading an AI-enabled email client at DoNotPay that was featured by Forbes and Wired, and building a voice agent to automatically handle reference checks for healthcare staffing agencies. She also enjoys participating in hackathons, where she has built AI dating apps and launched an AI crypto coin that scaled to $15M market cap.

Beyond her technical work, Ally has conducted significant research on Chinese censorship. Working with Jeffrey Shen, she created CensorScout and the Weibo Censorship Dashboard, two applications that increase transparency into censorship on Weibo. Their published paper on SSRN made daily top-tens in several sections and was in the top 10% of authors by downloads in the year following publication. This project was completed as part of Digital Propaganda & Censorship, an Independent Project at Phillips Academy.

Her entrepreneurial spirit is evident through her involvement with various organizations at Stanford, including co-founding the Stanford Chapter of Scholar of Finance and being a member of the Asia-Pacific Student Entrepreneurship Society. She also served as an intern at Stanford Women in Business, showcasing her interest in the intersection of business and technology.

Ally was selected as one of just 42 students to join the prestigious Masason Foundation after a rigorous three-round admissions process, further highlighting her exceptional potential. During her high school years, she contributed to STEM education as an Event Coordinator for Techstravaganza with Tomorrow's Women in Science and Technology.

She is bilingual in English and Japanese with limited working proficiency in German, giving her a global perspective that complements her technical skills and entrepreneurial mindset. In her free time, she enjoys hiking, attending DJ sets, eating sushi, and playing poker with friends.

name: pavan jayasinha
short_description: Pavan Jayasinha is a versatile technologist specializing in the intersection of machine learning, quantum computing, and low-level systems engineering. Currently a student at the University of Waterloo, he has contributed to cutting-edge research and development at organizations like Modular, Extropic AI, and the Institute for Quantum Computing, with particular expertise in GPU kernel optimization, quantum generative models, and robotics.
long_description:
Pavan Jayasinha is a multifaceted technologist pursuing a Bachelor of Applied Science at the University of Waterloo with an impressive 4.0 GPA. His technical expertise spans several specialized domains, with particular focus on machine learning, robotics, quantum computing, and low-level kernel development.

Pavan's professional experience demonstrates remarkable versatility across cutting-edge fields. At Modular, he worked as an AI GPU Engineering Intern, developing GPU kernels in Mojo language, optimizing end-to-end pipelines, and implementing multi-GPU tensor parallelism from scratch. His work at Extropic involved building high-performance JAX codebases for analog simulation of probabilistic ML models on hardware, conducting over 1000 Bayesian hyperparameter sweeps, and creating a state-of-the-art JAX library for tensor network simulation of quantum circuits on CUDA GPUs.

In the quantum computing space, Pavan has made significant contributions. At the Institute for Quantum Computing, he researched methods to realize the Bose-Hubbard Hamiltonian through Rydberg neutral atoms and built large-scale physics simulations. As an IBM Qiskit Advocate, he authored a chapter on Quantum Generative Adversarial Networks for the Qiskit Textbook QML course and mentored at the Qiskit Global Summer School. His quantum expertise extended to Zapata Computing, where he investigated quantum generative models and developed Orquestra codebase for QGANs.

Pavan has also contributed significantly to open-source projects, becoming the largest non-Google contributor to TensorFlow Quantum by implementing Bazel build infrastructure and cuQuantum SDK GPU kernels for quantum circuit simulation on heterogeneous devices. His project work includes developing a hybrid quantum graph neural network for particle trajectory reconstruction, which placed in the top 5 at QHack 2022, and building a quantum portfolio optimization project that placed in the 95th percentile at QHack 2021.

Pavan's academic achievements include being a Masason Scholar, selected as part of the 6th generation cohort by SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's foundation that supports youth with exceptional talents. He has received the President's Research Award and maintained Dean's Honours List status. He has earned multiple certifications in quantum computing, including becoming an IBM Certified Associate Developer for Quantum Computation using Qiskit.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Pavan has diverse experiences including serving as a lifeguard for the City of Toronto and working as a dog walker, demonstrating his well-rounded character and work ethic. His unique combination of expertise in quantum computing, machine learning, and low-level systems engineering positions him as a promising innovator at the intersection of these transformative technologies.

suggested_people.name: Harshil Avlani
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Physics student at MIT with award-winning research in quantum computing. Former Research Intern at MIT's Quanta Group and Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab, focusing on quantum error characterization and quantum machine learning applications.
suggested_people.long_description:
Harshil Avlani is a dual-major student in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), with an exceptional research background in quantum computing and physics. His academic journey showcases a consistent focus on quantum technologies and computational physics.

Currently, Harshil serves as a Research Intern with the Quanta Group at MIT's Research Laboratory of Electronics, where he applies his interdisciplinary knowledge to cutting-edge quantum research. Prior to this, he gained valuable experience as a Research Intern at Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab under Dr. Houlong Zhuang for over a year, developing expertise in quantum mechanical applications and quantum machine learning.

Harshil has achieved remarkable recognition for his research. His project "Analyzing the Effect of Mid-Circuit Measurement (MCM) on Spectator Qubits" earned him first place in the Systems Software category at the International Science Fair and qualified him as a finalist in the prestigious 2024 Regeneron Science Talent Search, where he received a $25,000 academic scholarship. This groundbreaking work identified a previously uncharacterized type of quantum error and revealed significant deficiencies in current quantum simulators.

His research portfolio includes collaborative work on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) for solving combinatorial optimization problems, documented in his GitHub repository. He has also worked with the Hauser Research Group at the University of Alabama, where he spent 9 months contributing to physics research projects, and gained experience in computer security at Arizona State University's SEFCOM Lab.

In 2022, Harshil participated in the MIT Beaver Works Summer Institute as a Quantum Software Student, further enhancing his skills in quantum computing applications. He has also co-founded the Quantum Beavers hackathon group, which tied for first place in the IBM Quantum Explorers Hackathon.

Harshil has already begun contributing to scientific literature, with a publication in Data in Brief journal on "Dataset on density functional theory investigation of ternary Heusler alloys" in February 2024. More recently, he has been exploring the intersection of quantum computing and transformer models in machine learning, with applications in mitigating misinformation through quantum-enhanced GAN architectures.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Harshil is an accomplished pianist and has a passion for aviation, being able to identify most major aircraft models by sight. His diverse research experiences across multiple institutions highlight his versatility and dedication to advancing the fields of quantum computing and physics through rigorous academic inquiry and practical applications.

suggested_people.name: Kailash Ranganathan
suggested_people.short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
suggested_people.long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

suggested_people.name: Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla
suggested_people.short_description: A multilingual Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard with exceptional achievements in quantum computing and international physics competitions. Ricardo combines technical expertise with diplomatic skills, having led international relations organizations and conducted research spanning solid-state physics, ESG consulting, and quantum algorithm development across multiple languages.
suggested_people.long_description:
Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla is a Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard University with a remarkable blend of technical expertise and international perspective. His academic journey is distinguished by significant achievements in quantum computing, where he serves as Vice President of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantum Computing Association (HUQCA) and won 2nd place at MIT's Quantum Computing Hackathon 2024, developing theoretical error bounds for quantum algorithms.

Ricardo's technical prowess extends beyond quantum computing to solid-state physics research, where he worked with 2D transition metal dichalcogenides and Van der Waals heterostructures under Professor Hongkun Park. His computational skills have been recognized through multiple hackathon victories, including Microsoft's Student Hackathon 2021 and CdCMx 2020, where he developed mathematical models for COVID-19 comorbidity analysis.

In the quantum computing field, Ricardo has demonstrated exceptional talent, helping to grow HUQCA to over 300 members. At the MIT Interdisciplinary Quantum Hackathon (iQuHACK), his team created an "experimental harness" that allowed them to run quantum simulations at scale and efficiently collect data, earning them second place. As Ricardo noted, "It's one thing to learn something in a classroom, and another to try to code one and see if it runs. That's different, and I think it adds an extra layer to fully mastering the concepts."

What sets Ricardo apart is his exceptional international background and linguistic abilities. Fluent in six languages (Spanish, English, French, Chinese, Russian, and German), he has leveraged these skills in various leadership roles. As Co-President of Harvard International Relations on Campus and in his work with the Harvard International Relations Council, he has bridged cultural divides and facilitated international dialogue. His language proficiency earned him first place in Harvard's Chinese Poetry Recitation Contest and supported his research for a Radcliffe Fellow's project on underground economies in Greater China.

Ricardo's professional experience spans diverse sectors, from ESG consulting at PwC China, where he spearheaded sustainable design strategies for LEED-certified real estate projects, to his upcoming role as a Business Analyst at Alibaba Group. During his internship at PwC Shanghai through the Harvard China Fund Student Internship Program, he significantly improved his professional Chinese language skills while working on technical projects. As Ricardo reflected, "My biggest achievement from this experience was the consolidation of my Chinese speaking, reading and writing skills at the professional level."

His commitment to diplomacy and international cooperation is evident in his work with the United Nations Information Center, where he led a conference commemorating the UN's 75th anniversary with 500+ Latin American students.

His academic excellence is further demonstrated by his impressive collection of medals from international physics competitions, including the International Physics Olympiad, European Physics Olympiad, and Mexican Physics Olympiad. Ricardo's multidisciplinary approach combines rigorous scientific training with global perspective, positioning him uniquely at the intersection of technology, diplomacy, and sustainable development.

suggested_people.name: Neil Movva
suggested_people.short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
suggested_people.long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

suggested_people.name: Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan
suggested_people.short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at UMD with diverse expertise in computer vision, high-performance computing, and quantitative finance. Currently researching LLMs under Dr. Tom Goldstein while interning at Scale AI for code reasoning models. Published work on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models at ICLR 2023.
suggested_people.long_description:
Vijaykaarti Sundarapandiyan is a Computer Science and Mathematics double major at the University of Maryland with a multifaceted background in AI research and software engineering. His technical interests span computer vision, concurrent and high-performance computing, networks, quantitative finance, and large model efficiency.

Currently, Vijaykaarti serves as a Technical Advisor Intern at Scale AI, where he works on code reasoning models for Olympiad-level competitive programming problems. Simultaneously, he conducts research on Large Language Models under Dr. Tom Goldstein at UMD. His research contributions include a notable paper on efficient pruning techniques for massive language models, recognized as a Notable TinyPaper at ICLR 2023, which has been cited 13 times since publication.

Vijaykaarti's professional experience is extensive for a student. He completed a software engineering internship at Uber, focusing on networking infrastructure with Envoy proxy. He also worked as a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory and at NonExomics, where he developed deep learning models for cancer prediction over a two-year period.

Within the UMD community, Vijaykaarti serves as Senior Quantitative Analyst and Lead Architect for the Smith Investment Fund's automated trading platform. He previously conducted computer vision research under Dr. Jia-Bin Huang. He has also contributed to social impact initiatives as a Software Engineer at Hack4Impact, developing web applications for nonprofit organizations.

His technical prowess is further evidenced by his competitive programming achievements, including participation in the ICPC NA South Division 2024 as part of the UMD GOATS team alongside Mazin Karjikar and Spencer Lutz. He has also competed at the ICPC Mid-Atlantic Regionals, where he previously placed 7th.

Beyond technical skills, Vijaykaarti is multilingual, with native proficiency in English and Tamil, and professional working proficiency in Spanish. His academic excellence is reflected in his numerous accolades, including being a Presidential Scholar Candidate, National Merit Finalist, and recipient of the UKG Global Scholarship. His community engagement is demonstrated through his Eagle Scout achievement and multiple Silver President's Volunteer Service Awards for significant community service hours.

name: collin qian
short_description: Fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara with a minor in Mathematics, maintaining a 3.95 GPA. Currently serving as President of Alpha Kappa Psi. Collin has diverse software engineering experience across multiple industries, including Databricks, Amazon, Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory, and Intuitive. He excels in hackathons, having won first place in three competitive events.
long_description:
Collin Qian is a high-achieving fourth-year Computer Science student at UC Santa Barbara, complementing his technical studies with a minor in Mathematics. With an impressive 3.95/4.0 GPA and High Honors recognition, he demonstrates exceptional academic aptitude. His coursework includes Data Structures and Algorithms, Discrete Mathematics, Algorithms Engineering, Machine Learning, Object Oriented Design and Implementation, Computer Organization and Logic Design, Intelligent and Interactive Systems, Intro to Computational Science, Vector Calculus, Linear Algebra, and Differential Equations.

Collin has built a diverse portfolio of software engineering experience across multiple industries. He is currently at Databricks and is set to join their Multi Cloud Efficiency Team as a Software Engineer Intern in summer 2024. At Amazon, he implemented the Smart Home Widget using Alexa Presentation Language for an in-vehicle infotainment product, programmed the Weather Forecast APL Card feature for the Weather Widget leveraging APL Skill Connections, and produced a C++ Native App utilizing Yocto SDK for Widget rendering, improving rendering performance by 25%. He also contributed to 10+ code reviews, resulting in a 15% reduction in code defects. His previous experience includes working at Amazon's Smart Vehicles Team, contributing to marine conservation technology at the Benioff Ocean Science Laboratory on the WhaleSafe and SharkEye Projects, developing test automation at Rocket Lawyer, and supporting telepresence technology at Intuitive, a leader in surgical robotics.

Beyond his professional experience, Collin has demonstrated exceptional project development skills through hackathon competitions. He won first place at SB Hacks XI with SnapSell, a solution that automates the Facebook Marketplace selling process. He also secured first place in the 2024 Jumpstart Designathon, creating a wireframe for neurodivergent users to manage food waste, competing at the Intermediate+ level. Additionally, he won the Spring 2022 Blockchain Project Series, earning $3,750 for developing a web forum that incorporated cryptocurrency bounties for questions.

Collin is actively involved in campus leadership as the President of Alpha Kappa Psi, having previously served as VP of Internal Affairs, VP of Alumni Relations, and Philanthropy Director. He joined the fraternity during his freshman year and values the community of "intelligent and lively individuals" it has provided him.

Originally from Cupertino, CA, Collin's educational background includes international experience, having attended Shanghai High School International Division before completing his high school education at Monta Vista High School.
